ph_descripcion: Photos by Arturo Rodriguez @arturorguezdotcom | I'm exploring caves that formed during the 2021 volcanic eruption on La Palma, one of the Canary Islands. Lasting 85 days, it was the island's longest known eruption. Speleologists Eduardo Díaz Martín and Octavio Fernandez Lorenzo, in collaboration with the Geological and Mining Institute of Spain, get a first look at a lava tube on the slopes of the Cumbre Vieja volcano. To get into this cave, Díaz Martín draws on an ancient tradition from the island's shepherds. They move swiftly along the cliffs and canyons using the “salto del pastor” (shepherd's jump) technique: A four-meter-long (13 ft) wooden spear—traditionally outfitted with a goat horn but today it's a steel tip—is thrust into the surface, allowing the user to slide down, vault, or climb the rugged landscape. @natgeoesp
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on February 28, 2023. May be an image of 2 people and nature.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @nicholesobecki | A coalition of cheetahs squares off for a shared meal—but this is no ordinary group of big cats. These are captive-born, hand-raised cheetahs bred to genetically reinforce wild populations in southern Africa. The fastest land animal on Earth, cheetahs face extinction pressure from habitat destruction, conflict with humans, trafficking, and climate change, and their numbers have plummeted to just around 7,000 adults worldwide. Having survived historical events that greatly reduced population size, cheetahs today have low genetic variability, which puts them at risk of disease and harmful mutations. This spotted crew is being trained to survive back in the wild, where they can bring fresh genetic stock and help ensure that the species isn’t consigned to history. But it must happen alongside efforts to stop trafficking, habitat loss, and poaching. | Rewilding programs like this one are possible thanks to leading #logistics experts like @dhl_global. Find out more about how DHL supports these missions and fights for animal rights across the globe.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on February 23, 2023. May be an image of big cat and outdoors.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @shinalodon | On assignment for @insidenatgeo as second assistant for @kiliiiyuyan upcoming story about indigenous stewardship for @natgeo magazine During our time working in Palau, we got to visit the wreck of a reconnaissance plane, Aichi E13A-1 (Allied reporting name: JAKE) of the Imperial Japanese Navy from the World War II. Here is Kiliii working around the plane that crashed in the shallow lagoon of Koror. Throughout those passing decades, marine life gradually flourish onto the plane that provides a substrate for them to grow onto. Corals and sponges encrust the eroded airframe, while reef fishes take shelter in the shadowy cockpit. Nowadays, Palau is world-renowned for its pristine marine environment and abundance of sharks that attract divers from all over the world, but the small nation of Micronesia was also a major battleground of the Pacific Theater, namely the Battle of Peleliu. Kiliii is exploring traditional indigenous methods of conservation land-management and climate change mitigation as part of a new collaboration between the National Geographic Society and @TheClimatePledge The partnership supports National Geographic Explorers documenting the global climate crisis. So please follow @kiliiiyuyan for the update of his works mostly on indigenous cultures and @shinalodon for other stuffs mostly about marine conservation.

#plane #wreck #underwater #marine #nature #conservation #history #koror #palau #micronesia #pacific #onassignment
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on December 16, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @renan_ozturk | Words by @freddiewilkinson

Not exactly a three hour tour!!!

We’re slowly coming back to normal life as we depart the Falkland Islands after an unforgettable voyage to the remote, mysterious South Sandwich Islands in the South Atlantic Ocean.

It all began earlier this year, when Dr. Emma Nicholson decided to answer the siren call of Mt. Michael, a ~ 900 meter unclimbed volcano located on a tiny speck of ash and rock known as Saunders Island. For more than twenty years, volcanologists have speculated about the strange thermal anomaly visible in satellite imagery that seems to emanate from within Michael’s crater. The heat signature, which at times has indicated surface temperatures of more than 1000 degrees C, was suggestive of molten lava close to the Earth’s surface — perhaps even one of nature’s rarest phenomena and volcanologists’ most valuable natural laboratory, an active lava lake. But because the volcanic gases constantly exiting the crater mix with the region’s infamous weather conditions to create a witch’s brew of sulfur dioxide plume, cloud, and storm — getting a clear-eyed look into the crater is virtually impossible from space. And, thanks to Saunders Island’s location, directly downwind of the Drake Passage at 57 degrees south and 1300 nm from the closest port, getting there the old fashioned way is a wee-bit inconvenient.

You might say Emma’s dream was to explore this uncharted volcano, maybe even “discover” a lava lake. But she (like all good field scientists) prefers another term: ground-truthing.

What Emma didn’t immediately reveal is that more people have been to the moon than had set foot on Saunders Island… and now we know why. Stay-tuned for the #LavaSandwichExpedition

Photo #2 ‘thermal anomaly’ sat image: copernicus_eu sentinelhub
Previous research:
2018 paper: alexburton johnson, danielle grayuk
2001 paper: 🙈#britishantarcticsurvey Thomas Lachlan-Cope, John Smellie
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on December 10, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @shinalodon | On assignment for @insidenatgeo as second assistant for @kiliiiyuyan upcoming story about indigenous stewardship for @natgeo magazine. Kiliii Yüyan is exploring traditional indigenous methods of conservation land-management and climate change mitigation as part of a new collaboration between the National Geographic Society and @TheClimatePledge. The partnership supports National Geographic Explorers documenting the global climate crisis.

We came to work in Palau, one of the world’s smallest countries in the western Pacific renowned for its pristine marine environment while the spirit of conservation lies deep in traditional culture. This island nation of Micronesia spearheaded a major movement to address thee global declines of shark populations by establishing the first shark sanctuary in the world in 2009, where commercial shark fishing are banned throughout the whole exclusive economic zone of its waters. It is no wonder why Palau is a major attraction to divers from around the world, enjoying economic benefits of healthy shark populations with shark diving tourism accounts for about 8% of the GDP, while a single grey reef shark is estimated to generate close to 2 million USD throughout its lifetime. Here is a shiver of Blacktip reef sharks in the shallow of “Shark City” of Rock Islands Southern Lagoon, a UNESCO world heritage site. These small reef sharks frequent this area as visitors often throw out their lunch, becoming an attraction of the Rock Islands. Not that we are encouraging feeding wild animals, but the sharks have accustomed to people and check us out even without feeding involved. This is only a small part of the story that @Kiliiiyuyan is working on but he definitely enjoyed working with the sharks here as we made a few visits to this area. Follow @kiliiiyuyan for the update of his current project and stories on indigenous culture and @shinalodon for other stuffs mostly about marine conservation.

#shark #reef #elasmobranch #blacktip #palau #micronesia #biodiversity #conservation #marine #pacific
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on November 28, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @paoloverzone | On assignment for @natgeo. The tallest adobe structure in the world, the minaret of the Agadez Mosque in Niger rises like a beacon above the desert at the end of the day. It stands 27 meters (88.5 feet) high and has served as a watchtower for centuries, guarding the Tuareg city of Agadez from enemies and welcoming caravans during their travels. The mosque was constructed in 1515, and its charm has remained unchanged since that time.
Follow @paoloverzone for more images and stories.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on October 14, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @paoloverzone | On assignment for @natgeo. At the Gobero site in Agadez, Niger, paleontologist Paul Sereno holds a fossil human jaw that was discovered during excavations there. Called Gobero for the area’s Tuareg name, the site is a part of the Sahara desert that can be identified as the Green Sahara at a time between 10,000 and 5,000 years ago. The Kiffian people were the first to inhabit the Gobero site, more than 9,700 years ago.
Follow @paoloverzone for more images and stories.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on October 13, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photos & video by @alice.zoo | For the final part of the story, food historian Sally Grainger cooked a selection of authentic Roman recipes using either Silphion, gathered by Miski in central Turkey earlier in the trip, or a substitute - asafoetida - in order to test and compare the flavours. All those present for the experiment at the makeshift Roman kitchen in Istanbul’s Botanical Gardens preferred the Silphion dishes. “It’s intense and delightful,” Grainger describes. “It has this intense ‘green’ flavor that actually brings out the qualities of the other herbs in the sauce.” It was a momentous day: this was the first time this flavour had been tasted in 2000 years.

The rest of the story is online @natgeo now - follow me @alice.zoo for more images from this story along with other projects about ritual and meaning.

#NatGeo #NationalGeographic #Silphion
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 29, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @alice.zoo | After the first part of the assignment, Professor Mahmut Miski brought a box of young ferula drudeana plants with him from where they had been propagated from seed in the Botanical Gardens in Istanbul. With Mehmet Ata, he planted a few of them in the garden alongside the mature plants. It takes around 15 years for Silphion plants to reach maturity, when they finally flower. The delicate plants, with their lengthy life cycle, seem especially so when you consider the threat of herds of local goats, who are easily able to make their way over the stone walls that surround the garden and graze on whatever they find.

The rest of the story is online @natgeo now - follow me @alice.zoo for more images from this story along with other projects about ritual and meaning.

#NatGeo #NationalGeographic #Silphion

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @alice.zoo | Ferula drudeana, the plant believed to be Silphion, is growing on the side of an active volcano in central Turkey. We finally approached it back in May after a day-long journey over land from Istanbul via taxi, train, and SUV, excited to see the mythical plant that botanists have been searching for for centuries. Crops and wildflowers grew in the surrounding fields, giving us a preview of the beauty of the garden still to come.

The rest of the story is online @natgeo now - follow me @alice.zoo for more images from this story along with other projects about ritual and meaning.

#NatGeo #NationalGeographic #Silphion
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 24, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @alice.zoo | Used by ancient Greeks and Romans for everything from food, to perfume, to medicine, and even contraception, the plant known as Silphion was so powerful and popular that it was even depicted on coins. It was, however, a victim of its own success, and eventually went extinct 2000 years ago. It is the first species ever to go extinct as a result of human appetite.

Since the 1980s Mahmut Miski, Professor of Pharmacognosy at the University of Istanbul, has been investigating a plant - ferula drudeana - which he believes to be Silphion. A precious few flowering plants are growing on the side of a volcano in Turkey. Here, he cups his hands around some of the plant’s flowering ends.

The rest of the story is online @natgeo now - follow me @alice.zoo for more images from this story along with other projects about ritual and meaning.

#NatGeo #NationalGeographic #Silphion
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 23, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @renan_ozturk, words by @m_synnott | @natgeo #TheArcricMystery expedition update!

More to come, but a quick note here to let everyone know that Polar Sun landed safely in Nome harbor last night after an east to west transit of the Northwest Passage. All told we sailed 5,877 nautical miles from southern Maine to Alaska over 112 days. Thanks to all of you who followed along. Knowing you were out there pulling for us meant everything to our crew !

I can say that as the skipper of a boat that has spent over 100 days in these waters, what you think about when passing through the Bering Strait is not a feeling of accomplishment or triumph. The thoughts going through my mind revolved around the foul current, the sea state, wind direction, and whether I could make port before the next southerly gale.

@expedition.studios #OnAssignment
ph_atributos: Photo shared by Nat Geo in the Field on September 21, 2022 tagging @natgeo, @renan_ozturk, @m_synnott, @rudy.le, @zartman_rigging, and @expedition.studios.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @gabriellanbaez | On assignment for @natgeo.

On September 20th, 2017 Hurricane María made landfall in Puerto Rico. Today, on the fifth anniversary of the storm, Puerto Rico faces yet another catastrophic aftermath caused by Hurricane Fiona.

During our time in the field, we learned that for many of the families we worked with time stood still. Since the storm, the living conditions in Puerto Rico have only deteriorated. The back to back trauma of an island in crisis hasn’t allowed us the space to grieve properly.

Hurricane María marks a before and after in Puerto Rico.

Today is an especially challenging day for Puerto Ricans on the island and in the diaspora.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 20, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @gabriellanbaez | On assignment for @natgeo.

Hurricane María is infamous for the levels of catastrophic damage to Puerto Rico’s already fragile infrastructure and for the political chaos it insued in the months after the storm. However, it is the death toll (approximately 4,645 dead) that makes the storm enduringly painful.

In 2018, two months before the first anniversary of the storm, my father died by suicide. Since then, I’ve been looking to document the stories and voices of those who also lost loved ones in the wake of the storm. At the beginning of the year, I pitched this story to @natgeo and was able to connect with four families with diverse losses. In our meetings we talked, looked at treasured possessions of their loved ones, and were able to sustain each other in reliving the painful memories that talking about Puerto Rico’s worst natural disaster in modern history brings to light.

Currently, a few days before the 5th anniversary of the storm, Puerto Rico has been impacted by Hurricane Fiona, a category 1 storm, causing an island wide blackout and massive floods.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 19, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @norikohayashi_photo | While on assignment for @natgeo, I met 89-year-old Taira and his wife Ichi (86), who live in a small apartment in central Tokyo within walking distance from my home. Both of them suffer from dementia. We spent several hours together, talking while I took pictures of their daily life. Listening to their conversations, many of them were imaginary stories that were created and understood only by them. They enjoyed those conversations very much. Despite their severe dementia, they are still happily married. However, it is dangerous for people with dementia to live by themselves as they often don’t grasp the consequences of their actions.

Aging society in Japan is deeply interconnected with the issue of dementia. There are about 6 million people over the age of 65 suffering from dementia in Japan, and it is estimated that 1 in 5 elderly people in this country will have dementia in 2025.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 06, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @renan_ozturk, words by @m_synnott

#TheArcticMystery expedition update

Almost immediately after Taya and Polar Sun
escaped from Pasley Bay, I saw through the binoculars that there was a wall of ice a few miles off to our south. The latest ice chart showed ice extending west from the coast of the Gulf of Boothia and another penis-shaped piece of 7/10th ice extending east from King William (photo 2). You didn't need to be an ice forecaster to see that the two pieces were about to join. For all we knew, this had already happened. One of the toughest things about doing the NW is the lag between what you see on the ice charts and what is there when you arrive at said location in real life.

The AIS showed a French boat passing to our west. They had just come through James Ross Strait and they reported it was still open and gave me a waypoint to aim for. There was also a Dutch boat heading south about 18 miles ahead of us. By plotting their location via their AIS signal I was able to draw an imaginary line for the location of the ice.

By nightfall, we had passed three more sections of ice. It wasn't until we were well south of Matty Island the next morning though, that I let myself believe we had finally put the crux of the Northwest Passage behind us.

A lot has happened since, but for now l'Il just say that Polar Sun is in Cambridge Bay, and @zartman_rigging, @rudy.le and I are investigating whether it might be possible to haul out here for the winter. The crew needs to get home and there is real concern that we lost too much time to make it up and over Point Barrow and through the Bering Strait before the fall storm cycles begin. The decision as to whether we should end this year's voyage here has been one of the toughest I've ever made.

Earlier this morning we hiked to the other side of the bay to look at some steel cradles that previous voyagers have used to haul out here for the winter. There is no boat yard here in Cambridge. If you want to get your boat out of the water in this part of the world, good luck figuring it out.

@expedition.studios #OnAssignment
ph_atributos: Photo shared by Nat Geo in the Field on September 04, 2022 tagging @natgeo, @renan_ozturk, @m_synnott, @rudy.le, @zartman_rigging, and @expedition.studios.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @renan_ozturk words by @m_synnott

#TheArcticMystery Expedition update cont.

Taya was rafted up next to us. They had come in the night before, approaching with the sound of metal crunching against rock as they motored over a shoal to reach the safe haven of "Ice Boulder Bay." It was a good thing they did. By morning their little sliver of open water was gone.

The wind had finally died and the sun was shining, so I decided to go ashore to stretch my legs and hopefully clear my head. The dinghy made a tinkling sound as it cut through the skim of ice that now covered the open water. When I got back to the boat in the afternoon, chunks of ice were breaking apart all around us sending mini tsunamis through the bay. The ice boulder itself, which had been our safe haven for a day and a half, now appeared ready to topple and possibly crush the boats. There was nowhere to go. But we couldn't stay where we were.

Taya set off first and Polar Sun followed. At first, we were only looking for a new spot to tie up. But after muscling past two huge flows, which entailed ramming them numerous times with the bow of the boat, it became clear that we had to go all out to free ourselves from Pasley Bay. A light west wind was suddenly creating small leads along the shore that seemed to appear just when we needed them. Where there had been a glacial wall of ice the night before, we found an opening. And then another. And another.

At one point, Polar Sun was so close to land I could have almost jumped off onto the beach. Taya, which only draws three feet, was in front, radioing back soundings. Two meters, said Alan. Polar Sun draws six feet - when she's not massively overloaded. I throttled up. If we hit the bottom, we'd somehow just have to power through.

As we neared Point Edward, the leads got bigger. Renan was up on the spreaders calling directions. Polar Sun took the lead. An hour later, Polar Sun and Taya were in open water.
But the ice was not done with us yet. According to the most recent ice chart, it was closing back up.

Through the binoculars, I saw another wall of ice ahead.

@expedition.studios #OnAssignment
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on August 31, 2022.

Photos by @renan_ozturk words by @m_synnott

#TheArcticMystery Expedition update cont.

Taya was rafted up next to us. They had come in the night before, approaching with the sound of metal crunching against rock as they motored over a shoal to reach the safe haven of "Ice Boulder Bay." It was a good thing they did. By morning their little sliver of open water was gone.

The wind had finally died and the sun was shining, so I decided to go ashore to stretch my legs and hopefully clear my head. The dinghy made a tinkling sound as it cut through the skim of ice that now covered the open water. When I got back to the boat in the afternoon, chunks of ice were breaking apart all around us sending mini tsunamis through the bay. The ice boulder itself, which had been our safe haven for a day and a half, now appeared ready to topple and possibly crush the boats. There was nowhere to go. But we couldn't stay where we were.

Taya set off first and Polar Sun followed. At first, we were only looking for a new spot to tie up. But after muscling past two huge flows, which entailed ramming them numerous times with the bow of the boat, it became clear that we had to go all out to free ourselves from Pasley Bay. A light west wind was suddenly creating small leads along the shore that seemed to appear just when we needed them. Where there had been a glacial wall of ice the night before, we found an opening. And then another. And another.

At one point, Polar Sun was so close to land I could have almost jumped off onto the beach. Taya, which only draws three feet, was in front, radioing back soundings. Two meters, said Alan. Polar Sun draws six feet - when she's not massively overloaded. I throttled up. If we hit the bottom, we'd somehow just have to power through.

As we neared Point Edward, the leads got bigger. Renan was up on the spreaders calling directions. Polar Sun took the lead. An hour later, Polar Sun and Taya were in open water.
But the ice was not done with us yet. According to the most recent ice chart, it was closing back up.

Through the binoculars, I saw another wall of ice ahead.

@expedition.studios #OnAssignment
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on August 31, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @renan_ozturk, words by @m_synnott.

#TheArcticMystery expedition update

In the two and a half weeks since my last post, Polar Sun has been navigating the crux of the Northwest Passage. At first, we made good progress, heading north from Pond Inlet up Navy Board Inlet, then west down Lancaster Sound to Beechey Island, where the Franklin expedition spent the winter of 1845-46. After a few scrapes with ice in Barrow Strait, we found ourselves flying south down Peel Sound between Somerset Island and Prince of Wales Island. Little did we know at the time that we were about 24 hours too late. The day before, our Swiss friend Draco had slipped through some 5/10th ice in James Ross Strait. But now a storm was brewing and the window was closing. We needed to find shelter, so we tucked into a place called Pasley Bay. It was a decision we would live to bitterlv regret.

This is what it looks like when you are trapped by ice in the Northwest Passage. Every day for ten days, the ice situation got a little worse, and we found ourselves battling around the clock to keep Polar Sun from being crushed or run aground by the ice During one particularly dicey maneuver, the bow went up onto a floe and when it slid off, the wind grabbed the boat and turned it 180 degrees. We found ourselves facing the wrong way, surrounded by ice, in dangerously shallow water. According to the depth sounder, we were on the bottom. On Friday, August 26th, I awoke to find that the ice had filled in the last sliver of open water. Luckily, we had tied to a small grounded ice berg which had prevented us from being pushed onto shore by slabs of ice that were six feet thick. The temperature was well below freezing and a thin sheen of ice covered the open water between the floes. "Winter is coming," said Jacob. I didn't reply, but in my head I was thinking, 'Holy shit. I can't believe we are actually getting frozen in for the winter, just like Franklin.

To be continued… @expedition.studios #OnAssignment
ph_atributos: Photo shared by Nat Geo in the Field on August 30, 2022 tagging @renan_ozturk, and @expedition.studios.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @krisgraves | I arrived before dawn to set up a 12-hour time-lapse video overlooking the Millennium Falcon at Star Wars: Galaxy's Edge at Walt Disney World Resort. My team and I gazed toward the sky as the sun came up and were pleasantly surprised to spot a rocket launch occurring in the distance. It turned out to be a ULA (United Launch Alliance) rocket. Later in the day, we were lucky to record a second rocket launch from SpaceX. See the full time-lapse video on @natgeo.

I was given the opportunity to capture life from behind the scenes at Walt Disney World Resort. The Walt Disney Company is majority owner of National Geographic Partners. @WaltDisneyWorld @starwars @natgeo #DisneyWorld50
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on August 24, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @renan_ozturk, words by @m_synnott |

My dream of sailing to Baffin Island was realized yesterday around 2am when we tied Polar Sun up to the brand new public wharf in Pond Inlet after a six day 680-mile crossing of Baffin Bay. I don’t think it’s possible to describe, at least not in a few words, how good it felt (not only to find that there’s now a dock in Pond) to close the loop on a dream I’ve been nurturing since I was 26, hanging on the side of Polar Sun Spire, looking out over Sam Ford Fjord and imagining how cool it would be to visit this magnificent place in a small boat during open water.

The plan had been to pull into Sam Ford Fjord and sail beneath Polar Sun Spire, but the breakup of the ice in that area is at least two weeks late, and unfortunately we had to pass it by. Sadly, this also meant that we weren’t able to pick up our friends @sarahmcnairlandry and @erikboomer, who have been climbing and kayaking in the area for the past several weeks. (They are now executing their backup plan and hiking overland back to Clyde River.)

When we finally made it up and over the middle pack, which you can see in photos 2 and 3, we got hit with a 20 knot headwind that stayed on us for the rest of the passage. Close hauled, we sailed in and out of fog banks in heavy chop, sometimes with extensive amounts of ice in the water. It was definitely a character building experience.

When the sheer-sided mountains lining the entrance to the Buchan Gulf materialized out of the gloom on day six, a hearty cheer, heard by no one besides us, rang through the cold clear air. That night, we battled our way through ten miles of pack ice to a tenuous anchorage in the lee of Cape Antrobus on Nova Zembla Island. The next morning, Polar Sun was visited by a pod of belugas, which seemed to pay no heed to the strange boat from Maine.

We have one more day here in Pond to catch up on our correspondence and get Polar Sun ready for the trials ahead. There is still a lot of ice ahead of us in the Northwest Passage, so we will take it one day at a time.

#TheArcticMystery
#OnAssignment
@expedition.studios
ph_atributos: Photo shared by Nat Geo in the Field on August 11, 2022 tagging @renan_ozturk, @m_synnott, and @expedition.studios.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by Reuben Wu @itsreuben | A group selfie of my assistant @zendrson, our security escort, and me under the light of the drone in front of one of the massive sarsen trilithons at Stonehenge. Because of the popularity of these ancient megaliths, guards are present 24 hours a day, and the entire site is fenced off to prevent uninvited guests from entering.

For more photos and stories on Stonehenge, follow me @itsreuben #stonehenge @natgeo @natgeotravel
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on August 11, 2022. May be an image of 3 people.

ph_descripcion:
Footage by Reuben Wu @itsreuben | The smaller, older bluestones, highlighted inside the stone circle, were part of Stonehenge before the larger sarsens were added around 2600 B.C.

Since these stones were inside the stone circle, it wasn’t possible to illuminate them with a drone. Instead, I used a technique where we attached lights to the end of a telescopic pole and @zendrson walked it through to light the stones one by one.

For more photos and stories on Stonehenge, follow me @itsreuben #stonehenge

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @chrisburkard | On assignment for @natgeo

The citizens of Iceland are no stranger to volcanic activity. The country is located between the North American and Eurasian tectonic plates, which make it a hot spot for eruptions when the plates move apart.

Feeling the heat on my face, squinting through my viewfinder at the bright light, and smelling the smoke, makes for an unforgettable photographic assignment.
ph_atributos: Photo shared by ChrisBurkard on August 04, 2022 tagging @natgeointhefield.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @renan_ozturk, words by @m_synnott |

Those of you who have been following #TheArcticMystery expedition may have noticed we dropped off the radar in mid July.

For a number of reasons, we’d like to hold back the bulk of the details about where we’ve been and the experience we’ve just had. The short version is that we spent the past two weeks in the western Arctic trying to figure out what happened to Franklin and his men on their ill fated expedition to the Northwest Passage in 1845.

With Polar Sun in the capable hands of Ben Zartmann @zartman_rigging, we flew from Ilulissat, Greenland to King William Island in Nunavut. There we met up with inveterate Franklin searcher Tom Gross and a small team including Gjoa Haven local Inuit guide Jacob Keanik. Over the next 12 days we covered nearly 500 miles on four wheelers, through some of the most rugged, remote and inaccessible terrain I’ve ever had the pleasure to explore.

King William Island’s 5,000-square miles, no point of which rises higher than 300 feet above sea level, is dotted with a maze of lakes, streams, rivers, mud bogs—and mile upon mile of bleached ridges of razor sharp limestone shingle that ate the tires of our four wheelers for breakfast.

As we followed the sad trail of Franklin’s men on their doomed march out of the most savage wilderness on Earth, we observed musk ox, caribou, foxes and endless waterfowl as they went about their daily lives, exactly as they have for thousands of years. And we walked away deeply humbled and with our imaginations and hearts filled to overflowing after one of the richest experiences of our lives.

We’re now reunited with Ben back on Polar Sun in Ilulissat, a bit worse for the wear, but excited to get back underway. Polar Sun is topped off with food, fuel and water, the rig is tuned, and the ice has broken up enough in Baffin Bay to warrant our next move, which is to begin sailing west across Baffin Bay toward the Northwest Passage.

Thanks to everyone who has supported us thus far. It is nice to know that so many of you appreciate what we are trying to do.

@expedition.studios #onassignment
ph_atributos: Photo shared by Nat Geo in the Field on August 04, 2022 tagging @renan_ozturk, @rudy.le, and @expedition.studios.

King William Island’s 5,000-square miles, no point of which rises higher than 300 feet above sea level, is dotted with a maze of lakes, streams, rivers, mud bogs—and mile upon mile of bleached ridges of razor sharp limestone shingle that ate the tires of our four wheelers for breakfast.

As we followed the sad trail of Franklin’s men on their doomed march out of the most savage wilderness on Earth, we observed musk ox, caribou, foxes and endless waterfowl as they went about their daily lives, exactly as they have for thousands of years. And we walked away deeply humbled and with our imaginations and hearts filled to overflowing after one of the richest experiences of our lives.

We’re now reunited with Ben back on Polar Sun in Ilulissat, a bit worse for the wear, but excited to get back underway. Polar Sun is topped off with food, fuel and water, the rig is tuned, and the ice has broken up enough in Baffin Bay to warrant our next move, which is to begin sailing west across Baffin Bay toward the Northwest Passage.

Thanks to everyone who has supported us thus far. It is nice to know that so many of you appreciate what we are trying to do.

@expedition.studios #onassignment
ph_atributos: Photo shared by Nat Geo in the Field on August 04, 2022 tagging @renan_ozturk, @irving_matthew, and @expedition.studios.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @renan_ozturk, words by @m_synnott |

Those of you who have been following #TheArcticMystery expedition may have noticed we dropped off the radar in mid July.

For a number of reasons, we’d like to hold back the bulk of the details about where we’ve been and the experience we’ve just had. The short version is that we spent the past two weeks in the western Arctic trying to figure out what happened to Franklin and his men on their ill fated expedition to the Northwest Passage in 1845.

With Polar Sun in the capable hands of Ben Zartmann @zartman_rigging, we flew from Ilulissat, Greenland to King William Island in Nunavut. There we met up with inveterate Franklin searcher Tom Gross and a small team including Gjoa Haven local Inuit guide Jacob Keanik. Over the next 12 days we covered nearly 500 miles on four wheelers, through some of the most rugged, remote and inaccessible terrain I’ve ever had the pleasure to explore.

King William Island’s 5,000-square miles, no point of which rises higher than 300 feet above sea level, is dotted with a maze of lakes, streams, rivers, mud bogs—and mile upon mile of bleached ridges of razor sharp limestone shingle that ate the tires of our four wheelers for breakfast.

As we followed the sad trail of Franklin’s men on their doomed march out of the most savage wilderness on Earth, we observed musk ox, caribou, foxes and endless waterfowl as they went about their daily lives, exactly as they have for thousands of years. And we walked away deeply humbled and with our imaginations and hearts filled to overflowing after one of the richest experiences of our lives.

We’re now reunited with Ben back on Polar Sun in Ilulissat, a bit worse for the wear, but excited to get back underway. Polar Sun is topped off with food, fuel and water, the rig is tuned, and the ice has broken up enough in Baffin Bay to warrant our next move, which is to begin sailing west across Baffin Bay toward the Northwest Passage.

Thanks to everyone who has supported us thus far. It is nice to know that so many of you appreciate what we are trying to do.

@expedition.studios #onassignment

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @khandelwal_saumya on assignment for @natgeo

I found Sahibjit by chance. While I was walking along the road that divides two neighbouring villages in India’s Punjab along the India Pakistan border, I saw pink and blue lights on the horizon. I had to find the source!

Sahibjit, 23, is a farmer attending to an ailing father in India’s Punjab along the India-Pakistan border. His struggles are aggregated by the lack of access to health facilities for which he will have to travel for at least 25kms to get his father the attention he needs.

#punjab #india
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Punjab.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @ismailferdous | The picture is from my ongoing story on Maritime New York. A woman jogging in Governors Island. Governors Island is a 172-acre island in New York Harbor, within the New York City borough of Manhattan. The island was a former military base that was transformed into a seasonal public park in 2012, but before that it was the home to Revolutionary-era governors, a Civil War base, stockade and prison, as well as a United States Coast Guard base.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on July 30, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @khandelwal_saumya on assignment for @natgeo

Parkash Kaur has seen 85 years of life. She lives in India’s Punjab along the India-Pakistan border. Dadi (grandma) has seen a country divide and witnessed the turmoil, gotten married at an early age, given birth to 2 sons, seen villages being flooded and people resettle and rebuild their lives, and seen her grandsons get married and have kids. Now she spends most of her time sitting on a cot at her home, staring away into some place in the distance with her limited vision, and lying down when she gets tired of doing this.

And when she sees a visitor, which is often, because people here in the village live a community life, she greets them with a smile and asks them for tea. Like she did with us. Always grateful for such heart warming encounters.

#punjab #india
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Punjab.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by Reuben Wu @itsreuben | About 40 miles west of Stonehenge lies Stanton Drew. The third largest complex of standing stones in England, it was built around 3000 to 2000 B.C.
The Great Circle, shown here in the first image, is one of the largest stone circles in Britain. In contrast to Stonehenge and Avebury, the stone circles here receive very little tourist attention.
Stanton Drew probably looks much as it did thousands of years ago, and unlike at Stonehenge, there was a very real feeling of solitude here.

Second BTS image by @apickup
The final image was created with 18 layered exposures.

For more photos and stories on Stonehenge, follow me @itsreuben #stonhenge
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on July 28, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by Reuben Wu @itsreuben | Carn Goedog is a remote site in Wales that was identified by geologists as the source of the original bluestones at Stonehenge. For us, finding the exact location of Carn Goedog was not easy because there were so many similar-looking rocky outcrops, we were dealing with low clouds and rain, and we had only a hand-drawn map as a reference for directions.

The first image shows me and my assistant @zendrson with the drone in the frame, brightly flaring the lens as it lightly rained.

The second image was created with 15 multiple exposures.
For more photos and stories on Stonehenge, follow me @itsreuben. #stonehenge
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on July 21, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by Noriko Hayashi @norikohayashi_photo | While on assignment for @natgeo , I met 90-year-old Fumie Takino, founder of a senior cheer squad called “Japan Pom Pom” (@japan_pom_pom ), and the eldest member of the team. Fumie started cheerleading 26 years ago and does a weekly practice session for 3 hours. On a Monday afternoon, she was practicing with four other members of the team (each of them around 80 years old).

“In Japan, there is a strong stereotype that elderly people should behave in a certain way. We actually received a kind of critical response from some elderly people saying, “Why do elderly women of their ages wear such costumes and dance like that?” But I want to tell the younger generation that they don’t need to behave or live in preconceived ways of the elderly when they get old. It is important to be yourself and do what you want to do regardless of your age”. I was really inspired by her positivity.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on July 19, 2022.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Robbie Shone @shonephoto | On assignment for @natgeo in a giant ice cave in Austria called Schwarzmooskogel. This photograph shows the magnificent Schneevulkanhalle or Snow Volcano Hall. Although it looks beautiful, it won’t be long before all this ice has melted away. As our climate changes and warmer air passes through this chamber, the ice will eventually disappear. Drone: @tobiasmargreiter Behind-the-scenes: @charlyschwarzphotos Assistant: @valentinmargreiter #endoftheicecaves
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on July 15, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @renan_ozturk | Years of effort and dreaming about a shot all came together yesterday in an unexpected moment.

On our final approach to Ilulissat, Greenland @m_synnott, our captain and @natgeo writer, spotted this beauty of a berg so we made a little detour to document it. The shots feel like they should be a cheesy inspirational poster with a quote about perseverance and some obvious over-the-top with photoshopping, but I assure you it’s not manipulated.

A perfect light breeze came in allowing the crew to turn the motor off and tack back and forth with full sails and we shot our little hearts out for a couple hours of pure joy.

Stay tuned as this #TheArcticMystery continues across the NorthWest Passage for the rest of the summer.

@expedition.studios #OnAssignment
ph_atributos: Photo shared by Nat Geo in the Field on July 15, 2022 tagging @renan_ozturk, @m_synnott, and @expedition.studios.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by Noriko Hayashi @norikohayashi_photo | While on assignment for @natgeo, I met Imiko and her husband Kiyotaka. They were wearing Innophys’s exoskeleton muscle suit while harvesting Japanese leek on their farm in the morning.

Working on the farm is physically demanding and can lead to injuries in the lower back. Imiko has suffered from cervical spinal canal stenosis for 20 years. “We started using the exoskeleton muscle suits since Feb 2021. Not only when we carry bundles of leeks or heavy things, but also when we have to squat for a long time. It makes our work easier. With the artificial muscle using air pressure, the suit adjusts to the movement. Every day, we work almost 10 hours both in the field and in our barn, and harvest 45 tons of leek each year".
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on July 13, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @renan_ozturk | words by @m_synnott

After 37 days and more than 2200 miles sailed
from southern Maine, Polar Sun has arrived in Disko Bay.
Last night we anchored in the Whale Fish Islands in what we
believe is the exact spot where the Franklin expedition
dropped the hook in July of 1845.
At long last it is time for us to pick up Franklin's trail and to
endeavor, as humbly as we can, to follow in the wakes of the
Erebus and the Terror into the Northwest Passage.

#TheArcticMystery @expedition.studios #OnAssignment
ph_atributos: Photo shared by Nat Geo in the Field on July 13, 2022 tagging @renan_ozturk, @taylorfreesolo, @m_synnott, and @expedition.studios.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @renan_ozturk | words by @m_synnott

Yesterday was a long, eventful day for the crew of Polar Sun. Two nights earlier we were swapping stories about running aground with some Dutch sailors who rafted up with us in Sisimiut. I knocked on wood at the time, but considering how poorly charted the waters are here in Greenland I should have known better. One huge difference between the Arctic and our home waters in New England is how much of the area in which we are cruising is uncharted or unsurveyed. Our Forward Looking Sonar (FLS) has been instrumental in keeping us off the bottom - until yesterday. The chart showed feet in this little tickle, but it was actually more like 3. I saw a 2.4 on the depth sounder, which I was expecting. When it suddenly went to 1.4 I threw the boat into reverse. But it was too late

Fortunately we didn't hit too hard as the bottom was thickly covered in kelp. But we did end up hard aground. We tried to kedge off with a stern anchor that we dropped 300 feet astern with our trusty dinghy, but the bottom was so foul that we couldn't get the Fortress anchor to set. It was low tide, so we had no choice but to sit and wait. An hour and a half later, with the help of our ice poles and some serious RPMs in reverse, we got free. There was talk of trying to still push through the tickle but we opted to back track with our tail
between our legs.

#TheArcticMystery @natgeo @expedition.studios expedition #OnAssignment
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in The Arctic Circle with @natgeo, @renan_ozturk, @m_synnott, and @expedition.studios.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @renan_ozturk, words by @m_synnott

As I write this post, #TheArcticMystery expedition is pushing north up the west coast of Greenland aboard my 47’ sailboat, Polar Sun. A little over a month ago, we set off from southern Maine with the goal of solving one of the greatest mysteries in Arctic history: what really happened to the Franklin expedition, which disappeared in the Northwest Passage in the late 1840s.
Dozens of worthy expeditions have preceded us with a similar goal, but we have new research that we hope will lead us to Sir John Franklin’s tomb on King William Island.

Soon, we will join Franklin’s route in Disko Bay, and from there, if the ice allows, we’ll attempt to follow in the wakes of the Erebus and the Terror into the Arctic Archipelago in which they vanished more than 150 years ago.

@renanozturk and I have been on some epic expeditions for @natgeo in the past, but I think #TheArcticMystery is our most ambitious assignment yet. Our voyage, as we have laid it out, covers more than 7,000 nautical miles and will span at least three and a half months. But the most daunting aspect of this enterprise is not the storm we faced in the Davis Strait or the prospect of being caught in the ice like Franklin — but rather, the time spent away from our loved ones. To help achieve at least a semblance of balance between our work and personal lives, we’ve brought aboard our wives @hamptonkew and @taylorfreesolo, and my six year old son Tommy, for the Greenland section of our voyage.

A few weeks together won’t make our time apart any easier, but the sparkle in Tommy’s eye as we stood atop the Sermilinguaq Glacier gave me hope that the spirit of adventure was stirring inside of him — like it does inside all of us who seek the high and wild places of this world.
ph_atributos: Photo shared by Nat Geo in the Field on July 07, 2022 tagging @renan_ozturk, @m_synnott, and @expedition.studios.

@renanozturk and I have been on some epic expeditions for @natgeo in the past, but I think #TheArcticMystery is our most ambitious assignment yet. Our voyage, as we have laid it out, covers more than 7,000 nautical miles and will span at least three and a half months. But the most daunting aspect of this enterprise is not the storm we faced in the Davis Strait or the prospect of being caught in the ice like Franklin — but rather, the time spent away from our loved ones. To help achieve at least a semblance of balance between our work and personal lives, we’ve brought aboard our wives @hamptonkew and @taylorfreesolo, and my six year old son Tommy, for the Greenland section of our voyage.

A few weeks together won’t make our time apart any easier, but the sparkle in Tommy’s eye as we stood atop the Sermilinguaq Glacier gave me hope that the spirit of adventure was stirring inside of him — like it does inside all of us who seek the high and wild places of this world.
ph_atributos: Photo shared by Nat Geo in the Field on July 07, 2022 tagging @renan_ozturk, @m_synnott, and @expedition.studios.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @renan_ozturk, words by @m_synnott

As I write this post, #TheArcticMystery expedition is pushing north up the west coast of Greenland aboard my 47’ sailboat, Polar Sun. A little over a month ago, we set off from southern Maine with the goal of solving one of the greatest mysteries in Arctic history: what really happened to the Franklin expedition, which disappeared in the Northwest Passage in the late 1840s.
Dozens of worthy expeditions have preceded us with a similar goal, but we have new research that we hope will lead us to Sir John Franklin’s tomb on King William Island.

Soon, we will join Franklin’s route in Disko Bay, and from there, if the ice allows, we’ll attempt to follow in the wakes of the Erebus and the Terror into the Arctic Archipelago in which they vanished more than 150 years ago.

@renanozturk and I have been on some epic expeditions for @natgeo in the past, but I think #TheArcticMystery is our most ambitious assignment yet. Our voyage, as we have laid it out, covers more than 7,000 nautical miles and will span at least three and a half months. But the most daunting aspect of this enterprise is not the storm we faced in the Davis Strait or the prospect of being caught in the ice like Franklin — but rather, the time spent away from our loved ones. To help achieve at least a semblance of balance between our work and personal lives, we’ve brought aboard our wives @hamptonkew and @taylorfreesolo, and my six year old son Tommy, for the Greenland section of our voyage.

A few weeks together won’t make our time apart any easier, but the sparkle in Tommy’s eye as we stood atop the Sermilinguaq Glacier gave me hope that the spirit of adventure was stirring inside of him — like it does inside all of us who seek the high and wild places of this world.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @stephaniemeiling | Jessica Nabongo (@jessicanabongo) is the first documented Black woman to visit every country in the world and is the author of “The Catch Me If You Can: One Woman’s Journey to Every Country in the World.””

Her passion for storytelling came from growing up in a house full of books and reflecting on how she wasn’t always able to find herself in those books. Because of that, Nabongo says, “When I travel, it’s important for me to tell the stories that we rarely hear” and bring more representation to the Black community. “We never see beautiful images of places where there is war, as if beauty and war can’t coexist. That’s why storytelling is so important to me. It’s about decentering myself and using my platform to tell stories of other people throughout the world.”

This weekend, National Geographic is capturing Black joy through personal stories and behind-the-scenes moments at the ESSENCE Festival of Culture in New Orleans.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on July 03, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @stephaniemeiling | While on assignment for @natgeo, I met Pitmaster Big Moe Cason @bigmoecason from Des Moines, Iowa, who is in New Orleans this weekend to bring the joy of barbecue to the ESSENCE Festival of Culture.

While he’s always had a love of cooking, Cason’s passion for barbecue took off after he came across barbecue cook-off shows. Inspired, he saved up money to buy his first barbecue trailer and eventually competed for the first time in 2006. Since then, Cason has competed in close to 400 competitions, along the way diversifying and perfecting his techniques to become the well-rounded, internationally known pitmaster he is today. His self-made success has taken him around the world to compete, teach, and bring the joy of barbecue to people of many cultures and backgrounds. He’s been featured on shows such as “BBQ Pitmasters,” “BBQ Pit Wars,” “The Kitchen,” and “Chopped,” and his own upcoming show, “World of Flavor With Big Moe Cason,” premieres July 25.

Cason says that barbecue plays an important role within Black culture and the Black community. He personally believes that “barbecue as we celebrate it today came from humble beginnings, the early slaves taking their homeland techniques and spices to create something, out of pure necessity, for their families.” To see where barbecue is today on a global level, Cason can’t help but feel humbled and thankful for those origins.

This weekend, National Geographic is capturing Black joy through personal stories and behind-the-scenes moments at the ESSENCE Festival.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on July 02, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @stephaniemeiling | While on assignment in New Orleans covering the ESSENCE Festival of Culture for @natgeo, I met Charmaine Durant, from Miami, Florida, and her girlfriends. This is Durant’s seventh trip to New Orleans for the festival, where she feels “the interaction with everybody is so communal that you leave with a lot of joy in your heart.” During each visit, Durant embraces the festivities, camaraderie, ambiance, and cuisine of New Orleans.

ph_descripcion: I’ve just returned from a scouting trip for a new series of Day to Night photographs for @insidenatgeo , all photographed in Canada. This part of the country is a wild and spectacular landscape, mountainous & sparsely populated. I’m planning to capture the caribou migration through this unique landscape. Looking forward to sharing more! Photo by Shaun Taylor. #natgeo #canada #yukon #scout #photography

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @renan_ozturk | words by @m_synnott

I didn’t want to say anything until we were officially underway—for fear of jinxing what I hope will be the trip of a lifetime—but since we just left the dock at Rumery’s Boat Yard in Biddeford, Maine, I think it’s time to say a few words about the voyage which has just begun.

In some respects our goal is straight forward: to sail Polar Sun, my Stevens 47, from Maine to Alaska via the Northwest Passage. But @Renan_ozturk and I are also on assignment for @natgeo to tell a story about the Franklin expedition, which disappeared in the Northwest Passage in the late 1840s.

There is a lot that has gone into getting us to this point, and I will try to fill in some gaps along the way, but for now we are heading into the Gulf of Maine en route to the Davis straight and eventually Nuuk Greenland around July 1st.

For anyone who might be interested in following our progress stayed tuned for the next 4 months @renan_ozturk @m_synnott

#TheArcticMystery expedition #OnAssignment.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Gulf of Maine.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Corey Arnold @arni_coraldo | Along with raccoons and coyotes, I’ve been chasing urban black bears over the past couple years in Asheville, NC and South Lake Tahoe, CA. In South Lake Tahoe, some town bears have even been skipping their long naps (torpor) during winter due to the plentiful year round food supply provided by or left unlocked by humans. Some animals, like the bears here are thriving in greater numbers in town then in the wild. Check out our story for the July issue of @natgeo magazine “Why Cities are Going Wild” written by @christinedellamore #blackbear #garbage #wildlife #onassignment #natgeo
ph_atributos: Photo shared by Nat Geo in the Field on June 08, 2022 tagging @natgeo, and @arni_coraldo.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Corey Arnold @arni_coraldo | I've spent the last three years criss-crossing the U.S. in search of urban coyotes, raccoons, and black bears on assignment for @natgeo. When I learned that a horse racing track in Chicago has a frequent coyote visitor that hangs out behind the scoreboard, I set up a camera trap in the building behind the scoreboard where I found evidence of coyote scat and recent kills. Getting the lighting right on a shot like this requires me acting as a coyote stand in. Sorry to say, the coyote never showed up. It was the first of many dream shots that weren't meant to be. Check out my feature in the July issue of the @natgeo magazine or visit my feed @arni_coraldo for more behind the scenes of urban wildlife action. #cameratrap #urbanwildlife #chicago

ph_descripcion: Photo by @KendrickBrinson | On assignment for @natgeo. I don’t know if you’ve noticed or not, but pickleball is becoming a more and more popular sport in the US. In Sun City, Arizona, an age-restricted community of retirees 55 and older, the Sun City Pickleball Club has 964 members as of last week. That’s 200 more members than the club had in January of this year! The community has 27 pickleball courts, 8 of which are under a shelter out of the sun, and there are whispers of plans to build more courts soon. I’ve talked to many of the newer and older players whose ages range from 54 to 90 years old on the courts here the past few days and so many of the players say the social aspect is what keeps bringing them back.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on June 01, 2022.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Robbie Shone @shonephoto | Hidden away on one of the lower levels of the Mina Rica in south east Spain is a mined level where the walls are totally covered with beautiful, but delicate, gypsum. What fascinated me the most is that this gypsum has been forming since the miners created the tunnel — making it only 150 years old. It felt surreal and almost otherworldly being in a space where we were completely surrounded by bright white gypsum. #giantgeode #pulpigeode #gypsumcrystals #OnAssignment @natgeo

ph_descripcion: Photo by Robbie Shone @shonephoto | I am here at the Pulpi Geode in Southern Spain, where the Rica Mine is full of an assortment of rocks and minerals, all boasting their own vibrant color. However, the stand-alone formation is gypsum, which is the same material that the crystals in the giant geode are made from. Here we see a beautiful, but extremely delicate gypsum flower clinging to the wall of one particular mine level. #giantgeode #pulpigeode #gypsumcrystal #OnAssignment @natgeo

ph_descripcion: Behind the scenes with @stephenwilkes | Here I am working into the night during my latest Day to Night of Bears Ears National Monument for @natgeo . The sun fully sets in Bears Ears at 8:10 p.m. The stars twinkle above my assistant @lennychristopher as he grabs a piece of gear from our basecamp. One of the extraordinary things about Bears Ears is that its history is constantly underfoot. After the first night, our incredible Navajo guide @louisdwilliams20 discovered our camp site was on the remnants of an ancient Navajo grain storage. Swipe to see us working to capture the full moon rise. Second image by @ivar_bas . #iphoneonly bearsearsnationalmonument #navajo #stars #moon #natgeo #photography

ph_descripcion: Behind the scenes with @stephenwilkes | Here I am working into the night during my latest Day to Night of Bears Ears National Monument for @natgeo . The sun fully sets in Bears Ears at 8:10 p.m. The stars twinkle above my assistant @lennychristopher as he grabs a piece of gear from our basecamp. One of the extraordinary things about Bears Ears is that its history is constantly underfoot. After the first night, our incredible Navajo guide @louisdwilliams20 discovered our camp site was on the remnants of an ancient Navajo grain storage. Swipe to see us working to capture the full moon rise. Second image by @ivar_bas . #iphoneonly bearsearsnationalmonument #navajo #stars #moon #natgeo #photography
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on May 09, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @paoloverzone | On assignment for @natgeo. ITER—designed to demonstrate the scientific and technological feasibility of fusion power—will be the world's largest experimental fusion facility. Fusion is the process that powers the Sun and the stars: when light atomic nuclei fuse together to form heavier ones, a large amount of energy is released. Fusion research is aimed at developing a safe, abundant, and environmentally responsible energy source. ITER Project is under construction in Saint-Paul-lez-Durance, in the south of France. The dimensions of the ITER machine components dwarf those who build them. Here Construction Coordinator, Lola Zedet, poses in front of one of nine Vacuum Vessel sectors that just arrived from South Korea.

Follow @paoloverzone for more images and stories.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 30, 2022.

Photo by @paoloverzone | On assignment for @natgeo inside the holy grail of fusion. This 30-meter-wide, 30-meter-high pit is where the ITER machine is currently being assembled. Its mission is to prove that we can gain net energy from fusing hydrogen atoms. Clean and safe energy to replace fossil fuels, once and for all.

ITER—designed to demonstrate the scientific and technological feasibility of fusion power—will be the world's largest experimental fusion facility. Fusion is the process that powers the Sun and the stars: when light atomic nuclei fuse together to form heavier ones, a large amount of energy is released. Fusion research is aimed at developing a safe, abundant, and environmentally responsible energy source. ITER Project is under construction in Saint-Paul-lez-Durance, in the south of France. Follow @paoloverzone for more images and stories.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 30, 2022.

Photo by Noriko Hayashi @norikohayashi_photo | While on assignment for @natgeo, I met Ikuko Akasaka, a legendary 82-year-old Geisha, who continues to perform after 64 years.

Once a week for 2 hours, Ikuko's trainer visits her to help her do several exercises to include stretching, weight training, and running. "Even if I am very busy and tired, I never skip this exercise," Ikuko told me. A Geisha's work is physically demanding as they perform while dressed in a kimono, wear a 2-kilo wig for several hours, serve drinks, dance, and ensure customers enjoy their time.

There were more than 400 geishas in Akasaka area in Tokyo when she started; nowadays, only 20 remain. Ikuko wants to train young women to pass on geisha’s arts and spirit to younger generations. “To stay healthy is to have a desire for life and to show gratitude for others. Every moment I want to learn new things and polish my art to become a better geisha. If you hate people, you can't live. I became who I am because of people who supported me. Instead of complaining, I am more grateful for what I have."
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 26, 2022.

Photo by Noriko Hayashi @norikohayashi_photo | While on assignment for @natgeo, I met Ikuko Akasaka, a legendary 82-year-old Geisha, who continues to perform after 64 years. Before she leaves home for work, Ikuko spends about 20 minutes doing her makeup by putting white paste (white powder mixed with water) on her face and neck with special brushes. She then dabs more white powder all over to make her face look softer. Lastly, she puts red color with a small brush called beni hake around the ends of her eyes, eyebrows, and lips.

There were more than 400 geishas in Akasaka area in Tokyo when she started; nowadays, only 20 remain. Ikuko wants to train young women to pass on geisha’s arts and spirit to younger generations. “To stay healthy is to have a desire for life and to show gratitude for others. Every moment I want to learn new things and polish my art to become a better geisha. If you hate people, you can't live. I became who I am because of people who supported me. Instead of complaining, I am more grateful for what I have."
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 26, 2022.

Photo by Noriko Hayashi @norikohayashi_photo | While on assignment for @natgeo, I met Ikuko, a legendary 82-year-old Geisha, who continues to perform after 64 years. “It is a genuine pleasure to be on stage. I love my job. If my life ended while I perform on a tatami mat, I would be happy.”

There were more than 400 geishas in Akasaka area in Tokyo when she started; nowadays, only 20 remain. Ikuko wants to train young women to pass on geisha’s arts and spirit to younger generations. “To stay healthy is to have a desire for life and to show gratitude for others. Every moment I want to learn new things and polish my art to become a better geisha. If you hate people, you can't live. I became who I am because of people who supported me. Instead of complaining, I am more grateful for what I have."

Ikuko is the first geisha to receive the Emperor’s Award, the Order of the Rising Sun, Gold and Silver Rays in 2016 for her long-time contribution and distinguished service in the field of culture and arts.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 26, 2022.

Photo by @balazsgardi | A seasonal worker scrapes the resin from an opium poppy in Zharay district, Kandahar province, Afganistan. Though banned under the former regime, the Taliban allowed the spring harvest to proceed this year across the south and the east of the country, where fields were bursting with white, red and purple flowers. Soon after we passed through, however, the Taliban reimposed a ban on the opium trade, depriving an already broken economy of its most lucrative crop.

To survey the impact of decades of war and daily life under the second coming of the Taliban, Jason Motlagh and I are driving along Afghanistan’s 1400-mile long National Highway 1, also known as the Ring Road.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 15, 2022.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Saul Martinez @saulmartinezphoto | On assignment for @natgeo while working on a project I have been documenting for 10 years now of Semana Santa. It’s the Holy Week festivities leading up to Easter Sunday in Guatemala. This is the time of year when tens of thousands of Catholic faithfuls prepare to participate in processions all throughout the country. Follow along to see how this unique tradition unites a country with so much inequality and cultural division.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 15, 2022.

Photo by @balazsgardi | Hazara girls receiving instruction at a public school in Angori, Ghazni Province, Afghanistan. A recent Taliban ruling barred girls from grades 6-12 from attending class, yet some continue to show up for class. After facing severe persecution under the former Taliban regime, ethnic Hazaras seized educational opportunities in the post-2001 era to secure government jobs and start businesses.

To survey the impact of decades of war and daily life under the second coming of the Taliban, Jason Motlagh and I are driving along Afghanistan’s 1400-mile long National Highway 1, also known as the Ring Road.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 14, 2022.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @balazsgardi | Rafiullah spends several hours each day filling bomb craters on the highway. Bomb blasts on this stretch of road appear every few hundred meters and wreak havoc on vehicles. In the near absence of government work crews, Rafiullah and his older brother shovel and pack dirt into the road for tips from passing motorists that amount to a dollar or two a day.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 12, 2022.

Photo by @cristinabaussan / Rosa Hernández, 23, holds her 4-year-old daughter in front of La Cachada's stage backdrop after seeing their play, “Some Day,” depicting stories of gender-based violence in El Salvador. "We are all exposed to violence," Hernández said, "so it's important that they give voice to our stories. I talk with my daughter a lot so when I saw the play many things came to my mind about the abuse that I lived.” La Cachada’s founding mothers, five street vendors from humble backgrounds, explore taboo topics such as forced motherhood, gang violence, and exploitative working conditions. ⁣
⁣
La Cachada, Salvadoran slang for “bargain,” is an all-female theater troupe by and for Salvadorans. Their performances initiate difficult conversations and provide an emotional release in a country where mental health stigma and deficient services mean traumas remain buried rather than confronted.⁣
⁣
Follow me @cristinabaussan for more stories of tenderness in the face of adversity.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 08, 2022.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @paoloverzone | While on assignment for @natgeo, I captured this full-scale replica of the world’s most powerful fusion energy machine, JET. Remote Handling Operators use this replica as a training facility to practice removing tiles and diagnostic measurements before doing it on the real JET at the UK Atomic Energy Authority near Oxford, UK.

The group first designed the play in 2015 to explore the taboo topic of forced motherhood in El Salvador, basing the script on their own personal experiences with abuse. ⁣

Photo by Hannah Yoon @hanloveyoon | Most people have heard of the lost boys of Sudan, but not much has been known or heard of the lost girls of Sudan. Thousands of boys and girls were displaced or orphaned during the Second Sudanese Civil War between 1983 to 2005. Rebecca Deng is one of the 89 lost girls who resettled in the US in 2000. Rebecca now has three children and is an international speaker and author. She also supports refugees/immigrants and those traumatized by both human and natural disasters. She wrote a book about her story and is hoping to also have a children’s book about her experience. Here she is with her daughter, Leona, 4, as they get ready to go out. Rebecca openly talks to her children about being a refugee and what that means for the people going through war and conflict today. In the second photo, Rebecca showed me some photos from her high school days.

This image was taken on assignment as part of an upcoming @natgeo story on current and former unaccompanied refugee youth from all over the world who live in and around Grand Rapids, Michigan. Paired with local foster families, these refugees navigate school, friends, and acclimating to a new culture and city.

#refugees #michigan #refugeeyouth #sudan
ph_atributos: Photo shared by Nat Geo in the Field on March 28, 2022 tagging @hanloveyoon.

Photo by Hannah Yoon @hanloveyoon | This week I've been spending time with different refugee youth who came to the US without their parents. This is Ar Sar Ni, 15, playing with her dog at her home in Grand Haven, Michigan. She came to Michigan almost 10 years ago with her three siblings as part of the Unaccompanied Refugee Minors Program (URM). She doesn’t remember much of her time at the refugee camp in Thailand other than the snacks she would get. Many Karen people fled Myanmar and ended up in Thailand at refugee camps. Thousands are still displaced and living in Thailand. It is easier for minors to get resettled to other countries.

This image was taken on assignment as part of an upcoming @natgeo story on current and former unaccompanied refugee youth from all over the world who live in and around Grand Rapids, Michigan. Paired with local foster families, these refugees navigate school, friends, and acclimating to a new culture and city. #refugees #refugeeyouth #michigan
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Grand Haven, Michigan with @hanloveyoon.

Photo by Hannah Yoon @hanloveyoon | This week I've been spending time with different refugee youth who came to the US without their parents. These two boys came from Afghanistan to Michigan in October 2021. They came without knowing any English and what life would be like here. One of them talked about how he misses Kabul and how lively it is. They are living with two other refugee youth at their foster family home in a small town outside of Grand Rapids, Michigan.

This image was taken on assignment as part of an upcoming @natgeo story on current and former unaccompanied refugee youth from all over the world who live in and around Grand Rapids, Michigan. ph_descripcion: Photo by @paoloverzone | While in Giza, Egypt documenting excavations in the Giza plateau, I captured workers “cleaning" the excavation site at the end of their workday. I did not interfere with their work but waited for the right moment to shoot during the cleaning process. My assistant @massimonicolaci was ready to move with the strobe and react quickly to adapt to the continuous change in workflow. Follow @paoloverzone for more stories on Egypt over the next few days.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on March 18, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @ralphpace / If only for a moment, a juvenile sea otter pauses in her mighty kingdom of Monterey, CA.

As a member of the weasel family (Mustelidae), sea otters lack fat storage and must rely on their fur (the densest in the animal kingdom) and a fast metabolism. To feed their metabolism sea otters must eat up to 30% of their body weight a day.

Like other weasels, sea otters are quite smart and can be rather mischievous. Still moments are rare. Catching the reflection of his own self on the dome of my underwater housing, this youngster paused for a moment before carrying on with his daily duties.

Shot for an upcoming @natgeo story on sea otters

Image taken under U.S. FWS permit # 37946D
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on March 08, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @andrea_frazzetta / Elena and Agata play pirates in the woods.
"Crescere Nel Bosco" is a school in nature located in Velletri in the heart of the Castelli Romani Regional Park, near Rome, Italy.
The project hosts about 40 children in kindergarten and about thirty in primary school: the dialogue with the state and “traditional” school in the area is constant and effective.
In the outdoors, children have more incentive to be together, to be in a group, to move around in company, to get out of the shell of the Internet and the shelter of the house.
"Growing in the Woods” is a documentation project focused on the most important experiences of education in nature in Italy. Supported by @InsideNatGeo’s Emergency Fund for Journalists.
Follow me @andrea_frazzetta to know more. #Italy #outdooreducation #backtonature
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on February 07, 2022.

Photo by @garth.lenz | A large and remote clear-cut of what is rapidly diminishing ancient coastal temperate rainforest on Vancouver Island. With the valley bottoms of these valuable and rare old-growth forests—consisting of hemlock, Douglas fir, western red and yellow cedar, and Sitka spruce up to 500 to 1,000 years old and with the largest of these trees up to 15 feet
(4.5 m) in diameter and 200 feet (60 m) tall—mostly clear-cut, logging companies are now focusing on the remote, high-elevation, and steep-slope forests, as they are virtually all that's left.
#deforestation #clearcutting #ancientforest #oldgrowthforest
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on January 13, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @garth.lenz | Surrounded by a sea of clear-cuts, Big Lonely Doug is a large coastal Douglas fir tree located in the Gordon River Valley on Vancouver Island, in British Columbia, Canada. With a height of 70 meters (230 feet) and a circumference of nearly 12 meters (39 feet), it's the second largest Douglas fir in Canada after the Red Creek fir in the nearby San Juan Valley. This area is also home to some of the last intact coastal temperate rainforests on southern Vancouver Island, the vast majority of which have been clear-cut. The nearby intact watershed of Fairy Creek has sparked protests and blockades in response to the proposed clear-cutting within that neighboring watershed. These protests and blockades, which began in August 2020, have been ongoing for over a year. They have widened to include multiple blockades of other intact forests in the region, recently overtaking the 1993 Clayoquot Sound clear-cutting protests as the largest civil disobedience campaign in Canadian history.
#BigLonelyDoug #Deforestation #OldGrowthForest #AncientForest
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on January 12, 2022.

Photo by @lauredutruy | Abellino, 9, attends school through an inclusion class for children with disabilities within the mainstream school system. After a very difficult experience in another institution last year, he joined this school in March 2021. That process is challenging for the young boy, born with Down syndrome. Here's he's using a chewy tube, which helps Abellino to focus.

These photographs are part of an ongoing story on how a family with three children with Down syndrome are getting through the pandemic in France. This work is supported by the @insidenatgeo COVID-19 Emergency Fund for Journalists.

#downsyndrome #trisomy21 #disabilityawareness
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on January 07, 2022.

Photo by @lauredutruy | Magdaléna, 10, visits a speech therapist two times a week. She has difficulties speaking due to oral hypotonia, a decreased level of muscle tone, which is often linked to Down syndrome. Speech therapy is crucial for improving her oral expression skills - and essential for social integration. Here the therapist uses Makaton signs, a communication system that the young girl has been learning for years.

These photographs are part of an ongoing story on how a family with three children with Down syndrome are getting through the pandemic in France. This work is supported by the @insidenatgeo COVID-19 Emergency Fund for Journalists.

#downsyndrome #trisomy21 #disabilityawareness

Photo by @lauredutruy / Nathanaël, 13, visits a physiotherapist every week. Physiotherapy supports children with Down syndrome in their neuromotor development and with combatting hypotonia (low muscle tone). It's also critical to social integration. Here Nathanaël grasps suction pads from a mirror, an exercise that helps improve his motor skills.

These photographs are part of an ongoing story on how a family with three children with Down syndrome are getting through the pandemic in France. This work is supported by the @insidenatgeo COVID-19 Emergency Fund for Journalists.

Photo by @noralorek | Michelle Savage and Heiður Maria Rúnarsdóttir hold their newborn as their cat roams nearby. According to tradition, the baby’s name won’t be revealed until the naming ceremony held on December 30.
With a staggering 16.5 percent more births than normal in the second quarter of 2021, Iceland is in the midst of a baby boom. Since the COVID-19 pandemic began, births in many wealthy countries across the world have plummeted. In the Nordic countries, the pattern has been the opposite. All five Nordic countries offer paid parental leave for at least 11 months, based on income from the previous year. Payouts range from about 53 percent of income in Denmark to nearly 100 percent—and as much as $6,000 a month—in Norway. In Iceland new parents receive 12 months of paid leave at 80 percent of their normal income, up to about $4,500 a month.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on January 01, 2022.
