ph_descripcion:
Photo by @garth.lenz | In this image shot from a helicopter over Canada's northern Alberta region, leafless dead and dying aspen are surrounded by healthy trees. The aspen dieback, as it's called, was brought about by prolonged drought as a result of climate change, which in turn made these aspen forests susceptible to insect infestation and other threats. Aspen become increasingly unhealthy, eventually dying and falling. Tent caterpillars are thought to be a major cause of aspen dieback, but research still is in the early stages and much is unknown.
The problem is compounded by the fact that the boreal forest is the world’s greatest terrestrial carbon sink as well as one its most concentrated, one of our greatest allies in the fight against climate change and global warming. However, as these aspen forests die and decompose, they release massive stored carbon into the atmosphere, further fueling climate change and the conditions that cause aspen dieback.
#AspenDieback #ForestThreats #borealforest #climatechange
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on December 30, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @lauredutruy | Élodie is seen with her three children. In 2008, the single mother adopted her first child, Nathanaël. Then Magdaléna and Abellino joined the family. They were all born with Down syndrome.

Since the first adoption, Élodie has been fighting for the integration of her children in society. She knows what they are capable of and is also aware of their limits. “I do not want to put pressure on them. I want them to grow up and blossom. I will see how they develop and what they will be able to do. The important thing is that they are well-grounded, and maintain a level of independence. We can cover their shortfalls together. I want to adapt with them and be open to what they will become,” explains Élodie.

These photographs are part of an ongoing story on how a family with three children with Down syndrome are getting through the pandemic in France. This work is supported by the @insidenatgeo COVID-19 Emergency Fund for Journalists.

#downsyndrome #trisomy21 #disabilityawareness
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on December 29, 2021.

Photos by @noralorek | In Iceland, Drífa Hrund Guðmundsdóttir has twins—Baldur Logi and Brynja Lill—who are now seven months old. During the pandemic, Guðmundsdóttir cherished the extra time she had with her two teenage daughters, and decided to have another child. “I think that was the tipping point for me,” Guðmundsdóttir says. “I realized I wasn’t ready to be done with the mom thing.”

With a staggering 16.5 percent more births than normal in the second quarter of 2021, Iceland is in the midst of a pandemic baby boom. A leading hypothesis on why this might be is that in times of economic uncertainty, the Nordic countries’ generous family leave pay helps alleviate concerns about increased financial burden. A new baby can act as a financial security net for the household.

All five Nordic countries offer paid parental leave for at least 11 months, based on income from the previous year. Payouts range from about 53 percent of income in Denmark to nearly 100 percent—and as much as $6,000 a month—in Norway. In Iceland, new parents receive 12 months of paid leave at 80 percent of their normal income, up to about $4,500 a month.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on December 29, 2021.

Photo by @noralorek | Snorri Magnússon started giving swimming lessons for babies in 1990. These days he's busier than usual and may teach three lessons a day, six days a week, at a pool in Mosfellsbaer, 15 minutes north of Reykjavik. Magnússon says swimming is just a minor portion of his teaching—the interactions between babies and parents and the joy of being in the water are most important to him.

With a staggering 16.5 percent more births than normal in the second quarter of 2021, Iceland is in the midst of a baby boom. Since the COVID-19 pandemic began, births in many wealthy countries across the world have plummeted. Meanwhile, Iceland has struggled to increase capacity in its maternity wards.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on December 28, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @andrea_frazzetta / Kindergarten in the Woods of Ostia, Rome. Children climb the branches of one of the trees in the courtyard.
A wooden panel welcomes visitors to the preschool:
"In this little piece of the world it is not forbidden: to play ball / to get dirty / to jump on hay bales / to play with water / to climb trees / to scream with joy / to laugh out loud / to go in puddles.”
“Asilo Nel Bosco of Ostia” is an Italian association that works on educational projects for children from two to 14 years old, where all the activities take place outdoors, in contact with nature.
Over the course of this year, I have documented several entities committed to outdoor education in my country. The pandemic has definitely challenged the school system and highlighted the need for a rethink.
This project was born from interest as a photojournalist but also as a reaction to the difficult and tragic year that shook my country. As a man and as a father, I sought a rapprochement with nature. And I've also done that through photography. Spending a lot of time with these children has been a joy and a way to reconnect with my childhood.
"Growing in the Woods” is a documentation project focused on the most important experiences of education in nature in Italy. Supported by @InsideNatGeo’s Emergency Fund for Journalists.
Follow me @andrea_frazzetta to know more. #Italy #outdooreducation #backtonature
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on December 16, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @garth.lenz / Big Lonely Doug. West Coast of southern Vancouver Island.  Surrounded by a sea of clearcuts, Big Lonely Doug is a large Coastal Douglas Fir tree located in the Gordon River Valley of Vancouver Island in British Columbia, Canada. With a height of  70.2 meters or 230 feet, a circumference o 11.91 meters or 39 feet, and a diameter of 3.91 meters or 12.4 feet it is the second largest Douglas Fir in Canada after the Red Creek Fir in the nearby San Juan Valley. This area is also home to some of the last intact coastal temperate rainforests on southern Vancouver Island, the vast majority of which have been clearcut logged. The nearby intact watershed of Fairy Creek has sparked protests and blockades in response to the proposed clearcutting within that neighbouring watershed. These protests and blockades which began at the end of August 2020 have been ongoing for over a year at the time of this writing. They have widened to include multiple blockades of other intact forests in the region and have now totalled approximately 1000 people arrested, recently overtaking the 1993 Clayoquot Sound protests as the largest civil disobedience campaign in Canadian history.

#BigLonelyDoug, CoastalTemperateRainforest, ClearcutLogging, AncientForest, #Deforestation, #OldGrowthForest, #AncientForest
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on December 15, 2021.

Photos by @lauredutruy / Nathanaël and his classmates are spending the morning in an orchard nearby the city of Carquefou, western France. The teenagers with mental disabilities attend school through an external teaching unit, a structure that allows them to receive education in a regular school environment.
The group takes part in apples picking. The activity introduces them to the professional field as the group gets paid for the kilos of fruits they will gather. With the money collected, the educators will let them buy treats and objects to enjoy at school.

These photographs are part of an ongoing story on how a family with three children with Down Syndrome are getting through the pandemic in France. This work is supported by the @insidenatgeo COVID-19 Emergency Fund for Journalists.

#downsyndrome #trisomy21 #disabilityawareness

Photo by @lauredutruy / Magdaléna, 10-year-old, is getting ready with other dancers in the dressing rooms. They are about to give a performance on stage. The project called Tandem, created by the association “Rien qu’un chromosome en +” brings children and adults with Down Syndrome and non-disabled relatives or closed ones together to dance. The COVID-19 health measures caused many difficulties throughout the year and challenged the initiative, but the group could finally perform this autumn in the city of Thouaré-sur-Loire, western France.

These photographs are part of an ongoing story on how a family with three children with Down Syndrome are getting through the pandemic in France.This work is supported by the @insidenatgeo COVID-19 Emergency Fund for Journalists.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @garth.lenz / Taken from a helicopter over northern Alberta, this image shows dead and dying aspen as a result of climate change. The dead and dying aspen can be differentiated from the few healthy aspen in this frame by their lack of leaves.
Prolonged drought as a result of climate change has made these aspen forests susceptible to many pests and other threats. All across boreal forests, the largest forest ecosystem on earth, increasingly large numbers of aspen are being decimated by Aspen Dieback. As aspen become increasingly unhealthy they lose their leaves, eventually die, and then fall to the forest floor and decompose.
This compounds the problem of climate change and Aspen Dieback as boreal forests and wetlands are the world’s greatest carbon sink. An acre of boreal forest is almost twice as effective at storing carbon as an acre of tropical rainforest and as a result they are one of our most effective and powerful allies in the fight against climate change. However as these aspen forests die and decompose they release their tremendous stores of carbon back into the atmosphere creating a vicious cycle by further fuelling climate change and the conditions that will likely result in even more extensive Aspen Dieback in the future.
#AspenDieback #ForestThreats #borealforest #climatechange
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on December 07, 2021.

pg_descripcion:

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @garth.lenz / Big Lonely Doug. West Coast of southern Vancouver Island. Surrounded by a sea of clearcuts, Big Lonely Doug is a large Coastal Douglas Fir tree located in the Gordon River Valley of Vancouver Island in British Columbia, Canada. With a height of 70.2 meters or 230 feet, a circumference of 11.91 meters or 39 feet, and a diameter of 3.91 meters or 12.4 feet it is the second largest Douglas Fir in Canada after the Red Creek Fir in the nearby San Juan Valley. This area is also home to some of the last intact coastal temperate rainforests on southern Vancouver Island, the vast majority of which have been clearcut logged. The nearby intact watershed of Fairy Creek has sparked protests and blockades in response to the proposed clearcutting within that neighbouring watershed. These protests and blockades which began at the end of August 2020 have been ongoing for over a year at the time of this writing. They have widened to include multiple blockades of other intact forests in the region and have now totalled approximately 1000 people arrested, recently overtaking the 1993 Clayoquot Sound protests as the largest civil disobedience campaign in Canadian history.

#BigLonelyDoug, CoastalTemperateRainforest, ClearcutLogging, AncientForest, #Deforestation, #OldGrowthForest, #AncientForest
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on December 06, 2021.

Photo by Arturo Rodriguez @arturorguezdotcom / La Palma volcano by the numbers:

-71 days of eruption
-846 earthquakes in the last week alone
-11 million square meters of land destroyed
-1242 homes razed by lava flow, hundreds more buried by volcanic ash
-7000 people evacuated
-70 km of roads destroyed
-348 hectares of crops devastated

#CanaryIslands #lapalma #Spain #volcancumbrevieja

ph_descripcion: Photo by @shonephoto Robbie Shone / A tell-tale sign that winter has arrived in the Alps are these wonderful cloud inversions. The snow will soon be falling and accessing the caves will be too difficult. In spring, when the snow melts, the water will finds its way underground where new and beautiful ice formations will form in the caves. Sadly though, in recent years this has got less and less. #EndOfTheIceCaves #IceCaves @natgeo @natgeointhefield
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on November 21, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @javier_aznar_photography / Prairie Rattlesnake (Crotalus viridis) photographed in the road, in New Mexico, USA.

We were driving at sunset when we spot this snake sunbathing on the pavement. This is one of the main threats for the rattlesnakes as well as other reptiles, who are killed by road traffic.

Next time on the road, specially from Spring to Autumn when snakes are active, drive carefully to avoid running over any animal.

Follow me @javier_aznar_photography for more images and stories

#animals #usa #reptiles #newmexico
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on November 21, 2021.

Rattlesnakes have long retractable fangs that they use to inject the venom, killing the preys in a really short time. The venom also helps them digesting the food.

Photo by @orehuiying / A pot of prawn broth boils at the One Michelin Star Peranakan Restaurant Candlenut's kitchen in Singapore. Aromatic and spicy, Peranakan cuisine combines recipes and techniques of cooking of the indigenous Malay and immigrant Chinese, Indian and Arab communities in the region among others. At Candlenut, Chef owner Malcom Lee puts a contemporary spin on things, using buah keluak in butter cake and a rempah to flavor fried barramundi.

Follow me @orehuiying as I continue to photograph little known stories in Singapore on film. #Singapore #Peranakan #Nonya #heritage #culture

ph_descripcion: Photo by @orehuiying / A dish of pickled belimbing fruit- a close relative of starfruit, prepared by Tanya Pillay-Nair in her Singapore home. Her cooking draws on her Chitty Melaka heritage and is a blend of Malay, Peranankan Chinese and Indian cuisine. Also known as Perankan Indians, the Chitty Melaka is a small community in Singapore who are descendants of South Indian traders who first settled in Melaka during the reign of the Melaka Sultanate (15th – 16th centuries) and married local women of Malay and Chinese descent. Follow me @orehuiying as I continue to photograph little known stories in Singapore on film. #Singapore #Peranakan #Nonya #heritage #culture #analogue
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on November 12, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @ralphpace / A sea otter pup sleeps on her sleeping mother in the Elkhorn Slough of Moss Landing, CA.

Mothers have just six short months (roughly) to get her pup ready for the world. In this time the pup must learn how to properly groom itself, find food and learn to avoid predators. During these hard six months, mothers will be pushed to the limits in order to provide the nutrients that both her and her newborn need. You can often find mothers and their young away from large groups where they can get some much needed rest.

As this pup fell deeper and deeper into sleep, it’s head would lower into the water until it would wake up. Her mother would then rub her back to sleep.

Follow @ralphpace for more on otters in CA . Shot on assignment for an upcoming @natgeo article.

Image taken under U.S. FWS permit # 37946D

#seaotter #otter #California
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Elkhorn Slough Reserve.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @javier_aznar_photography / Western Pygmy Rattlesnake (Sistrurus miliarius streckeri) found crossing a rural road in Texas. These uncommon, low-density rattlesnakes occur in a patchy distribution from Mississippi west to East Texas where they are threatened by development and persecution often in the form of road mortality, a fate we prevented for this snake by moving it off the road as a car approached. Together with the other two subspecies of Pygmy Rattlesnake (the Carolina and Dusky), they make up the smallest species of rattlesnake with a uniquely delicate and slender rattle that is barely audible when rattling.

Follow me @javier_aznar_photography for more images and stories #Snake #rattlesnake #pygmy #animals
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on November 07, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @garth.lenz / As our eyes are turned to COP26 and Glasgow there is much discussion of the immediate need to protect our forests and the critical role they play in sequestering carbon and stabilizing the climate. This is perhaps nowhere more important than across the world’s boreal forests, the greatest terrestrial carbon sink on the planet.
Photographed from a helicopter over northern Alberta, this image shows dead and dying aspen as a result of climate change. The dead and dying aspen can be differentiated from the healthy aspen in this frame by their lack of leaves. Other sections of dying aspen and be seen extending to the horizon. “Aspen Dieback” as a result of climate change has made these aspen forests susceptible to many pests and other threats. All across boreal forests, increasingly large numbers of aspen are being decimated by Aspen Dieback. As aspen become unhealthy they lose their leaves, eventually die, and then fall to the forest floor and decompose releasing their tremendous stores of carbon back into the atmosphere and creating a vicious cycle by further fuelling climate change and the conditions that will likely result in even more extensive Aspen Dieback and more intense global warming in the future.

#AspenDieback #ForestThreats #borealforest #climatechange
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on November 05, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @ralphpace / A female sea otter pulls mussels from the reef off Monterey, CA.

Although otters are able to feed on a variety of prey, many otters tend to specialize in one or two prey items and will often revisit the same foraging areas over and over. In the case of mussels it is advantageous to revisit the same exact cluster because once they break through to the rock it becomes easier to peel off mussels on the edge.

Follow @ralphpace for more on otters in CA . Shot on assignment for an upcoming @natgeo article.

Image taken under U.S. FWS permit # 37946D

#seaotter #otter #California
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Monterey, California.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @shonephoto Robbie Shone / Work continues on the NGM assignment titled ‘End of the Ice Caves’ following researchers from the University of Innsbruck underground inside Eisgruben ice cave, Austria. For several years, the researchers have been studying this 5000 year old ice, making it the oldest-dated cave ice in the eastern Alps. The age was obtained through radiocarbon dating of a piece of wood found at its base. @natgeo @natgeointhefield #IceCave #EndoftheIceCaves

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @orehuiying / Portrait of Chef owner Malcom Lee of one Michelin Star Peranakan Restaurant Candlenut (@candlenutsg) in Singapore. It is the only Peranakan restaurant in the world to be awarded a Michelin star. Traditional Peranakan cuisine is a combination of Chinese, Indian and Malay cooking. At Candlenut, Chef Malcom puts a contemporary spin on things, using buah keluak in butter cake and a rempah to flavor fried barramundi. “Peranakans many years ago were open to new ingredients and techniques, and to innovation,” he says. “We’re maintaining the same mindset.”

Follow me @orehuiying as I continue to photograph little known stories in Singapore on film. #Singapore #Peranakan #Nonya #heritage #culture #analogue
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on October 31, 2021.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Keith Ladzinski @ladzinski - Storm clouds breaking at sunrise over the mountains of Great Basin National park, home to a high abundance of Bristlecone Pines nestled on the mountains below the drifting clouds. Bristlecone are a the oldest living trees on earth, the oldest of which is over 5,000 years in age. These trees live at high altitude, mostly in rocky areas, ecosystems that are generally unsuitable for most flora. In recent years however, as temperatures continue to warm, ecologists are seeing other species of trees sprouting at higher elevations and could eventually become quite problematic for Bristlecone. That coupled with ever increasing wildfires, are making life on earth for the oldest trees a place of questionable existence. To see more from this assignment please visit @ladzinski
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Nevada.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by Justyna Mielnikiewicz @justmiel / Mitrovica is a city divided along the bridge. The northern part is populated mostly by Serbs and the south is where Albanian Kosovians live. The bridge is open for pedestrians but not for vehicle traffic. Italian Carabinieri, as part of the KFOR Contingent (a NATO-led international peacekeeping force), oversees a movement there.
Kosovo Serbs are the main ethnic minority in Kosovo and about half of them live in North Kosovo. Other smaller Serb communities are located in the southern and eastern part of Kosovo often as enclaves where they live in tight communities. During the 2013 Brussels Agreement, negotiated by the governments of Kosovo and Serbia, a self-governing association of municipalities with a Serb majority population in Kosovo was to be created. However it was postponed over conflicts about the extent of powers.

On the second photo Jasmina holds a print of her missing father's only photo (from his ID). He was a teacher in a Serbian school in Ferizaj (Uroshevac in Serbian ) and disappeared in September, 1999. He, with few others, went under the protection of the KFOR’s Polish contingent (a NATO-led international peacekeeping force) to Ferizaj to collect school files of Serbians who fled the city. He never returned and Jasmina is determined to find out what happened but so far it has been in vain. She is a head of the Association of Missing Persons in Shtërpcë ( Štrpce in Serbian ) city representing families of other 15 missing Serbians  . Since the war, she has lived there as an IDP  - Strpce is one of the enclaves in Southern Kosovo populated by ethnic Serbs .

The Medieval Serbian kingdom covered areas of present-day Kosovo but Ottoman invasion into the region in XIV century  ended Serbian control for over 500 years. Albanians under Ottoman went from being a largely Christian population to one that is mainly Sunni Muslim.  In 2008 Kosovo declared independence which was recognized by over 100 countries but not Serbia .Serbian and  Albanian are two official languages of Kosovo.

Follow me @justmiel  for more images and stories #kosovo #balkans #missingpersons #Mitrovica
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on October 30, 2021.

The Medieval Serbian kingdom covered areas of present-day Kosovo but Ottoman invasion into the region in XIV century  ended Serbian control for over 500 years. Albanians under Ottoman went from being a largely Christian population to one that is mainly Sunni Muslim.  In 2008 Kosovo declared independence which was recognized by over 100 countries but not Serbia .Serbian and  Albanian are two official languages of Kosovo.

Follow me @justmiel  for more images and stories #kosovo #balkans #missingpersons #Mitrovica

ph_descripcion:
Photo by Justyna Mielnikiewicz @justmiel /  Besarta Jashari standing next to her uncle Adem Jashari 's bust was the only survivor of the March 7, 1998, attack on Prekaz by Serbian law enforcement. At the time she was 10-years-old. Today she works in a bank in Pristina, Kosovo and plans to write a book about her experience. The attack, where 60 people were killed, made the UN security council turn to Chapter VII but military operations at that point did not take place. The Prekaz attack led to the increase of KLA's popularity among ethnic-Albanians in many parts of Kosovo.

In the second photo , Diamond is 10 and his family took him for a birthday trip  to Adem Jashari Memorial Complex. In the photo Diamond  poses with his cousin Ermisa in front of the damaged house where Kosovian fighters and their families were attacked by Serb forces  and died in 1998. 
 
The Memorial Complex Adem Jashari was built in honor of the family and life of the Kosovo Liberation Army fighter Adem Jashari. He was killed in March 7, 1998, during an operation which  later was known as the Attack on Prekaz .It was an operation by Serbian law enforcements to capture Kosovo Liberation Army (KLA- a militant group of ethnic Albanians that sought the independence of Kosovo from Yugoslavia. ) fighters . Adem and his brother were among  the leaders of that movement  . Houses were surrounded and most people refused to surrender . Eventually 60  family members ( about half of them  women and children)  including  KLA leaders were killed with mortars fired on houses .  Houses  which were fire on that day are left untouched as a living memory of the event . Scaffolding around the bullet-ridden ruins serves as a museum pathway for visitors coming from all over Kosovo .
 
Follow me @justmiel  for more images and stories #kosovo #balkans #unchapter7
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on October 28, 2021. May be an image of 1 person.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by Justyna Mielnikiewicz @justmiel / The current president of Kosovo is Vjosa Osmani. The 38-year-old law professor won the election last spring with some 300,000 votes and holds the record in Kosovo for receiving the most votes in an election. She is a leader of the "Guxo" initiative and was running as the candidate of the Vetëvendosje Movement for president.

In 2008 the Republic of Kosovo declared independence from Serbia, until then it was a Serbian province. Between 1998-1999 Serbian troops and ethnic Albanian separatists fought a war which was ended by a NATO air campaign against Serbian forces. The Republic of Kosovo was recognized by over 100 countries, among them  the U.S. and most of EU countries. Serbia continues to claim it as part of its own sovereign territory with support from Russia (its close ally) and China. Relations between the two countries began to normalize in 2013, as a part of the Brussels Agreement. Kosovo has a population of nearly 1.8 million people with Albanians constituting the vast majority. It is considered the youngest population in Europe with roughly half its citizens being under the age of 30. In the 2021 parliamentary elections an unprecedented number of 44 female candidates running for 120 seats  in the Assembly of Kosovo were elected.

#kosovowoman # balkans # femaleleader
#vjosaosmani
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on October 27, 2021.

Photos by Justyna Mielnikiewicz @justmiel / Serbian Orthodox Church at the Village of Babin Most where in 1999 a Serbian policeman brought 16-year-old Vasfije and raped her. The village has a majority of ethnic Serbs with about 60 Albanian houses at the other end of the settlement.

In the second photo Vasfije Krasniqi Goodman holds hands with her niece at her brother’s home. Vasfije was raped by Serbian police at the age of 16 and her brother has fought for her wellbeing and justice ever since.

Vasfije is a Kosovo Albanian activist and politician serving in the Assembly of the Republic of Kosovo where she focuses on the support for the survivors of wartime sexual violence. With her family's support she was the first woman to publicly acknowledged her rape in 2017. Nobody has been convicted in her case. Official estimates suggest that as many as 20,000 women were raped during the 1998-1999 conflict between ethnic Albanian guerrillas and Serbian forces. No perpetrators were punished for any of those acts. In April 2021, Kosovo President Vjosa Osmani declared April 14th, the day of Krasniqi's rape, the "Day of Sexual Violence Survivors.“

In 2008 the Republic of Kosovo declared independence from Serbia, until then it was a Serbian province. Between 1998-1999 Serbian troops and ethnic Albanian separatists fought a war which was ended by a NATO air campaign against Serbian forces. The Republic of Kosovo was recognized by over 100 countries, among them  the U.S. and most of EU countries. Serbia continues to claim it as part of its own sovereign territory with support from Russia (its close ally) and China. Relations between the two countries began to normalize in 2013, as a part of the Brussels Agreement. Kosovo has a population of nearly 1.8 million people with Albanians constituting the vast majority. It is considered the youngest population in Europe with roughly half its citizens being under the age of 30. In the 2021 parliamentary elections an unprecedented number of 44 female candidates running for 120 seats  in the Assembly of Kosovo were elected.

#rapevictims #womanrights #rallyforherjustice #kosovowoman
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on October 27, 2021.

Photo by @orehuiying / Ornate blackwood carved furniture is on display at the living room of the NUS Baba House (@nusbabahouse). The three-storey 19th-century Peranakan townhouse has been restored and converted into a museum in 2008. It is one of the last remaining intact Peranakan residential homes in Singapore that still has many original and unique architectural features of fine workmanship and quality in place.

Nikhil Joshi, a senior lecturer at the NUS Department of Architecture and conservation and lime expert, is part of the team leading the restoration efforts.

Follow me @orehuiying as I continue to photograph little known stories in Singapore on film. #Singapore #Peranakan #Nonya #heritage #culture

Photo by Justyna Mielnikiewicz @justmiel / Musicians prepare for the first concert of the Kosovo Opera in the temporary location of Youth and Sport Palace. Recently the Kosovo Parliament approved its creation and opened 101 positions for musicians. The inaugural concert with eight Arias from various operas will take place this weekend. Activity within music institutions of Kosovo was halted in 1991, still in Yugoslavian era. Albanian language schools and institutions worked in a parallel system with classes conducted in private houses until war broke out in 1999 as Kosovo fought for its independence. With the end of the war in 2000 the Kosovo Philharmonic and the International Festival of Chamber Music were created. Opera is the newest cultural project implemented by the government.
In 2008 the Republic of Kosovo declared independence from Serbia, until then it was a Serbian province. Between 1998-1999 Serbian troops and ethnic Albanian separatists fought a war which was ended by a NATO air campaign against Serbian forces. The Republic of Kosovo was recognized by over 100 countries, among them  the U.S. and most of EU countries. Serbia continues to claim it as part of its own sovereign territory with support from Russia (its close ally) and China. Relations between the two countries began to normalize in 2013, as a part of the Brussels Agreement. Kosovo has a population of nearly 1.8 million people with Albanians constituting the vast majority. It is considered the youngest population in Europe with roughly half its citizens being under the age of 30. In the 2021 parliamentary elections an unprecedented number of 44 female candidates running for 120 seats  in the Assembly of Kosovo were elected.

Photo by @orehuiying / Traditional Peranakan shophouses with elaborate facades pepper the Joo Chiat neighborhood in Singapore. Most of these buildings have been demolished to make space for high-rise apartments, offices and malls as Singapore went through urbanisation in the 1960s and 70s.

Previously, there was not a simple definition Peranakans- a cultural group that are thought to descend from mixed-race foreign settlers and local Malay communities in the Malay Archipelago. A recent research by the Genome Institute of Singapore confirmed that Peranakan Chinese have Chinese-Malay ancestry.

Follow me @orehuiying as I continue to photograph little known stories in Singapore on film. #Singapore #Peranakan #Nonya #heritage #culture

ph_descripcion: Photo by @orehuiying / Peranakan women traditionally wear “kasut manek”- hand beaded slippers to complete their "sarong kebaya"- an embroidered sheer blouse paired with a long tubular skirt. The intricacy and fine workmanship of a pair of kasut manek is also a hallmark of highly accomplished Peranakan women, whose skills in embroidery and beadwork are highly valued. Previously, there was not a simple definition for this cultural group that are thought to descend from mixed-race foreign settlers and local Malay communities in the Malay Archipelago. A recent research by the Genome Institute of Singapore confirmed that Peranakan Chinese have Chinese-Malay ancestry. ph_descripcion: Photo by @orehuiying / Participants wearing traditional Peranakan ”baju kebaya” blouse and sarong attend a class in Peranakan beading taught by expert Angeline Kong, at the Straits Enclave (@straits_enclave), a historic house-turned-museum in Singapore. In the past, young Peranakan girls were required to undertake beading in order to showcase a girl’s patience, attention to detail and endurance. These virtues, along with cooking and spice-pounding skills, would demonstrate to a matchmaker the signs of a ‘well-bred’ daughter and a successful candidate for marriage. Photo by Arturo Rodriguez @arturorguezdotcom / Seargent Armando Salazar from GIETMA-UME (Environmental and tech emergency group from Military Emergency Unit) walks over volcanic slags that are more than 300 degrees celsius to collect samples in a thermal suit for IGME-CSIC (Geological and Mining Institute of Spain from Spanish National Research Council) during the eruption of Cumbre Vieja volcano. The ongoing event marks the first time this volcano has erupted since 1971. The island of La Palma is part of the Spanish Canary Islands and is one of the most volcanically active zones in the archipelago with a population of about 85,000 people. The latest eruption was preceded by several earthquake swarms. Careful monitoring allowed officials to begin some evacuations before the lava started flowing, after 30 days of eruption more than 7000 villagers have been evacuated and almost 1000 homes have been destroyed by the ongoing eruption.

#CanaryIslands #lapalma #Spain #volcancumbreviejra
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on October 20, 2021.

Previously, there was not a simple definition for this cultural group that merges Chinese, Malay, and Western aesthetics, heritage and values. A recent research by the Genome Institute of Singapore sheds light on the genetic identity of the community and its long history, its findings confirmed that Peranakan Chinese have Chinese-Malay ancestry. ph_descripcion: Photo by Sara Hylton @sarahyltonphoto / Saying farewell to the city of Kolkata, West Bengal, one of the most populous cities of India with a rich and complex history. Kolkata has many layers to uncover. I was grateful to witness the city come to life throughout the Durga Puja festival which pays homage to the Hindu goddess Durga and is one of the most significant celebrations for the Bengali community. For more scenes from the Durga Puja festival follow me @sarahyltonphoto #bengal #kolkata #festival #durgapuja

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @garth.lenz In this image shot from a helicopter over northern Alberta, leafless dead and dying aspen are surrounded by healthy trees. Aspen Dieback brought about by prolonged drought as a result of climate change has made these aspen forests susceptible to insect infestation and other threats. Aspen become increasingly unhealthy, eventually dying and falling. Tent caterpillars are thought to be a major cause of Aspen Dieback but research is in the early stages and much is still unknown.

The problem of climate change induced Aspen Dieback is compounded by the fact that the boreal forest is the world’s greatest terrestrial carbon sink as well as one its most concentrated and as a result it is one of our greatest allies in the fight against climate change and global warming. However as these aspen forests die and decompose they release their massive stored carbon into the atmosphere further fuelling climate change and the conditions that are causing Aspen Dieback.

#AspenDieback #ForestThreats #borealforest #climatechange
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on October 19, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @garth.lenz I wish I could say that these are Aspen trees that have simply lost their Autumn leaves due to wind but they are not. These are dead and dying Aspen. Prolonged drought as a result of climate change has made these aspen forests susceptible to many pests and other threats. Tent caterpillars are thought to be a major cause of Aspen Dieback but research is still relatively recent and there is much that is still not known. Aspen become insreasing unhealthty losing their leaves, breaking off, and eventually dying and falling.

#AspenDieback #ForestThreats #borealforest #climatechange
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on October 15, 2021.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Sara Hylton @sarahyltonphoto / Kolkata, West Bengal comes alive as people celebrate Durga Puja and pay homage to the Hindu goddess Durga. Durga Puja is one of the most significant celebrations for the Bengali community. Here, people celebrate early morning on Maha Saptami, where nine plants, tied together, are dipped in the Ganges river. The plants are representative of the nine manifestations of the female power, Shakti. Follow me @sarahyltonphoto for more on the festival! #kolkata #india #durgapuja
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on October 14, 2021.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @shonephoto Robbie Shone / Inside Eisriesenwelt (ice cave), Austria, the ‘castle’ formation is one of the most iconic ice formations in the cave. ph_descripcion: Photo by Keith Ladzinski @ladzinski - Informally known as the #MagicTree, this beautiful #Bristlecone tree here is an estimated 1,400 years old and is an icon of Nevada, so much that it’s stamped on the back of the Nevada Quarter. These trees can live upwards of 4,000 years old, the oldest of which is an estimated 4,852 according to the Guinness Book of World Records. With wildfires becoming an ever increasing threat driven by drought and heat index rise, these ancient trees are becoming more threatened. To see more photos from this assignment please visit @ladzinski
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on October 11, 2021.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @shonephoto Robbie Shone / It’s almost time to close the doors on the ice cave season for another year. In a couple of weeks, Eisriesenwelt, near Salzburg, Austria (pictured) will see the final tour group exit the cave and head down the mountain for the last time this year. But for how many more years will we be able to admire the beautiful ice formations that these caves offer? As our climate changes and the world warms, just like the polar regions, this ice is melting away too. #EndOfTheIceCaves #IceCaves @NatGeo @Natgeointhefield
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on October 11, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @paoloverzone and @aalessandroalbert / We are in Moscow to continue our 30 years project on the Muscovites. View of the Moscow river and the third transport ring. In 1991, the week after the August Coup, Russia was part of the USSR (the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics ) we were walking around the city with a 4x5 Plate Camera not really knowing that we were witnessing the last days of Communism , Alessandro was 25 and I was 23, Our trip resulted in more than 250 plates, both black and white and color, we then continued this project in 2001 and 2011. We are now back in Russia 2021 to complete our work: the Moscow Project.

Follow us @paoloverzone and @aalessandroalbert for more images and stories
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on October 09, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @philipcheungphoto / Wild horses run for cover during a sand storm along the original route of the Central Pacific Railroad in Clark, Nevada.

Historians estimate that at any one time, between 10,000 and 15,000 Chinese laborers were working on constructing the western portion of North America's first transcontinental railroad, suffering over 1000 casualties.

Follow me @philipcheungphoto as I continue photographing the history of the Central Pacific Railroad and acknowledge the crucial role that the Chinese railroad workers had in America.

#centralpacificrailroad #cprr #transcontinentalrailroad #chineserailroadworkers #landscape #nevada #philipcheung
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on October 08, 2021.

ph_descripcion: Photos by @marcozorzanello / Despite the depth of the Venice lagoon being just 1-3 meters deep, this wide water basin sees a heavy amount of shipping traffic. The lagoon’s environment has been completely reshaped after centuries human modification. The erosion of the lagoon, due to the increased flow of water from the sea, the effects of climate change, and shipping pollution, are just some of the problems that are threatening this unique ecosystem. Old-school engineers and environmental engineers disagree on the best approach for preserving the lagoon. One project from the environmental engineers has been recently supported by the EU though. The idea is to build many small water barriers to fight erosion using only organic material with low impact to the ecosystem instead of making stronger, more permanent, and more expensive barriers.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on October 07, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @arkodatto / A single blade of a current generation wind turbine lies in transit on a national highway in Gujarat, between Bhavnagar and Ahmedabad. The carriage has been stationary for a week and has become the shelter for the crew responsible for moving this gigantic industrial artefact, in the sweltering heat of coastal Gujarat.
According to industry and governement projections, India currently has an output of 10,000 megawatt of electricity per year from its wind energy sector. The coastal areas of Gujarat have some of the most dense concentration of wind turbines, along with states like Rajasthan and Tamil Nadu.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on October 07, 2021.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @leeannolwage / Ngeno-Zacharias Nakamhela, who is showing the signs and symptoms associated with dementia, cleans her kitchen at her home in Kalkfeld. Nakamhela has always been a homemaker and loves spending her days repetitively washing the dishes, even if they are clean. Her husband, Ndikuhoole Johanna Nakamhela, and her carer, Getrud Kangandi, allow her to enjoy this activity and leave all the crockery on the counter so it is easy for her to reach.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on October 06, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @lauredutruy / Nathanaël, a 13-year-old boy born with Down Syndrome, attends a speech therapy session in Nantes, France. Two times a week, the specialist helps him improve his reading and speaking skills and pronunciation. Speech therapy is essential for his social and future professional integration.

In 2020, months of lockdown due to the COVID-19 pandemic resulted in loss of regular medical care, making Nathanaël’s development more difficult. The sessions resumed this year but health regulations created new difficulties for the young boy. Wearing masks limit all visual communication, a form of communication which is crucial for children with mental disabilities.

These photographs are part of an ongoing story on how a family with three children with Down Syndrome are getting through the pandemic in France. This work is supported by the @insidenatgeo COVID-19 Emergency Fund for Journalists.

#downsyndrome #trisomy21 #disability
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on October 05, 2021.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @arkodatto / Laborers return home after a day's work at the Gujarat International Financial and Tech City. GIFT City, as it is known, is currently India's first operational smart city that has been built from scratch; however, a large part of it remains under construction. The city has multiple modern infrastructural facilities, which include a city-wide integrated underground tunnel to facilitate smooth running and maintenance of services like electricity, water, sewage, waste collection, and a city-wide centralized cooling system. There is an automated integrated waste treatment plant that claims to be the first of its kind which has not only automated the process of collecting garbage but has also automated the process of segregation of waste.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on October 05, 2021.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @stuartpalley / Orange County Public Works and volunteers for the Oiled Wildlife Cleanup Network on site of a 126,000+ gallon oil spill washing ashore off the coast of Huntington and Newport Beaches on Saturday. The oil was from a ruptured pipeline off the coast where oil rigs extract oil. Tides brought tar balls and impacted some wildlife as crews installed booms and built berms to keep oil out of the Santa Ana River mouth.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on October 05, 2021.

Photos by Zhou Na @zhounaphoto / Last week Paul Salopek started his walk (@outofedenwalk ) again in Tengchong, China. It's a place on the border with Myanmar, the country Paul already walked through. For the next few weeks，Paul will climb mountains, cross waters, and walk in forests. He plans walk in China for the next one and half year as he retraces our ancestor’s global migration.

⁩ #EdenWalk #WalkinChina #tengchong
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on October 03, 2021.

Captions: Picture 1: Moscow, October 1 st 2021. Pictures 2/3: Moscow 2011. Picture 4: Moscow 2001. Picture 5/6/7/8 Moscow1991. Pictures 9/10 making of 1991.

Follow us @paoloverzone and @aalessandroalbert while we document the Muscovites in the next days
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on October 02, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @philipcheungphoto / A couple prepares to shoot targets at Monument Point, Utah, along the original route of the Central Pacific Railroad.

Chinese laborers reached Monument Point in April 1869, and it was established as a maintenance station to care for the track near its location.

Historians estimate that at any one time, between 10,000 and 15,000 Chinese laborers were working on constructing the western portion of North America's first transcontinental railroad, suffering over 1000 casualties, most undocumented. 

Follow me @philipcheungphoto as I continue photographing the history of the Central Pacific Railroad and acknowledge the crucial role that the Chinese railroad workers had in America.

#centralpacificrailroad #cprr #transcontinentalrailroad #chineserailroadworkers #landscape #utah #philipcheung
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on October 01, 2021.

Photos by Arturo Rodriguez @arturorguezdotcom / After ten days of constant eruption of the Cumbre Vieja (Old Summit) Volcano on La Palma Island, Canary Islands, Spain, lava flow and debris reached the sea last night. This is a view from the Ramon Margalef vessel which belongs to Spanish Institute of Oceanography (IEO). The first image is a few minutes after the lava reach the sea, the second one was taken just before sunrise, and the last photo is of (from left to right) Roberto Moreira, captain of the vessel, Maria Gomez-Vallesteros, chief of marine environment at IEO, and Eugenio Fraile, oceanographer at IEO.

#CanaryIslands #lapalma #Spain #institutoespañoldeoceanografia
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 29, 2021.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @babaktafreshi // The crescent moon was about to set over the light of the nearby town of Hurricane, Utah. I was on the top of Gooseberry Mesa near Zion National Park, where I took NASCAR National Series Winner @bubbawallace on a night sky adventure. We were both using telephoto lenses and short exposures of one to two seconds to reveal the earthshine, sunlight reflected by the Earth onto the dark side of the moon. Our moon connects us all together; the same moon hangs gracefully above all cultures. It is a shared window for every one of us—every poet, writer, and artist who has been inspired by its mesmerizing glow. // Explore the latest gear that's #madeforoutside at @columbia1938, including Omni-Heat Infinity, the gold standard in warmth.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by Arturo Rodriguez @arturorguezdotcom / The Cumbre Vieja (Old Summit) Volcano eruption on La Palma Island, Canary Islands, Spain. After a week of over 20,000 low intensity earthquakes, the volcano erupted last week. There are currently 6,500 displaced people from two villages, Los Llanos and El Paso, and more than 300 homes affected. People are trying to save their personal belongings before the lava reaches their homes while some villages, like Jedey, are completely covered with more than 20 centimeters of volcanic ash.

#CanaryIslands #lapalma #Spain
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 27, 2021.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @marcozorzanello / A seahorse preserved in an alcohol ampoule at the zoological "Giuseppe Olivi" Museum in the city of Chioggia, near Venice, Italy. There are three well-known species of seahorses in the Mediterranean Sea. They live in sheltered areas such as seagrass beds. Seahorse populations are one of the biological indicators for determining the health of the water. In the past this species disappeared in the Venetian laguna ecosystem, mainly due to the heavy pollution of the water. The cultivation of invasive shellfish for food also destroyed the seahorse's particular environment. Thanks to restoration programs in the last couple of decades though, the Venice Lagoon habitat has become cleaner and many species have come back.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Laguna di Venezia.

ph_descripcion:
Photo and video by @marcozorzanello / This is an aerial view of the Venetian Lagoon's canals. In the second video, a young phd researcher from Padua University sails to a slat marsh for rising biological samples.
Venice would not be Venice without its surrounding water basin. With 550 km2 (212 square miles) of surface area, it is the largest wetland of the Mediterranean. It is divided from the sea by a strip of barrier islands, the littoral, that runs for about 60 km, interrupted by the lagoon inlets. Inside the lagoon basin is Venice and more than 50 islands, about 40 km2 of salt marsh, and a 1,500 km network of canals. The depth of the lagoon is generally between 1m and 3m. Since 1987, the Venice Lagoon is part of the UNESCO World Heritage Site list.
The erosion of the lagoon, due to the increased flow of water from the sea, and pollution, are just some of the problems that are threatening this unique ecosystem. Water, mud, and slime are on the surface of this world with surreal traits, where large container ships, cruises, fishermen and hunters share the same water space.
Both the EU and Italian governments have launched a large program to re-build this ecosystem, with the construction of sandbanks and artificial islands.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 23, 2021.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @babaktafreshi // The Milky Way emerges above the moonlit desert landscape of Gooseberry Mesa in Utah, where I took NASCAR National Series Winner @bubbawallace on an astrophotography adventure. The road to Zion National Park is visible on the right. Exploring the night sky is not just about recording outer space. It leads you to a lifetime of adventures. It becomes a lifestyle where you are embraced by the outdoors and the hidden beauties of night while others enjoy parties, watch TV, or sleep. Like the explorers of new worlds, you are gifted with experiences that most others have missed. More than 80 percent of the world’s population lives under light-polluted skies, and seeing the natural starry night is now a rare and often life-changing experience for urban people. This 13-second exposure at ISO 3200 was made using a 14mm wide-angle lens at f/2. // Explore the latest gear that's #madeforoutside at @columbia1938, including Omni-Heat Infinity, the gold standard in warmth.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 22, 2021.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @stuartpalley / Mendocino hotshot firefighters pack up after protecting Giant Sequoias in the Sequoia National Forest Sunday while fighting the Windy Fire, which threatened the Long Meadow Grove along the Trail of 100 Giants. The Windy fire, as it's called, spread over 20,000 acres (8,000 ha), the blaze burning through dense pine and threatening groves in the area. The fire was started by lightning on September 9, moving through forests that haven’t seen flames in decades and are vulnerable because of trees weakened or killed off by drought and bark beetles.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 22, 2021.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @stuartpalley / Trees stand completely burned from ground to crown after wildfire burned through the Sequoia National Forest over the weekend. The Windy fire, as it's called, spread over 20,000 acres (8,000 ha), the blaze burning through dense pine and threatening groves in the area. ph_descripcion: Photo by @stuartpalley / Embers fall out of a Giant Sequoia in the Long Meadow Grove after the #WindyFire ignited the tree's canopy Sunday evening. Firefighters kept flames largely out of the grove, where the Trail of 100 Giants Path winds through in the Sequoia National Forest, extinguishing spot fires and utilizing previous prescribed burn footprints to corral the main fire around the grove. Fire is critical for a healthy forest ecosystem in the Southern Sierra, and these giants have survived centuries of fire. It was fascinating to witness how mild prescribed burns in recent years led to healthy fire in and around the grove. The Windy Fire was a bit over 25,000 acres with 4% containment. #giantsequoia
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Trail Of 100 Giants.

ph_descripcion: Photos by @waynelawrence / Suzanne Brennan Firstenberg collaborated with Ruppert Landscape to install an artwork composed of 143 sections of white flags and 3.8 miles of walking paths at the foot of the Washington Monument. White benches are placed throughout to allow visitors to sit in quiet reflection. Suzanne chose white flags to represent the lives lost because they are a sign of purity and of the spirit—and to make it easier for people to personalize them. For those that cannot make it to Washington, D.C., requests for messages can be made online and the flag will be available to view on a digital map of the installation. @inamericaflags
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 17, 2021.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @macstonephoto / The ancient bald cypress along the Black River in North Carolina comprise the oldest swamp in the world. Protected by The Nature Conservancy (@tnc_nc), this old growth forest is one of the few remaining virgin swamps left in the United States. With the record age of 2,624 years, these sentinel trees have witnessed millennia of storms, hurricanes, droughts, fires, sunrises and moon sets. But on September 15, 2021 at precisely 8:06pm, the sky illuminated with a new and historic feature. SpaceX’s Inspiration4 flight ushered in a new era becoming the first all-civilian crew to reach orbit. The launch was visible in North Carolina for only 120 seconds. While deep in the swamp, I noticed something strange streaking behind the canopy. Alarmed, I yelled in confusion to my assistant, Zach, thinking it was a comet or a rocket. I quickly recomposed my camera and captured the SpaceX rocket heading northeast across the heavens. It was incredible to witness and what also struck me was the duality of the moment—new technology soaring over ancient trees. For more photos of swamps and wetlands, follow @macstonephoto
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in North Carolina.

ph_descripcion:
Photos and video by @davillasana / Alexa Smith, a transgender migrant from Honduras, spends most of her days inside as she doesn’t always feel safe in her new neighborhood of Memphis, Tennessee, due to violence and insecurity. Her and her boyfriend, also a migrant from Honduras, have been fighting more often, she says, causing a great strain on their relationship.

Wanting a break from tensions at home, Alexa decided to take a trip to Texas where her sister also recently migrated to from Honduras. Writer Aurora Almendral (@aurora_alm) recently visited Alexa for @natgeo about her life now in the United States after crossing into the country earlier this year.

As I’ve been following Alexa since 2018, she’s very familiar with my work as a photojournalist and loves looking at pictures—she’s even helped me select photos and I love hearing her feedback. This gallery includes a moment of Alexa looking at images I made on this most recent trip.

Keep an eye out for our upcoming @natgeo story about Alexa and Kataleya, two trans migrants from Honduras who have overcome incredible odds while still facing challenges in the United States.

#lgbtqia #transwomen #migration #resilience #usa
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 17, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @stuartpalley / The #KNPComplex burns in Sequoia National Park Wednesday evening September 15th, 2021. The fire is comprised of the Paradise and Colony Fires, both lightning ignited blazes that started last week. The fire was close to the Giants Grove of Giant Sequoias in the park, as crews worked to protect infrastructure and the trees in advance of the fire. The National Park Service has conducted numerous prescribed burns over the years in Giant Sequoia Groves, and fire crews are optimistic that this previous managed “good fire” will allow a healthy burn to move through the forest around some famous trees like the General Sherman and others, if or when the fire reaches the area. The reduced fuel loading will reduce fire intensity.

As of the morning update the fire has not yet reached Giant Sequoia Groves. Giant Sequoias are adapted for life with wildfire, but intense fire conditions that reach the crowns can damage and kill them. Last year at the Castle Fire experts estimate 10% of the Giant Sequoias in the region were damaged or killed. After an intense fire season covering major wildfires and drought throughout the state, I look forward to continuing to document this important story on one of America’s treasured national parks and groves of trees. Currently the complex is nearly 9,000 acres and 0% contained. A Type 1 Incident Management Team has taken over the fire as firefighting resources pour in to help in managing and suppressing the fire.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Sequoia National Park.

ph_descripcion: Photos by @macstonephoto / The land steward for The Nature Conservancy (@tnc_nc), Zach West, paddles through a stand of old growth bald cypress along the Black River. This river and its floodplain provides refuge for the oldest known bald cypress on the planet, which is more than 2,600 years old. @tnc_nc and its partners are working to conserve more habitat along this river corridor to protect these ancient trees. For more imagery of wetlands and swamps around the world follow @macstonephoto

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @andrea_frazzetta / Ezra, 4 years old, walking with his schoolbag towards the kindergarten in the woods of Bergamo - "Come Tetto il Cielo” (The Sky as a Roof).
Inspired by the educational projects of northern Europe, the project involves fifteen children from 2 to 6 years old and their families.
Following the principles of the Pedagogy of the Forest, and Experiential Learning, the children have the opportunity to carry out recreational activities in the woods, in direct contact with nature, during all seasons.
This image is part of the series "Growing in the Woods”, a documentation project supported by @InsideNatGeo’s Emergency Fund for Journalists.
Bergamo was one of the hardest-hit cities in the world during the first wave of the pandemic in March 2020.
The health emergency, which has overwhelmed Italy like few other countries in the world, has undoubtedly put the school system in serious difficulty. In particular, it has highlighted how this needs new, and safe, spaces, and a rethinking of the teaching method.
From January to June 2021, I documented 6 schools located in 6 different areas of the country, from North to South, in an attempt to tell the story of the diversity of the territories, the change of the seasons, and how these are intrinsically linked to the experiences of the children.
We live in a society that has the duty to find a different relationship with nature.
Through the photographic documentation of these stories, my goal is to spark reflection and debate, on a fundamental issue.
Follow me @andrea_frazzetta to know more. #Italy #outdooreducation #backtonature
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 16, 2021. May be an image of 1 person.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by Arturo Rodriguez @arturorguezdotcom / Cherokee is one of rancher Jenifer Santos' goats. These animals are very territorial and are used to fighting for pack leadership. In this case, Cherokee was defeated and suffered an ugly broken shoulder. Veterinary surgery for livestock is not available on the island where Jenifer lives so a dog vet tried to fix it by fitting a prothesis but he wasn’t able to successfully and unfortunately Cherokee passed away. Jenifer may have decided to euthanize Cherokee from the very first moment as most of the ranchers usually do but she chose to give it an opportunity even though she is almost bankrupt.

In the Canary Islands, the southernmost region of Spain, where Jenifer lives, the primary sector is going through a terrible crisis due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Thousands of farmers in the country have been waiting for almost a year for public subsidies from Europe, but the response from the continent has been slow. Additionally, the Canaries are still trying to escape the 2008 economic crisis that hit the region harder than any other place in Spain, with unemployment rates that have risen 35% (25% in 2021).

This work is supported by the @insidenatgeo COVID-19 Emergency Fund for Journalists. #CanaryIslands #Tenerife #Spain #Covid-19
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 15, 2021.

ph_descripcion: Photos by Michael Seeley @mseeley20 / Less than 12-hours from launch, SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket and the Crew Dragon “Resilience” sits on historic LC39A launch pad at NASA’s Kennedy Space Center. SpaceX is set to launch the Inspiration4 mission to orbit during a launch window that opens at 8:02pm (ET) Wednesday, September 15. This will be the first all-civilian space mission in history, and it will be the first time SpaceX will have 3 Dragon capsules in orbit at the same time.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 15, 2021.

Photo by Christopher Gregory-Rivera @cgregoryphoto / San Juan, Puerto Rico marks 500 years of its founding this year. The group Reenactors of Puerto Rico led a procession through the streets of Old San Juan, helmed by Rafael Mayoral in the uniform of Ponce De León, Spanish colonist who founded the city. Puerto Rico is often referred to as the “oldest colony.” It was under Spanish rule for 400 years since Columbus colonized it in 1493. It was invaded by the United States in 1898, as part of the Spanish-American War, and remains a U.S. colony to this day.

The reenactment groups source period accurate uniforms and arms to “bring history alive.”
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 15, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @davillasana / For an upcoming @natgeo story, writer Aurora Almendral (@aurora_alm) and I followed up with two transgender women from Honduras who recently migrated to the United States. Having documented the migration of Kataleya Nativi Baca and Alexa Smith since 2018, seeing them achieve a large part of their dreams was moving. At the same time, however, new sets of issues have been daunting and difficult for them to navigate. 

Due to unstable living conditions in Virginia, Kataleya spent nearly all her savings to live with someone in Texas she’d known online for three years. Though José didn’t pick her up at the airport when she arrived, forcing her to sleep in the baggage claim area, she eventually made it to his apartment in Houston where Aurora joined us.

These images are from our time with Kataleya in her new daily life routines, such as cleaning (while dancing!) the apartment when José and his roommates worked. Though this new prospect of living in Texas seemed promising, it didn’t last long—stay tuned for our story to learn more about Kataleya’s journey.

#lgbtqia #transwomen #migration #resilience #usa
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 14, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @lauredutruy / Élodie is sitting with her children in their bungalow as the family is spending holidays on a campsite in Brittany, western France in August 2021. 
In 2008, the single-mother adopted her first child Nathanaël, then Magdaléna and Abellino. They were all born with Down Syndrome.

The children have textbooks to work on over the summer holiday to help them retain information learned over the preceding school year, which has been challenging due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Here Élodie is seen helping her 13-year-old son Nathanaël doing mathematics by showing him how to count with hands clapping.

This photograph is part of an ongoing story on how a family with three children with Down Syndrome are getting through the pandemic in France. This work is supported by the @insidenatgeo COVID-19 Emergency Fund for Journalists.

#downsyndrome #trisomy21 #disability
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 14, 2021.

natgeoexpeditions, natgeoyourshot, natgeoadventure y 9 más siguen esta cuenta
ph_descripcion:
Photos by @davillasana / Since 2018, I’ve followed the journeys of Kataleya Nativi Baca and Alexa Smith, who were pushed to flee Honduras due to transphobia and violence. From the circumstances forcing them north, through Central America and Mexico to the United States, they’ve faced unthinkable challenges.

Recently I teamed up with writer Aurora Almendral (@aurora_alm) for a @natgeo story about how Kataleya and Alexa are adjusting to their new lives in the United States.

While Kataleya found a room to rent in Virginia with a friend, their transphobic landlord insulted them on a regular basis, threatening to call the police if they didn’t leave by the end of the month. Kataleya decided to move to Texas into the apartment of a Honduran man she’d known online for three years. Hearing of the less expensive living conditions and with the prospect of more stability, she felt it was a more secure option.

These are some images of Kataleya’s hectic moving day, treasured items she took with her, and the beginning of her unexpected journey to Texas. Many thanks as well to @womenphotograph for supporting part of this project.

#lgbtqia #transwomen #migration #resilience #usa
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 13, 2021.

From the circumstances forcing them north, through Central America and Mexico to the United States, they’ve faced unthinkable challenges.

Recently I teamed up with writer Aurora Almendral (@aurora_alm) for a @natgeo story about how Kataleya and Alexa are adjusting to their new lives in the United States.

While Kataleya found a room to rent in Virginia with a friend, their transphobic landlord insulted them on a regular basis, threatening to call the police if they didn’t leave by the end of the month. Kataleya decided to move to Texas into the apartment of a Honduran man she’d known online for three years. Hearing of the less expensive living conditions and with the prospect of more stability, she felt it was a more secure option.

These are some images of Kataleya’s hectic moving day, treasured items she took with her, and the beginning of her unexpected journey to Texas. Many thanks as well to @womenphotograph for supporting part of this project.

#lgbtqia #transwomen #migration #resilience #usa
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 13, 2021.

Photos by Arturo Rodriguez @arturorguezdotcom / La Palma Island, par of the Canary Islands, in the southernmost region of Spain is a small island that is suffering less than other islands of the archipelago because a large part of the local economy is based around agriculture and not the tourism. There used to be many cargo ships transporting food between the Canary Islands and the European continent but last year, due to the COVID-19 pandemic, shipments slowed dramatically. The primary sector has suffer the consequences from this but is now recovering faster than the tourism industry.

This work is supported by the @insidenatgeo COVID-19 Emergency Fund for Journalists. #CanaryIslands #Tenerife #Spain #Covid-19
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 10, 2021.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @amr.alfiky / The statue of Confederate General Robert E. Lee was sawed in half for easier transport after its removal from the plinth on Wednesday morning. The statue, which weighs 12 tons, was erected in 1890 and was the last Confederate statue on Monument Avenue in Richmond, Virginia to be taken down after the issue was debated in the courts for over a year.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 08, 2021.

ph_descripcion: Photos by @amr.alfiky / The 12-ton statue of Robert E. Lee that stood 6 stories tall on Monument Avenue in Richmond, Virginia was removed today. Erected in 1890, the monument was used to attract elite, white homeowners to the area, keeping Black homeowners out. It quickly became a symbol of white supremacy and was recently used as a space for protest following the murder of George Floyd in 2020. People watched on as the statue was removed. In the last photo, Devon Henry, owner of the construction company that removed the Robert E. Lee statue, hugs his mom, Freda Thorton, after the statue was removed.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 08, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @donaldmiralle / Scenes from the Paralympics Marathon as athletes pass the famed Zojoji Temple on a rainy day. These images are in no particular order, but the last image has a nice story to it. The runner is Harvard Vatnhamar of the Faroe Islands. At age 45 he is the ONLY competitor for his country participating in the Paralympics. He was in last when I shot this photo of him at the halfway point of the race. But he ran the most of the race cheering, yelling, smiling at the crowds, who went crazy as he made his way through. And he actually worked his way up the field by the end of it finishing 10th. Harvard is what the Paralympics and actually what all sports should be about. It’s not about competing but participating and just showing up, and in doing so you give something positive to those around you. It’s all about the journey getting to the start and the finish line!

@tokyo2020 @paralympics #tokyoparalympics
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 05, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @philipcheungphoto / Arabella Hong Young, 93, a singer and actor, poses for a portrait at her assisted living facility in Las Vegas, Nevada.

Arabella is a 3rd generation descendant of Hung Lai Woh, a railroad worker who arrived in the United States in the mid-1860s from Dai Long Village, in the Guangdong Province of Southern China, as a teenager, to work for the Central Pacific Railroad.

Historians estimate that at any one time, between 10,000 and 15,000 Chinese laborers were working on constructing the western portion of North America's first transcontinental railroad, suffering hundreds of casualties, most undocumented.

Follow me @philipcheungphoto as I continue photographing the history of the Central Pacific Railroad and acknowledge the crucial role that the Chinese railroad workers had in America.

#centralpacificrailroad #cprr #transcontinentalrailroad #descendants #chineserailroadworkers
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 04, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @donaldmiralle / Adopted by American parents at the age of 13 months from a Russian foster care, Jessica Long had her lower legs amputated when she was 18 months because of fibular hemimelia.

Now at 29 years of age, Jessica Long has gone to 5 Paralympics, winning 29 medals, 16 of them gold, making her one of the most successful Paralympians in history.

Thank you for being such an amazing bright light to all @jessicatatianalong
Hands down one of the most inspirational athletes I’ve shot in the last 25 years!

These 10 photos are from Jessica’s last swim tonight in the Women’s S8 100m Butterfly at the @tokyo2020 @paralympics winning her 16th career Paralympic Gold Medal to close out the meet. She won her 1st Paralympic medal when she was 12. Unbelievable…
ph_atributos: Photo shared by Nat Geo in the Field on September 03, 2021 tagging @jessicatatianalong, and @paralympics.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @leeannolwage / Pastor Ndikuhoole Nakamhela (76) and his wife Ngeno (76) met at 15, and have been married for 51 years. In 2013, after retiring to Kalkfeld near the Namibian capital of Windhoek, Ngeno began acting ‘out of context’, with memory lapses and mood changes. The doting Ndikuhoole cared for her as her suspected dementia advanced, but in January 2021 the family employed a day-time carer. This is an ideal model for later-life care, where someone living with dementia-type symptoms is able to age in the familiarity and comfort of their home.
September is Alzheimer’s Awareness Month. Follow @leeannolwage and writer Leonie Joubert @science_scribe as we explore how communities in rural Namibia perceive and treat those living with these brain conditions. #alzheimers #dementia #namibia
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 02, 2021.

Photos by Arturo Rodriguez @arturorguezdotcom / Remo is a Malinois breed dog shepherd which is the perfect partner of Jenifer Santos. It is her bodyguard, her alarm system, her best friend and her workmate. In the Canary Islands, the southernmost region of Spain, the primary sector is going through a terrible crisis due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Thousands of farmers in the country have been waiting for almost one year for public subsidies from Europe, but the response from the continent has been slow. The Canaries are still trying to escape the 2008 economic crisis that hit the region harder than any other place in Spain, with unemployment rates that have risen 35% (25% in 2021).

This work is supported by the @insidenatgeo COVID-19 Emergency Fund for Journalists. #CanaryIslands #Tenerife #Spain #Covid-19
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 02, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by Arturo Rodriguez @arturorguezdotcom / Remo is a Malinois breed dog shepherd which is the perfect partner of Jenifer Santos. It is her bodyguard, her alarm system, her best friend and her workmate. In the Canary Islands, the southernmost region of Spain, the primary sector is going through a terrible crisis due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Thousands of farmers in the country have been waiting for almost one year for public subsidies from Europe, but the response from the continent has been slow. The Canaries are still trying to escape the 2008 economic crisis that hit the region harder than any other place in Spain, with unemployment rates that have risen 35% (25% in 2021).

This work is supported by the @insidenatgeo COVID-19 Emergency Fund for Journalists. #CanaryIslands #Tenerife #Spain #Covid-19
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 02, 2021.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Ben Depp @deppphoto / Flotsam marks the high water mark on some of the taller levee in Port Sulpher, Louisiana following Hurricane Ida. I’m always drawn to the ways that water and storms and wave energy leave a print on the landscape, kinda like “I was here”. In many buildings in South Louisiana you can find a high water mark from previous floods still printed on the walls. I thinks it’s a helpful reminder to not get too comfortable.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 01, 2021.

Follow me @rubensalgadoescudero to see more of the world through my lens. The above photo was taken in Berlin, Germany on assignment with @natgeo documenting Berlin’s electronic music scene, its importance in society here and how it is and has adapted to the Covid-19 Pandemic.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @ralphpace / A female sea otter slips back into the water while her pup sleeps in the protection of pickleweed in Elkhorn Slough, CA.

Like other marine mammals, sea otters are known to haul out of the water. In healthy animals, sea otters haul out for a variety of reasons but is mostly attributed to avoiding predators, warming up and conserving energy. Life in the sea is extreme for sea otters and without proper heavy blubber as insulation, sea otters are constantly walking a fine line between making it and emales with pups are especially vulnerable to energy depletion between caring and feeding their pups.

Follow @ralphpace for more on otters in CA . Shot on assignment for an upcoming @natgeo article.

Image taken under U.S. FWS permit # 37946D

#seaotter #otter #california
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Elkhorn Slough Reserve.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @lauredutruy / Magdaléna is seen by the swimming pool of the campsite where she is spending holidays with her family in Brittany, western French coast in August 2021. Her mother chose that specific campsite because the staff includes specialised educators who take care of disabled children. The young girl born with Down Syndrome attends daily adapted activities which allow her mother to spend time on her own.

After months of lockdown in France, campsites were allowed to re-open with strict regulations and the use of the recent controversial health pass.

This photograph is part of an ongoing story on how a family with three children with Down Syndrome are getting through the pandemic in France. This work is supported by the @insidenatgeo COVID-19 Emergency Fund for Journalists.

#downsyndrome #trisomy21 #disabilities
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on August 31, 2021.
