ph_descripcion:
Photos by Arturo Rodriguez @arturorguezdotcom / These images may be hard for some to look at but the life of fishermen sometimes is brutal. The Nuevo Olimar fishing boat belongs to the Canary Islands' fleet and is the only crew in the whole country to fish in a sustainable and artisanal way. They fish one by one with fishing rods, and they always release any tuna under 26 pounds. However, the Spanish government gives the entire fleet (37 boats for a population of 2.5 million) nearly the same fishing quota of just one tuna seiner that belongs to large companies who routinely kill fish before they reach the reproductive age. On top of that, last year, because of closed markets and restaurants and the lack of cargo planes transporting fresh food between the Canary Islands and the European continent as a result of the COVID-19, the price of the red tuna dropped to 5€ per kilo and other varieties dropped as low a few cents per kilo. The fishing industry, the primary economic sector for the islands, is going through a terrible crisis due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The Canaries are still trying to escape the 2008 economic crisis that hit the region harder than any other place in Spain, with unemployment rates that have risen 35% (25% in 2020).

This work is supported by the @insidenatgeo COVID-19 Emergency Fund for Journalists. #CanaryIslands #Tenerife #Spain #Covid-19
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on August 30, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by Caitlin O’Hara @caitlin_oh / Rivko Knox, 83, collects signatures for the Stop Dark Money petition during the March On for Voting Rights event in Phoenix on August 28.

Knox, who was a member of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee in the 1960s, has been organizing for the anti-war and civil rights movements since she was in her 20s. “I’m an intellectual pessimist but an operational optimist. Sometimes I feel like, what’s the use? But then I’ll go out and collect signatures or march. What else can we do?”
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on August 28, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @nina_berman / Terry G. Collins (left), 73, and Hezekiah Jackson, 65, pose for a portrait at the March On for Voting Rights rally in Washington, D.C., on Saturday.

They arrived yesterday from Birmingham, Alabama. “We’ve come to D.C. a number of times,” Collins said. “We both grew up in Birmingham. We remember the church bombing, and I was a part of the march that happened in Birmingham for civil rights in 1963, and we are still here.

“We are part of the Urban Solutions Progress Network. It’s a local civil society organization working with a lot of youth over the years. We go wherever the action is. Our hope for today is that the Congress will realize that this country will be what it’s supposed to be. It’s supposed to stand for equal rights and for anyone who is a citizen to be able to vote. We want the millennials to understand that we have unfinished business.”
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on August 28, 2021.

Photo by @emileducke / Siberia’s massive wildfires are unlocking extreme carbon pollution, releasing nearly 800 million tons of carbon dioxide since June. That is roughly as much as Germany does in a year.

Terentiy Ignatyev, 64, works with his family members in the fields around Argas as smoke hangs overhead.

Taken while on assignment for @natgeo for a story on the forest fires raging in the Yakutia (Sakha Republic) region of Russia this year.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Siberia.

ph_descripcion:
Video and photos by Arturo Rodriguez @arturorguezdotcom / This is the view from the top of Guardilama where you can see almost the entire island of Lanzarote and the vineyards of La Geria, where grapevines grow on volcanic soil. In the Canary Islands, in the southernmost region of Spain, the GDP dropped 20% last year as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. Tourism is essentially the only major industry in this small archipelago. 40% of the Canary Islands' GDP comes from tourism with around 200,000 jobs depending directly on this sector and almost one million indirectly–close to 50% of the total population. Lanzarote Island is one of the islands that relies heavily on white wine production but according to Victor Díaz, the President of Regulatory Council of Lanzarote, the wineries have lost around 40% of the sales due to the pandemic.

This work is supported by the @insidenatgeo COVID-19 Emergency Fund for Journalists. #CanaryIslands #Lanzarote #Spain #Covid-19
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on August 24, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @philipcheungphoto / Esme Salzman, 17, and her sister Ava, 20, photographed at their home in Los Angeles, California.

Esme and Ava are 6th generation descendants of Lee Wong Sang, a railroad worker who arrived in San Francisco in 1866 from Sun Chuen Village, Guangdong Province of Southern China, as a 19-year old, to work for the Central Pacific Railroad. 

Historians estimate that at any one time, between 10,000 and 15,000 Chinese laborers were working on constructing the western portion of North America's first transcontinental railroad, suffering hundreds of casualties, most undocumented. 

Follow me @philipcheungphoto as I continue photographing the history of the Central Pacific Railroad and acknowledge the crucial role that the Chinese railroad workers had in America.

#centralpacificrailroad #cprr #transcontinentalrailroad #descendants #chineserailroadworkers
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on August 21, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @ralphpace / A female sea otter carries her several week old pup across Moss Landing Harbor in California.

Sea otter pups are born too buoyant to dive and will rely on their mother exclusively for the first two months and are typically fully weened by six months. These six months are very hard on the mother and very important for the pup. There is lots to learn for the baby to be successful on its own. In addition to needing to forage for herself, she will need to feed the baby along with teaching it how to successfully groom itself, forage, use tools and make a living in the harsh ocean.

It’s a wonderful treat to work on a story in my home town of Monterey, CA. Sometimes, I will be working on my boat and when I look up and this cuteness swims by.

Follow @ralphpace for more on otters in CA while working on the upcoming @natgeo story.

Image taken under U.S. FWS permit # 37946D

#seaotter #otter #california
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Monterey, California.

Photo by Andrea Bruce @andreabruce / Most of the residents of Corail, Haiti, now live in the streets—their homes too cracked and broken by the recent earthquake to inhabit. They sleep in the streets with whatever they can find to protect them from mosquitos and rain.
Days after a magnitude 7.2 earthquake devastated the western part of Haiti’s southern peninsula, access to the villages most affected is scarce. #haiti
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on August 19, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by Andrea Gjestvang @andreagjest / From their home by the Reppafjord in Finnmark, northern Norway, Karen Anne Oskal Eira and Nils Eira have a panoramic view of the place where the fjord landfill for the copper mine Nussir will be located. They are Sámi reindeer herders and are strongly opposed to the planned mine. They fear losing the summer pasture for their reindeers if mining operations one day expand, and that the fish are poisoned or disappear completely due to the landfill.

“It’s not humans who own the earth. The earth owns us,” said Nils Eira.

These images were made on assignment for @natgeo in the far north of Norway together with @brettvsimpson last week.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on August 17, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by Andrea Gjestvang @andreagjest / From their home by the Reppafjord in Finnmark, northern Norway, Karen Anne Oskal Eira and Nils Eira have a panoramic view of the place where the fjord landfill for the copper mine Nussir will be located. They are Sámi reindeer herders and are strongly opposed to the planned mine. They fear losing the summer pasture for their reindeers if mining operations one day expand, and that the fish are poisoned or disappear completely due to the landfill.

“It’s not humans who own the earth. The earth owns us,” said Nils Eira.

These images were made on assignment for @natgeo in the far north of Norway together with @brettvsimpson last week.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on August 17, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @emileducke / The Siberian village of Byas-Kyuyol burned within hours of the wildfire reaching it. Thirty homes were lost. Residents who fought for days to keep the flames at bay were forced to flee on tractors and motorbikes through the smokey haze. Just days earlier, I took this picture on the road to the village, as the fire raced ever closer: trees scorched and charred, the ground blackened, turned to ash.

Taken while on assignment for @natgeo for a story on the forest fires raging in the Yakutia (Sakha Republic) region of Russia this year.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on August 16, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @philipcheungphoto / Robert Low, 36, photographed at his home in Alameda, California.

Robert is a 5th generation descendant of Hung Lai Woh, who arrived in the United States in the mid-1860s from Dai Long Village, in the Guangdong Province of Southern China, as a teenager, to work for the Central Pacific Railroad. Historians estimate that at any one time, between 10,000 and 15,000 Chinese laborers were working on constructing the western portion of North America's first transcontinental railroad.

Follow me @philipcheungphoto as I continue photographing the history of the Central Pacific Railroad and acknowledge the crucial role that the Chinese railroad workers had in America.

#centralpacificrailroad #cprr #transcontinentalrailroad #descendants #chineserailroadworkers
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on August 14, 2021.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @emileducke / Smoke this thick feels as if you’re almost drowning, all the time. This summer, it has covered swathes of Siberia for weeks. Wildfires have torn through the forests of Yakutia (Sakha Republic) at a record rate, and much of the burden of fighting them has fallen on local villagers — such as Oleg Shcherbakov, 37, pictured here pushing his motorbike through a headache-inducing haze. Time was running short: the fire was now just 400 metres away from his village, Kyuyorelyakh.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on August 13, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @ralphpace / A pair of southern sea otter pups have a play date while their mothers rest in Elkhorn Slough in Watsonville, California

Southern sea otters are currently listed as endangered but numbers are much better than they once were. Extensive fur hunting throughout the 18th and 19th almost drove the population to extinction. It was thought otters were extinct in California until 1914, when a small remnant population of otters was found in Big Sur, CA. Through protection and massive efforts by scientists and conservationists the population in California has rebounded to nearly 3,000 today but has now plateaued.

California sea otters only inhabit 13% of their traditional range due to limited kelp forests and predation from a growing number of great white sharks. But, plans are in the works to potentially help these otters out by relocating/reintroducing them to their old range.

Over the next few months I’ll be diving and working with conservationists to document these remarkable animals. For more on this story you can follow @ralphpace & @natgeointhefield

Image taken under U.S. FWS permit # 37946D

#seaotter #otter #california
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Elkhorn Slough Reserve.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by Eunice Adorno @euadorno / I walked the old avenues of Mexico City for several days. They were built to emulate the four cardinal points that communicated to the Templo Mayor, linking its location to the conception of the universe. These roads of the great Tenochtitlan are a fundamental part of the city's layout.

I was walking south through Iztapalapa, Tlalpan, Chalco; to the west with México-Tacuba and to the north with Calzada de los Misterios towards Tepeyac.

On one of those walks, I was accompanied by my dear friend Rubén, a chronicler of the city, who constantly repeated to me: “always imagine that you walk on water”. From that slogan, I made my own lines and my own imagination, an experience that was shaped like a drawing, an outline of a personal map of my own walk.

This memory and learning exercise reflects, in my understanding, the old relationship with water.

I chose as a background this blue plastic, used for different functions in the city, such as street commerce, or even as a raincoat.

On this blue background there is a series of images that constitute memories of how the city coexisted with water, and the transformation it underwent over time.

The avenues that I traveled and photographed were traced with the same plastic material.

This map is my own memory and my relationship with the landscapes that I saw.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on August 13, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by Eunice Adorno @euadorno / Tomorrow, August 13, is the 500th anniversarythe 500th anniversary of the Spanish Conquest.

I had many crossed thoughts while I walked the old avenues, built to emulate the four cardinal points that communicated Templo Mayor, linking its location to the conception of the universe. I also found myself traveling along what was perhaps the same path that Cortes entered.

I went to the south through Iztapalapa, Tlalpan, Chalco; to the west with México-Tacuba and to the north with Calzada de los Misterios towards Tepeyac.

On one of those walks, I was accompanied by my dear friend Rubén, a chronicler of the city, who constantly repeated to me: “always imagine that you walk on water”. From that motto I made my own tracing and my own imaginary. 

Here is a bit of those encounters and what we are now. @euadorno #mexico #cdmx #fotografiamexicana #photooftheday #euniceadorno #500anniversaryconquestspanish
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on August 12, 2021.

Photo by @philipcheungphoto / Connie Young Yu, 80, poses for a portrait at her home in Los Altos Hills, California.

Connie is a 4th generation descendant of Lee Wong Sang, who arrived in San Francisco in 1866 from Sun Chuen Village, Guangdong, China, as a 19-year old, to work for the Central Pacific Railroad. Historians estimate that at any one time, between 10,000 and 15,000 Chinese laborers were working on constructing the western portion of North America's first transcontinental railroad.

Follow me @philipcheungphoto as I continue photographing the history of the Central Pacific Railroad and acknowledge the crucial role that the Chinese railroad workers had in America.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by Arturo Rodriguez @arturorguezdotcom /
Here’s a little #Behindthescenes and, I have to say, this isn’t footage isn't sped up.

La Palma Island (Canary Islands), in the southernmost region of Spain, is a small island. Thanks to its agricultural industry the island is suffering less than other islands in wake of COVID-19 the archipelago's tourism industry. Farmers on the island have seen a huge decline in exports nevertheless. There used to be many cargo ships transporting food between the Canary Islands and the continent; now, due to the COVID-19 pandemic, there are far fewer.
This work is supported by the @insidenatgeo COVID-19 Emergency Fund for Journalists. #CanaryIslands #Tenerife #Spain #Covid-19

Video by my assistant Fernando Leal @ferleal.photo
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on August 12, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by Andrea Gjestvang @andreagjest / By the fjord Reppafjorden in Norway, not far from the North Cape, a company plans to build a zero emissions copper mine and to dump the waste in the fjord. The plans sparked major protests among environmentalists, local fishermen and the Sami people.

Magnus Storvoll Strømseth and Therese Hugstmyr Woie from the largest environmentalist youth organization in Norway keep watch on the construction site overnight. If the machines arrive, they are ready to exercise civil disobedience to prevent the mining company from starting its work. These images were made on an ongoing assignment for @natgeo in the far north of Norway together with @brettvsimpson this week.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on August 11, 2021.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @shonephoto Robbie Shone / I’m on the road again for National Geographic Magazine as part of the ‘End of the Ice Caves’ story. I first visited the Schneevulkanhalle (snow volcano hall) inside Schwarzmooskogelhöhle, Austria in 2013. Back then, there was more ice than today, or yesterday when this photograph was taken. Now, there is a lake inside the chamber. A sad sign that this beautiful ice is melting, and melting fast due to our warming world. #EndOfTheIceCaves #IceCaves @NatGeo @Natgeointhefield
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on August 11, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @donaldmiralle / As the sun sets on the flags of 205 countries at the Tokyo 2020 Olympics a year later, you can’t help but feel the pull on your heart strings. So many dreams & expectations go into these Games, from the host country, to the athletes, to the media, that once it comes to an end one can’t help but feel a bit of PED (Post Event Depression). Amplified more by the fact we all had to wait through an extremely difficult year to get to where we are today.

To strike gold at an Olympic Games is no easy feat. Not only do you have to be the best in your country in your specific event, but then be the best on the planet in that given moment on the biggest world stage. For those who have trained their entire lives for this moment, the fact of the matter is that for every athlete who receives a gold medal at the Olympics, there are over 200 who fall short. In a world where athletes are judged and monetized by how much hardware hangs around their necks, this is a harsh reality to swallow. It would be great to see media put less emphasis on the medal count but rather on the stories of their journeys from the start to the finish line.

As a photographer going into these Olympics I had low expectations due to the uncertainty leading up to it, but I can say without hesitation that the Tokyo 2020 Games exceeded all my expectations. For the kindness & pride of the Japanese hosts who somehow pulled off the largest event since Covid-19 changed our planet, you are all amazing. Thank you to all volunteers at every venue and the photo managers who facilitated the positions to the photos we shot. It’s amazing how much planning goes into each image and event you shoot at the Olympics.

Special thanks to @natgeo @natgeointhefield @natgeoadventure and @jeffheimsath who had faith in me and went to bat for me when I pitched the idea of covering @tokyo2020 @olympics

Finally a huge thanks to everyone who followed my Olympic journey here. Even though I didn’t have time to reply to most your messages, I read and appreciated every single one of them! 🙏🏽

Arigato and Sayōnara Tokyo!
♥️🇯🇵✌🏽
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on August 10, 2021.

It’s amazing how much planning goes into each image and event you shoot at the Olympics.

Special thanks to @natgeo @natgeointhefield @natgeoadventure and @jeffheimsath who had faith in me and went to bat for me when I pitched the idea of covering @tokyo2020 @olympics

Finally a huge thanks to everyone who followed my Olympic journey here. Even though I didn’t have time to reply to most your messages, I read and appreciated every single one of them! 🙏🏽

Arigato and Sayōnara Tokyo!
♥️🇯🇵✌🏽
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on August 10, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @donaldmiralle / DAY 16: Horse Jump over Kanagawa 🐎

I have an Olympic tradition that I usually shoot Equestrian Team Finals as one of my last assignments of the Games. Ended up seeing the only wave of my trip, glad it was of my favorite Japanese woodblock print “The Great Wave off Kanagawa” 神奈川沖浪裏 by the Japanese artist Hokusai. Seemed like a fitting backdrop for a jump and an added bonus with @martinfuchs_official on his white horse Clooney against the night sky.

Almost to the finish line here in Tokyo, the Japanese have done an amazing job as hosts pulling off one of the most difficult Olympic Games amidst Covid-19. Feel free to see more of my #behindthescenes from @tokyo2020 @olympics in the highlight stories or on my feed at @donaldmiralle
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Tokyo 東京, Japan.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @donaldmiralle /

Day 15: 🇨🇦🥇
Oh Canada!

Comeback from deficit at halftime, tied at end of regulation, tied at end of 2nd overtime, and down on penalty kicks. But somehow the Canadians held in there and won the gold medal. What a gritty performance and great game…

Felt bad for Swedes who controlled 1st half, time of possession, shots on goal, and were up in penalty kicks with chance to end it twice. Props to Canadian goalie Stephanie Labbe @stephlabbe1 who played lights out after the first goal. @teamcanada @canadasoccer

After long game, long bus ride back to Tokyo it’s now 5am and can’t edit anymore. Time to sleep before my last day shooting! Finish line in site!
@olympics @tokyo2020
ph_atributos: Photo shared by Nat Geo in the Field on August 06, 2021 tagging @teamcanada, and @canadasoccer.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @philipcheungphoto / Tai Lee, 6, poses for a portrait in his bedroom in San Mateo, California.

Tai is a 6th generation descendant of Lim Lip Hong, one of the first Chinese hired by the Central Pacific Railroad in 1864, where he worked as a headman. Historians estimate that at any one time, between 10,000 and 15,000 Chinese laborers were working on constructing the western portion of North America's first transcontinental railroad.

Follow me @philipcheungphoto as I continue photographing the history of the Central Pacific Railroad and acknowledge the crucial role that the Chinese railroad workers had in America.

#centralpacificrailroad #cprr #transcontinentalrailroad #chineserailroadworkers #descendants #philipcheung
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on August 06, 2021.

Photo by Reuben Wu @itsreuben / A drone carrying a powerful LED light circles above the iconic silhouette of Stonehenge in Wiltshire, UK. This behind the scenes photo shows the lighting technique I use to capture this world-famous monument in an otherworldly glow for an upcoming @natgeo story about Stonehenge.

Follow me @itsreuben for more updates from this story and other projects.

#stonehenge #natgeo #reubenwu

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @donaldmiralle / DAY 15: Cleared for takeoff…

So I cleared my 14 days quarantine here in Tokyo for the @tokyo2020 @olympics a couple days ago, just in time to head back home Sunday. I haven’t seen any of the the city since I’ve been here, just the inside of my hotel room and venues with taxis and busses in between.

So today I went for run in the surrounding area around my hotel and it was a completely new world out there. Was smart to take my phone as I was able to take these photos, dumb to run 8 miles in the middle of the day 90 degrees and 90% humidity! 🥵

Daily life was what I really wanted to shoot while being here in Japan but unfortunately the restrictions didn’t allow it. Should I go and explore more my last couple days and take my camera with me?

For more #behindthescenes photos + videos from the Tokyo Olympics feel free to follow @donaldmiralle or in the stories/highlights here…Arigato!
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on August 06, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @donaldmiralle / Day 14 of the Tokyo Olympics: Light Speed ⚡️

Pedro Pichardo gains speed on the runway en route to winning the gold medal in the Men’s Triple Jump.

It was fun to play with a little light today at the track on the last morning session (and my first and only session.)

It won’t be long now, we’re getting to the end of this trip, it’s been a blur but it’s been good. Thanks for following along, ready to go home to family, but a couple more events to finish strong on 💪🏽
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on August 05, 2021.

Photo by Arturo Rodriguez @arturorguezdotcom / Last year in the Canary Islands, the southernmost region of Spain, tourism dropped to zero because COVID-19. Tourism is essentially the only major industry in this small archipelago. 40% of the Canary Islands GDP comes from this industry and around 200,000 jobs depend directly on this sector and almost one million indirectly–close to 50% of the total population. In these pictures you can see seven cruise ships anchored outside the capital city of Tenerife and empty hotels and beaches in Gran Canaria.

This work is supported by the @insidenatgeo COVID-19 Emergency Fund for Journalists. #CanaryIslands #Tenerife #Spain #Covid-19
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on August 05, 2021.

Photo by @cristinabaussan / With the increase in the number of deportations from the United States, I spent weeks with deportees in El Salvador to document how they are re-adapting to life in a culture they grew up far away from and are finding community in the people and traditions that remind them of their American home.⁣
⁣
Early morning in San Salvador, El Salvador. More than 100,000 Salvadorans have been deported from the United States since 2015, according to the most recent data provided by Salvadoran authorities.⁣
⁣
"Sometimes in life you have to let go of what you know to embrace what’s on the horizon and hope for the best,” said Alex Morales, a 29-year-old who was deported to El Salvador in 2019. ⁣
⁣
This image was made on assignment for @natgeo as part of a National Geographic Migration Series launching this summer. Follow me @cristinabaussan more stories of tenderness in the face of adversity.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on August 04, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @cristinabaussan / With the increase in the number of deportations from the United States, I spent weeks with deportees in El Salvador to document how they are re-adapting to life in a culture they grew up far away from and are finding community in the people and traditions that remind them of their American home.⁣
⁣
Walter Blanco, 50, and his mother, Elena Mejía, 91, hold a family portrait of Mejía and her four sons. "We must not wait until people die to demonstrate our love," she said. "We must do it while we are still on this Earth." Blanco was deported back to El Salvador in 2001 after migrating to the United States at age 13 to join his mother in Maryland. ⁣
⁣
These images were made on assignment for @natgeo as part of a National Geographic Migration Series launching this summer. Follow me @cristinabaussan for more stories of tenderness in the face of adversity.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on August 03, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @donaldmiralle / DAY 11: A study of “Poetry in Motion”.

A little fun with some in camera multiple exposures I shot this past week. These new cameras do an amazing job sandwiching up to 10 images seamlessly in camera, and even saves the individual files so you can pluck out the frame you want! The hardest part is keeping camera still as we don’t bring tripods into venues…

With all the buzz as @simonebiles returns to competition tonight at gymnastics, thought the first image was appropriate…

Image #1: Simone Biles performs her one vault at @tokyo2020 before pulling out.

Image #2: Team China spins to a silver medal in the Men’s Synchronized 10m Platform.

Image #3: Team South Korea strikes first in the Bronze Medal Fencing Team Epee Match.

For more #behindthescenes of the @tokyo2020 @olympics follow me at @donaldmiralle and the stories in bio!
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on August 02, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @stephenedwardferry / As an avid cyclist myself, I am happy to be documenting how the residents of Bogotá, Colombia have turned massively to the bicycle as a healthy way of maintaining social distance and reducing costs during the pandemic. According to government stats, bike use in Bogotá increased by 80% since the plague began. Current daily use is estimated at 830,000 riders or nearly one out of ten people.

I start my documentation by visiting the Patio Bonito neighborhood which is a hub for thousands of riders who set out from working-class neighborhoods in the south of the city to their jobs in the center. Rush hour begins before 6 am, as riders on all sorts of bikes head to work. Many will travel at least 10 miles to their destination.
Estoy contento documentar el uso masivo de la bicicleta en Bogotá para una beca de la National Geographic. Para mantener el distanciamiento social y reducir gastos durante la pandemia, los bogotanos están montando sus bicis más que nunca. Según la alcaldía, se ha incrementado en un 80% el uso desde abril de 2020 y hoy en día unas 800,000 personas por día montan bicicletas, es decir casi una por cada diez personas.

Arranco esta documentación en el barrio Patio Bonito, un punto donde miles de personas pasan desde los barrios obreros del sur hacia sus trabajos en el centro de la ciudad. La hora pico empieza antes de las 6 am, cuando los viajeros montados en toda clase de bicis arrancan. Muchos viajarán mas de quince kilómetros para llegar a sus destinos. ~ This work is supported by the @insidenatgeo COVID-19 Emergency Fund for Journalists. #Covid-19 #Bogotá #PatioBonito #bicycles #bicis
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on August 02, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @stephenedwardferry / As an avid cyclist myself, I am happy to be documenting how the residents of Bogotá, Colombia have turned massively to the bicycle as a healthy way of maintaining social distance and reducing costs during the pandemic. According to government stats, bike use in Bogotá increased by 80% since the plague began. Current daily use is estimated at 830,000 riders or nearly one out of ten people.

I start my documentation by visiting the Patio Bonito neighborhood which is a hub for thousands of riders who set out from working-class neighborhoods in the south of the city to their jobs in the center. Rush hour begins before 6 am, as riders on all sorts of bikes head to work. Many will travel at least 10 miles to their destination.
Estoy contento documentar el uso masivo de la bicicleta en Bogotá para una beca de la National Geographic. Para mantener el distanciamiento social y reducir gastos durante la pandemia, los bogotanos están montando sus bicis más que nunca. Según la alcaldía, se ha incrementado en un 80% el uso desde abril de 2020 y hoy en día unas 800,000 personas por día montan bicicletas, es decir casi una por cada diez personas.

Arranco esta documentación en el barrio Patio Bonito, un punto donde miles de personas pasan desde los barrios obreros del sur hacia sus trabajos en el centro de la ciudad. La hora pico empieza antes de las 6 am, cuando los viajeros montados en toda clase de bicis arrancan. Muchos viajarán mas de quince kilómetros para llegar a sus destinos. ~ This work is supported by the @insidenatgeo COVID-19 Emergency Fund for Journalists. #Covid-19 #Bogotá #PatioBonito #bicycles #bicis
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on August 02, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @dguttenfelder David Guttenfelder.
Scott Babineau of the Red Cliff Band of Lake Superior Chippewa teaches a group of teenagers how to build a wigwam. The boys camped together in a Nebandawi’iweg scouting trip to Waabaabikaa-minis (Sand Island) one of the unique islands that make up the Apostle Islands National Lakeshore / Wenabozho Ominisan, which are Ojibwe native lands and the heart of the Anishinaabe story of creation.
During the five days, the boys learned about Ojibwe historical & cultural connections to the islands, identifying inner-generational trauma, and paddled canoes 6 miles round trip from the mainland.

Over the next month I’ll be kayaking, hiking, and exploring the wilderness of 21 unique islands of Wenabozho Ominisan / the Apostle Islands National Lakeshore. Follow along here at @natgeointhefield & @dguttenfelder
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Apostle Islands.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @dguttenfelder David Guttenfelder
A National Park Service biologist gently holds a Piping Plover chick, preparing to release it after an ID band was placed on its leg. To protect the most endangered shore birds of Lake Superior’s Apostle Islands National Park, the NPS, Bad River Band of the Lake Superior Chippewa, Wisconsin DNR & the US Fish & Wildlife Service are working together to guard and monitor nesting Piping Plovers on Outer Island and Chequamegon Point on Long Island.

To make this photo, I used a 100mm macro lens (to photograph up close these tiny chicks, as young as 5 days old) at the widest aperture f2.8 to minimize the depth of field and separate the baby bird from the island background.

Over the next month I’ll be kayaking, hiking, and exploring the wilderness areas of 21 unique islands of the Apostle Islands National Lakeshore. Follow along here at @natgeointhefield & @dguttenfelder
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Apostle Islands.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @donaldmiralle / And on the 5th day of the Olympics, Simone Biles pulled out of competition.

Weird night at Gymnastics with arguably THE star of this Olympics Simone Biles pulling out after this one vault due to mental health issues. I can’t imagine the enormous pressure and the “weight of the world” that she and other athletes of her caliber have on their shoulders, where anything but gold is a failure.

Congrats to the US Team for winning the silver medal even without their star, and all the best to @simonebiles
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on July 28, 2021.

Photo by @dguttenfelder David Guttenfelder
Bazile Panek, a National Park Ranger and member of the Red Cliff Band of the Lake Superior Chippewa, joined a flag raising ceremony at the Apostle Islands National Lakeshore at Little Sand Bay, WI. The flag raising marked the first time in the park’s half century history that the Red Cliff flag has flown alongside the USA flag. It will remain there permanently.
Wenabozho Ominisan (The Apostle Islands) is Ojibwe native land and the heart of the Anishinaabe story of creation.

Photos by @lauredutruy / Abellino is taking part in “The Heroes' race” on July 4th 2021, a fundraising marathon event in Cordemais, western France. The 8-year-old boy born with Down's Syndrome put on his Spiderman costume that day. Alongside hundreds of participants, he runs to raise funds for associations helping and supporting disabled individuals. In 2020 and due to COVID-19 measures, the event happened virtually. Following a recent easing of health regulations related to the pandemic by the French government, the event took place physically this year.

In the second photo, Abellino’s sister, Magdaléna, is sitting with her friend who is also running for the Heroes’ race that day.

These photographs are part of an ongoing story on how a family with three children with Down Syndrome are getting through the pandemic in France. This work is supported by the @insidenatgeo COVID-19 Emergency Fund for Journalists.

#downsyndrome #trisomy21 #mentaldisabilities
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on July 26, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @cristinabaussan / Hundreds of thousands of Salvadorans have been deported in the past decade, and many arrive in a country they barely know. Over the past few weeks, I’ve met Salvadoran deportees who are searching for a sense of identity and finding community in the people and traditions that remind them of their American home. 

Walter Blanco visits his grandmother’s grave in Intipuca, El Salvador. She was one of the main reasons Blanco's mother migrated to the United States when he was still a child to send back remittances to support her family. Blanco joined her in Maryland when he turned 13 and got deported to El Salvador in 2001. "I often wonder if I would have become someone important there," he said. "But I've learned to quickly let go of that thought."

This image was made on assignment for @natgeo as part of a series on migration in Central America. Follow me @cristinabaussan for more stories of tenderness in the face of adversity.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on July 24, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @cristinabaussan / Hundreds of thousands of Salvadorans have been deported in the past decade, and many arrive in a country they barely know. Over the past few weeks, I’ve met Salvadoran deportees who are searching for a sense of identity and finding community in the people and traditions that remind them of their American home. ⁣
⁣
Elena Mejía, 91, sits by the sewing machine she used to make dresses for women in Intipucá before migrating to the United States. After being diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease, Mejía returned to live with her son who was deported back to El Salvador in 2001. Moments of her life in the U.S. working as a housekeeper at various hotels are some of the few memories she carries with her today. ⁣
⁣
This portrait was made on assignment for @natgeo as part of a series on migration in Central America. Follow me @cristinabaussan for more stories of tenderness in the face of adversity.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on July 22, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Video and photos by Arturo Rodriguez @arturorguezdotcom / On La Palma island (part of the Canary Islands), in the southernmost region of Spain, tourism and banana plantations are the economic engine of the island. There used to be many cargo ships transporting food between the Canary Islands and the European continent but due to the COVID-19 pandemic there are not and because of that the primary sector is suffering the consequences and unemployment rates are rising very fast. Europe is a huge, slow animal and usually incapable of responding rapidly a crisis like this. On top of the pandemic, the Canaries are still recovering from the 2008 economic crisis that hit the region worse than any other place in Spain, with unemployment rates as high as 35%.

This work is supported by the @insidenatgeo COVID-19 Emergency Fund for Journalists. #CanaryIslands #Tenerife #Spain #Covid-19
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on July 21, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @cristinabaussan / With the increase in the number of deportations from the United States, I spent weeks with deportees in El Salvador to document how they are re-adapting to life in a culture they grew up far away from and are finding community in the people and traditions that remind them of their American home.

1. Walter Blanco, 50, moved to Maryland at age 13 to reunite with his mother. He was deported to his hometown of Intipucá, El Salvador, in 2001 after an aiding and abetting conviction stripped him of his green card. “In the U.S., there are doctors, lawyers, and engineers,” he said. “Here too.”

2. Elena Mejía, Blanco’s mother, migrated to the United States in search of economical stability and later became a U.S. citizen. “My mom was a tailor,” Blanco said. “The best at making dresses.” But when she arrived to Maryland as a young mother, Mejía became a housekeeper at various hotels to send money home to her family in Intipucá, El Salvador. When Blanco was deported in 2001, Mejía sent him a suit that he wears on special occasions.

These images were made on assignment for @natgeo as part of a series on migration in Central America launching this summer. Follow me @cristinabaussan for more stories of tenderness in the face of adversity.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on July 20, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @cristinabaussan / With the increase in the number of deportations from the United States, I spent weeks with deportees in El Salvador to document how they are re-adapting to life in a culture they grew up far away from and are finding community in the people and traditions that remind them of their American home.

1. Walter Blanco, 50, moved to Maryland at age 13 to reunite with his mother. He was deported to his hometown of Intipucá, El Salvador, in 2001 after an aiding and abetting conviction stripped him of his green card. “In the U.S., there are doctors, lawyers, and engineers,” he said. “Here too.”

2. Elena Mejía, Blanco’s mother, migrated to the United States in search of economical stability and later became a U.S. citizen. “My mom was a tailor,” Blanco said. “The best at making dresses.” But when she arrived to Maryland as a young mother, Mejía became a housekeeper at various hotels to send money home to her family in Intipucá, El Salvador. When Blanco was deported in 2001, Mejía sent him a suit that he wears on special occasions.

These images were made on assignment for @natgeo as part of a series on migration in Central America launching this summer. Follow me @cristinabaussan for more stories of tenderness in the face of adversity.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on July 20, 2021.

ph_descripcion: Photos by Luke Sharrett @howdyluke / A pair of White Oak trees grow in Constitution Grove at Naval Support Activity Crane in Crane, Indiana. White Oak timber growing on base is harvested by the US Navy for use aboard the wooden-hulled frigate U.S.S. Constitution. Built in 1797, the historic vessel is docked in Boston’s Charlestown Navy Yard and periodically requires new white oak timber to maintain a state of good repair. #natgeo #whiteoak #nsacrane #forestry #ussconstitution
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on July 20, 2021.

ph_descripcion: Photos by @dzalcman / This is a copy of a letter that was sent by Rosebud Lakota Chiefs White Thunder and Swift Bear in 1880 when they learned of the death of their children Ernest and Maud at the Carlisle Indian Industrial School. “They are far very far away from us. We cannot bear to have them sleep so far from this earthly home, our hearts will grieve too long if we do not have what is left of them.” The letter went unanswered. For more coverage from their journey home, more than 140 years later, follow @dzalcman and @bmorinstories.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on July 19, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @cristinabaussan / With the increase in the number of deportations from the United States, I spent weeks with deportees in El Salvador to document how they are re-adapting to life in a culture they grew up far away from and are finding community in the people and traditions that remind them of their American home.

1. Mayra Machado, 36, was first deported to El Salvador in January 2017 after being convicted for writing false checks at age 18. Desperate to reunite with her kids, she didn’t stay long before migrating again. But she was detained by immigration agents and was sent back for the second time to El Salvador in January 2020 after more than two years in Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) detention. She hasn’t seen her children in person since. Machado says she has no plans to attempt a third journey to the U.S.. “I refuse to give ICE another day of my life,” she said.
2. When Machado was deported in 2020, she carried this purse with only three items in it – her phone, so that her kids could reach her, her lipstick, and a pair of sunglasses to feel protected from the outside world.

These images were made on assignment for @natgeo as part of a series on migration in Central America. Follow me @cristinabaussan for more stories of tenderness in the face of adversity.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on July 17, 2021.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @shonephoto Robbie Shone / The loss of the ice caves is not just about losing a beautiful underground landscape, but also about losing an important scientific resource. Like tree rings that can be analysed for climate information, the layers within the ice can also provide climate information. The nature of their formation means the records reveal details of past winter seasons. Organic material trapped within the ice can be radiocarbon dated to find out when the ice was deposited. #EndOfTheIceCaves #IceCaves @NatGeo @Natgeointhefield
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on July 17, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @acacia.johnson / A walrus skull rests in a field of wildflowers on Round Island, Alaska. This remote island in the Bering Sea—known as Qayassiq, or "place to go in a kayak" in Yup'ik—is home to thousands of male walrus that come to rest on its shores every summer.

Since 1960, the island has been protected as part of the Walrus Islands State Game Sanctuary, where a permit program allows small groups of visitors to camp on the island every summer to observe walrus in the wild. It also remains an important hunting ground for Yup'ik communities who coordinate a subsistence hunt for walrus every fall, continuing the traditions that have taken place here for over 5,700 years.

Taken on assignment for an upcoming @natgeo story about this remarkable place.

#walrus #alaska #walrusislands #qayassiq #roundisland
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on July 16, 2021.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @shonephoto Robbie Shone / It’s quite simply a race against time to document the beautiful European ice caves before they melt away and disappear due to climate change. We have just returned from Hochschneid ice cave, located in the Höllengebirge, Austria. Here, climate scientist Tanguy Racine from the University of Innsbruck, admires the pristine ice at the bottom of the cave. To the right, is ice that formed when water entered the cave and froze. To the left, behind Tanguy, is ice formed from snow that fell into the cave from the entrance, creating a snow cone. #EndOfTheIceCaves #IceCaves @natgeointhefield @natgeo
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on July 16, 2021.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @dzalcman / I’m currently with a caravan making its way from Carlisle, PA to the Rosebud Reservation with nine Rosebud children who were taken to the Carlisle Indian Industrial School and buried there for over a century. As we pass through other Native nations, the caravan has stopped for communities to pay their respects before they return home for a feast and funeral this weekend.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on July 16, 2021.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @dzalcman / This caravan of Rosebud youth & community members are bringing back their nine relatives who were buried at the Carlisle Indian Industrial School for the past 140 years. Carlisle was the first boarding school for Native children opened in the US, with the explicit mandate of coercive assimilation. We’ve made it from Carlisle, PA to Iowa City, IA and will reach the Rosebud Reservation in South Dakota tomorrow. On Saturday, the tribe will hold a funeral for the nine children and lay them to rest in their historic homelands. Follow along as @bmorinstories and I continue to document their journey.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on July 15, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @acacia.johnson / A Pacific walrus approaches the shore of Round Island, Alaska—known as Qayassiq, or "place to go in a kayak", in Yup'ik. Here, male walrus gather onshore by the thousands every summer to recuperate after the mating season. One of my favorite things about watching walrus is their incredible grace in the water, and the way their skin quickly changes from pale to rosy in color as they emerge from the cold waters of the Bering Sea and warm up.

Taken on assignment for @natgeo for an upcoming story about Alaska's Walrus Islands State Game Sanctuary.

#walrus #alaska #roundisland #pacificwalrus #walrusislands
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on July 15, 2021.

Taken while on assignment for @natgeo for a story on this island's remarkable ecosystem, its significance, and the adventure involved in traveling there.

#alaska #walrus #roundisland #walrusislands #pacificwalrus

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @emin_ozmen / Abdullah (L) 24, and Adnan 30, stand by their sheep at nightfall on Bagok mountain near Mardin, Turkey.
To protect themselves from the cold night, they wear a typical shepherd's outer garment (Kepenek in Turkish). It is a sleeveless, buttonless garment generally made of felt worn on the shoulders and covering the whole body.
This picture is part of my ongoing work in South East Turkey, documenting the daily life of nomads and their transhumance in a context where COVID-19 sometimes challenges their way of living.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on July 12, 2021.

Photo by @cristinabaussan / With the increase in the number of deportations from the United States, I spent weeks with deportees in El Salvador to document how they are re-adapting to life in a culture they grew up far away from and are finding community in the people and traditions that remind them of their American home.

Over one thousand Salvadorans were deported from the U.S. in 2021 alone, an experience that is largely recognized as traumatic, and more so for immigrants who have lived decades in the United States. 

This image was made on assignment for @natgeo as part of a series on migration in Central America. Follow me @cristinabaussan for more stories of tenderness in the face of adversity.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on July 12, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @cristinabaussan / With the increase in the number of deportations from the United States, I spent weeks with deportees in El Salvador to document how they are re-adapting to life in a culture they grew up far away from and are finding community in the people and traditions that remind them of their American home.

Alex Morales, 29, works from his home in La Libertad, El Salvador. In 2019, Morales was deported to a country even his mother had shared little about; to him, it felt like the Wild Wild West. But after nearly two years of being back, he is finding his ground. He now runs his own Airbnb and manages other properties at the beach town where his mother grew up. “I’m going to be a big fish in a little pond,” Morales said of his work.

This image was made on assignment for @natgeo as part of a National Geographic Migration Series launching this summer. Follow me @cristinabaussan for more stories of tenderness in the face of adversity.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on July 10, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @cristinabaussan / With the increase in the number of deportations from the United States, I spent weeks with deportees in El Salvador to document how they are re-adapting to life in a culture they grew up far away from and are finding community in the people and traditions that remind them of their American home.

Alex Morales and his daughter, Rose, watch a soccer game in San Salvador, El Salvador. Growing up with immigrant parents who worked several shifts to sustain his family, Morales shares that what keeps him up at night is making sure he gifts his daughter the same opportunities he had going to school in the United States. After living in the U.S. for nearly twenty-four years, Morales was deported to his hometown of La Libertad, El Salvador in 2019.

This image was made on assignment for @natgeo as part of a National Geographic Migration Series launching this summer. Follow me @cristinabaussan for more stories of tenderness in the face of adversity.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on July 09, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @cristinabaussan / With the increase in the number of deportations from the United States, I spent weeks with deportees in El Salvador to document how they are re-adapting to life in a culture they grew up far away from and are finding community in the people and traditions that remind them of their American home.

1. Alex Morales, 29, first migrated to Los Angeles with his mother and stepfather when he was five before moving to Arkansas. He was deported to El Salvador in 2019 after being convicted of theft obtained by physical threat. Before he got sent back to his hometown of La Libertad, one of his cell mates told him, "You are literally going to freedom."

2. Alex Morales' gi, a martial arts robe, that he wore during his childhood in Arkansas hangs outside his home in La Libertad, El Salvador. Morales first got into martial arts as a young boy when he felt responsible for protecting his immigrant family living in the United States. A few months after his deportation, a close friend flew down to visit him and brought him his uniform.

These images were made on assignment for @natgeo as part of a National Geographic Migration Series launching this summer. Follow me @cristinabaussan for more stories of tenderness in the face of adversity.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on July 08, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @annaliminowicz / Patrycja Donaburska has been undergoing psychiatric treatment for four years, and has been in therapy for two years.
During the pandemic, her anorexia worsened, panic attacks on public transport returned, and she had panic attacks at home, which she had never had before.
One of her cats is also depressed.

I am currently documenting how COVID-19 is affecting mental health in Poland.
This work, called “Virus of fear” is supported by the @insidenatgeo COVID-19 Emergency Fund for Journalists.

 #mentalhealth #Poland #covid19 #depression #fear
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on July 07, 2021.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @shonephoto Robbie Shone / I’m currently on assignment for National Geographic Magazine working on the ‘End of the Ice Caves’ project. This week I’m photographing Buso Della Neve del Zingarella ice cave on the Asiago plateau in North Italy. This is a stunning ice cave in which the vertical entrance is corked with a giant ice plug like a wine bottle. Like all ice caves, this one is changing dramatically and losing its ice volume. It had been a few years since my guide Francesco Sauro had been there and the old route through the ice plug is now blocked, so with the help of an experienced caving team from Miles Beyond, we found a new route to follow that had been carved out by the wind. @NatGeo @natgeointhefield #endoftheicecaves #icecaves
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on June 29, 2021.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @shonephoto Robbie Shone / I’m here at Buso Della Neve del Zingarella ice cave on the Asiago plateau in northern Italy, where I’ve been working on the next instalment of the ‘End of the Ice Caves’ story for National Geographic Magazine. The ice formations in the cave have changed considerably over the last decade. I’m photographing it before it’s gone forever. @NatGeo @natgeointhefield #endoftheicecaves #icecaves

Photo by @mfimages / A worker shelter himself behind the shield while observing nickel casting process at PT. Aneka Tambang Tbk (ANTAM) ferronickel plant in Pomalaa, Indonesia.

I'm currently on assignment in Southeast Sulawesi to see how nickel is being mined and processed as Indonesia is scaling up the production in a bid to support the global electric vehicle industry.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @lauredutruy / Élodie and her three adopted children Abellino, Magdaléna and Nathanaël gather with friends for World Down Syndrome Day on March 21st, 2021 in western France. Usually many public events are organised throughout the country to raise awareness.

However, for the second year in a row, celebrations were canceled due to COVID-19. Instead, the family decided to meet with friends and other families of mentally disabled individuals in order not to be alone and share a picnic in the forest.

Élodie and her children baked cakes with candies forming the number 21 which stands for Trisomy 21, and a sock for the international hashtag #socksbattle4Ds (Socks battle for Down Syndrome).

These photographs are part of an ongoing story on how a family with three children with Down Syndrome are getting through the pandemic in France. This work is supported by the @insidenatgeo COVID-19 Emergency Fund for Journalists.

#downsyndrome #trisomy21 #mentaldisabilities
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on May 19, 2021. May be an image of 7 people, people sitting, people standing, tree and outdoors.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @juanarre / Marinelly Hernandez gets a treatment of vitamins through an IV line for treatment of COVID-19 at the home and the ETCR (Espacios Territoriales de Capacitación y Reintegración) territorial spaces for reintegration in La Guajira, Colombia. Close to 47 residents have been diagnosed over the past nine months with COVID and the lack of proper treatment has forced former rebels to seek traditional treatment and homeopathic remedies to treat symptoms of COVID 19.

Marinelly is one of 171 former FARC members in the process of reintegration. Since the signing of the historical peace process between the Colombian Government and FARC (The Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia) in 2016, former rebels have reunited with families and started their own, despite precarious living conditions at the transitional encampments. The implementation of the peace process has been undermined by politics and slow to fully implement by the current government, creating a climate of uncertainty for many former rebels as they are now the target of selecting killings, discrimination, and "abandoned and betrayed by the state," said Marinelly.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on May 17, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @stephenwilkes / A rare quiet moment between eruptions at the volcano Fagradalshraun in Iceland. While on assignment for @natgeo, we were helicoptered onto a mountain top location to create my latest Day to Night photograph.  After 20 hours of filming, our team & gear were then airlifted out. As we were heading out and passing the volcano, our pilot mentioned that perhaps we should look into the volcano during its quiet phase. Suddenly to my surprise, we were directly over top of It. The lava, which had been violently pouring out of the side of the mountain just minutes earlier, was just beginning to pulsate within the magma chamber. From above, the volcano looked like a heart, beating with magma. I made a few frames, and we quickly moved away.

After all we had experienced during this shoot, it was a remarkable ending, viewing the volcano from this dynamic perspective.#volcano #magma #iceland #aerial #photography
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on May 16, 2021.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Arturo Rodriguez @arturorguezdotcom / In the Canary Islands, the southernmost region of Spain, Jenifer Santos wakes up before sunrise every day to work on her organic livestock farm. The primary sector is going through a terrible crisis due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Thousands of farmers in the country have been waiting for almost one year for public subsidies from Europe, but the response from the continent has been slow. The Canaries are still trying to escape the 2008 economic crisis that hit the region harder than any other place in Spain, with unemployment rates that have risen 35% (25% in 2021). This work is supported by the @insidenatgeo COVID-19 Emergency Fund for Journalists. #CanaryIslands #Tenerife #Spain #Covid-19
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on May 16, 2021.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @balazsgardi / The early vaqueros were known as “soldiers of leather,” brought from Spain by Jesuit missionaries to guard the missions that ran down Mexico’s Baja peninsula. Today, their descendants still make their own shoes, saddles and protective wear the old way, using cowhide and goatskin tanned with palo blanco bark. Made to last, they are both tools of necessity and works of art that some vaqueros sell in town as a secondary source of income.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on May 15, 2021.

Photo by Robbie Shone @shonephoto / The huge entrance to Eisriesenwelt cave, near Salzburg, Austria is a well known and iconic feature in the landscape. A strong draught blows through the entrance, which reverses direction according to the seasons. In winter, one gets sucked into the cave, whereas in summer, one has to fight their way against the strong headwind to get inside. The draught is created because the cave has another entrance higher than this one pictured.
In summer, warm outside air blows through the cave from top down, melting the ice formations inside the cave as it does so. As the climate warms the summer melting gets worse and worse each year. To see a short behind-the-scenes film about the making of this photograph, see the previous post. Shot for “End of the Ice Caves” for @NatGeo magazine. @natgeointhefield #endoftheicecaves #icecaves
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on May 14, 2021.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @balazsgardi / In Mexico’s Baja peninsula Erlinda Arce wakes up before dawn to prepare coffee and breakfast over a mesquite-fueled stove. Much of her day will be spent preparing meals for the family, typically meat stews with beans and tortillas. Any extra time is dedicated to making blocks of goat cheese that they sell to support themselves.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on May 14, 2021.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Robbie Shone @shonephoto / Framed in a rock grotto “The Castle” formation in Eisriesenwelt cave near Salzburg, Austria looks at its best this time of the year. Over the course of the year the portcullis-type feature will gradually melt away. Eventually due to warming climates, this formation won’t form at all. ph_descripcion: Photo by @shonephoto Robbie Shone / The beautiful blue ice formations in Eisriesenwelt cave near Salzburg, Austria are always a pleasure to photograph. “The Castle” formation shown here is one of my favourites. It’s fun to weave yourself through the windy interior of this formation a bit like exploring a castle, but for me I enjoy lighting it up and seeing the different blues sparkle in the ice. Documenting these formations is important as they are under threat from warming climates. Shot for “End of the Ice Caves” @NatGeo magazine. Check out the story to see my location for this photograph. @natgeointhefield #EndoftheIceCaves #IceCaves
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on May 02, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by Walé Oyéjidé @ikirejones / Somewhere in Philadelphia, two gloved assailants approach each other from opposite corners of a ring. For one furious round, the city’s ubiquitous orchestra of sirens, dirt bike convoys, and Water Ice trucks, will be quietened as onlookers stare with the attention of devoted Mass-goers. It’s silent as a confessional; save for the landing of blows and the bold encouragement of over-eager coaches. In that small ring, punches and counterpunches serve as counter-intuitive ways to heal those who were on the verge of being broken, those with homes in disarray, and those who live in comfort; but nevertheless, need an escape. Outside, the news laments a pandemic. But here, among the fighters, the ring sings of peace.

This work is supported by the @insidenatgeo COVID-19 Emergency Fund for Journalists.
Follow me @ikirejones for celebrations of beauty in all its forms.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 30, 2021.

Photo by @annaboyiazis / How do you say watermelon in Arabic? Jordanian-American Mohammad, 8, rests on a hammock in California, shielding his eyes from the afternoon sun. Mohammad’s mom Huda AG is instrumental in helping Iraqi and Syrian families acclimate. I made this picture as I highlight how the new arrival community of Syrian refugees and asylum-seekers in California is contributing to America during the pandemic.

This work is supported by the @insidenatgeo COVID-19 Emergency Fund for Journalists. In collaboration with @miryslist and the @newarrivalsupperclub

To see additional stories focused on human rights, public health, and women and girls’ issues, follow me @annaboyiazis

#california #dream #watermelon
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 29, 2021.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @shonephoto Robbie Shone / I have just returned from Eisriesenwelt ice cave, located near Salzburg, Austria, where I have been working on “End of the Ice Caves” for @NatGeo magazine. I’m always in awe when I get to visit this spectacular natural wonder. However, I’m also left with a feeling of sadness as these majestic landscapes are melting due to climate change. Pictured here are the formations known as “The Elephant” on the left and “The Castle” on the right. Can you make out the elephant? Hint: the head is on the left. #endoftheicecaves #icecaves
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 28, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @isadorakosofsky

Mary sits in the communal area of the memory care unit at a skilled nursing facility in Albuquerque, New Mexico.

Studies estimate that the mental health fallout of the pandemic will be three times the medical footprint. Psychologists have seen an elevated rate of grief, depression, and anxiety amongst long-term care residents after a year of isolation and loss of community members. Clinicians working with individuals with dementia and Alzheimer’s Disease have noted changes in mood and declines in cognition. While vaccinations have allowed residents to reunite with their families, some states, like New Mexico, have set guidelines that encourage outdoor and scheduled visitation only. In New Mexico, 4,264 long-term care residents contracted Covid-19 and 997 died from the virus since March 2020.

To follow the development of this forthcoming story, and to see more stories about the impact of the pandemic on adults with disabilities and senior citizens, follow me @isadorakosofsky
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 25, 2021.

Photo by @philipcheungphoto / Old vehicles are scattered near the route of the Central Pacific Railroad in Golconda, Nevada, where thousands of Chinese railroad laborers once worked on the western portion of North America's first transcontinental railroad.

In 1868 the Central Pacific Railroad arrived at the mining and agricultural town. The railroad bolstered its economy by providing a faster way to transport its goods, and like many railroad towns, it had a large Chinese population.

Over the next few months, I will continue photographing the history of the Central Pacific Railroad and acknowledge the crucial role that the Chinese railroad workers had in America.

#centralpacificrailroad #cprr #transcontinentalrailroad #chineserailroadworkers #landscape #nevada #golconda
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 25, 2021.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Stephen Alvarez @salvarezphoto / This panther pictograph lends its name to Panther Cave shelter in Seminole Canyon. For 4,000 years this huge feline image has looked over the confluence of the Rio Grand and Seminole Canyon. Seminole Canyon State park once led boat tours to this panel but low water levels in Lake Amistad has made public visitation impossible.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 24, 2021.

Photo by Michael Seeley @mseeley20 / Captured with a sound-activated camera left overnight at Kennedy Space Center's LC-39A, this is a close-up of the Crew-2 SpaceX Falcon9 rocket. The "9" refers to the 9 Merlin rocket engines, which generate 1.7 million pounds of thrust, more than enough to carry astronauts Shane Kimbrough, Megan McArthur, Aki Hoshide, and Thomas Pesquet to orbit on their way to the International Space Station. 

This morning's launch was the first time a previously-flown Falcon 9 booster was used for a crewed mission, and the Crew Dragon capsule has flown previously as well.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 23, 2021.

Photo by Michael Seeley @mseeley20 / At 5:49 am (EDT) Friday, the Crew-2 mission successfully launched from NASA's Kennedy Space Center and historic LC-39a seen here in a 326-second exposure captured from 5 km west of the pad. The mission sent astronauts Shane Kimbrough, Megan McArthur, Aki Hoshide, and Thomas Pesquet to orbit on their way to the International Space Station. 

As the Crew Dragon flew east, the down-range streak glowed bluish-white from sunlight catching the second stage rocket plume.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 23, 2021.

Photo by @andrea_frazzetta / To celebrate Earth Day I’m sharing some pictures from my project "Growing in the Woods".
In this photo the children of the " Kindergarten in the Wood " of Milan.
The health emergency, which has overwhelmed Italy like few other countries in the world, has undoubtedly put the school system in serious difficulty. In particular, it has highlighted how this needs new, and safe, spaces, and a rethinking of the teaching method.
The lack of outdoor experiences faced by the children of today's cities has created a new type of disorder, identified by the scientific community as "Nature Deficit Disorder".
Immersion in nature reduces stress in children who are stimulated to develop greater intellectual qualities, health, and serenity.
Building a relationship with Nature from an early age is a prerequisite for developing sensitivity towards the environment and a desire to protect it.
Thanks to the support of @InsideNatGeo’s Emergency Fund for Journalist in the coming months I will be working on a project to document the most important outdoor education entities in my country.
Follow me @andrea_frazzetta to know more. #EarthDay #backtonature
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 22, 2021.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @jaredsoares / Residents of Ward 8 gather at the intersection of Martin Luther King Jr. Avenue and Malcolm X Avenue SE in the Congress Heights neighborhood of Washington, D.C. to raise awareness about HR 51, a bill introduced by Democratic Delegate Eleanor Holmes Norton, D.C.’s nonvoting House member, that would make D.C. a state Thursday April 22. The House of Representatives voted this morning, 216-208 to pass the bill that would grant D.C. statehood. The bill will now head to the U.S. Senate to be voted on at a later date.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 22, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @andrea_frazzetta / To celebrate Earth Day I’m sharing some pictures from my project "Growing in the Woods". In this photo Caterina, one of the children from the school "Il bosco dei piccoli" in Veglio, Italy, during a snow exploration trip in the nearby mountains.
All children should have the right to a "good start". The chance to grow up in a clean world, safe in what they drink, eat and the air they breathe. But the water is no longer pure, the air is soaked in all kinds of pollutants, the earth is contaminated by synthetic chemicals. It is said that this is the unwanted fruit of development and progress. Yet today it would also be important to know how to stop and find a necessary balance with our wonderful planet.
The Covid-19 pandemic has brought about a sudden and destabilizing change in our lives. But this epochal moment could be an opportunity to rethink our society and to give a chance to ecological education, a cultural premise towards sustainability.
Thanks to the support of @InsideNatGeo’s Emergency Fund for Journalist in the coming months I will be working on a project to document the most important outdoor education entities in my country.
Follow me @andrea_frazzetta to know more. #EarthDay #backtonature @lagricultura
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 22, 2021.

Photos by @lauredutruy / In France, most group activities are forbidden due to COVID-19 measures, including most events to support mentally disabled individuals, even though they are significant in encouraging social inclusion. However, the government has made exceptions for sport practice by priority groups, including people with disabilities.

Despite difficulties to maintain their initiative, the association “Rien qu’un chromosome en +” created a project called Tandem, which brings children with Down Syndrome and non-disabled adults together to dance.
Magdaléna, a 10-year-old girl born with Down Syndrome is part of this program. She is seen here at a class in March 2021 as they prepare for a stage performance at the end of this year.

This work is supported by the @insidenatgeo COVID-19 Emergency Fund for Journalists.

#disabilities #downsyndrome #trisomy21
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 22, 2021.

Despite difficulties to maintain their initiative, the association “Rien qu’un chromosome en +” created a project called Tandem, which brings children with Down Syndrome and non-disabled adults together to dance.
Magdaléna, a 10-year-old girl born with Down Syndrome is part of this program. She is seen here at a class in March 2021 as they prepare for a stage performance at the end of this year.

This work is supported by the @insidenatgeo COVID-19 Emergency Fund for Journalists.

#disabilities #downsyndrome #trisomy21
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 22, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @philipcheungphoto / People explore the historic Summit Tunnel #6 in the Sierra Nevada mountain range in California, where Chinese laborers from the Central Pacific Railroad once worked to build the western portion of North America's first transcontinental railroad.

Getting the railroad through the Sierra Nevada was the most challenging obstacle across the entire line. It took Chinese laborers years of digging, drilling, hammering, and blasting their way through the solid granite rock. Many Chinese men lost their lives from accidental explosions and the harsh winters they had to endure.
 
Over the next few months, I will continue photographing the history of the Central Pacific Railroad and acknowledge the crucial role that the Chinese railroad workers had in America.

#centralpacificrailroad #cprr #transcontinentalrailroad #chineserailroadworkers #landscape #california
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 22, 2021. May be an image of 2 people.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by Stephen Alvarez @salvarezphoto / Val Verde County Texas.
We spent a day with Shumla archaeologist Vicky Roberts looking at archaic era paintings in the lower Pecos River valley of Texas. The paintings are over 4,000 years old. What did they mean to the hunter gathering communities that painted them? To a large degree we don’t know the specifics of the stories recoded on the rock shelters in Texas but we do know that they were important enough to paint huge murals in fine detail.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 21, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @renan_ozturk / Words by @m_synnott #TheLostWorldExpedition

Look hard enough and you can find frogs from the Arctic Circle to the Sahara Desert—and practically everywhere in between. But nowhere are they more plentiful than in the rainforests that girdle South America’s equatorial region. At last count, scientists like Dr Bruce Means had cataloged about 1000 different species that live in the Amazon Basin. Of course, these are only the ones we know about, and if Bruce is right, there are likely ten times that number that have yet to be discovered. Sadly, we will never know how many have already been lost to extinction.

According to Bruce, the reason there is so much frog biodiversity in the Amazon is that speciation takes place over evolutionary time, and there is nowhere on earth where frogs have lived for longer. DNA analysis of tree frogs collected on past expeditions in the Paikwa River Basin suggests that many of them took up residence in the region between 70 and 80 million years ago, which is twice as long as they have been living in North America. “About the most profound statement I can make,” says Bruce, “is that the longer life is allowed to proliferate in a rich, untrammeled environment like the Paikwa River Basin, the more that species will differentiate and diversify.”

Over the years, Bruce’s quest to document this biodiversity has become more urgent as he has witnessed firsthand how the “pork-knockers”—freelance Guyanese mining prospectors—have been transforming once pristine rainforests and rivers into poisoned scars in the earth.

“When I saw what was happening, and I realized how many species were going extinct every day,” says Bruce, “I knew that there was no more important contribution I could make to the world than to document as much of this biodiversity as I could before it was lost forever.

Like the world within the speck of dust in the Dr. Seuss book ‘Horton Hears a Who!’, Bruce says that there are tiny universes of life all around us that we don’t even know exist. And when they disappear, they become missing strands in the ecological web that connects all living things.

@taylorfreesolo @expedition.studios
ph_atributos: Photo shared by Nat Geo in the Field on April 19, 2021 tagging @renan_ozturk, and @expedition.studios.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @_joannademarco / Hal Safi detention centre is where many asylum-seekers are detained after arrival in Malta. During the pandemic, reports emerged on inhumane conditions: overcrowding, violence, self-harm, filthy sanitary facilities and lack of outdoor access. Hundreds were detained for several months. In 2021, authorities said that many people have been released, and steps are being taken to improve conditions.

This work is supported by the @insidenatgeo COVID-19 Emergency Fund for Journalists.

#Malta #Covid19 #migration
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 19, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @marcozorzanello / The amazing thing about seeing sea turtles is the feeling of tranquillity. It was layng on the botom of the Fushifaru Thila point, a well know place for diving in the Maledives, looking at us as extraneous animals. Even if we, as human beings, are able to reach and explore almost every single place of this planet, we are still guests in the marine world.
Due to global warming and the human invasion of this environment, the global coral reef is disappearing faster than predicted. Coral reef isn't only a tourist attraction, it's the home of an imeasurable number of known and unknown living species. Maldivian identity has a close bond with the coral. The coral reef is the barrier that protects them from the wide ocean and it is the material from which their ancient buildings were made. They also depend on it for their main national income—tourism.
This photography project is shining a light on a local problem, but speaks to a global issue.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Fushifaru Maldives.

Photo by @philipcheungphoto / In Lovelock, Nevada, a McDonald's restaurant near the route of the Central Pacific Railroad where thousands of Chinese railroad workers once worked to complete the western portion of North America's first transcontinental railroad in 1869.

The establishment of Lovelock started with building the Central Pacific Railroad through the area in 1868, which also stimulated the local livestock and agriculture industry, and like many railroad towns, it had a large Chinese population.

Over the next few months, I will continue photographing the history of the Central Pacific Railroad and acknowledge the crucial role that the Chinese railroad workers had in America.

#centralpacificrailroad #cprr #transcontinentalrailroad #chineserailroadworkers #landscape #nevada
