ph_descripcion: Photo by Robbie Shone @shonephoto / Ice caves in the European Alps are melting at an alarming rate. When we think about the effects of climate change on the cryospheric components of the earth, we naturally think of majestic ice sheets, glaciers and sea ice. Ice caves are vulnerable too. Recently we began the ‘End of the Ice Caves’ National Geographic magazine story. Pictured here, within the tourist part of Eisriesenwelt (Giant Ice World) is an iconic ice formation beyond a grill of icicles. This photograph was taken almost eight years ago but during my recent assignment for @natgeo I noticed the icicles were no longer there. I’m hoping they form each season and that they will grow again, but it could be another warning sign. Stay tuned for more. @NatGeo #icecaves #endoftheicecaves
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 16, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @kianahayeri / Dad-e Khoda (14), from Yaftal district of Badakhshan, Afghanistan poses for a portrait inside a mud outpost on Karsai Peaks that now serve as the front line. He joined the militia group 4 months back, fighting against the Taliban that control the very district he comes from.
Mohammad Asif, (14), also from Yaftal district, poses for a portrait at Faizabad Juvenile Rehabilitation Center where he has been institutionalized for 1.5 months. He had followed the footsteps of his older brother who had joined the Taliban at age 16 and was killed last year. He was only 20.
When I asked Mohammad Asif to imagine himself in 10 years, he shrugged. I challenged him to try harder and see himself beyond the soulless cells of JRC. It took several tries, but he eventually responded: "I don't know, I'll probably be dead?!"
These two kids are the legacy of the American invasion. On Wednesday, President Biden declared that “it is time to end the forever war in Afghanistan." Speaking from the same spot in the White House where President Bush ordered the start of the war nearly two decades ago, Biden made a case that there was no longer any justification — if there ever was — to believe that the U.S. military presence could turn Afghanistan into a stable democracy.
#Badakhshan #Afghanistan
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 15, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @nataliekeyssar / Throughout history, people all over the world turn to faith and ritual during times of crisis. Statistically many embrace religion during tough times, or become more observant when confronted with loss and uncertainty. To explore this idea, I spent the past few weeks traveling across Alabama, one of the most religious states in the U.S., according to the Pew Research Center, looking at the way that faith has intersected with one of the most difficult years anyone can remember.

Mussarat Qureshi, a devout Muslim and long time member of the Huntsville Islamic Center Mosque, took over as Principal of the Center’s Islamic School this year, and has successfully organized a safe return to in person learning. Recently, she spent a quiet Saturday afternoon at her home Athens, Alabama, with her husband, Dr Nauman Qureshi. The couple spent their afternoon going for a walk in the neighborhood and connecting with family over the phone. Dr Qureshi is a kidney doctor, and between education and healthcare, the couple has been on the front lines of the pandemic in numerous ways this year, while caring for ailing parents and attempting to maintain contact with their children and grandchildren. Faith has been a balm for each of them, as they have focused on their faith, their prayers, and keeping their community safe. Now finally vaccinated, they hope to begin to see more of the grandchildren soon. In the meantime they lean on FaceTime. Dr. Quereshi often spends time reading the Quran with his 14 year old granddaughter on FaceTime, going over the subtleties of the Arabic words with her.

Its been such a joy and an honor to spend time during these pivotal and personal days with spiritual leaders and communities over these past few weeks. Thank you so much to everyone who let me join them for these beautiful, hopeful moments.

And huge thanks @insidenatgeo for the generous support for this project, publishing in full soon on @natgeo. Follow me @Nataliekeyssar for more stories of resilience during crisis.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 15, 2021.

Photos by @kianahayeri / On the edge of Kohna Deh village in Nili District of Daikundi, Afghanistan, residents, mainly women and young girls, from about 10 different families gather by the creek to wash clothes, blankets, and textile a day before the arrival of spring, in preparation for NowRooz celebration. Known as 'Khana Tekaani', this tradition stems from the Zoroastrians' idea of "purifying with cleanliness as a measure for keeping Evil away from the kingdom of Good.”
#Afghanistan #NowRooz #Nili #Daikundi
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 15, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @marcozorzanello / I met Mr. Hussain Manik, from Male, in the old Friday Mosque of the city. This building is well known as Malé Hukuru Miskiy (Dhivehi: މާލެ ހުކުރު މިސްކިތް) and was built in 1658 with interlocking mechanisms that mainly consist of coral stones.
The month of Ramadan begins today. It marks the time when the Quran was revealed to the prophet Muhammad. In this period, Muslims fast from sunrise to sunset each day.
Islam is one of the main pillars of Maldivian identity, and officially is the only religion in the country.
The fast helps believers purify their hearts, renew their faith, seek forgiveness, and increase self-discipline. It is also a time to focus on what is most important and positive in a believer’s life.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Male, Capital City Maldives.

Photo by @andrea_frazzetta / "Il bosco dei piccoli" (The Wood of the Little Ones) is a school for children located in the hills of Biella, in the town of Veglio, and is the first of its kind in Piedmont.
In this picture one of the children during the outdoor music workshop. "Here children experience the learning immersed in a context of nature and woods, welcomed in a small mountain community. Fundamental to our teaching is a meaningful and deep relationship, built day after day."
The health emergency, which has overwhelmed Italy like few other countries in the world, has undoubtedly put the school system in serious difficulty. In particular, it has highlighted how this needs new, and safe, spaces, and a rethinking of the teaching method.
"Growing in the Woods" is a documentation project supported by @InsideNatGeo’s Emergency Fund for Journalist. Ecological education it’s a cultural premise towards sustainability.
Follow me @andrea_frazzetta to know more. #backtonature
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 12, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @andrea_frazzetta / The Covid-19 pandemic has brought about a sudden and destabilizing change in our lives. But this epochal moment could be an opportunity to rethink our society and to give a chance to ecological education, a cultural premise towards sustainability. The conditions are all there. In Western countries six out of ten citizens demand education to be one of the main objectives, even before economic development, of the post-coronavirus. The health emergency, which has overwhelmed Italy like few other countries in the world, has undoubtedly put the school system in serious difficulty. In particular, it has highlighted how this needs new, and safe, spaces, and a rethinking of the teaching method. The lack of outdoor experiences faced by the children of today's cities has created a new type of disorder, identified by the scientific community as "Nature Deficit Disorder". Building a relationship with Nature from an early age is a prerequisite for developing sensitivity towards the environment and a desire to protect it.
Thanks to the support of @InsideNatGeo’s Emergency Fund for Journalist in the coming months I will be working on a project to document the most important outdoor education entities in my country.
We live in a society that has the duty to find a different relationship with nature. Through this project, my goal is to spark reflection and debate, on a fundamental issue.
Follow me @andrea_frazzetta to know more.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 11, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photo and video by @marcozorzanello / Magoodhoo Reef (Dhivehi: މަގޫދޫ), Faafu Atoll, Maldives.
I have been following the two marine biologists, Davide Seveso and Simone Montano, from MaRHE Center, University Bicocca Milan, while they are monitoring the reef restoration program. Since the beginning of the COVID-19 pandemic, the two biologists couldn't visit Maldives. When they arrived on the island reef, both scientists were surprised by the strong growth of the coral, probably due to the absence of the massive tourism and intense human activity.

Coral reef world wide is living an intense crisis due to global warming. Maldives is an archipelago of 1192 islands made and protected by coral. The consequence of the reef desappearing could cause an intense erosion of the island shore from the ocean waves. This group of marine biologists are selecting the strongest coral that can survive bleaching and other illnesses.

#climatechange #maldives #identity
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 10, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by Walé Oyéjidé @ikirejones / Photography, for me, is not an unconscious act. Intention is everything. Before pushing the shutter button, I ask myself, "how does this person hope to be seen?" "How will I add to the legacy they've built?" And "with this shared moment, can we help reshape the world into something better?"

Much has been said about the city of Philadelphia. Its calamitous street violence and collapsing school systems are well known. Less seen is the spirit of resilience that permeates among its residents. Despite all this town has endured there are those who wrestle beauty from the grips of turmoil. There are those who insist on finding joy because they know no better way to survive.

Ellis "El-Dog" Ferrell of Fletcher Street Urban Riding Club is one of them. For decades, this quiet horseman has taught the youth of Philadelphia to ride.

There are sounds we know well in the city. Loud noises resounding against the walls of historic row homes, followed quickly by collective regret. But there are other sounds, too. Joyous ones.

I raise my camera as three boys race past me on horseback. Black hoodies. Black boots. Backs straight, but heads tilted back. With wild laughter pouring from their throats like a Coltrane solo.

If you've never heard the echoing of galloping hooves in the middle of a narrow street in West Philadelphia, I regret to inform you: you have never heard poetry.

This work is supported by the @insidenatgeo COVID-19 Emergency Fund for Journalists.
Follow me @ikirejones for celebrations of beauty in all its forms.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 10, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by Philip Cheung @philipcheungphoto / A sheepdog guards its flock along the original route of the Central Pacific Railroad in Utah's West Desert, where thousands of Chinese railroad workers once worked to complete the western portion of North America's first transcontinental railroad in 1869.

Over the next few months, I will continue photographing the history of the Central Pacific Railroad, and acknowledge the crucial role that the Chinese railroad workers had in America.

#centralpacificrailroad #cprr #transcontinentalrailroad #chineserailroadworkers #landscape
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 09, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @marcozorzanello

Ahmad, 35 years old, from Maafushi, Male Atoll, Maldives. Due to the Covid-19 pandemic, he lost his work and now still unemployed. As many of Maldivians he was rising some money sailing little boat for tourists. I met him near the local jetty, while he was sit on the tipical Maldivian chair, and speaking with his friend Rashid. They spoke to me directly in Italian, and told about how the Maldivan identiy and life style has been changed in the last decades thanks to the tourism. As many of them, they left their old occupantion as fishermans, to join some tour operator.

Maldives is the lowest country in the world with an average ground-level elevation of 1.5 metres (4 ft 11 in) above sea level, and a highest natural point of only 5.1 metres (17 ft). Following the IPCC report within 2100 the level of the ocean could rise up to 1 mt due to the climate change. With this prediction, many of the 1192 island could disappear.

#climatechange #Maldives
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 09, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @nataliekeyssar / Throughout history, people all over the world turn to faith and ritual during times of crisis. Statistically many turn to religion during tough times, or become more observant when confronted with loss and uncertainty. To explore this idea, I spent the past few weeks traveling across Alabama, one of the most religious states in the U.S., according to the Pew Research Center, looking at the way that faith has intersected with one of the most difficult years anyone can remember.

The Flatline Church at Chisholm in Montgomery Alabama, led by Pastor Dewayne Rembert, opened up two years ago with a mission to help the community and focus on outreach to the poor. When the pandemic hit, they moved to drive in services to protect their congregation while still connecting with them and offering them support. On March 28, as storms rolled into the area on Sunday morning, Pastor Rembert decided to hold their first indoor services in a year, citing increased levels of vaccination and lower virus levels, they carefully blocked off seating for social distancing, required masks, opened doors for ventilation, and sat separated by family group. Associate Pastor Keelan Adams gave a passionate service to a small but emotional group of attendees, moved by their first time being together after such a hard year. After the service church volunteers served food to anyone in the area who was hungry, part of the Church’s primary mission to serve despite the many obstacles in its path.

Thank you so much @insidenatgeo for the generous support for this project, publishing in full soon on @natgeo. Follow me @Nataliekeyssar for more stories of resilience during crisis.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 09, 2021.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Robbie Shone @shonephoto / Ice caves in the European Alps are melting at an alarming rate. When we think about the effects of climate change on the cryospheric components of the earth, we naturally think of majestic ice sheets, glaciers and sea ice. Ice caves are vulnerable too. This week we began the ‘End of the Ice Caves’ National Geographic magazine story. Pictured here is the Eispalast (Ice Palace) in Eisriesenwelt cave (Giant Ice World) in Austria. Stay tuned for more. @NatGeo #icecaves #endoftheicecaves
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 09, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @renan_ozturk | Waves of vapor pouring over the Tepuis.

It’s safe to say we could count on one hand the times there was a ‘view’ beyond the jungle canopy on this expedition. It often happened in 10-30 min pulses like this of dancing clouds and waterfalls.

Do these type of clouds even have a name?!

“The goal of 2021 @natgeo Lost World Expedition was an elevational transect of the Upper Paikwa River Basin near Guyana’s northwestern frontier with Brazil and Venezuela to look for new species of amphibians and reptiles in one of the world’s richest and least explored hotspots of biodiversity. The final section of our transect led us through a pristine, untouched cloud forest and culminated with a first ascent of an unclimbed 7,000-foot tepui called Weiassipu.” - writer @m_synnott

@expedition.studios @taylorfreesolo #thelostworldexpedition
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Tepuy Wei-Assipu.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by Philip Cheung @philipcheungphoto / A storm passes over the original grade of the Central Pacific Railroad in Western Utah, which is now part of the Transcontinental Railroad National Back Country Byway. Due to the railroad’s special history, it is listed on the National Register of Historic Places. The byway follows the grade through the remains of old railroad towns and where thousands of Chinese laborers worked to complete the western portion of North America's first transcontinental railroad in 1869.

Over the next few months I will continue photographing the history of the Central Pacific Railroad, and to acknowledge the crucial role that the Chinese railroad workers had in America. 

#centralpacificrailroad #cprr #transcontinentalrailroad #chineserailroadworkers
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 07, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Video and photo by @alessandra_sanguinetti / I lived in San Francisco for six years but as often happens we’re too busy and don’t explore the city we live in enough. So it’s a real treat to be on assignment to document the city’s 17-mile Crosstown Trail, starting at Land’s end along the dramatic trail overlooking the ocean with glimpses of the magical Golden Gate Bridge, winding through city streets, distinct neighborhoods, discovering hidden stairways, passageways, quirky corners, and breathtaking summits.
Catalina, my teenage daughter came along and we both agreed that it was a gift to see the city on foot, slowly, as if for the first time.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 06, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @renan_ozturk / words by @m_synnott

The cliff continued for another 400 feet above us, but the narrow, vegetated ledge on which we had spent the night appeared to offer an end run to Weiassipu’s summit plateau. After weeks of living in the jungle, it was time to complete our elevational transect and turn our attention toward home.

We set off around 9am, bushwhacking our way south through a hanging, Dr. Seussian forest of twisted, moss-covered trees and dense thickets of saw grass, reeds, and vines. In places, the vegetation was so thick that the only way forward was to crawl on our hands and knees through tunnels wreathed in spider webs heavy with dew. Through openings in the shrubbery, we caught occasional views across the valley toward the east face of Mount Roraima. It had rained overnight, and the tepui was ornamented with a dozen or so massive cascades, including the legendary Diamond Waterfall, which burst from a hole in the side of the cliff like a scene from the movie Up.

After half a mile, the ledge turned a corner and we found ourselves staring in awe across the summit plateau. Twin towers rose in the distance above a vapor-filled sinkhole that incised the summit like a bottomless abyss. In the span of a few feet, we had stepped from a cloud forest into a quaking bog covered in pitcher plants, yucca and bizarre Venus fly trap-like carnivorous plants. It started to rain. Mist poured over the tepui rim. Soon we were lost in a lost world, the fog so thick we could barely see each other as we fanned out, desperate to find a frog—or at least something vaguely resembling a summit.

Eventually, Fuco and I met up in an area where car sized, tabletop rocks balanced atop tiny pedestals. Alex Honnold was MIA. We crawled beneath a mushroom-shaped rock and huddled together under my poncho. No one said anything. We just stared into the gloom. But I know we were thinking the same thing: That summits have a funny way of not living up to one’s expectations—and finding new species of frogs on a tepui is not for the faint of heart.
@taylorfreesolo @expedition.studios #citizenscience #onassignment
ph_atributos: Photo shared by Nat Geo in the Field on April 02, 2021 tagging @renan_ozturk.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @katieorlinsky |
Words by @neilshea13
We flew into the heart of Alaska’s Brooks Range blind, wrapped in high white gauze. Louie, the pilot, was unfazed. He ate oranges and steered through passes we could only imagine. But soon the clouds dissolved and there it was—the town of Anaktuvuk Pass, home of the Nunamiut, who have lived and hunted in these mountains for generations. They settled here only in 1950 and chose the spot for good reason. Anaktuvuk means “the place of many caribou droppings,” and the Nunamiut are linked to the animals, spiritually and practically. As Louie circled town we saw them down on the plain—small groups of caribou, little families, wandering over the snow, waiting for the right moment to push north toward their calving grounds. A boy later asked us why we’d come and we said, To learn about caribou. He grinned and said, You came to the right place.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on March 31, 2021.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Sabina Pierce @sabinashoots / Researcher Sarah Kane plays with Rico, a 5-year-old Long-Haired German Shepherd, to tire him out so he’s relaxed before getting his blood taken and mouth swabbed for any traces of COVID-19 before starting the study at the Penn Vet Working Dog Center in Philadelphia. Rico is participating in a study to see if dogs can sniff out COVID-19 in humans. Blood and mouth swabs were taken from the 5 dogs that are participating in the COVID-19 sweat study to see if they have any antibodies or are infected with COVID-19 before the start of the study. The dogs will train on samples of sweat from T-shirts from volunteers who were infected and wore the T-shirt overnight.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on March 29, 2021.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @chrisburkard / On Tuesday evening, after shutting down the eruption site due to dangerous gas levels on a low wind day, two Icelandic Search and Rescue (ICE-SAR) team members monitor the surrounding area for leftover visitors. The legendary ICE-SAR teams are called upon for anything rescue related, from car crashes to avalanches, and for the last the latest eruption of Mount Fagradalsfjall. So far, the volcanic eruption site has created numerous rescue scenarios due to the volatile weather, uneven terrain, and overall unpreparedness of many visitors. ICE-SAR have been on site 24 hours taking gas readings to ensure the safety of the public since most visitors do not have the proper masks to protect them from the fumes.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on March 26, 2021.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @chrisburkard / Lava erupts like fireworks from the southwestern side of Mount Fagradalsfjall, the new eruption site in Iceland. This has been a unique opportunity to experience a living, breathing, and transforming landscape. If the flow continues at the rate it has been, these delicate moss fields will soon be eaten by lava in coming days, making way for new landforms. With science & volcanology teams studying the eruption site daily there is a prediction that it may even pour lava into the ocean, as the eruption is a little under 3 kilometers from the Atlantic Ocean.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on March 26, 2021.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @chrisburkard / The Fagradalsfjall eruption in Iceland is truly a spectacle. It’s calculated that on high visitation days over 10,000 people a day have flocked to witness this slow-moving silica volcano. Even during a year with limited travel and relatively no outside tourism, it has drawn human interest on a scale we are only able to fully grasp from the sky.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on March 25, 2021.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @chrisburkard / Like city lights from above, the evening glow cast by the lava flow creates a literal river of patterns and shapes before moving toward the weaknesses and low points of the surrounding landscape. Using a drone to capture Mount Fagradalsfjall’s eruption gives us an intimate perspective that we haven’t had the chance to see very often in years past.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on March 25, 2021.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @chrisburkard / Truth be told, photographing Mount Fagradalsfjall’s eruption in Iceland was my first time photographing lava. I realized very quickly that some of the most unique perspectives come from moving slowly and exploring the freshly cooled rock along the base of the flow. The shapes, textures, and cooling patterns create a million different ways to photograph this new earth being formed. Even the color of the rock can change pending the air temperature, sun exposure, and cooling time. Much of this rock is broken up into a million pieces as the surges of new magma and lava push through it and against it in almost a tidal wave effect, making these art forms finite. They do sometimes last forever but often only hours.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on March 25, 2021.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @chrisburkard / Since the morning of its eruption, the airspace around Iceland’s newest erupting volcano, Mount Fagradalsfjall, has been buzzing with small planes, helicopters, and drones. Airborne tourism has risen tremendously over the last few years in this country as many believe that to truly appreciate the scale and beauty of Iceland you need to see it from above. From the air, you can feel the heat rise up and hit you almost instantly, it’s palpable and creates near tropical conditions as the warm air contrasts with the cold wet air off the ocean.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on March 25, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @cgregoryphoto / Family, friends, and activists gathered to commemorate the murder of Santiago “Chagui” Mari who was killed 45 years ago today on March 24,1976 and Jose “Fefel” Varona who was died 53 years ago on March 25th whom are both buried in the same grave.

Santiago was the son of the pro-independence and socialist leader Juan Mari Bras, his murder is largely seen as a political attack on the independence movement on the Island. Despite the conviction of Henry Coira for Santiago’s death, testimony presented evidence that he did not act alone and had possible links to violent right wing groups. The family has to this day maintained an intense fight for justice seeking the possible collaborators and access to documents that the FBI has withheld in the case.

Jose “Fefel” Varona died 53 years ago on March 25, 1968 as a result of a U.S. Airforce bombing in Vietnam; possibly making him one of the only U.S. Citizens to die not by friendly fire. Varona was representing a student group in a cultural exchange delegation to North Vietnam when bombers attacked the school they were visiting on April 18, 1967, he died of his injuries almost a year later in Moscow where he received medical care.

Many in Puerto Rico joined the global movement towards socialism and de-colonialism in the 1960’s and 1970’s as a way to seek national liberation, despite a large scale effort by the part of the F.B.I. and the local Puerto Rican police to criminalize and suppress the movement. During this time there were various killings of pro-independence activists and Santiago’s death is seen as one such case. Varona became a symbol of the independence and student movement.

In the last image, Cacimar Cruz Crespo takes down a banner with the image of Varona after the ceremony.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on March 24, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @thomaspeschak / I am fortunate to spend most mornings this month with meerkats.

Courtesy of nine adults and four three-week olds pups, my early morning pre-dawn starts have been very entertaining. I got to see the youngsters emerge from the burrow for one of their earliest glimpses of daylight, watch them nurse above ground for the first time and now successfully hunt armored Katydids.

Photographed on assignment for @natgeo while working on a story on the impacts of climate change on the Kalahari desert. In collaboration with the @tswalufoundation

#tswalu #kalahari #meerkats #meerkatmondays #edgeofimpossible
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Tswalu Kalahari Reserve.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @thomaspeschak / Today is National Aardvark day and the Tswalu Kalahari Reserve is probably the best place in the world to encounter this secretive animal. BUT even here it is anything but straightforward to make photographs of this eclectic animal, which sports rabbit like ears, a pigs snout and a kangaroo like tail.

During the parched dry season we looked for and tracked Aardvarks for weeks and to date I only have a two photographs that are good enough to appear in my forthcoming @natgeo feature. To see the pics you are going to have wait until August 2021 when the story is published.

Photo shot on assignment for @natgeo in collaboration with @tswalufoundation and @k.e.e.p_kalahari_project_
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Tswalu Kalahari Reserve.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @thomaspeschak / Giraffes can be real boneheads! By chewing on bones, they extract minerals like calcium. This phenomenon is called osteophagia and translates into “feeding on bone”. Bones however are never swallowed and the minerals just supplement the giraffe’s regular diet of Acacia leaves and flowers. Shot on assignment for @natgeo working with @tswalufoundation
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on March 18, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @thomaspeschak / Over the next few weeks I will share some of my adventures and experiences while on assignment for @natgeo in southern Africa’s Kalahari desert. This may be one of the world’s harshest drylands but it is overflowing with life, home to some of the continent’s most unique animals. Meerkats, pangolins, aardvarks, Cape cobras, sociable weavers and many more species have evolved exceptional behaviors to endure extreme temperatures, optimize unpredictable rainfalls, and survive seasonal food shortages. But now climate change threatens to severely disrupt if not eliminate this 60 million-year-old ecosystem in less than 60 years, causing these interdepended iconic species to fall like desert dominos.

I am currently in the Kalahari to document and tell the story of the regions animals and plants, the threats they face and the cutting edge climate change research carried out by the scientists of the @tswalufoundation and the @k.e.e.p_kalahari_project_

For more photographs and behind the scenes videos from the Kalahari follow National Geographic Photographer @thomaspeschak

#kalahari #desert #meerkats #climatechange
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Tswalu Kalahari Reserve.

ph_descripcion:
photos by @renan_ozturk / words by @m_synnott / @natgeotv video director @taylorfreesolo

Science and the search for new species was the raison d’etre of the 2021 @natgeo Lost World Expedition, but the actual beating heart of our expedition was the team of native Akawaios who served as guides, porters, citizen scientists and friends. Some of 70-odd Akawaois who accompanied us live in this village, which is called Wayalayeng. It is home to about 50 families and can only be accessed by foot or boat. To reach Wayalayeng we flew to the village of Phillipai from Georgetown and then proceeded via the Kukui and Ataro Rivers aboard dugout canoes with outboard motors.

Over the years that I have been exploring our planet, I have secretly dreamed that one day I might find a real Shangri-La. The term was coined by British author James Hilton in his 1933 novel, Lost Horizon, and is defined as “a remote beautiful imaginary place where life approaches perfection; utopia.” It is tempting to project this vision onto Wayalayeng, and I’ll admit that I have. But the truth is that life in this village is hard. Wayalayeng lacks basic amenities that many of us take for granted in our daily lives—electricity, running water, cellular communications and medical care.

Wayalayeng sits on the edge of a plateau, and the land is ideally suited to the creation of a landing strip. I spoke with Akawaios both for and against the idea, but the consensus seems to be for maintaining the status quo. An airstrip would bring miners into the area. Apparently, there are outsiders who currently hold over 100 mining claims in the area. So far, the Akawaois have held them off. For hundreds of years, they have lived communally, subsisting on crops of cassava and hunting for fish, deer, tapirs and agoutis. Their vision of sustainability for this remote corner of the world has been passed down from one generation to the next—and it does not include mining. No one knows better than the Akawaios that the real treasures of El Dorado are not gold and diamonds, but the plants, animals and people who call this magical place home. #TheLostWorldExpedition @expedition.studios #Akawaios
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on March 15, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @renan_ozturk / words by @m_synnott

The goal of 2021 @natgeo Lost World Expedition was an elevational transect of the Upper Paikwa River Basin near Guyana’s northwestern frontier with Brazil and Venezuela to look for new species of amphibians and reptiles in one of the world’s richest and least explored hotspots of biodiversity. The final section of our transect led us through a pristine, untouched cloud forest and culminated with a first ascent of an unclimbed 7,000-foot tepui called Weiassipu.

The expedition was led by @dr_bruce_means, an intrepid 80-year-old ecologist and evolutionary biologist whose life’s work has been to catalog and document the unique flora and fauna of South America’s tepui region. Tepuis, which rise high above the rainforest like tabletop mesas, are made from some of the oldest rock on Earth, iron-hard orange quartzite that is 1.6 to 1.8 billion years old. These “Lost Worlds” represent the last remaining vestiges of an ancient plateau called the Guiana Shield, and their summits have been called “islands in the sky” on account of the endemic species that often occur only on a single mountaintop.

For more about why biodiversity matter and details on the new species of frogs discovered on this expedition (not pictured), please stay tuned for a feature article in the Yellow Book, as well as a @natgeotv episode directed by @taylorfreesolo with Renan.

For now, we’d like to thank the incredible team that worked tirelessly to document this story including Alex Honnold, Federico Pisana, Matt Irving, Ryan Valasek, Rudy Lehfeldt Ehlinger, Brian Irwin and most importantly, the team of indigenous Akawaios who we’ll be telling you more about in our next post. #TheLostWorldExpedition #BiodiversityMatters
ph_atributos: Photo shared by Nat Geo in the Field on March 12, 2021 tagging @natgeo, and @renan_ozturk.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @anushbabajanyan / I began to work on a story about distance education in Armenia in April 2020. Working with students and teachers showed me the strangeness and hardship of our common reality. The story that I photographed was the story of my life as well. Distance education was not productive for us, and I eventually became the main teacher for my two children. I often photographed the kids and myself, setting the camera on a timer. In this photograph, Ella and I were doing math, she did not feel like it, and I hugged her thinking of our slow and repetitive days to which we saw no end.

It’s been one year since the World Health Organization declared the COVID-19 outbreak a global pandemic. To commemorate the anniversary, we are sharing photographer’s stories of the pandemic from around the globe. 

This work was supported by the @insidenatgeo COVID-19 Emergency Fund for Journalists.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on March 11, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @nannaheitmann / Working in remote Russian villages in the Republic of Dagestan made me think back to Gabriel García Márquez’s book, One Hundred Years of Solitude. In the book, an insomnia plague strikes the fictional, isolated town of Macondo and nobody really understands what is happening to them at first.
The COVID-19 pandemic hit the poor and remote region in Dagestan, with an obsolete medical system, most when the pandemic first started in Russia. The local nurses thought at first that it was the annual flu but once their patients started dying and falling sick in masses they didn’t understand what was happening, nor how to treat it, nor were they provided with any medical equipment and medicine.
I was particularly saddened to see sick, pregnant women and young children suffering COVID-19 symptoms, being surrounded by cosmonaut-looking medical staff. I visited the only COVID-19 maternity ward in Dagestan, in the capital Makhachkala and photographed the birth where the newborn was immediately isolated from her sick mother.

It’s been one year since the World Health Organization declared the COVID-19 outbreak a global pandemic. To commemorate the anniversary, we are sharing photographer’s stories of the pandemic from around the globe. 

This work was supported by the @insidenatgeo COVID-19 Emergency Fund for Journalists.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by Bethany Mollenkof @fancybethany / This was one of the first self-portraits I made of my pregnancy during the pandemic. We had just decided to start telling friends we were expecting a baby when COVID-19 forced us into lockdown. It felt contradictory to be hopeful for the future while the world was shutting down. To grow a life in such dark times of death felt powerful and I wanted to document it for my daughter.

I am a pretty private person and I never would have imagined I would share such a personal set of images, but I think the pandemic made me lose my inhibitions in documenting and sharing my story. The pandemic stripped away a lot of fears and amplified my desire to connect with others.

Photo by @florence.goupil / The Shipibo-Konibo Indigenous people from Peruvian rainforest use the Amazon healing plants as a way to connect with nature. Their vast connection with biodiversity and traditional plant-based medicine are under threat amid the coronavirus pandemic.

During the pandemic in Peru, I accompanied the Shipibo-Konibo people in their quest to survive this violent disease. I was able to enter their world and understand why they consider the plants of the Amazon to be like doctors protecting humanity. I saw them take refuge in their origin, in their forest and I felt myself take refuge with them.

Photo by Brian Otieno @storitellah / It’s been one year since the World Health Organization declared the COVID-19 outbreak a global pandemic. To commemorate the anniversary, we are sharing photographer’s stories of the pandemic from around the globe. 

A volunteer disinfects a public bus in Kibera, Kenya where public transit is essential for nearly all of the residents. Public transport is a lifeline for most Kibera residents who want to move around in and within the city. While we were all being asked to stay at home, some went out of their way to serve and protect their communities.

Photo by Danielle Villasana @davillasana / It’s been one year since the World Health Organization declared the COVID-19 outbreak a global pandemic. To commemorate the anniversary, we are sharing photographer’s stories of the pandemic from around the globe. 

Kataleya, a transgender migrant from Honduras waiting to seek asylum at the United States border, finds a moment of joy in a year that has been a downward spiral for her. Only a few weeks from being summoned to present her case, which included testimony of being beaten up by her transphobic brother back in Honduras, COVID-19 hit and the U.S./Mexico border closed indefinitely to asylum seekers, hurtling her life into a downward spiral of depression and instability with employment, living situations, and safety.

This work was supported by the @insidenatgeo COVID-19 Emergency Fund for Journalists.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on March 11, 2021.

Photo by Rita Harper @__rita.p / It’s been one year since the World Health Organization declared the COVID-19 outbreak a global pandemic. To commemorate the anniversary, we are sharing photographer’s stories of the pandemic from around the globe. 

Breonna Leon is a geriatric nurse in Atlanta, Georgia and has seen many of her patients die from COVID-19. She believes Black Americans were dying at higher rates due to issues dealing with systemic racism in healthcare, access to adequate and healthy foods, education level, and empathy in the medical field. When a historic event like COVID-19 happens, we are at a disadvantage health-wise due to the pre-existing conditions we have. This is largely due to unhealthy diet and the consumption of highly processed foods. Through my research and documentation, I had an intimate look at how food deserts are plaguing black communities in Atlanta.

This work was supported by the @insidenatgeo COVID-19 Emergency Fund for Journalists.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on March 11, 2021.

Activists in Johannesburg, South Africa decided to distribute parcels of organic vegetables as well as seedlings and gardening materials to hundreds of vulnerable households to fight the growing food insecurity caused by the lockdown. As a mother, this pandemic got me concerned about the well-being, the safety and the future of my child.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @kianahayeri / Ashak (vegetarian dumplings) and Mantou (beef dumplings) are a time-consuming afghan dish that is often prepared and served on holidays or special gatherings. ph_descripcion:
Photo by @akasharabut / Happy Mardi Gras from New Orleans! Laniya Rayford, 18, plays the cymbals at Edna Karr High School in New Orleans. She was in line to be drum major for Karr but things changed after the pandemic hit. This Mardi Gras would have been her last performance with the marching band. St. Charles Avenue is a major parade route, this is where she would have been marching with her peers during a regular Mardi Gras season.
High School marching band members in New Orleans are some of the hardest working teenagers in the world. They have practice every single day of the year including summer and in the rain or shine. The average parade route is 6 miles long and most students are expected to attend school the following morning after a parade. It is common for many parade routes here in New Orleans to take up to 6 hours to reach the end. This year Laniya isn't on her normal practice routine. Edna Karr marching band director Chris Herrero has been delivering instruments to students and offering one on one instruction to help seniors prepare for college. The students really miss playing music with each other.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on February 16, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @akasharabut / Julianne Merino is an artist living and working in New Orleans.
With Mardi Gras being cancelled this year it was still important for her to make a costume. “My costume came from a desire to embody the Mississippi River. 
The idea is to look like a creature that crawls out onto the shore of the Mississippi. The chainmail, decorated in bait and fishing lures, represents a cast net to catch shrimp, oysters and crawfish. The glass beads are hand-strung from glass bead parade throws from Mardi Gras past. I wanted to embody the Mississippi River as an integral part of New Orleans and its history. It’s also an important destination on Mardi Gras day to reach the river at the end of Saint Anne parade. It’s the point in the day when you feel like you can take a deep breath, and finally sit down on the river steps, bump into familiar faces and mysterious creatures in costume, and really feel connected to your community. The Saint Anne parade originally started to go the the river to pay homage to those who have lost their lives to HIV. I think it’s a really beautiful release, and I hope to see everyone there next year.”
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on February 16, 2021.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @akasharabut / Happy Mardi Gras! The Flaming Flaggettes are a drag flag team that have been performing every Mardi Gras since 2016. This year they’ve had to find alternatives to parading in the streets due to Covid-19. They’ve been making videos for their IGTV account instead of performing in public spaces. Last week they performed a choreographed dance and released their sweet performance during a day when they would have been normally parading through the streets.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on February 16, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @akasharabut / Happy Mardi Gras! Things are pretty different this year. We’re not having our traditional Mardi Gras celebrations because of the pandemic. The Flaming Flagettes are keeping the spirit a live through making Mars Gras videos. The Flaming Flagettes are a drag flag team that have been performing every Mardi Gras since 2016. The group mother's are Jacob Reptile and Chris Staudinger.  Jacob explains "After my house fire in 2016 I moved in With Chris Staudinger (our other krewe motha)  and told him About an idea of creating an all drag flag group, so we gathered up a bunch of queeridos and after the first meeting we decided we were truly the Flaming Flagettes, an all drag flag team and we performed for the first time at the Southern Decadence parade 2016, with about a dozen people.  Every parade worthy holiday we have performed since! Except Halloween. I used to march in the 9th Ward Marching Band as a ribbon dancer. We used to march the Endymion Saturday through the neighborhood. We (9th ward Marching Band) don’t march anymore really so the flagettes filled the hole that it created in the neighborhood.
Every Mardi Gras we usually perform at a Carnival Ball and the Saturday before Tuesday we choregraph a few songs and dance down the streets welcoming other krewes like Krewe De Nim and Spirit Sticks to join us. And the whole neighborhood comes out to dance with us and basically bar crawl the gay bars throught the Marigny and French Quarter. But as of Covid-19, we started making music videos instead of doing parades. We dont want to promote gatherings or lead to anyone being unsafe so we release the video the same time we would be marching to help brighten peoples day. We have done three videos and I suppose we will continue at least with Easter and we cant wait to dance again with everyone!” You can check out their IGTV for videos.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on February 16, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @akasharabut / Happy Mardi Gras!! Terrance Williams Jr. is a 17 year old Big Chief of the Black Hawk Hunters. His suit is hand sewn and beaded by him. His mother picked the colors and all 3 of her sons (all Mardi Gras Indians) dedicated their suits to their mom.
"Mardi Gras Indians is a New Orleans tradition that is an African culture expressed in the city by African American women, men and children. It's a tradition that allows us to express our own afro centric being." Big Chief Tyrone Caspy of Mohawk Hunters and board member of the Mardi Gras Indian Council
On a typical Fat Tuesday morning the Mardi Gras Indians will dance and sing in the streets in their handmade suits. Traditionally a new suit is made every year out of beads and feathers. There are no words that can describe the feeling of seeing the Mardi Gras Indians on the streets. Their tradition and culture are what keeps the spirit of New Orleans alive.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on February 16, 2021.

Photo by @kianahayeri / Mina Rezaei, 31, decorates her cafe in preparation for Valentine's day. Though she doesn't believe in celebrating it, she says it is needed for her business, one of the most successful cafes in western Kabul.
For the past few years Valentine's Day culture, often referred to as 'the lovers' day' by Afghans, has slowly found its way into streets of Kabul. In the last 20 years, Mina and an entire generation of largely urban Afghans have grown up with all the basic liberties that the Taliban had erased during the rulings in the 90s. Now they are gripped by fear that all those rights they've gained could be at risk.
#kabul #afghanistan #valentinesday
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Kabul, Afghanistan. May be an image of 6 people.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @akasharabut / Happy Valentine's Day from Ms. Shirley of Central City, New Orleans. Today is also the eve of Lundi Gras. A major holiday weekend and a very special night here in New Orleans. Since Mardi Gras parades have been officially cancelled, locals across the city have taken the spirit of Mardi Gras and harnessed it into transforming their homes into house-floats. Ms. Shirley's block adopted the theme of Alice and Wonderland. Many of her family members including herself have been Queens for various Social Aid and Pleasure Clubs, Ms. Shirley's birthday is also on February 15th and every year she throws "The Queen Block Party" on the Sunday of Bacchus Parade. It was quite intuitive for Ms. Shirley to decorate her house in favor of the Queen of Hearts. #mardigras2021
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on February 14, 2021.

Photo by @kianahayeri / Overlooking Kookcha River in the city of Faizabad, the capital of the most northeastern province of Afghanistan. Badakhshan was the only province that the Taliban did not conquer during their rule from 1996 to 2001 and thus it was one of the few provinces of the country that witnessed little insurgency in the Afghan wars – however in the last decade Taliban insurgents have managed to attack and take control of several districts in the province. They continue to gain ground on a daily basis.

Photo by @andreabruce / Washington, D.C., government workers move trash cans on the Hill for security reasons.

Tuesday, the day before the 2021 presidential Inauguration, the city was quiet, with more street closures and an absence of the D.C. bustle one normally experiences during morning rush hour.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by Muhammad Fadli @mfimages / Yono checks the plants at a farm located on the fourth floor of a mosque in West Jakarta, Indonesia. This farm is a great example of community and space-based agriculture in a packed urban environment such as Jakarta. 

Initially, this farm was started by a few locals from the area with around $3,500 USD from a donor during the early weeks of the COVID-19 outbreak that pushed the Jakarta's government into lockdown. Since then, the farm has been growing rapidly with great results, producing various vegetables for local consumption and for sale. The profit will go to the mosque welfare fund and also to feed the farmer’s families. Currently, the farm has 15 people involved from the local community, almost all of them are informal workers.

I'm currently on assignment for a story about food security and economic impact of the pandemic in Jakarta, Indonesia. Follow me @mfimages to see more of my work.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on January 06, 2021.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @amandamustard / Happy New Year from southern Thailand, where I recently visited a chicken-adorned temple that has drawn hundreds of thousands of Thai tourists in 2020. They are visiting Wat Chedi Ai Khai in Sichon, Nakhon Si Thammarat, Thailand, to pay their respects to a statue of a legendary 9 year old boy, Ai Khai (or 'Egg Boy', pictured in images 2 and 3), to make wishes for prosperity and good luck. For many in Thailand, times of uncertainty and desperation can often be met with superstitious solutions. In stark contrast to the rest of the country during the pandemic, the Sichon area has seen a massive spike in tourism as a result of popularity of this wish-making temple. Visitors can perform a range of merit-making actions, including the purchase and donation of chicken statues, fireworks, children's toys and clothing, and food items said to be desired by the spirit of Ai Khai.

Until a new outbreak in December 2020, Thailand has largely kept COVID at bay since May with a strict response and tight border control - while cases and deaths remain low, the local economy has suffered with the loss of tourism revenue, which normally accounts for about 15% of Thailand's GDP.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on January 05, 2021.

ph_descripcion: Photos by @katieorlinsky / Outtakes and a behind the scenes shot from the Gila Gliff Dwellings National Monument in Gila, Hot Springs, New Mexico. Archeologists believe that in the late 1200s the Mogollon people used these natural caves to build interlinked permanent homes within five different cliff alcoves. Inside you can still see the remnants of rooms, windows, pottery, storage areas and even black spots on the ceiling from cooking soot. It is believed the Mogollon only resided in these structures for twenty years before abandoning the community for unknown reasons. Caves along the Gila River have been used as temporary shelters for a variety of groups of nomadic people for thousands of years. Taken on assignment for an upcoming story on New Mexico’s Gila Wilderness in @natgeo.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on December 21, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @marshallscheuttle // Sponsored by @kiamotorsusa // Eldorado Valley is situated between the Las Vegas Valley and Boulder City. Symbolic of the constant evolution of southern Nevada, Eldorado has witnessed many phases. Once a respite for Hoover Dam workers, now it is a natural playground for adventurers. Artists and creatives like Asia Jade embrace the beauty of this harsh landscape as a natural getaway in the backyard of Las Vegas. She is ecstatic to once again take to the winding Southwest roads in 2021 to renew her love of travel and bask in the vibrant energy of the desert. // Tune in to Dick Clark’s New Year’s Rockin’ Eve with Ryan Seacrest live from Times Square on ABC to learn about how the #KiaSorento road-tripped across the country to deliver the iconic 2021 New Year’s Eve numerals to Times Square Plaza—just in time for the @rockineve ball drop. #KiaNYE

ph_descripcion: Photo by @lujanag / Tierra del Fuego, Argentina. Family lunch during the annual "yerra". The "yerra" is an activity from the countryside that takes place every year. During this event, the animals are identified, counted and marked. It is one of the most outstanding traditions and usually brings together the whole family. I have been documenting the life of this family of baqueanos and field workers for several days. I was fortunate to be able to participate in several events that are meaningful to them and above all to share and get to know them. One of the most wonderful things about our work as storytellers is having the opportunity to enter these incredible worlds. Finishing these stories gives a little bit of melancholy when people make you feel part of the family.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on December 18, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @katieorlinsky / Rancher and former Catron County commissioner Hugh B. McKeen and his calf “Red” in Alma, New Mexico, located on the edge of the Gila National Forest and Wilderness. Numerous cattle ranches surround the Gila National Forest, and many maintain grazing allotments within the forest itself. McKeen told me that Red was orphaned after a wolf attacked her mother. The Mexican gray wolf, native to the region, almost went extinct until a re-introduction program began in 1992. Cattle owners are compensated for any verified wolf attack on their livestock, but the program is still extremely unpopular with local ranchers.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on December 17, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photos by Elliot Ross @elliotstudio / Across the United States and especially in the Southwest, places like Los Angeles will see a significant increase of extreme heat by the year 2050. According to UCLA scientists, downtown Los Angeles will experience 16 days over 95°F compared to today’s average of 4 days per year. While that might not seem significant to people living in hotter places, LA, like other cities with historically mild climates, were not designed to protect and shelter its citizens from these kind of temperatures. A lack of trees, a sea of asphalt, millions of automobiles and intense glare off of reflective surfaces like high-rises all contribute to the very real and sometimes lethal effects of extreme heat events.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on December 16, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @katieorlinsky / Biscuit the horse grazes during a horseback pack trip into the backcountry of New Mexico’s Gila Wilderness. In 1924 the Gila became the first designated wilderness area in the United States, thanks in large part to conservationist Aldo Leopold, who envisioned wilderness as “a continuous stretch of country preserved in its natural state, open to lawful hunting and fishing, big enough to absorb a two weeks’ pack trip, and kept devoid of roads, artificial trails, cottages, or other works of man." To this day instead of cars and roads, the Gila has horses and trails.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on December 14, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @katieorlinsky / Jill Wick, biologist and native fish program manager with the New Mexico Department of Game and Fish, uses an electrofisher to catch gila trout in Whitewater Creek along the northwest boundary of the Gila Wilderness. It is one of the few places in the world where you can catch a gila trout. I was fortunate that the creek had recently been stocked with around 1,000 young fish spawned earlier this spring and Jill was able to catch and release dozens of this iconic speckled species. Gila trout are actually relatives of Pacific salmon that evolved over time to survive the harsh high desert conditions. There existence has been threatened since the late 19th century due to the stocking of the Gila River with nonnative trout, overfishing and habitat deterioration fortunately as early as the 1920s conservation efforts to restore the species began and over the next decades Gila trout have been returned to numerous streams in New Mexico and nonnative trout have been removed.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on December 13, 2020.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @aliciavera / A woman prays outside of the Basilica de Guadalupe in Mexico City despite its closure due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Many devotees clashed with government officials who asked them to leave the premises.

Every year on December 12th, Our Lady of Guadalupe’s Feast Day, millions of pilgrims visit the site where the Virgin Mary purportedly appeared to an indigenous man on a hilltop, leaving an imprinted image on his cloak that is on display today. Our Lady of Guadalupe has become one of the most important symbols in Mexico where her image has been used to represent everything from faith, identity, motherhood and social justice. This year, the Basilica will remain closed to the public on Feast Day to avoid large crowds gathering in order to prevent the spread of COVID-19 which has claimed approximately 110,000 victims in the country. Instead, the Archdiocese of Mexico has organized a virtual pilgrimage and has launched a campaign called “Pilgrims stay home.” Despite warnings, thousands of devotees arrived ahead of its closure showing an act of faith and devotion that not even the pandemic can stop.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on December 12, 2020.

Photo by @aliciavera / Employees of the Basilica de Guadalupe light approximately 15,000 candles left by pilgrims ahead of its closure due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The candles are meant as a symbol of their presence.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @katieorlinsky / Hello from the Gila Wilderness (pronounced Hee-La), where I recently returned from a horseback pack trip into the backcountry with writer Peter Gwin and Overheard at National Geographic podcast producer Brian Gutierrez. The Gila is the first designated wilderness area in the United States. This milestone of American conservation was created in 1924 thanks in large part to Aldo Leopold, a philosopher, writer, forester, and outdoor enthusiast considered by many to be the father of wildlife ecology. Leopold envisioned wilderness as a place to be protected both for, and from, humans, “Wilderness is the one kind of playground which mankind cannot build to order…. I contrived to get the Gila headwaters withdrawn as a wilderness area, to be kept as pack country, free from additional roads, ‘forever.'” Meanwhile the Gila’s history began long before Aldo Leopold, and the region’s future is far more complex than he could have ever imagined. I’ll be sharing a sneak peek over the next few days!
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on December 11, 2020.

Photo by @aliciavera / Ana Rita Ruedas Arana, 64, poses for a portrait at the Basilica de Guadalupe in Mexico City. She has been visiting the Basilica for the last 14 years from Jalisco, Mexico.

Every year on December 12th, Our Lady of Guadalupe’s Feast Day, millions of pilgrims visit the site where the Virgin Mary purportedly appeared to an indigenous man on a hilltop. Our Lady of Guadalupe has become one of the most important symbols in Mexico where her image has been used to represent everything from faith, identity, motherhood and social justice. This year, the Basilica will remain closed to the public on Feast Day to avoid large crowds gathering in order to prevent the spread of Covid-19 which has claimed approximately 110,000 victims in the country. Instead, the Archdiocese of Mexico has organized a virtual pilgrimage and has launched a campaign called “Pilgrims stay home.” Despite warnings, thousands of devotees are arriving ahead of its closure showing in an act of faith and devotion that not even the pandemic can stop. "The Holy Virgin, she heals us, saves us, she helps us all. I've asked her save the world because life is a gift."
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on December 10, 2020.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @maddiemcgarvey / Linda Alexander waited in a food giveaway line for more than five hours outside the Dunlow Community Center, in Dunlow, West Virginia. After picking up the food and bringing it home, Linda came back to the center as a volunteer, working with her daughter, Christina, and grandchildren until the last car passed through the line, which was after sundown. “I don’t know what we’d do without them there,” Linda says about Bill and Addie Likens, who run the community center and have been providing food for thousands of families each month since March, when the COVID-19 pandemic hit. “This community would be hurting.”

@FeedingAmerica is the nation’s largest hunger-relief organization with a network of 200 food banks and 60,000 food pantries and meal programs that together provide food to more than 40 million people per year. Learn more at feedingamerica.org/FeedTheLove. #FeedTheLove
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on December 01, 2020.

Photo by Brian Otieno @storitellah / Fishermen on the shores of Lake Naivasha sort their morning catch, preparing the fish for sale to traders in Naivasha town and beyond.
Lake Naivasha is a shallow freshwater lake situated in the eastern Rift Valley of Kenya, about 80 km north of Nairobi. It is ranked third behind Lake Victoria and Lake Turkana in the total volume of fish landed and provides livelihoods, water, and food to thousands who live on its shores. Even though naturally subject to considerable fluctuations in water level, heavy rainfall from February to June 2020 caused massive flooding and submerged private properties of hundreds of families and businesses located along the edges of the lake. In May this year, lake Naivasha reached its highest level since 1932. As the water levels continue to rise, cases of human-wildlife conflict are spiraling and fishermen are living in fear of being displaced and losing their only source of income in the coming months. #lakenaivasha #fishermen #rainfall
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on November 30, 2020.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @nataliekeyssar / Luz Rodriguez poses for a portrait in a street studio I set up outside a food distribution event at CENTI, a local church in Queens that passes out around 500 boxes of groceries to those in need every week. Rather than focusing on the winding lines of those waiting for food in the wake of the pandemic, I wanted to create a space to connect with the people I was photographing, and hear more about their situations. Those who wanted to could come over for a portrait and an interview during the hours they spent waiting for food. Luz is currently out of work and so is her whole family. She lives with her mother, her children and her brother. She says she’s very grateful for all the help she’s received in the midst of such a difficult situation. She worked for an 87-year-old man, taking care of him for the last 15 years. He got COVID-19 and died two weeks later, and since then she’s been without work.

Queens was was hit very hard by the first wave of the pandemic in NYC in the spring. The community is largely essential workers, from delivery drivers to cooks, cleaners, and construction workers, many of whom did not have the option to work from home. With population density and many living in tight quarters, infection rates in the area were very high. Tragic losses of life were compounded by the economic fallout, as many lost their jobs or had their incomes cut, and a continued high cost of living in the city. Now Queens is wrestling with rampant food insecurity. Families struggling to make ends meet are finding innovative ways to participate in the informal economy and depending on food donations to get by, and churches, government programs, and community organizations are mobilizing to help in every way they can.

Follow me @nataliekeyssar for more stories about resilience in hard times.

@FeedingAmerica is the nation’s largest hunger-relief organization with a network of 200 food banks and 60,000 food pantries and meal programs that together provide food to more than 40 million people per year. Learn more at feedingamerica.org/FeedTheLove. #FeedTheLove
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on November 27, 2020. May be an image of 1 person.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by Elliot Ross @elliotstudio / In Los Angeles, and in many other American cities, researchers led by Jeremy Hoffman at The Science Museum of Virginia, are finding a direct correlation between the historic practice of redlining and a significant increase in surface temperatures that residents face in day to day life. Tree cover and the essential shade it provides is one critical factor that results in this heat disparity. With extreme temperatures set to take off in the coming decades, it’s important to recognize that heat related fatalities will disproportionately impact minority and lower income neighborhoods across the United States.
·
Photo no.1 - Underneath the iconic Hollywood sign sits the affluent neighborhood that’s aptly named Hollywoodland. With it’s dense tree cover, this neighborhood enjoys an average surface temperature that’s over 5°F cooler than the rest of Los Angeles.
·
Photo no.2 - This was taken above the formerly “A” graded neighborhood of Los Feliz that has a leafy tree canopy with 15 percent cover, and as a result, is on average nearly 4°F cooler than the rest of the city. These hills above downtown are very affluent and have a low minority population.
·
Photo no.3 - An aerial view of nearby Angelino Heights, which was formerly redlined. While sitting at an elevation similar to the previous 2 neighborhoods, a lack of trees and high volume of concrete and asphalt surfaces makes this neighborhood nearly 6°F warmer than Hollywoodland.
·
Taken on assignment for @natgeo
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on November 23, 2020.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by Rashod Taylor @rashodtaylorphoto / It is such an honor and privilege to photograph my family for @natgeo to tell their story. I use the wet plate collodion process to bridge the past to the present. Black military families understand the complicated history in America but at the same time are willing to make the ultimate sacrifice to protect and serve. The first image is of my cousin Staff Sergeant Vanessa Lewis Williams of the Georgia Army National Guard as she sits for a tintype portrait at the Georgia Army National Guard Readiness Center in Macon, GA she and her sister Combat Veteran Valerie E. Lewis share their stories on being deployed, serving in the same unit and their experience as women in the military. Follow @rashodtaylorphoto for more images and keep an eye out for the upcoming story in @natgeo

(2) Portrait of Combat Veteran Valerie E. Lewis sitting for a tintype portrait at her parents home in Griffin, GA.

#onassigment #militaryfamily #usa #georgia
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on November 23, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photos by Elliot Ross @elliotstudio / Shade is a precious commodity in Los Angeles, especially for commuters and people experiencing homelessness. While famous for its sun, the heat in Los Angeles can be fatal for those that can’t escape it in time. In most years in the U.S., heat kills more people than hurricanes, tornadoes or floods. Unless, more is done to mitigate heat island effects and increase shade cover, this trend is certain to become worse in the coming years. According to UCLA scientists, by the year 2050, downtown Los Angeles will experience 16 days over 95°F compared to today’s average of 4 days per year. In a city that was designed for moderate temperatures, this is a cause for concern, especially for marginalized populations.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on November 18, 2020.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @kiliiiyuyan / As a photographer, it’s one of my greatest pleasures to travel with a brilliant writer while working on a story. We get a chance to learn more about our story and also have the writer distract the people we’re photographing for a critical moment.

Here are some behind-the-scenes as Charles Mann and I work with Indigenous Americans across the United States for an upcoming story on the sovereignty of Native nations. From left to right: Photographing the chiefs of the five biggest Oklahoma tribes, talking to a Yurok fire ecologist, picking white corn with a Mohawk elder, driving through a recently burned forest in Northern CA. Follow me @kiliiiyuyan, for more from the Indigenous perspective. Photo of Kiliii Yuyan by @christiantoews #nativeamericanheritage #behindthescenes #onassignment
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on November 18, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Luján Agusti @lujanag / Detail of the eye of a mare called "Lluvia,” which means rain in Spanish. She is a very special horse with one albino eye and one brown eye. Horses like this are commonly called "zarcos." I am currently working on a story with a family of old settlers of Tierra del Fuego who are dedicated to the countryside and horses. They are a family of "baqueanos,” those who are openers and knowers of the roads. #onassignment #tierradelfuego #horses
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on November 18, 2020.

Photos by Elliot Ross @elliotstudio / In Los Angeles, and in many other American cities, researchers led by Jeremy Hoffman at The Science Museum of Virginia, are finding a direct correlation between the historic practice of redlining and a significant increase in surface temperatures that residents face in day to day life. Tree cover and the essential shade it provides is one critical factor that results in this heat disparity. With extreme temperatures set to take off in the coming decades, it’s important to recognize that heat related fatalities will disproportionately impact minority and lower income neighborhoods across the United States. Take a look at these two aerials shot last week.
·
Photo no. 1 - Here we’re above the formerly redlined neighborhood of Wellington Heights near downtown that has a low tree canopy coverage at 5 percent and has a minority population of 99%. This area, as with many formerly redlined zones, was subjected to large infrastructural projects - in this case the Pomona Freeway.
·
Photo no. 2 - This was taken above the formerly “A” graded neighborhood of Los Feliz that has a leafy tree canopy with 15 percent cover. These hills above downtown are very affluent and have a low minority population.
·
Taken on assignment for @natgeo
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on November 17, 2020.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by Cesar Rodriguez @cesar_rodriguezb / Documenting this year’s Day of the Dead in Mexico during the COVID-19 pandemic was something like never before. There were empty and gray cemeteries, without the aromas of marigolds and incense, without mariachis or ”Norteños.” La Catrina (the death) was alone in her domain and the very same pandemic seemed to enlarge her, to make her gigantic.

Ironically, when José Guadalupe Posada, creator of La Catrina, died in Tepito, he died alone and forgotten, his remains were forgotten in a common grave.

“Death, as José Guadalupe Posada taught us, is the art of passing away to a better life,” said writer Juan Villoro.

Taken on assignment for @natgeo and @icrc.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on November 13, 2020.

Photo by Cesar Rodriguez @cesar_rodriguezb / Andres and Alan wait inside their truck while their family mourns their grandfather, Eduardo Martinez, who they said died in a robbery. He was buried in Mexico’s Xico-Chalco cemetery, in one of the areas set aside for pandemic victims. “Like a painting, we will be erased. Like a flower, We will dry up here on earth. Like plumed vestments of the precious bird, that precious bird with the agile neck, we will come to an end.”–Nezahualcóyotl, ruler of Texcoco(1402-1472).
Taken on assignment for @natgeo and @icrc

ph_descripcion: Photo by Brian Otieno @storitellah / Fishermen at Lake Naivasha, a fresh body of water in Kenya's Great Rift Valley, check their nets in the early hours. Lake Naivasha is ranked third behind Lake Victoria, and Lake Turkana in the total volume of fish landed and provides livelihoods, water, and food to thousands who live on its shores and beyond. From February to June 2020, heavy rainfall caused widespread flooding in many lakes in East Africa. These calamities coincided with the COVID-19 pandemic and affected ecosystems and livelihoods. Especially vulnerable were communities such as fishermen, who depend on fisheries as their only source of income. The measures instituted by the Kenyan government to reduce the spread of COVID-19 further aggravated this situation. The dusk to dawn curfew and the cessation of movement to cities, which are the main fish markets such as Nairobi, disrupted the fish supply chain. It resulted in a loss of employment and income for many already disadvantaged fishermen. #lakenaivasha #kenya #fishermen
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on November 12, 2020.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @kiliiiyuyan / Not all fire is terrible and destructive. From what the Karuk and Yurok people of Northern California tell me, 100 years of fire suppression in the US has made Americans afraid of fire. Yet even today, the tribes of NorCal practice ‘good fire’, which is generally low-intensity prescribed burning, making the landscape more suitable for acorn-bearing oaks, deer, and even salmon. At the same time it removes all the hundred years of unburnt fuel waiting to turn into the next raging wildfire.

Jason Reed, a Karuk tribal member, does a cultural burn near Somes Bar, CA, using his traditional knowledge of conditions to aid fire-resistant species like this oak, while taking out young firs that would eventually shade them out. His family has been practicing fire since the last ice age, meaning that enormous swaths of California have been managed by fire for over 13,000 years. Follow me @kiliiiyuyan, for more about Indigenous technology. #karuk #goodfire #california #wildfire
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on November 10, 2020.

Photo by Cesar Rodriguez @cesar_rodriguezb / Family members of Eduardo Martinez mourn his death. His family said he died in a robbery. He was buried in Mexico’s Xico-Chalco cemetery, in one of the areas set aside for pandemic victims.
Before doing this project, as inspiration, I read Octavio Paz’s book “Labyrinth of Solitude,” in which he writes about death. “The cult of life, if it really is deep and total, is also the cult of death. Both are inseparable. A civilization that denies death ends up denying life.”
Taken on assignment for @natgeo and @icrc
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on November 09, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @nicholesobecki / An Islamic cemetery spans the base of one side of Jebel Barkal, a small mountain that the ancient Kushites and Egyptians alike believed was the home of the god Amun. The legendary Kingdom of Kush, with its capitals in what is now northern Sudan, helped define the political and cultural landscape of northeastern Africa for more than a thousand years. At their height, from about 760 B.C. to 650 B.C., five Kushite kings ruled all of Egypt from Nubia to the Mediterranean Sea, embarking on ambitious building programs up and down the Nile. Yet past archaeologists have offhandedly—and inaccurately—dismissed the Kushite kings as racially inferior, and their accomplishments as an inheritance of older Egyptian traditions. #sudan #history #identity
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Jebel Barkal.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @daniele_volpe / Rosa Marina Apen (left), and Feliciana Curruchic Velasquez pray in front of the altar they have made to honor the memory of Encarnación Apen Curruchic, Rosa Marina's brother and Feliciana's son, who was kidnapped in 1982 when he was 18.

In Guatemala, and in other countries of the region, the "Day of the Dead" celebrations are deeply felt. The tradition consists of visiting the tombs of loved ones during November 1 and 2. Generally, families bring food and drinks as a way to "share" that with the relatives that died. The tradition is a happy occasion, accompanied by music and surrounded by food street vendors. This year, due to COVID-19, Guatemalan authorities decided to restrict access to the cemeteries to avoid crowds.

After the 36-year-long Guatemalan Civil War (1960-96), according to the UN, Guatemala counts more than 200,000 victims and 45,000 missing people including civilians. After the peace accords, human rights organizations started an effort to find the remains of the "desaparecidos." Chimaltenango was one of the departments of the country hardest hit by the state repression and has well-known atrocities that happened in San Juan Comalapa.

In 2003, forensic anthropologists started digging in a plot of land where an army camp once stood. They found the remains of 220 people in several mass graves. People that were kidnapped by the Guatemalan Army, executed and buried inside that army camp. After DNA analysis, 172 of them are still unidentified.

Taken on assignment for @natgeo and @icrc.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on November 08, 2020.

Photo by @daniele_volpe / Maria Saturnina Us Alvarez (center), accompanied by her daughters Sara Tuyuc Us (left) and Rosario Tuyuc Us, leads a Maya ceremony at her home to honor the loved ones that passed away during Day of the Dead celebrations. The family lost four members during the Guatemalan Civil War. Because of the COVID-19 pandemic they were unable to travel to visit their loved ones’ grave sites. They feel that the pandemic doesn't change how they connect with the deceased since they are used to practicing Mayan spirituality at home.
