Photo by César Rodríguez @cesar_rodriguezb. /
A young boy with a bouquet of marigolds waits for his mother outside a bakery as she buys offerings for Día de los Muertos, or the Day of the Dead, in San Andres Mixquic, Mexico. The yellow flower is strung over headstones and laid on altars, thought to represent the brightness of the sun illuminating a path for the spirits to return to Earth from Mictlán, the underworld. This year, the usually festive traditions around Dia de los Muertos were largely celebrated in private, but the souls of the dead aren’t just in cemeteries, as Mexican Poet Jaime Sabines said “To die is to be everywhere in secret. Because with death you walk; we live with her since we are born.”
Taken on assignment for @natgeo and @icrc
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on November 06, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @nicholesobecki / Every Friday at the Hamid el-Nil mosque in Omdurman, groups of sufis come together to engage in the dhikr, or the absolute absorption in worship during which prayers, dances and spins may be repeated with enough fervour to induce a trance. Sufism is the mystical element of Islam, with sufis first coming to Sudan in the sixteenth century. Sudan has one of the largest Sufi communities in the world, and a popular saying goes: "If there is a family in Sudan that does not have at least one Sufi member, it is not Sudanese." The dervishes also played an important role in last year's revolution, joining the protests in what some consider to be a turning point. Many victims of the protests are buried here in the cemetery at Hamid el-Nil mosque. #sudan #history #identity
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Omdurmanامدرمان.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Eliana Aponte @eliaponte / Karla González Toro (c) arrives to a bazaar known as “La Cuevita" newly named "Feria de Monterrey" in the municipality of San Miguel de Padron, Havana, Cuba. It is a place where you can find all kinds of products at very low prices compared to state-run stores. Karla wanted to buy shoes. After waiting for more than two hours in line with many people waiting to enter, she didn't find what she wanted, but bought flip-flops and earrings for her birthday party. I am documenting for @natgeo the life of a Cuban family that does not have a monetary income from abroad and is struggling to survive in the middle of a pandemic.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Havana, Cuba.

This cemetery was built in the plot of land of a former army camp during the civil war and where forensic anthropologists found 220 human remains. Now the place serves as a memorial to honor the victims of state violence.

In Guatemala, and in other countries of the region, the "Day of the Dead" celebrations are deeply felt. The tradition consists of visiting the tombs of loved ones during November 1 and 2. Generally, families bring food and drinks as a way to "share" that with the relatives that died. The tradition is a happy occasion, accompanied by music and surrounded by food street vendors. This year, due to COVID-19, Guatemalan authorities decided to restrict access to the cemeteries to avoid crowds.

After the 36-year-long Guatemalan Civil War (1960-96), according to the UN, Guatemala counts more than 200,000 victims and 45,000 missing people including civilians. After the peace accords, human rights organizations started an effort to find the remains of the "desaparecidos." Chimaltenango was one of the departments of the country hardest hit by the state repression and has well-known atrocities that happened in San Juan Comalapa.

In 2003, forensic anthropologists started digging in a plot of land where an army camp once stood. They found the remains of 220 people in several mass graves. People that were kidnapped by the Guatemalan Army, executed and buried inside that army camp. After DNA analysis, 172 of them are still unidentified.

Photo by David Guttenfelder @dguttenfelder / Ralph Gaines and Angelo Austin argue with a Trump supporter protesting the validity of the presidential vote count outside the TCF Center, where votes are being tallied, in Detroit, Michigan.

Austin said, "My ancestors helped to build this city. These people think I'm wrong for not wanting to support the president who is a racist and a sexist. They are out here without a mask and not social distancing because they don't care about anyone but themselves."

"The votes were counted," Gaines added. "We should all be coming together right now. We need a president who leads and who takes care of everybody. He's just causing chaos."
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on November 05, 2020.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by Christopher Gregory-Rivera @cgregoryphoto / Fulton County officials count ballots on Thursday morning at the State Farm Arena in Atlanta, Georgia. Fulton County includes most of Atlanta, and the last 140,000 mail-in ballots are likely to have a big impact on which candidate wins the state—and possibly the election. 

Two days after the presidential election, the winner is still up in the air. President Trump has set in motion a series of legal challenges in the states where preliminary results show him losing to former Vice President Joe Biden. The race is likely to come down to a handful of states, including Georgia, Arizona, Nevada, and Pennsylvania.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on November 05, 2020.

Photo by @gregkahn / Protesters with Extinction Rebellion DC gather at Union Station to march through the streets of Washington, D.C., today. The group stopped in front of FOX News’s D.C. offices to hold a rally demanding climate action.

The march's organizers, ShutDownDC and Extinction Rebellion DC, said President Donald Trump has put the world at further risk by exiting the Paris Agreement and deregulating other environmental protections. These groups also used the uncertainty of last night's election results to call for all votes to be counted and to adopt the Green New Deal in government.

Photo by @nataliekeyssar / On the day after the election, activists from Action Together NEPA gathered at a small rally across the street from the Lackawanna County Courthouse in Scranton, Pennsylvania. Mary Del Plato, who came to the protest with her daughter and grandchildren, watched the speakers anxiously as her granddaughter Aubrielle Maldonado hugged her. “It's very important that we get every single vote counted and get the right president in office,” she said. When asked if she thinks Joe Biden will win Pennsylvania, she said, “That's my dream.”

Protesters demanded that every vote be counted, in response to threats from President Trump to try to stop the counting of mail-in ballots in the hotly contested swing state. A handful of speakers talked about the importance of honoring the voting process and about hot-button issues like the pandemic and the economy. The mood was somber.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on November 04, 2020.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by Christopher Gregory-Rivera @cgregoryphoto / Puerto Rican Trump supporter Michael Rodriguez near the entrance to the polling station on Election Day at the Robert Guevara Community Center in Kissimmee, Florida. After twice voting for Democratic President Barack Obama, today he's voting for Trump. “A lot of people don’t like the president, but I love that man. I love how he talks, I love how he tells you the truth whether you like it or not. All the others are politicians, they lie for you to believe them,” he said.

Azalea Park and Kissimmee are among Latino strongholds in Orlando. The Puerto Rican population saw a bump in size after roughly 50,000 people fled the aftermath of Hurricane Maria in 2017 and settled in the Orlando area—which had already counted upwards of 380,000 Puerto Ricans.

Anecdotal evidence suggests that although the Puerto Rican community largely has voted Democratic, a segment is "purpling" as older-generation migrants vote for more conservative and religious values. Some consider the Latino vote in Florida to be one of the main deciding factors in toss-up counties and regions in the 2020 election.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on November 03, 2020.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by Christopher Gregory-Rivera @cgregoryphoto / A voter completes a ballot in a booth at the polling site at Christ the King Episcopal Church in Azalea Park, Florida. The state has seen record numbers of early voting and mail-in ballots this year, which is likely to have the state's highest ever voter turnout.

Azalea Park and Kissimmee are among the Latino strongholds in the Orlando area. The Puerto Rican population saw a bump in size after roughly 50,000 people fled the aftermath of Hurricane Maria in 2017 and settled in the region.

Anecdotal evidence suggests that although the Puerto Rican community has largely voted for Democrats, this segment of the population is purpling because the older generation of migrants are voting in line with more conservative and religious values. Some believe the Latino vote in Florida will be one of the main deciding factors in toss-up counties for the 2020 election.

The Central and South American immigrant communities have been impacted by President Trump’s aggressive immigration and deportation policies, according to Azalea Park community leader and priest Jose Rodriguez.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on November 03, 2020.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @andreabruce / People who joined a march to the polls Saturday and were pepper-sprayed and arrested by local police in Graham, North Carolina, discuss the trauma of that day. While they were talking, a truck drove past and a man yelled out, "N------, go home!" "What year are we living in?" asked Monica Gibbs.

The Alamance County Sheriff's Office has a history of racial profiling and tension around racial issues. The Alamance County Courthouse, where people were arrested and pepper-sprayed, has a controversial statue of a Confederate soldier prominently displayed outside.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on November 03, 2020.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by Christopher Gregory-Rivera @cgregoryphoto / Ocoee, Florida, is the site of the most violent incidents of voter suppression in the history of the United States. A century ago, on Election Day in 1920, two affluent Black men from Ocoee, Mose Norman and Julius "July" Perry, organized the Black community to vote and were brutally attacked by the Ku Klux Klan and local law enforcement. This incident led to the deaths of Perry and anywhere from three to 50 members of the Black community, as well as two Klansmen. After the massacre, the Black community was ousted from the town and their lands were confiscated. For the next 65 years Ocoee became a sundown town, where Black people were banned after sunset by threat of violence.

(1) George Oliver, the first Black commissioner of Ocoee. (2) Narisse Spicer's great-grandparents fled Ocoee during the massacre and resettled in Apopka, Florida. “We are 100 years later into this, and we are still dealing with voter intimidation and voter suppression and issues of race and violence. It is definitely time, and well overdue, to start thinking about how we can change the future so that future generations don’t experience the same thing,” she said. (3) Pam Grady stands in front of July Perry’s former land. “We are not mourning the death of July Perry; we are celebrating his bravery,” she told me. “These people paved the way for us to have the right to vote.” (4) J. Carl Devine's grandparents fled Ocoee after the massacre. “When one group is trying to suppress another group from voting, that’s when the whole Constitution is then in jeopardy. When one person is denied, all of us are denied.” (5) Jacqueline Perry Blalock (left) and Sha’ron McWhite are both descendants of July Perry. “Our ancestors laid the foundation of the importance of [expressing] our right to vote, and we need to continue that on so that our future generations will have a better opportunity at an equal life. That is what I would like to see,” McWhite said. (6) The city maintains the site of the former African-American cemetery in Ocoee, but it has yet to acquire the land and create a space for reflection as members of the Black community have proposed.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on November 03, 2020.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @nataliekeyssar / A man became agitated and started yelling when the polls opened late in Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania, today. He complained, saying everyone had jobs to go to and kids at home. Eventually the constable came out to try to calm him down, which resulted in a short argument. Many voters in the line said they shared the man’s frustration.

Voters lined up before 7 a.m. on Election Day at Wilkes-Barre's Toyota SportsPlex located at 38 Coal Street, a nod to the industry that once drove this region. Most people waited quietly as the polls opened a bit late on the frigid morning, although a few voters complained of the delays and others of their original polling places being closed without warning. Wilkes-Barre is a contested city in Luzerne County, an important swing county in Pennsylvania.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on November 03, 2020.

Photo by @andreabruce / Daniel Jorge, 10, and Abisai Jorge, 8, stand in their church, Iglesia Apostolica de la Fe Un Cristo Jesus, in a former gas station, in Newton Grove, North Carolina.

Their sister (not pictured) said their town is very small and a food desert, with less than 100 people in her graduating class. "Most people here are farmers—cotton and tobacco," she said. "We sometimes help with field work during the summer."

They said their grandparents moved here from Mexico and had 15 children and now have 56 grandchildren.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on November 03, 2020.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by Christopher Gregory-Rivera @cgregoryphoto / The Cruz Rodriguez family is photographed at friend Barbara Ortiz’s house, in Kissimmee, Florida. From left: Juan Luis, Camila, Aida, and Loise. The family left Puerto Rico after Hurricane Maria and have faced an uphill battle to gain a footing in the states. Yet they've found a community of supportive fellow Puerto Ricans, like Barbara.

When asked if he had faith in the candidates' ability to deliver on campaign promises, Juan Luis said, “We have to see to believe.” Aida answered, “You are talking to a marriage that went through a hurricane, earthquakes, is going through COVID, that came to Florida, and all of a sudden our daughters faced serious health issues—we are survivors. Don’t play me. Don’t talk pretty—act.”

Later in our conversation, she told me, “I want change, I don’t want a circus. I want somebody who will talk to me with integrity.”

Kissimmee and the surrounding area are Latino strongholds in Orlando. The mostly Puerto Rican population saw a sizable bump after roughly 50,000 people fled the aftermath of Hurricane Maria in 2017 and settled in the Orlando area—which had already counted upwards of 380,000 Puerto Ricans.

Anecdotal evidence suggests that although the Puerto Rican community has largely voted Democratic, a segment of the population is "purpling" from the votes of an older generation of migrants with more conservative and religious values. Some consider the Latino vote in Florida to be one of the main deciding factors in toss-up counties and regions in this election.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on November 02, 2020.

Allen, who volunteered at the polls for the past 14 years, said that the most important issue of the 2020 election is the COVID-19 pandemic. "People are dying and losing their jobs. And families aren't able to come together like they are used to. And the division. The pandemic shouldn't be a partisan issue. Humans are humans and we should all care about one another."

ph_descripcion: Photo by Graham Dickie @instadickie / MOVE Texas communications director Charlie Bonner before a drive-in "get out the vote" concert that MOVE hosted in Houston, Texas, on October 29. Headlined by rapper Bun B, the concert took place next to a 24-hour polling place, the first of its kind in Texas. MOVE is a nonpartisan organization focused on galvanizing youth voters. “This is a generation very in touch with our values," Bonner said. "Now we are at a point where we are taking action on our values at the ballot box. And so whether it be racial justice and police violence or acting on climate change, acting to prevent campus sexual assault—all these sorts of things [our generation] has really led on."
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on November 02, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Christopher Gregory-Rivera @cgregoryphoto / Joy Rees hands out McMuffins to early voters in Ocoee, Florida. She and her husband came out to show their support for voters. Ocoee is the site of one of the most violent incidents of voter suppression in U.S. history. A century ago, on Election Day in 1920, two affluent Black men from Ocoee, Mose Norman and Julius "July" Perry, organized the Black community to vote—and were brutally attacked by the Klu Klux Klan and local law enforcement. This led to the death of Perry and around 30 members of the Black community and two Klansmen. For the next 65 years it was a "sundown town," so called because Black people seen in the town after dark would have been endangered and were effectively barred from living in the town. When I asked Joy about this, she said, “It is frightening it is part of our history, but we have to overcome it. Being nice to people is one way to overcome it.”
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on November 01, 2020.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by Christopher Gregory-Rivera @cgregoryphoto / Malik Low, from Orlando, was drawn to vote in nearby in Ocoee, Florida, on the 100th anniversary of the Ocoee massacre, one of the most violent incidents of voter suppression in U.S. history. On Election Day in 1920 two affluent Black men from Ocoee, Mose Norman and Julius "July" Perry, organized the Black community to vote—and were brutally attacked by the Klu Klux Klan and local law enforcement. The incident led to the death of Perry and around 30 members of the Black community and two Klansmen. For the next 65 years it was known as a "sundown town," a place where Black people would have been endangered at night and were effectively barred from living in the town.
“There are literally people who lost their lives trying to vote, so I feel like 25-30 minutes [waiting] is nothing in comparison to what some people back then went through,” Low said.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on November 01, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @nataliekeyssar/ Last night, Our Lady of Sorrows Church in Corona, Queens created a haunted house in their parking lot to raise money for their after-school and other educational programs. Families from the neighborhood were led through the spooky scene by youth volunteers wearing skull masks over their regular face masks, and at the end kids were given candy and families were offered boxes of groceries for those in need. For many of the children who attend the Catholic school and after-school programs at the church, school lunches and after-school meals are a crucial stop gap against food insecurity as the economy struggles amid the pandemic.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on October 31, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photos by Timothy O’Connell @timothyoconnell_  / Workers at Blue Harvest Fisheries help guide Acadian Redfish onto a conveyor belt after the fish is offloaded from a boat in New Bedford, MA. ph_descripcion:
Photo by César Rodríguez @cesar_rodriguezb / Monica González standing at Torre Latinoamérica’s view point in Mexico City, Mexico. In the coming days I will be documenting how the COVID-19 pandemic will affect Day of The Dead celebrations in Mexico City On assignment with @natgeo and @icrc . Festivities and parades are cancelled. Cemeteries are closed so people can’t visit and honor their dead loved ones.
To understand more the relationship between Mexicans and death, writer Octavio Paz said “Our cult of death is also a cult of life, in the same way that love is a hunger for life and a longing for death.”
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on October 27, 2020.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @amandamustard / In early September, nearly 200 elephants in Surin, Thailand’s ‘elephant capital’, traveled by foot from around Baan Na Klang to the local elephant hospital for an annual medical checkup. Measurements and various samples were taken from each elephant, and supplements and medications were given for the elephants’ health. If any elephants were unable to travel due to sickness or being in musth (a period when the males are ‘in heat’, causing a dangerous spike in testosterone that requires them to be separated from other elephants and people), the vets went directly to the homes to perform the checkups.

Thailand has an estimated 3800 elephants, many of which were born and raised in captivity. Unfortunately, due to the lack of land and other dangers posed by human development, it is rarely a realistic or safe option to rewild the elephants, creating a need for them to be in the custody of humans for their lifetimes. Tourism is the main source of income to sustain the elephants, and amid the pandemic, this revenue has almost disappeared. (Thailand’s elephant tourism industry is sustained only through constant breeding of its captive population.)

In Surin, the Elephant Kingdom Project is one of the only elephant support programs of its kind in Thailand, providing monthly stipends, food, and health support to 200 registered elephants so that owners don’t turn to forms of income that risk the elephants’ welfare, such as street begging or illegal logging. In Surin and elsewhere in the country, harsh methods—bullhooks and chains—are used to train and control elephants.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on October 27, 2020.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by Luján Agusti @lujanag / Tierra del Fuego, Argentina. Vedrana plays with a one month old colt, while his mother is being cared for during the anual "yerra". The "yerra" is an event during which various tasks of the countryside are carried out. Among them, the animals are marked, vaccinated, dewormed, or given medication and cures in case they need them. Vedrana's family is an old settler of the island of Tierra del Fuego and is dedicated to the countryside and horses. During the next few weeks I will be working with them and learning more about their lifestyle. I will also be exploring how the pandemic has affected life in the countryside, even in contexts as isolated as ours.
#tierradelfuego #countryside #natgeo
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on October 27, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @nataliekeyssar/ Ciria helps her daughter Katya with her online math class over breakfast on Friday morning in their apartment in Queens. Like so many other children, Katya's school has gone virtual due to the pandemic, and like so many other parents, Ciria had to shut down her business, complicating the family's schedule and budget considerably. Despite all of this, Ciria does everything she can to make it work. They can't afford a computer, so Katya takes her classes on a smart phone. Katya translates word problems from English to Spanish for her mom, and Ciria draws elaborate diagrams and enlists household objects to make the numbers come to life for her daughter. They are both patient, through frozen screens and language barriers, drinking nutrition supplement tea that Ciria used to sell at her shop and now uses to feed her family during these lean times. Katya's face lights up each time her mom helps guide her to the correct answer. "I love to study, " she says. "I want to study forever."
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on October 25, 2020.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by Bethany Mollenkof @fancybethany / For decades, Black citizens in Tulsa have demanded the city investigate whether victims of a race massacre a century ago are buried in unmarked graves in Oaklawn Cemetery. For the past few years, Rev. Robert Turner (pictured) has been one of the loudest voices among the dedicated advocates for finding the lost and demanding reparations for their descendants. Now at least 11 bodies have been found in an unmarked mass grave. While more investigation is needed to verify their identities, finding this grave felt like a complicated moment of relief, rage, and grief for the community.

The 1921 Tulsa Race Massacre remains one of the worst incidents of racial violence in U.S. history, and also one of the least known. News reports were largely suppressed, despite the fact that hundreds of people were killed and thousands left homeless when white rioters attacked the predominantly Black Greenwood District, an affluent area of Tulsa once called Black Wall Street.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on October 23, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @nataliekeyssar/ Bety Fandiño poses for a portrait outside a weekly free food distribution at a church in Jackson Heights, Queens. The pandemic has been difficult for everyone, but its been especially tough on this community composed largely of immigrant essential workers, where infection levels were among the highest in New York. A lot of families have been struggling to put food on the table, and church food pantries like this one help to make sure that people dont have to choose between buying food or paying rent. While photographing people waiting, sometimes for hours, for food, I've been bringing my polaroid camera along to snap a few behind the scenes pictures. I find that creating immediate, physical photographs can help make the process of documenting these stories feel a lot more collaborative and interactive. The polaroids often don’t make it into my final projects, but i love their beautiful imperfections and the conversations i have while making them. Beth told me that when the virus hit, she lost her job as a nanny in Manhattan, and since then started coming to the food pantry, but she kept her outlook positive, and very grateful for the food pantry. "I'm unemployed, but I haven't had to go without food. I can keep moving forward." Despite the difficult situations that brought them there, I noticed that nearly everyone I spoke to that day, like Bety, wanted to focus on the positive, always expressing gratitude and almost never complaining about these hard times.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on October 20, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photos by @nicholesobecki / It was hot, and there was a sense of anxiety in the air. Hundreds of people sat with their families in makeshift tents, or took shelter in this school, after they lost their home to mass flooding in Sudan’s capital of Khartoum. Over 800,000 have been affected and more than 120 people have died in the worst floods in decades. The women here meeting with displaced families are not from an NGO, but rather a neighborhood resistance committee who call themselves the “Kandakes of the Southern Belt.” During the revolution, grassroots ‘resistance committees’ like the “Kandakes” organized protests to remove former President Omar al-Bashir, but today have become more established and expanded their reach, working to support not only flood victims, but those impacted by the economic crisis, the COVID-19 pandemic, and beyond. “Women have always been strong throughout our history, like the ancient queens,” Zainab Hassan, from the “Kandakes” told me. “And now we’re leading again.” #sudan #history #identity
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on October 19, 2020.

Hundreds of people sat with their families in makeshift tents, or took shelter in this school, after they lost their home to mass flooding in Sudan’s capital of Khartoum. Over 800,000 have been affected and more than 120 people have died in the worst floods in decades. The women here meeting with displaced families are not from an NGO, but rather a neighborhood resistance committee who call themselves the “Kandakes of the Southern Belt.” During the revolution, grassroots ‘resistance committees’ like the “Kandakes” organized protests to remove former President Omar al-Bashir, but today have become more established and expanded their reach, working to support not only flood victims, but those impacted by the economic crisis, the COVID-19 pandemic, and beyond. “Women have always been strong throughout our history, like the ancient queens,” Zainab Hassan, from the “Kandakes” told me. “And now we’re leading again.” #sudan #history #identity
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on October 19, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photos by @nicholesobecki / Mohamed Kassim shows his friend Suleiman Altaher, who was visiting from Khartoum, around the ancient city of Kerma. Kerma is one of the oldest inhabited towns in Africa and a place of immense historical importance. The area around Kerma has been occupied for at least 8000 to 10,000 years, but the town reached its peak around 1800 BC to 1600 BC, when it was capital of the Kingdom of Kush and an important trade centre during Egypt's Middle Kingdom. It was at this time that Kerma's kings built two monumental mud-brick temples, known as deffufa; the oldest, and arguably largest, mud-brick buildings on the continent. #sudan #history #identity
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on October 18, 2020.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @sarah_stacke / The last of the day’s light brushes trees lining Tatham Gap Road near Robbinsville, N.C. I spent hours on Tatham Gap, a remote dirt passage through the mountains. The history of this place is heavy and in the air. The challenge of making a photograph that speaks to something that happened long ago is real.

Tatham Gap runs along the Old Army Road that was built by N.C. troops in early 1838 in preparation for the forced removal of Cherokee citizens, thus making the road a section of the Trail of Tears. The road passes over Snowbird Mountain, elevation 3800 ft. In crossing Snowbird along the Old Army Road, the Cherokee prisoners climbed the highest point along the entire 900-mile Trail of Tears. An estimated 17,000 Cherokee were forced off their homelands and into Oklahoma in 1838. The Eastern Band of the Cherokee Indians are descendants of those that hid in the hills, returned from the West, or were allowed to stay through political relationships.

#landback #ebcihomelands #trailoftears
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Robbinsville, North Carolina.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @nataliekeyssar / Cynthia Degante, 9, poses for a portrait at her mother's flower stand in Corona Queens. Queens New York has been hit hard by the economic fallout of the pandemic, due to lost jobs, incomes, and tragically lost loved ones. Cynthia's mother's flower business, and the many informal vendors in the area, are one way that these hard working families are able to continue to put food on the table.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on October 16, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @nicholesobecki / Before the revolution Aya Khalid was working at a clinical lab, raising her two young children, and struggling to make sense of a country that she felt had no future. Then, a movement emerged which eventually brought millions of Sudanese onto the streets and ended Omar al-Bashir’s three-decades reign in Sudan. “It wasn’t even a thought to stay home,” said Aya, who was protesting on the frontlines, often caught between teargas and gunfire. Now she’s quit her old job, dedicated herself to martial arts, and is working at Muqatel Training Center to share what she’s learned with other women. “I want to be the first woman to win gold for Sudan,” Aya told me. “And if not I want to produce female fighters who can do that.” #sudan #history #identity
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Khartoum, Sudan.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @andreabruce / Early voting started today in North Carolina. People lined up over an hour before the polls opened, eager to cast their vote in Greensboro, NC. At the NC Cooperative Extension, Rupert Macintosh, who is “over 80” and walks with a cane, said he waited in line for almost two hours. “But I enjoyed it!” he added.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @nicholesobecki / Model Suzan Charles has her makeup and hair done by fashion stylist Maab Siddig and makeup artist Waad Al Fatih ahead of a photoshoot at Khartoum’s edgy Graphious Studio. The shoot was inspired by Sudan’s rich, ancient history, with Suzan portrayed, according to Maab, as “a symbol of justice and power, like the Kandakes of olden times.” The white thoub cloth worn by Suzan has become a symbol of the recent revolution that overthrew the repressive regime of President Omar al-Bashir, and is also a reference to ancient Nubian queens, connecting their power to the power of the women at the forefront of this latest chapter in Sudan’s history. “The revolution changed me personally, beyond just the politics,” Maab told me. “It decided our future, but it also made us look to the past with a different perspective.” #sudan #history #identity
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Khartoum, Sudan.

ph_descripcion: Photos by @nicholesobecki / This double wedding celebration was over the top, with drummers and dozens of dancers, hundreds of well wishers, two camels, and pistol-toting celebrants. Taking place in a village outside El Obeid in Sudan’s North Kordofan region, I was so overwhelmed that for a while I forgot to ask a really simple question: Where were the brides? Zainab Hamad’s uncle led me to her, and as the music faded we entered a shaded compound where the bride sat alone with her henna artist as she prepared to be married. The quiet serenity here was such a sharp contrast to the chaos outside. Zainab allowed me to make this portrait of her, the last rays of the sun ebbing, before she emerged into the new life that awaited her. #sudan #history #identity
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on October 13, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photos by @CarltonWard / Deep in the Fakahatchee Stand, @Malia_Byrtus sets and tests photo and video camera traps for our @pathofthepanther project with @insidenatgeo. ph_descripcion: Photo by @kiliiiyuyan / Dennis Donahue, a Karuk tribal member, picks acorns for with his mom Maymi within earshot, learning the subsistence traditions of his culture. His mother says she fed her kids acorn meal from an early age so they would learn to love the taste of their traditional food. Today is Indigenous Peoples' Day, a time to celebrate the incredible resilience of the world’s first peoples. Today I see a generation of Native youth that has worked hard to decolonize, leading their communities back to revitalized identities and traditional ways of life. We are reclaiming the lands, culture, and traditional knowledge that allowed us to live closely with the natural world for thousands of years. Today is a day to remember the sacrifices of our ancestors, but also a day to give thanks to all the things that support us, and look ahead to the generations that will come after us.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on October 12, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @kiliiiyuyan / Members of the Choctaw Nation of Oklahoma practice a fierce game of stickball on a field outside their new cultural center in Durant. Stickball, a truly Indigenous game, has been revitalized after decades of being banned in an attempt to suppress the cultures of the Oklahoma tribes. Today, players drive for hours to participate in this vital part of their traditional identities. Today is Indigenous Peoples' Day, a time to celebrate the incredible resilience of the world’s first peoples. Today I see a generation of Native youth that has worked hard to decolonize, leading their communities back to revitalized identities and traditional ways of life. We are reclaiming the lands, culture, and traditional knowledge that allowed us to live closely with the natural world for thousands of years. Today is a day to remember the sacrifices of our ancestors, but also a day to give thanks to all the things that support us, and look ahead to the generations that will come after us.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @nicholesobecki / Players from Sudan’s first ever women’s club football league during a co-ed training on a dirt field on the outskirts of Khartoum, Sudan. The move to allow the league reflects the new transitional government’s aspirations for the country and allows female players to push for wider acceptance. Sudan was once a football pioneer, joining FIFA in 1948 and co-founding the Confederation of African Football with Egypt, Ethiopia and South Africa at a meeting in Khartoum in 1957. But women's football faced an uphill battle after the country adopted the Islamic sharia law in 1983. Bashir's 30 years of iron-fisted rule ended after he was ousted following months of protests, triggering hopes that more liberal, pro-women policies would emerge. #sudan #history #identity
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Khartoum, Sudan.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @sarah_stacke / A section of the Great Smoky Mountains near the Qualla Boundary, home of the Eastern Band of the Cherokee Indians (EBCI). The Cherokee’s ancestral homelands once covered much of present-day North Carolina, South Carolina, Tennessee, Alabama, and Georgia. Today, the EBCI is reclaiming culturally and historically important lands lost during colonization.

Sunsets in the Great Smoky Mountains rarely disappoint. This looks like a moment I experienced in solitude, but there were people picnicking and sitting in camping chairs all around me. As soon as the reds and oranges faded from the sky, they got in their cars and sped away and then, suddenly, I was alone.

#landback #ebcihomelands #greatsmokymountains
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Great Smoky Mountains National Park.

ph_descripcion: Photos by @nicholesobecki / Meroë was one of the main centers of the powerful Kingdom of Kush (c 900BC to AD 400), which ruled over large parts of the Middle Nile Valley and, at one point, also over Egypt. Their vast influence, distinctive pyramid design, and works of art left a lasting testament to the grandeur of these kings and queens, many of who were laid to rest in these burial grounds. It took me two trips to Sudan and a fair bit of effort to get permission to photograph this ancient site at night, but it was worth it. Moving slowly amongst the tombs, and waiting for the necessary long exposures, was a meditation on time. Can you spot the shooting star? #sudan #history #identity
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on October 10, 2020.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @sarah_stacke / Chota is a special place. The light, the land, the stillness, the history. Though the landscape has changed over hundreds of years, the mountain horizon and soft sun on a cloudy day persevere.

The town of Chota was an Overhill Cherokee capital in the 1700s. Destroyed in 1780 by American forces during the Revolutionary War, it was rebuilt but never recovered. By 1813, an elderly Cherokee couple were the only people living at Chota. In 1979, the site was flooded by the creation of Tellico Lake, but Chota was raised above lake level. Archaeologists unearthed the foundation for the Council house, now marked with a monument situated directly above its former location. The remains of 91 Cherokee people were also unearthed, including Oconostota, a well-known Cherokee warrior. Oconostota was reinterred at Chota and the others were reinterred a few miles away at the Sequoyah Birthplace Museum in Vonore, Tennessee.

#landback #chota #ebcihomelands
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on October 08, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @nicholesobecki / Men jostle to buy bread outside a bakery in Sudan’s Suakin town, in the country’s eastern Red Sea region. Among the most pressing of the challenges Sudan faces today is its economy, battered by decades of mismanagement and corruption. The cost of some staple foods like bread and sugar have doubled over the past few weeks, driving inflation to a record high of 167%. Seemingly endless bread and fuel lines are a common site across the country, and on September 10 Sudan declared an economic state of emergency. The country’s one-year-old transitional government has been battling multiple crises in 2020, including the economy, the COVID-19 pandemic and massive flooding. #sudan #history #economy
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Suakin Port ميناء سواكن.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @nicholesobecki / Portrait of Alaa Salah, an engineering student and activist who became the face of the revolution in Sudan after a photograph of her standing atop a car in a white toub, leading a crowd of protesters in a chant, went viral. For her role in fueling the revolution that ousted President Omar al-Bashir from 30 years of authoritarian rule, Alaa became known as a “Kandake,” or an ancient Nubian queen. She also came to symbolize the integral role women played on the front lines of the pro-democracy protests, where they often outnumbered men. #women #sudan #history #identity
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Khartoum, Sudan.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @dashaunaemarisa / I had the pleasure of meeting Yolanda, Jason, & Harper Lucas while working on a story for @natgeo about infant mortality. Yolanda and Jason struggled with infant mortality for 10 years before their son Harper was born. “I internalized everything for a long time. As we look back a lot of things could have been avoided but we were in such a painful place we did not use our voices back then,” she says. In 2006, Yolanda met with evangelical preacher Joel Osteen who suggested that Yolanda “activate her faith.” Yolanda went on to buy a new SUV and carseat to prepare for her child. “The difference is that this baby is going to live,” she said. Jason Harper Lucas II was born in July of 2007. Yolanda is celebrating 20 years in business, 25 years of marriage, and the life of her son Harper. #women #maternal #health #cleveland
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on October 06, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @annieflanagan / Hermelinda Cortés, pictured with son Santos Timmons Cortés at their Virginia home, is part of the editorial advisory team for the Country Queers podcast, an oral history project gathering rural queer stories. She and Rae Garringer, the podcast’s host, met at a 2013 event where she facilitated a conversation among rural queer Southerners. Garringer hopes to interview her for the project someday.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on October 06, 2020.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @sarah_stacke / You never know exactly what a day on assignment will offer and that’s a thrill. I ran into Dana Robinson at Chota, the site of a long-ago Cherokee town in eastern Tennessee. Dana was running his Beagles to let them practice catching rabbits. In between serious mosquito attacks, I caught a moment between Dana and Queenie, one of his beloved pups.

Chota was destroyed in 1780 by American forces during the Revolutionary War. After losing possession of the land for about 200 years, Chota is again owned the Eastern Band of the Cherokee Indians. A memorial at the site honors the Cherokee history of the land, which is now visited by tribal members and the public.

#landback #chota #ebcihomelands
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Vonore, Tennessee. May be an image of 1 person.

ph_descripcion: Photos by @nicholesobecki / One of the great joys of working in Sudan is the coffee, which is strong and dark, and available on nearly every corner. Walking along the main street of Suakin, the smell of roasting beans drew us into this turquoise, Ottoman-era gem. I ordered a coffee with “dawa,” meaning medicine in Arabic and representing ginger here. My colleague Mohammed Alamin ordered chai; a mistake he rectified on the second cup (sorry to all you tea drinkers our there!). After my third jolt the barista laughingly shooed me out, and it was time to get back to work. #coffee #sudan #history #identity
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on October 06, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @nataliekeyssar/ Yesterday I met Mia and Gordo, two kittens who came to a Catholic church in Corona, Queens to receive their blessings for the Feast of St. Francis after morning mass. I went to the church to work on an assignment about the hard times facing this community largely comprised of immigrant essential workers whose labor is indispensable to New York City, but who have been disproportionately affected by the virus and its economic fallout. Despite these hard times, there was a festive atmosphere and the service felt hopeful. The animals at mass really seemed to brighten everyone's day. I hope they brighten yours too. (Swipe for a closeup of Mia and her human, Korina!)
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on October 05, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @annieflanagan / “I want to see this land thrive,” Robin Thirkill, 45, said while working on her farmstead, Flossies Farmstead, in Prospect, Virginia. Here, she holds a chicken before slaughter. Robin, who works as a hospice nurse on the weekends, moved to her family’s land in 2007 and began farming soon after. Thirkill, was featured in the eighth episode of Country Queers podcast, an oral history project gathering rural queer stories.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on October 05, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @nicholesobecki / A Sudanese family from nearby Karima tour the ancient site of El Kurru, a pyramid field of the kings and queens of ancient Kush. The rulers buried there were many of the so-called ‘Black Pharaohs‘— the leaders of Kush who conquered and ruled Egypt from about 715–653 BCE. I’d been struggling with how to make this extraordinary but empty space come alive in my images when a beat-up old sedan pulled up, and this family piled out. After I explained what I was doing they laughingly let me tag along on their tour. #sudan #history #identity
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on October 04, 2020.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @sarah_stacke / On a quiet morning I drove 45 minutes from my hotel to an unassuming field alongside the Tennessee River. Thirteen years ago, the Eastern Band of the Cherokee Indians (EBCI) purchased this 70-acre site because it’s home to the historic Cowee Mound and village, thought to date from about 600 A.D. The council house of the Cherokee town of Cowee was located on the mound in the 18th century, when the town served as an important commercial center. In the 1840s, shortly after an estimated 17,000 Cherokee were forced off their homeland by the U.S. government and onto the Trail of Tears, the Halls, a white family, acquired the property. The land remained in the Hall family for 175 years until they returned ownership of it to the Cherokee. The lines covering the mound, in the right of the frame, are likely made from deer walking through the tall grass. Cowee, in fact, roughly translates to “the place of the Deer clan.”

In the Great Smoky Mountains, the EBCI is reclaiming culturally and historically important lands lost during colonization.

I’m in this photo. Can you find me?!

#landback #ebcihomelands #cowee #drone
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Franklin, North Carolina.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @annieflanagan / Rae Garringer and friend Jacob Mack-Boll attend the Isom Days Festival in Kentucky. Garringer started an oral history project on the rural queer community. Garringer had no experience with oral history when Country Queers began, but the format’s accessibility attracted them. “[This] project is a story of what happens when you feel like this is so urgent that you just need to do it, even though you don’t have all the tools or a lot of money or a lot of training or a lot of support.”
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on October 02, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @annieflanagan / Rae Garringer began the Country Queers oral history project in 2013 and now hosts the podcast. Most of the project’s initial audio came from a road trip they took in 2014, interviewing 30 people in 30 days. “So many lesbians grilled for me,” Garringer says. “It was summertime, so all the butches got their grills out and made food.” Here, Garringer is pictured with goats Trillium and Thistle where they live in Kentucky. Though COVID-19 has demanded physical isolation from others, Garringer feels more connected to a broader queer community now that events have been moved online. “Making things accessible online is exciting for me at least, as a rural queer person.”
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on October 02, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photograph by Karla Gachet @kchete77 Emilio Cruz and his extended family share a Friday evening in Wasco, CA. His older brother, Constantino, died of a heat stroke in 2005. He left four kids and his wife was pregnant at the time of his death. He had been working in a tomato farm and experienced a heat stroke that sent him to the hospital. He got out five days later and went back to work. He collapsed in the middle of the day, and did not survive. His body was sent back to his parents in Oaxaca. Emilio, who was 15 at the time, went back with his brother’s body. This was a tragedy for the whole family. Emilio still works in the grape fields. #HEAT #migrantfarmworkers #CentralValley
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on October 01, 2020.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @stuartpalley / The Glass Fire burns northeast of Calistoga, Ca shortly after midnight. The blaze was over 51,000 acres and 2% contained. Above thermal belts, the fire burned actively much of the night and was already spotting past containment lines as of writing. The fire started during a north wind event, and another Red Flag Warning (RFW) starts in 90 minutes for a 31-hour period. I embedded last night with a strike team near Angwin cutting dozer line and protecting homes. The fire behavior was extremely active.

I’m here in Sonoma and Napa counties on assignment covering the Glass Fire impacting wine country and the wine industry itself. This hits close to home as friends yet again are being evacuated and losing structures and businesses for the 3rd time in 4 years, in some cases. The fall harvest is also being adversely affected. Driving past wineries I’ve visited as a tourist and knowing they are gone, I have trouble holding back tears. This all feels incredibly personal.

The fire also impacts the laborers who work in the fields and pick the grapes. With fire closures for safety and a new agricultural permit access system, implementation mid-fire siege is an ongoing issue.

Stay safe out there, have an evacuation plan ready, and follow local emergency alerts. Follow evacuation orders, and don’t hesitate to leave if you feel uncomfortable.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on October 01, 2020.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @sarah_stacke / On a hazy mountain evening Sarah Elizabeth Burkey and I walked the trails at Kituwah, a site cherished by the Eastern Band of the Cherokee Indians (EBCI). It was Sarah’s idea to get off the beaten path and into the trees. Sarah is a songwriter, storyteller, and recording artist. She was one of the first people I met when I started working in Cherokee years ago.

In the Great Smoky Mountains, the EBCI is reclaiming culturally and historically important lands, like Kituwah, that were lost during colonization. The trails at Kituwah are enjoyed by tribal members and the public.

#landback #kituwah #ebcihomelands
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Cherokee, North Carolina.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @annieflanagan / Hermelinda Cortés and her son, Santos Timmons Cortés eat dinner on their porch in Virginia. Cortés returned home to Virginia in 2012. Though she says growing up in the area could be hard, she didn’t feel at home in cities. “It’s pretty important for me to be near the mountains. I just feel more sane.” Cortés is part of the editorial advisory team for the Country Queers podcast, an oral history project gathering rural queer stories.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @nicholesobecki / Making this portrait of thirteen-year-old Alla Mohammed in the main hall of the National Museum of Sudan felt eery and full of mystery. The museum houses the largest Nubian archeological collection in the world, but has been closed to the public since the COVID-19 pandemic began earlier this year. The air was heavy with dust, and a committee had to come together to open the museum doors for us. Among so many treasures, this granite statue of a baboon stood out, depicted here in an adoration pose. #sudan #history #identity
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Khartoum, Sudan.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @sarah_stacke / Eastern Band of the Cherokee Indians Vice Chief Alan B. Ensley inside the tribe’s Council chambers. Before becoming Vice Chief, Ensley served as a Council Representative for 22 years and has voted “highly and definitively in favor” of the tribe reclaiming lands lost during colonization. “It can be real sensitive having to buy back your own burial grounds,” says Vice Chief Ensley.

2. In the early 2000s, the tribe swapped land they owned near Waterrock Knob off the Blue Ridge Parkway for land adjacent to the Qualla Boundary, home of the EBCI, that was owned by the Great Smoky Mountains National Park. The tribe used the newly acquired land to build state of the art K-12 schools for its members.

3. At work near Watterrock Knob photographing the piece of land the tribe swapped with the park. Waterrock Knob is one of the best places in North Carolina to watch a sunrise, sunset, or stargaze on a clear night. Photo by @sheenabringsplenty

#landback #cherokee #behindthescenes
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 30, 2020.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @sarah_stacke / No project or assignment happens alone. Relationships are key. While working in Cherokee, North Carolina, and beyond on a story about the Eastern Band of the Cherokee Indians (EBCI) reclamation of stolen lands, Sheena Brings Plenty (@sheenabringsplenty) is my guide, fixer, grip, and friend. Sheena has lived in Cherokee for 12 years, her husband is the longtime photographer for the Cherokee One Feather newspaper, and their daughter is an enrolled member of the EBCI. Here, we test the light and scout a spot before a portrait of a Cherokee leader at Kituwah, a sacred Cherokee site.

#landback #cherokee #ebcihomelands
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Cherokee, North Carolina.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @sarah_stacke / Nikwasi Mound in Franklin, North Carolina, was the center of a centuries-old Cherokee town until 1819 when its residents were forced off their land by the U.S. government. Franklin was built on top of the town, destroying all but the mound. The council house – the spiritual and political center of Nikwasi town – sat on top of the mound and about 100 houses, a field for playing stickball, a dance ground, and hundreds of acres of crops, orchards, and gardens surrounded it. Since the town of Franklin turned the mound’s grasses brown with herbicide, the Eastern Band of the Cherokee Indians have been trying to reclaim it. Franklin and now Nikwasi Initiative, who currently owns the deed, have resisted returning the site to the Cherokee. In 2017 the tribe purchased an old auto parts store next to the mound with plans to convert it into a branch of the Museum of the Cherokee Indian.

#landback #nikwasi #ebcihomelands
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Franklin, North Carolina.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @sarah_stacke / Eastern Band of the Cherokee Indians (EBCI) tribal member Amy Walker, 78, picks beans in her garden at Kituwah, a sacred Cherokee site. Walker plants many of the same crops her ancestors did for thousands of years at Kituwah. “The garden keeps me connected to them,” she says.

Time with Amy is always a gift. Before going into the garden, we sat in her truck, drank coffee, and shared stories of being women and mothers. A cultural tradition, Amy’s hair is cut short to symbolize the grief she’s experiencing after losing her youngest daughter to ovarian cancer.

In the Great Smoky Mountains, the EBCI is reclaiming culturally and historically important lands lost during colonization. Kituwah was reclaimed by the tribe in 1996 after losing ownership of it in the early 1800s.

#landback #kituwah #cherokee
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 27, 2020.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @amandamustard / At Elephant Nature Park in Chiang Mai, Thailand, founder Sangduen ‘Lek’ Chailert is often called the ‘elephant whisperer’. She’s devoted her life to the welfare of Thailand’s captive elephants, rescuing many and giving them the space to live safely and freely under the care of her mahouts. Elephant Nature Park is a place for tourists to learn more about elephants without performances, riding, or other unnatural activities to generate income. While this model is the gold standard, it’s financially unrealistic for many smaller camps across Thailand to transition to such a donation-focused approach when there is still significant demand from many tourists to ride elephants and see circus-style performances. Many camps have expressed that they would be happy to transition, but if and when the demand dictates. In the face of this complex problem, Lek began a movement to change the culture of elephant tourism in Thailand, providing education both to tourists as well as establishing an alliance of camp owners to learn from her experience and begin shifting their own business models towards a more sustainable approach.
Now, due to the collapse of tourism amidst the pandemic, many elephant camps have lost almost their entire source of income. There is now a rare window of opportunity for camps - that can afford it - to change their model if they so choose. Elephant Nature Park has been offering support and consultation to camps making this decision, and has also been providing funding to those who are struggling to keep their elephants fed during these unprecedented times.

1️⃣ – Portrait of Lek Chailert at Elephant Nature Park
2️⃣ – A small herd of elephants walk up a river each morning to a large, contained area where they can safely graze.
3️⃣ – The ‘Skywalk’ area where tourists can observe the elephant’s natural behavior.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 27, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @laurelchor / Loy Ho is chairwoman of the Lantau Buffalo Association, which aims to preserve the feral cows and water buffalo on Hong Kong’s largest island. Behind her is a cow resting after eating the American hay she imports. She says that as Beijing tightens its control on Hong Kong, the city is “being forced into something we don't recognize, so we try to tell the government what we actually want.” But as an environmental advocate, she is used to the authorities not listening: “It's like banging into a big heavy wall and they look at us like we are aliens.” Follow @laurelchor for more about #HongKong and the #nationalsecuritylaw.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Lantau Island 大嶼山. May be an image of 1 person.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @nicholesobecki / Like most days in Sudan, everything went wrong until suddenly it all went right. Through friends I was invited to a wedding happening later that day in the Red Sea mountains, but there was no fuel to be found. Once fuel was secured, we promptly lost our way. Once found, it began to pour rain. But as the skies cleared the dancing began, each man competing for the highest leap. I was reminded of how a place can reveal itself to you through the kindness of strangers — and a little luck. #sudan #wedding #history #identity
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 25, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Laylah Amatullah Barrayn @laylahb / Jamila, who did not to give her last name, posed at a memorial for Breonna Taylor in Louisville, Kentucky. “Mentally, I’m a little drained, but I am looking to be the change I want to see. Even the small things that I do can affect change. I'm allowing myself to evolve, doing what I’m supposed to do, whatever feels right, taking care of my mind, body, and soul,” she said.

Photo by Karla Gachet @kchete77 Jose Chavez gets ready in the morning at his home in Bakersfield, CA. Jose's wife, Martha, gave birth a week prior to this photo. She wakes up with Jose, at 4:30 am to make him lunch to take to work.

Jose is a mayordomo and organizes a group of 25 men to prune cherry trees . He has been working in the fields for 20 years. He was a worker himself for 10 years before becoming a mayordomo, so he says he is very conscious of giving people breaks and having ice water available all day long.
#onassignment for @natgeo #HEAT #migrantfarmworkers #CentralValley

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @williamodaniels / In Saint Denis, near Paris, 800 refugees, most of them from Afghanistan, are living in a makeshift camp, under a highway bridge. Their only access to clean drinking water is one public tap for all of them. I spend some time there during last week’s heatwave that reached 35 Celsius, a record breaking temperature for mid-September in Paris.
Solidarites Migrants Wilson @refugees_paris, is a group of volunteers who supports them by distributing food and providing them with information.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 25, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Matthieu Paley @paleyphoto / After a forest fire, smoldering spots are identified one by one and the thick layer of humus that covers the forest floor is extinguished. Using powerful hoses, firefighters douse the ground with a mix of water and wetting agent, a chemical substance that increases the spreading and penetrating properties of water by lowering its surface tension. Near Bordeaux, France. This is part of an ongoing global story for National Geographic magazine on the issue of Air Pollution. For more on environmental issues worldwide, follow @paleyphoto #water #airpollution #forestfire #firefighters
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 25, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Karla Gachet @kchete77 Mardonio Solorio poses for a portrait with his daughters in Fresno, CA. He was affected by a heat stroke in 2008 while working in the fields. About a year ago he also got sprayed when a neighboring farm fumigated next to the field Mardonio and his daughter, Addilene (19, far right), where working at. The doctor told him he will have asthma as a result for the rest of his life. #HEAT #migrantfarmworkers #CentralValley
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 24, 2020.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by Laylah Amatullah Barrayn @laylahb / Tamika Palmer, mother of Breonna Taylor, posed at a memorial for her daughter in Louisville, Kentucky the day before the grand jury’s decision. "She had an old soul. When Breonna was about seven years old, she would always ask her grandmother, my mother, if she was okay. And grandma would say, I'm just tired, baby. And Breonna, her little self, would say, ‘well let me check your sugar, grandmama.’ And my mother would let her do it! Breonna would go get the kit, clean the finger, and do the finger prick, and check her grandmama's sugar. And I would be like oh, lord, lol! Even then, you knew that she wanted to take care of people.

Breonna was a go-getter, they called her a 'Boss Queen.’ For her age, she had her head on straight. She always lifted people up. Her friends. She was a problem solver, people came to her, they trusted her sense of judgement. She was honest and had integrity. She told you the truth even when you didn't want to hear it…She always felt charged to tell the truth, even in difficult situations, she would always say ‘this is the truth, but what are we going to do to fix it. I'm here with you and not going to leave you hanging,’” Palmer said.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 24, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photos by @nicholesobecki / Many historians believe that the Red Sea port of Suakin was likely Ptolemy's Port of Good Hope, Limen Evangelis, which is similarly described as lying on a circular island at the end of a long inlet. For 3,000 year it remained strategically important to an array of empires, bringing great riches to the shores of Sudan, before falling to disrepair in the 20th century. Wandering the ancient site on a Friday afternoon, it was beautiful to see the community just beyond its gates coming here to bask in their own history, gaze out at the sea, and scramble over the coral ruins. #sudan #history #identity
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 24, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Matthieu Paley @paleyphoto / As seen through the front window of a reconnaissance helicopter, a Canadair firefighting plane drops about 6 tons of water over a nascent forest fire. The water was picked up moments earlier in a designated area on the Gironde river, near Bordeaux, France. The helicopter indicates the area where to drop the water by pointing its nose to it. Firefighters specialists inside the helicopter help guide the Canadair pilots over the radio. This is part of an ongoing global story for National Geographic magazine on the issue of Air Pollution. For more on environmental issues worldwide, follow @paleyphoto #forestfire #firefighters #firefighting
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 24, 2020.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @laurelchor Swadiq Khan owns Chrisly Cafe, a chain of “cha chaan teng” – or traditional Hong Kong diners. As a mixed-race child, he faced discrimination. “A cha chaan teng is a very inclusive space. Anyone can come here.”

As Hong Kong loses rights and freedoms it once had, many young people are feeling hopeless about their future. Khan wants to help by hiring them: “We have a lot of grievances, we have anger. But we should press on. This is the hard-knock spirit I learned from growing up in a public housing estate. I am just a small-time business owner, I can't change the world. I can only do a little bit for the people around me.” 

Follow @laurelchor for more about #HongKong and the #nationalsecuritylaw.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Hong Kong.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @sarah_stacke / In the Great Smoky Mountains, home of the Eastern Band of the Cherokee Indians, the tribe is reclaiming culturally and historically important lands lost during colonization. Kituwah, also known as the “Cherokee Mother Town,” was the original Cherokee settlement and considered the place of origin for the Cherokee people. This sacred site, which archaeologists date to nearly 10,000 years ago, was reclaimed by the tribe in 1996 after losing ownership of it in the early 1800s. Kituwah Mound, which was located at the center of the village, is still visible today despite nearly 200 years of farming while not under Cherokee ownership.

#landback #cherokee_museum
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Cherokee, North Carolina.

ph_descripcion: By @CarltonWard / The Florida Wildlife Corridor claimed all four or our vehicles during the Last Wild Places film expedition for @insidenatgeo. My Land Cruiser went down first. Mud tires and lockers were little help when the trail turned to soup. Next were the rental suburban and 4Runner. To end strong, we got the rental RV stuck 20 feet from its parking spot, just hours before the camera team’s flights back to Utah and Montana. #WetSeason Photos by @danny_schmidt @torilinder @ricksmith_media @morth_photo @leyoho. @Fl_WildCorridor @PathofthePanther #KeepFLWild
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 22, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Matthieu Paley @paleyphoto I The first few minutes of a forest fires are extremely crucial! Following a phone call from local resident smelling smoke, the emergency helicopter of the Fire and Rescue Service in Bordeaux, France, does a fly over to survey the extent of a nascent fire. Via radio, fire specialists in the helicopter instruct firefighting teams on the ground and in the air on how to best intervene to control the fire. This is part of an ongoing global story for National Geographic magazine on the issue of air pollution. For more on environmental issues worldwide, follow @paleyphoto #forestfire #firefighters #airpollution
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 22, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @andreabruce At 8 pm on Saturday, September 19, 2020, courthouses across the United States held vigils in honor of the late Justice Ruth Bader Ginsberg. Here, at the Michigan Hall of Justice in Lansing, MI, mourners lit candles and placed rocks in front of her image. Around 80 people attended for an hour of somber silence. Many of the attendees came alone. Several wept. The vigil was held by the local Planned Parenthood
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 20, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Maddie McGarvey @maddiemcgarvey / Mytrang Nguyen and Kim-anh Aslanian comfort each other at a memorial for Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg outside of the Supreme Court on September 19, 2020. “She was a trailblazer, she gave to us what we didn’t have the vision to see. I worry they don’t make women like her anymore but she made all of us,” Nguyen said. The Supreme Court Justice died on Sept. 18, 2020 due to metastatic pancreatic cancer. She was 87.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 20, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @carltonward / On assignment for @insidenatgeo making a Last Wild Places film about the Florida Wildlife Corridor / Film director @danny_schmidt navigates pine woods on the Smoak Ranch — a Florida cattle ranch that has been protected by a conservation easement with @nature_org. That morning we were looking for Florida black bears — one of many species this ranch and neighboring properties support. The Florida Wildlife Corridor is a statewide network of public conservation lands, and private working lands (like this ranch) that together form connected habitat for wide ranging wildlife. Learn more at @fl_wildcorridor and @pathofthepanther. #FloridaWildlifeCorridor #LastWildPlaces #KeepFLWild
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Florida Wildlife Corridor Foundation.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Tomas van Houtryve @tomasvh A volunteer from the group Charpentiers Sans Frontières (Carpenters Without Borders) places a symbolic oak branch at the top of a wooden roof frame in front of the cathedral of Notre-Dame de Paris. The beams and frame were hewed and assembled by hand, using only traditional woodworking skills and based on the original design of the cathedral. The frame was raised only for demonstrative purposes—there is still much repair work to be done on Notre-Dame before workers will eventually get to the roof. A massive fire ravaged the cathedral in April 2019. Follow @tomasvh for more stories and images. #NotreDamedeParis #NotreDame #notredamecathedral
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 19, 2020. May be an image of 1 person.

ph_descripcion: Photos by @carltonward / On assignment for @insidenatgeo making a Last Wild Places film about the Florida Wildlife Corridor. The Suwannee River was a major theme for the project. It flows 240 miles from headwaters in Georgia's Okefenokee Swamp to Florida's Gulf of Mexico coast near Cedar Key. The river's forested banks provide a vital linkage in the Florida Wildlife Corridor, and the fact that the surrounding landscape remains largely undeveloped is a main reason that the estuaries around Cedar Key remain nealry pristine. The abundance of clean water flowing downstream supports clam and oyster aquaculture of national importance. Upstream, long rotation pine plantations drive rural economies while providing land use compatible with the health of the Suwannee watershed. If the working forests are replaced by suburban development, the whole system will degrade. Please follow me @carltonward @pathofthepanther and @fl_wildcorridor to learn more about efforts to keep Florida wild. #LastWildPlaces #FloridaWildlifeCorridor
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 18, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photos by @carltonward / On assignment for @insidenatgeo and @pathofthepanther making a Last Wild Places film about the Florida Wildlife Corridor. While working on Miccosukee lands, we based out of the Clyde Butcher Gallery within Big Cypress National Preserve. The flooded forest behind the gallery, past the skunk ape crossing sign (last photo), made for a great team activity — see whether @torilinder and @morth_photo could push @ricksmith_media in a canoe for stabilized 8K video gliding through the swamp without capsizing. The cameras survived and the results will be breathtaking. Please follow me @carltonward and @fl_wildcorridor to learn when the film comes out next year. #lastwildplaces #keepflwild
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 17, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photos by @carltonward / On assignment for @insidenatgeo and @pathofthepanther, making a Last Wild Places film about the Florida Wildlife Corridor. A highlight of the expedition was spending two days with Betty Osceola @osceolabetty , a member of the Panther Clan of the Miccosukee Tribe and passionate advocate for the Everglades. Betty's profound connection to her ancestral home, strengthened by weekly airboat tours deep into the River of Grass, makes her voice resonate with wisdom that the world needs to hear. It will be a great privilege to share Betty's story in her own words when the film comes out next year. When not on her airboat, she can be found driving motorcycles and tending crops at her home within Big Cypress National Preserve. Please stay connected with @carltonward and @fl_wildcorridor for updates as our #LastWildPlaces project develops. #FloridaWildlifeCorridor #KeepFLWild
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 16, 2020.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @stuartpalley / The Castle Fire burns in the Sequoia National Forest near Camp Nelson, CA Sunday September 13th, 2020. The blaze is part of the SQF complex, a series of lighting caused fires in the southern Sierra Nevada mountains of California. The fire was increasing in containment and then a weather change caused the fire to explode into massive bark beetle-killed pines, causing the fire to grow. Sadly, homes were lost in the Alpine Drive area and firefighters are working to save houses in the rural and remote Sequoia Crest area, near the Alder Sequoia grove and the 5th largest tree in the world.

There are millions of trees killed by drought and ensuing bark beetle infestations in CA, and the Castle Fire is in part fueled by dead and down trees, living trees that are extremely dry, and dense undergrowth. Heat, drought, and an incredibly strong lightning storm combined with forest management, wildland urban interface construction, and climate change all coalesce on the peaks to create this surreal scene from California’s record setting wildfire siege.

#CastleFire #SQFComplex #LongExposure #CAFire
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 14, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @carltonward / A highlight of our film expedition was getting to spend a day with my own family. I am one of the six characters in the National Geographic Society’s Last Wild Places film about the Florida Wildlife Corridor. The film team visited my family’s ranch in Central Florida and I was able to see my wife and ride horses and check camera traps with my kids, who are 9th generation Floridians. That’s me and my oldest daughter Eldridge in the first photo, captured by director @danny_schmidt, who is also in then final photo standing behind @ricksmith_media. My motivation is to improve land conservation policies so that next generation of people connected to working farms and ranches will have alternatives to the development that is otherwise on track to consume most of the remaining green space in Florida. @pathofthepanther is a #LastWildPlaces partner with @insidenatgeo. Please connect with me @carltonward and @fl_wildcorridor as we fight to #keepFLWild.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 12, 2020.

ph_descripcion: How many camera traps can you count in this photo? This is @malia_byrtus - field program manager for the @pathofthepanther project doing her daily work in the Everglades. Malia is a behind-the-scenes hero managing the network of custom photography and video camera traps deployed throughout the Florida Wildlife Corridor for a #LastWildPlaces partnership with @insidenatgeo (and me @carltonward). Our purpose is to capture elusive animals like the Florida panther and Florida black bear as part of a campaign to inspire the new land conservation needed to keep Florida wild.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Everglades, Florida.

ph_descripcion: Photos by @carltonward On assignment for @insidenatgeo making a Last Wild Places film about the importance of protecting the Florida Wildlife Corridor. We experienced some magical light as we followed clam farmers through their daily work in the nearshore Gulf of Mexico around Cedar Key, where the water quality of the estuary depends on conserving the wild and timber lands upstream on the Suwannee River. The first two photos show sister and brother Gretchen and Ian Stone (@gretchstone) on their morning commute to their clam lease before and during sunrise. The last photo, a drone shot, shows the oyster bars and barrier islands that structure the estuary around Cedar Key. The film our team captured during these late summer days is going to be powerful. Please follow @carltonward @pathofthepanther and @fl_wildcorridor as the story unfolds. #LastWildPlaces #KeepFLWild
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 09, 2020.

Photo by Kris Graves @themaniwasnt
I The Former Jefferson Davis Memorial, Richmond, Virginia. This summer, the main sculpture was pulled down by protestors. Mayor Levar Stoney took it upon himself to start removing all other symbols from this Confederate sculpture and others placed throughout the city of Richmond. Only a few monuments remain within city limits. To view more of my work, please visit @themaniwasnt and @kgpnyc

ph_descripcion: Photo by Kris Graves @themaniwasnt I Old Slave Mart, Charleston, South Carolina. Constructed in 1859, this was one of many private auction slave markets in Downtown Charleston. As the Civil War ended in 1865 and the Union Army occupied the city, all slaves that were then imprisoned at this market were freed. To view more of my work, please follow @themaniwasnt and @kgpnyc

ph_descripcion: Photo by @williamodaniels |The city of Paris recently experienced one of the strongest heatwaves in years with some temperatures up to 39 Celsius recorded (102F). Here, a man walks under a mister near the Seine river, with the famous Pont Neuf bridge seen in the background. Every summer, the city of Paris set up Paris Plage (meaning Paris beach), an event that offers Parisians and visitors free places to relax and take advantage of leisure activities during the hot summer days.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Paris, France.
