ph_descripcion:
Photo by @stephenwilkes Yolanda King, the 12 year old granddaughter of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. speaks at the Commitment March on the 57th anniversary of her grandfather’s “I Have a Dream” Speech. “My generation has already taken to the streets – peacefully and with masks and social distancing – to protest racism”. Yolanda’s speech was one of the highlights of this historic march. I had the incredible opportunity to photograph the Commitment March: Get Your Knee off our Necks, in Washington, D.C. Thousands gathered in front of the Lincoln Memorial  on the 57th anniversary of Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr’s. “I Have a Dream” Speech. It was a peaceful and inspiring day of speeches and protests. The protesters all came together with a unified message, seeking criminal justice reform and remind the everyone of their right & need to vote.  As  I photographed from a remarkable vantage point with the Washington monument behind me, I reflected on the fact that this is a transformational moment in our country,and I felt grateful that this march was taking place. On assignment for @natgeo
#DayToNight #commitmentmarch
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on August 30, 2020.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @stephenwilkes 57 years after Dr. Martin Luther King Jr gave his iconic “I Have a Dream” speech, the Reverend Al Sharpton spoke at the Commitment March on August 28th in Washington DC. The Commitment March had thousands of people come from around the nation, both young and old to peacefully march together to confront racial injustices and criminal justice reform.

I had the incredible opportunity to photograph the Commitment March: Get Your Knee off our Necks, in Washington, D.C. Thousands gathered in front of the Lincoln Memorial. It was a peaceful and inspiring day of speeches and protests. The protesters all came together with a unified message, seeking criminal justice reform and remind the everyone of their right & need to vote.  As  I photographed from a remarkable vantage point with the Washington monument behind me, I reflected on the fact that this is a transformational moment in our country,and I felt grateful that this march was taking place. On assignment for @natgeo
#DayToNight #commitmentmarch
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on August 30, 2020.

Photo by @waynelawrence  “The greatest change I would like to see come from a movement like this is that we all become advocates. People that don’t look like me, I need them to speak up for me when I’m not in the room. Not just at BLM events, not just when they’re around [people of color] who look like me. I need them to do that on an everyday basis unconsciously and consciously.” —Mi-Chael York (right) with John Meché

Yesterday's Commitment March honored the 57th anniversary of the March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom, which occurred on August 28, 1963, and emphasized the work still to be done, especially on police and criminal justice reform.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on August 29, 2020.

So I’ve been doing this work for a really long time.” —Addis, who preferred not to give her last name, traveled to the Commitment March with a group of friends from Milwaukee, Wisconsin.

"We have a lot of inequality going on here in America. I want to make sure that I have an opportunity to put my footprint, make an impact, and show that we can make a change here in America. Not just America, but the whole world in general,” Marcus Daniel said.

Photo by Wayne Lawrence @waynelawrence “I’m fighting for all of our children and grandchildren, my children and their grandchildren, for their freedom, so they don’t have to do this.” — Toy Slaughter (left), from Pittsburgh, on August 27, with Gam Cheinsaw (right): “There are so many more names than the names that are written on streets and written on T-shirts and people just need to know about it.”

Today's Commitment March honors the 57th anniversary of the March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom, which occurred on August 28, 1963, and emphasizes the work still to be done, especially in police and criminal justice reform.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by Joshua Rashaad McFadden @joshua_rashaad On August 27, 2020, a day before the March on Washington, a cyclists gathered at the Lincoln Memorial to raise awareness of the racial disparity within the cycling community, including the profiling and policing of people of color on bikes. The cyclist group embarked on a six-day trip, biking from New York City to Washington, D.C., to join hundreds of other cyclists and protestors at the Commitment March to make their voices heard.

The march honors the 57th anniversary of the March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom, which occurred on August 28, 1963, and emphasizes the work still to be done, especially in police and criminal justice reform.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on August 28, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @giles_price As part of a conceptual series of images shot on assignment during the COVID-19 pandemic, I’ve used a thermal camera to examine what daily life currently looks like with restrictions placed on ordinary events and new routines becoming our everyday. Even with lockdown restrictions eased, many cities in the UK have seen a reduction in the numbers of people visiting. Central London in particular has seen a 73% decrease post lockdown, caused by loss of international and UK visitors. Here, the normally crowded beach at Bankside, on the River Thames, has only a few visitors on summer days. To view more of my work please follow me at @giles_price.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on August 27, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @laurelchor To local resident Dan Yiu, Cheung Chau Island represents two things that Hong Kong has lost: a sense of community and freedom. In the wake of the new national security law, which essentially criminalizes dissent, I asked Hong Kongers where they feel the most connected to the city and took their portraits there. Yiu, who is an educator, now worries about schools’ independence: “A lot of my teacher friends, they're very scared. But they feel that they do not have the strength, the power to do anything.” Follow @laurelchor for more on #HongKong and the #nationalsecuritylaw.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Hong Kong.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @kiliiiyuyan Yesterday evening the Indian Relay races started, and I photographed the riders and horses thundering by, like these two in their race regalia. It was a tough decision to make, whether to photograph with a high shutter speed and freeze the action, or a very slow shutter speed to blur the background and give a feeling of the tremendous speed. With only 3 passes, lasting 3 minutes total, I would only have time for one strategy. Did I make the right choice? Follow me @kiliiiyuyan, for more from the Indigenous world. #native #blackfeet #montana #nativesovereignty
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on August 22, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @giles_price As part of a conceptual series of images shot on assignment during the COVID-19 pandemic, I’ve used a thermal camera to examine what daily life currently looks like with restrictions placed on ordinary events and new routines becoming our everyday. Here, a pupil at L’Ecole de Battersea - an English-French bilingual preparatory school in South London – has their temperature checked on arrival. The school has installed IQ air purifiers with HEPA filters, which remove PM2.5 particles containing bacteria and viruses. Fogging machines, which use Hypochlorous acid to decontaminate the school, are also used throughout the building. This has resulted in no reported cases of COVID-19 at the school during the pandemic so far. To view more of my work please follow me at @giles_price.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on August 20, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Hi everyone, this is Kiliii Yuyan on assignment in NW Montana. I’m here to spend time with Native American race teams in a unique sport called Indian Relay. What is Indian relay racing? It’s bareback racing on horses, where riders will leap from the back of a horse and then immediately onto the back of another. Photo by @kiliiiyuyan Yesterday I spent the evening with a Blackfeet family, who brought 8 kids from 3 to 16, all learning the way of the horse. This image is of the most experienced, Richie Pemberton, in the middle of dismounting Queen at high speed. Follow me @kiliiiyuyan, for more from the Indigenous world. #native #blackfeet #montana #nativesovereignty
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on August 19, 2020. May be an image of 1 person.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @joshuacogan |Veronica Ochoa Flores is the matriarch of the Flores family, leading and organizing all harvest and market operations for the family farm. Timing both ripeness and shelf stability requires a understanding of the plants needs and the consumers desires. With these markets often hours away these logistics are no small task for small farms. If leaves wilt or vegetables soften, it will mean the hours of labor to get the plant ready from seed will have gone to waste. For more images on our relationship to land, environment and food systems follow me @joshuacogan
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on August 17, 2020.

ph_descripcion: I’m @CarltonWard, on assignment in my home state of Florida for @insidenatgeo working with a team to make a Last Wild Places film about the Florida Wildlife Corridor — a statewide network of public conservation lands and working farms and ranches that together provided connected habitat for wide ranging wildlife. We’ll be traveling by RV throughout the Florida Wildlife Corridor over the next three weeks. Please stay tuned for more updates from the field. Our first stop was Usher Land & Timber — a multi-generation forestry and cattle farm near the Suwannee River. In the first photo, filmmakers @danny_schmidt and @ricksmith_media are interviewing logger and conservationist @lynettaushergriner (also featured in the second photo). @fl_wildcorridor @pathofthepanther #lastwildplaces #keepflwild
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on August 14, 2020.

I took this photo less than a month after the sweeping national security law – which essentially criminalizes dissent – came into force. Even as the city is going through such turmoil, the skies remain beautiful. Follow @laurelchor for more on the #nationalsecuritylaw in #HongKong.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @laurelchor What makes Hong Kong special? Residents are proud of the city’s iconic streets, even as classic architecture and neon signage continuously disappear. Chronic nostalgia is a part of the Hong Kong’s soul: people cling onto the present as if it were already their past, because they don’t know how long it will last. For many, Beijing’s tightening grip and the new national security law has worsened fears that the city is changing beyond recognition. Follow @laurelchor for her work on the #nationalsecuritylaw in #HongKong.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Hong Kong.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by David Guttenfelder @dguttenfelder Wrapped in warm blankets, two friends sit on the roofs of their cars (parked to keep a safe social distance) to watch the sunset together over Minneapolis’ Lake Bde Maka Ska.

To me, it looked like an old-school Drive-In movie theater. People had parked their cars with wide space between them, sat behind the steering wheel or on the hood or rooftop, played music on their car radios, and watched nature’s cinematic, wide screen beauty.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Minneapolis, Minnesota.

ph_descripcion: Photo by David Guttenfelder @dguttenfelder Praying from the pews, worshippers at the New Hope Baptist Church in St. Paul, MN wear masks, gloves and keep their distance during Sunday morning services. The congregation, which had been holding drive-up services in the parking lot, have returned to the church with new coronavirus safety precautions and a live steaming choice for those who still prefer to stay home.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in St. Paul, Minnesota.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by David Guttenfelder @dguttenfelder Dave Lundberg stood in his Farmington, Minnesota front yard wearing a party hat and a “Over The Hill” t-shirt, surrounded by balloons and birthday signs, to celebrate his 50th birthday. During the Minnesota state-wide Covid-19 stay at home order his family-decorated the yard and Lundberg greeted friends and strangers passing by, honking their car horns.

The Midwest USA is seldom seen as an epicenter. The so-called flyover states are often overlooked. So during the early days of the Covid-19 pandemic, some imagined that our small towns and farm communities might, mercifully, be spared. And compared to the agonies of urban areas elsewhere, maybe we have been. But here too, there have been many heartbreaking lives lost and livelihoods destroyed. Families are struggling, weary, and bracing for what’s still to come.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Farmington, Minnesota.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @giles_price. We find ourselves unexpectedly living in an age when body temperature has assumed a new set of implications: we’re all potential carriers and spreaders of Covid-19. As part of a conceptual series of images shot on assignment, I have used a thermal camera to examine what daily life looks like with current restrictions placed on ordinary events and new routines becoming our everyday. Here, people enter and leave what is normally a congested shopping centre, Westfield Stratford City in East London, in June. With spending on non-essential items down 22% compared with last year, many customers continue to stay away from shops while health risks remain from the virus. To view more of my work, please follow me at @giles_price.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on August 07, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @joshuacogan A field of golden wheat ready for harvest in the Northern Neck region of Virginia (with a some purple iron weed in the second image). One of the teachings for me in the journey of this story, was seeing the broad range of items in a traditional market basket that one finds in the mid-atlantic. Due to the variety of micro-climates, altitudes, soil types and precipitation, farmers are able to sustain a broad range of plants and animals that feed people throughout the country. For more images on our relationship to land, environment and food systems follow me @joshuacogan
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on August 04, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @joshuacogan What is often most striking to me about farming is the combination of both intense physical labor and tenderness it requires in equal parts. After harvesting for hours, to the point of broken nails and calloused fingers on the Ochoa family farm where everything is done by hand, each individual berry is treated with care. Not only does the price that they fetch at market reflect this, but it is also a reflection of pride and respect farmers have for the plants themselves. For more images on our relationship to land, environment and food systems follow me @joshuacogan
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on August 02, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @joshuacogan Light beams pass through vining pea shoots on the Flores Family Farm in the Northern Neck of Virginia. The family grows some 200 types of crops throughout a growing season. While many large scale farms that focus on single crops were hit hard by the changes to the food system from the pandemic, a smaller farm like the Flores who had more direct access to their consumers was able to fare far better. For more images on our relationship to land, environment and food systems follow me @joshuacogan
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on July 31, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @giles_price We find ourselves unexpectedly living in an age when body temperature has assumed a new set of implications: we’re all potential carriers and spreaders of Covid-19. As part of a conceptual series of images shot on assignment, I used a thermal camera to examine what daily life looks like with current restrictions placed on ordinary events and new routines becoming our everyday. During lockdown thousands of homeless people in the UK were given emergency accommodation, this funding ran out at the end of June and people returned to the streets along with more made homeless by job losses. Here, in front of the National Gallery, London, homeless people queue to receive food from a mobile feeding van run by NishkamSWAT, a Sikh welfare and awareness charity who help the disadvantaged in society. For more of my work follow me on @giles_price

Photo by @cedricgerbehaye While the number of contaminations is increasing day after day and as Belgium passes into the orange zone in the epidemiological surveillance of the European Center of Disease Control, the number of daily tests remains constant and getting tested is still too often an obstacle course. Currently, Belgium is one of the few countries where there are restrictions on testing asymptomatic people.

1. In the radiotherapy department of the Tivoli hospital in La Louvière, Belgium, tests are carried out on a patient with COVID-19.  

2. X-ray of the thorax of a 69 year old patient with COVID-19.

Featured work created with the National Geographic Society COVID-19 Emergency Fund. To see more of my work follow @cedricgerbehaye
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on July 30, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @joshuacogan| Gerardo Flores checks the water flow on his sprinklers each morning. The farm gets it's fresh water from the springs that surround the marsh lands on the Northern Neck of Virginia. The silty nature of these water bodies often clogs the pumps that feed the irrigation systems, so require constant attention to make sure the morning and evening waterings run smoothly. To learn more about midatlantic food systems, agriculture and the environment follow me @joshuacogan
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on July 27, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photos by Keith Ladzinski @ladzinski / What you’re looking at here is a situation that spiraled out of control - This is a large scale #algaeBloom, one that has taken over hundreds of miles of #LakeErie. It’s the result of excess phosphates and nitrates in the water that have been introduced on a running timeline that dates well over 100 years. It’s primarily a derivative of large scale agriculture runoff that enters into the lake through tributary Rivers, irrigations or wind driven sediment. When the weather heats up, typically throughout July to September, these blooms ignite, only subsiding when temps cool down. Once these substances enter the water it can take 100,000’s of years for them to break down. As of now there’s no solution to remove them from the water, but hopefully in the future that will change. In the meantime this problem is wreaking havoc on the lakes ecosystem and the drinking water that millions upon millions of people rely on. To see more photos from this assignment please visit @ladzinski
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on July 26, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photos by Keith Ladzinski @ladzinski / A #WesternTigerSwallowtail butterfly collecting nectar from a blooming thistle near the rim of the @blackcanyonnps. This act of pollination is critical to a thriving ecosystem. Getting this photo was no easy task but admittedly fun all the same - My assistant @angelajpayne and I stalked this butterfly through a sage field for the better part of 30 minutes to get these photos, each with a small strobe in hand waiting for it to perch long enough so I could get low, grab focus, adjust the lights and snap off a frame or two. In the end it was a lot of fun minus the ant bites all over my legs and a few cactus needles! Glad it worked out in the end. To see more photos from this assignment please visit @ladzinski
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on July 25, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photos by Keith Ladzinski @ladzinski / Rock climbing in the Black Canyon of the Gunnison is notoriously adventurous and committing. It’s a sea of rock among steep cliffs, ambiguous to find your route and easy to loose your way. Once you drop in, up is the way out, unless you opt for the full rappel to the bottom of the gorge where river crossings, poison ivy and a steep trail out, if you can find it, is your only exit alternative. While working on this story I was in the best of hands with @mgclimber1 - aka Marcus Garcia, seen here climbing up the steep cliffs. He knows this maze riddled zone well and is a legend in the area, having climbed here over the last 20 years. He’s always excited to drop into the canyon for some vertical fun. To see more photos from this assignment please visit @ladzinski
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on July 23, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @giles_price We find ourselves unexpectedly living in an age when body temperature has assumed a new set of implications: we’re all potential carriers and spreaders of COVID-19. As part of a conceptual series of images shot on assignment during the pandemic, I’ve used a thermal camera to examine what daily life looks like with current restrictions placed on ordinary events and new routines becoming our everyday. Here, a participant in the Oxford University COVID-19 vaccine trial has her blood taken by a member of staff from the Vaccine Institute, St George’s, University of London and St George’s University Hospitals NHS Trust. Although there’s a long way to go, early results from the initial phases of the trial are extremely promising. To view more of my work, please follow me at @giles_price.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @TasneemAlsultan The Mina valley, surrounded by mountains, lies approximately 6 km away from the Grand Mosque to the east of Mecca. Usually it hosts around 2.5 million Muslim pilgrims during the Hajj season, which begins next week. This year, due to COVID-19, Saudi Arabia has taken precautions for the safety of the pilgrims and many changes will take place. Next week we will follow the pilgrims journey during this special event.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Mecca, Saudi Arabia.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Tomas van Houtryve @tomasvh The early morning is always my favorite time to visit the banks of the Seine River in Paris, just before the morning bustle of the city begins. This summer is particularly calm since the arrival of tourists from abroad has been curtailed by the COVID-19 pandemic. Bustling activity is taking place—night and day—inside the Notre-Dame cathedral however, seen on the left of this photo. Highly motivated teams of workers are still removing fire debris, melted scaffolding, and lead contamination from Notre-Dame, more than a year after a massive fire ravaged the roof and spire of the cathedral. Follow @tomasvh for more stories and images. #NotreDamedeParis #NotreDame #notredamecathedral
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on July 23, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @laurelchor My dog Digby soaks in the views on Lantau, Hong Kong’s largest island. I try to escape to the outdoors as much as I can. This city may be known for its skyscrapers, but 40% of its territory is protected wilderness. Even up in the mountains though, I’m often reminded of the last year of unrest when I come across pro-democracy protest slogans graffitied on sign posts. ph_descripcion: photo by @joshuacogan Gerardo Flores holds a few of the thousands of onion seedlings ready for planting on his farm in the Northern Neck Virginia tidewater region. The sandy loamy soil is great for many crops that don't grow well in wetter darker soils in the western mountainous areas of the east coast. Part of the reason I began this project was to understand exactly where my food was coming from as COVID disrupted so many supply chains. The question I was holding was whether this pandemic might actually change our food systems for the better? To learn more about what we found out about midatlantic food systems, agriculture and the environment follow me @joshuacogan

ph_descripcion: photo by @joshuacogan Being away from home is always hard, but especially during COVID times. We have a tradition of doing shabbat (the jewish sabbath) on friday night together, and this is the first one I had to miss for months since the pandemic started. While I got to photograph and join the dinner at with Jordan and Laura on their farm in the shenandoah valley, my family called me in for candle lighting back home which made me feel less far away. During lockdown in the UK, a quarter of British adults said they felt lonely, which has raised concerns about long-term mental health risks as the pandemic continues. Research by the Mental Health Foundation found that the worst affected were those aged 18-24 of which 44% expressed that the feeling of loneliness had impacted on their mental health. In this image, a lone figure walks through the Barbican Estate in London. To view more of my work please follow me at @giles_price.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @joshuacogan Early in the morning, farmer Jordan Green gets cracked corn meal from the feeder to put in his chicken coops as his dog gets shade from the summer heat. Jordan, who does free range animal farming in the Shenandoah Valley has seen his sales boom since the pandemic began, and has been trying to keep up with demand. Compared to commodity and industrial chicken farms, each one of Jordan's coops are outside on grass and moved across the field twice a day. To see more on my current project on regional agriculture, supply chains and food production during COVID times follow me @joshuacogan

ph_descripcion: Photo by Keith Ladzinski @ladzinski / A whirlpool from an exposed manhole, draining a heavily flooded area in Port Clinton, Ohio. This water is from excessively high lake levels, 36 inches higher than average, from snow melt off and a wet spring. ph_descripcion: Photo by @giles_price As part of a conceptual series of images shot on assignment during the COVID-19 pandemic, I’ve used a thermal camera to examine what daily life currently looks like with restrictions placed on ordinary events and new routines becoming our everyday. One such example is a daily temperature check using thermal technology. Here, a worker on a Laing O’Rourke construction project in Olympia, London, has his temperature taken in a purpose-built modular screening unit at the front entrance of the site. The camera automatically scans his face to find the inner canthus/tear duct of the eye, as this is the only place on the face to register an accurate body temperature reading. To view more of my work please follow me at @giles_price.
ph_atributos: Photo shared by Nat Geo in the Field on July 13, 2020 tagging @natgeointhefield, and @giles_price.

The CT scan of the chest is an important tool in monitoring the evolution of inflammation and the diagnosis of patients with COVID-19.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @giles_price As part of a conceptual series of images shot on assignment during the COVID-19 pandemic, I’ve used a thermal camera to examine what daily life currently looks like with restrictions placed on ordinary events and new routines becoming our everyday. Here, pupils at L’Ecole de Battersea - an English-French bilingual preparatory school in South London - are asked to line up in socially distanced class bubbles before entering the school. Since reopening at the start of June the school has been seeking solutions to lower the risk of transmission between staff and pupils and have implemented a range of measures. Contact-free temperature checks are now standard at the school entrance as well as the installation of IQ air purifiers with HEPA filters, which remove PM2.5 particles containing bacteria and viruses. Fogging machines, which use Hypochlorous acid to decontaminate the school, are also used throughout the building. This has resulted in no reported cases of COVID-19 at the school during the pandemic so far. To view more of my work please follow me at @giles_price.
ph_atributos: Photo shared by Nat Geo in the Field on July 12, 2020 tagging @natgeointhefield, and @giles_price.

In this image, Londoners are enjoying being back on Primrose Hill and looking out over the city as lockdown is gradually eased, but social distancing remains in place. ph_descripcion: Photo by Keith Ladzinski @ladzinski / A nuclear power plant on the fringe of a wetland in Oak Harbor, Ohio. In total, the Great Lakes region has 38 nuclear facilities, the newest of which was built in 1975. These plants create carbon free energy but produce substantial nuclear waste. They pose a big question as to what to do with them once they’ve reached their productive life, which for many is already happening. To see more photos of my #GreatLakes assignment, please visit @ladzinski

ph_descripcion: Photo by @cedricgerbehaye Undertakers Greg and Jean-Pierre from the Donato funeral service seal the coffin of a 48 year old man who died from COVID-19 in La Louvière, Hainaut region in Belgium. Both men work 7 days a week and 24 hours a day because their colleagues are at risk given their advanced age. For a few weeks the COVID-19 death rate in the country was the highest in the world due to the counting system which included unconfirmed cases in nursing homes for elderly people where tests were impossible or done only late. ph_descripcion: Photo by @nicholesobecki The coronavirus pandemic has altered the world immeasurably, and often in difficult, painful ways. As I’ve covered the impact of the virus here in Kenya though, I’ve also tried to look for the lighter, more mundane transformations. Prince Executive Barbers was not only the coolest barbershop I’ve ever seen, with its old school vibe and vivid lime and pink walls. It was also one of the safest, with frequent and mandatory hand washing, masks and face shields. I know where I’ll go next time I need a trim. Follow me on @nicholesobecki for more coverage of the Covid-19 crisis in Kenya.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Nairobi, Kenya.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @nicholesobecki Portrait of Raymond Brian, a Ugandan refugee and a non-binary person who goes by the name of Mother Nature, outside the safe house they helped found in a Nairobi suburb. Like several others in the house, Mother Nature had been approved for resettlement to a third country before the coronavirus crisis hit and all travel was put on indefinite hold. Scroll to the second frame to meet Chris Wasswa, who goes by the name Tina, sharing a quiet moment with his boyfriend of nearly two years. Both Mother Nature and Tina are among the nearly 500 migrants in Kenya (and more than 3,000 across Africa and 10,000 worldwide), who have been left in limbo by the pandemic. For gay and transgender Ugandan refugees in Kenya, such delays comes with immediate risks. “The delay was really traumatizing,” said Mother Nature, explaining that their community has also had to grapple with rising homophobia as fear and uncertainty around the virus leaves people searching for someone to blame, however unfairly. Now, restrictions on resettlement are lifting, and those waiting to rebuild their lives are once again allowing themselves to hope. Follow me on @nicholesobecki for more coverage of the Covid-19 crisis in Kenya.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on July 01, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @nicholesobecki They came in the early morning of May 4, defying a court order and evicting about 7,000 people from their homes in Nairobi’s Sewage settlement, including Patrick Mwangi and his family. Then the excavators came, and even the chance to gather ones belongings was lost. Deprived of their home, they were forced to sleep out in the open for over a week, leaving them at higher risk of exposure to Covid-19 and of being arrested for breaking curfew. These mass evictions have led to an outcry from human rights groups, but a second round took place in Ruai just weeks later. They’ve also led to a further breakdown of public trust. “I used to believe what they told us about Covid-19,” Patrick told me. “But if the virus were real I can’t believe the government would have left so many of us homeless.” Follow me on @nicholesobecki for more coverage of the Covid-19 crisis in Kenya.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on June 30, 2020.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @pepbonet_noor |
A fusion of citizen science and sustainable tourism on board the 1965 classic yacht, Falcao Uno. Under the leadership of marine biologists from @cleanwavemovement, they created a floating laboratory, investigating invasive species and micro plastic pollution; in collaboration with
Lifexperiences Events they are exploring new ways to engage tourists in the protection and regeneration of the Mediterranean Sea.
Here in the photo they use the Manta to trawl for microplastics off the coast of Mallorca. Plastic pollution continues to threaten the delicate marine ecosystem of the Mediterranean Sea, as the world's population consumes 1 million plastic bottles every minute.
On board the floating laboratory, Falcao Uno, marine biologists and @cleanwavemovement founder Philipp Baier, work together on a marine citizen science initiative, Med Gardens, to regenerate the coastal seabeds around the Balearic Islands.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on June 29, 2020.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @pepbonet_noor |
Gori Mayol, left, is a responsible, traditional fisherman from Port de Sóller. He has been fishing since he was 13 years old, his father taught him how to fish on his boat. Now, Gori is the captain of the same Llaüt (traditional Majorcan fishing boat) and works with a sailor & fisherman, Vincent Colom (half Majorcan and half French). For them sustainable fishing is very important, they use now nets with bigger holes for the small fish not to be caught.
When they grab some small fish or small lobsters they throw them back into the sea. Responsable fishing by the local fishers is growing fast. Good news for the planet.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on June 25, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by L. Kasimu Harris @visionsandverbs | “Big Sam” Williams of Big Sam’s Funky Nation taking a solo during an online performance from the driveway of his New Orleans home, on Memorial Day. Williams, like so many artists who sheltered-in-place, turned to the internet to remain connected to their fans and offered entertainment and a respite from the isolation. The online concerts have also afforded Williams and his band an opportunity recoup some income through cash apps. Live performance venues in New Orleans remain shuttered do to the coronavirus.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on June 25, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @nicholesobecki | Their bags were packed, their furniture sold, and their business shuttered. After years of waiting Bidasi Munyaneza, who is blind, and his daughters Amour Kazena and Solange Nirere — all refugees from the Democratic Republic of Congo — had been approved for resettlement to Australia on March 30. Then global restrictions on travel because of the coronavirus put that process on hold. After years of trauma, the delay and uncertainty of their situation hit the family hard. They’re among more than 3,000 refugees in Africa and 10,000 worldwide whose resettlement was halted temporarily by the pandemic, according to the International Organization for Migration. Now, restrictions are beginning to ease, raising hopes that Bidasi and his family may finally begin the next chapter of their life. “All I can think of is Australia, and peace,” Bidasi said. “I just want to live without fear.” Follow me on @nicholesobecki for more coverage of the Covid-19 crisis in Kenya.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on June 25, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Keith Ladzinski @ladzinski | Manned by a large crane on the surface, a transport cage is seen here being lowered hundreds of feet down into Chicago’s TARP (Tunnel And Reservoir Project). This subterranean network of tunnels is roughly 109 miles long and is a waste and flood water diversion system for Chicago’s metropolitan area. From these tunnels, water is directed and contained in multi-billion gallon reservoirs where it’s cleaned and reintroduced back into a nearby channel that eventually leads to the Mississippi river. Seeing Engineering at this level is a widely eye opening perspective into the lengths necessary for clean water and management in our heavily populated world. Big thank you to the engineers and PR team at TARP for the inside look.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Chicago, Illinois with @ladzinski.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @nicholesobecki | Fashion stylist Wambui Thimba poses wearing a creation by designer Angelsmile for a #QuarantineFashion series she launched with photographer and roommate Barbara Minishi, who also led the production design and lighting for the project, to safely showcase Kenyan fashion in the midst of the Covid-19 pandemic, from the parking lot of their apartment in Nairobi. Minishi said the project for her epitomized the saying “bloom where you’re planted,” allowing the roommates to “use their skills… while still honoring the parameters of #stayhome and social distancing.” Follow me on @nicholesobecki for more coverage of the Covid-19 crisis in Kenya.

ph_descripcion:
Infrared photo by @pepbonet_noor |
Cúber is an artificial water reservoir located on the slopes of Puig Major and Morro de Cúber, on the island of Mallorca.
Together with the Gorg Blau reservoir, it supplies water to the city of Palma de Mallorca and in the surrounding area.
The water from these two reservoirs is distributed to the municipalities of the metropolitan area of Palma de Mallorca through the Torrente de Almadrava.
The Serra de Tramuntana has been declared a World Heritage Site by UNESCO under the Cultural Landscape category. This is the international community’s acknowledgement of the near-perfect symbiosis between the action of human beings and nature, which has occurred for centuries, resulting in a monumental work by humans in which culture, traditions, aesthetics, spirituality and identity are merged.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on June 22, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @nicholesobecki | As protests continue across the US, Kenyans went to the street to demand justice for their own victims of police killings — and express solidarity with movements worldwide. A police watchdog said 15 deaths have been linked to police action since authorities imposed a coronavirus curfew in late March, but rights groups say the number is even higher. The demonstration ended near the apartment block of 13-year-old Yasin Moyo, who was shot and killed by police while playing on his balcony after curfew. ph_descripcion: Photo by @lynseyaddario | COVID-19 Patient, Foysal Ahmad, 51, rests before attempting to walk with the help of medical staff and physiotherapists at Royal Papworth Hospital in Cambridge, England, June 15, 2020. Ahmed was among some of the most severe COVID-19 patients in the country, though after 55 days in the ICU, is making great strides with his recovery. He is on an ECMO machine, Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation, which pumps and oxygenates a patient's blood outside the body—which essentially does the job of the lungs externally in order to give the body a chance to rest and recover. Royal Papworth is one of only five hospitals in England to provide ECMO machines for respiratory failure, and its critical care unit, pictured here, was among one of the hospitals in a England which took part in the trial for the steroid drug called dexamethasone, would has been shown to reduce mortality in severely ill COVID-19 patients. The official government death toll of COVID-19 in the United Kingdom is one of the highest in the world, with over 41,000 deaths. Featured work shot on assignment for @natgeo. To see more of my work follow @lynseyaddario.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on June 19, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photos by Keith Ladzinski @ladzinski | Fertilizer, being poured into a large underground container to be mixed and loaded into industrial sprayers. Feeding the masses is difficult and complex work, fertilizer is critical for large scale agriculture to provide higher yield as well as bring nutrients and immunities to high volume crops. Fertilizer ingredients typically have the big 3 - Nitrogen: the top nutrient plants absorb and ensures health. Phosphorus: which helps plants to store energy and helps with photosynthesis absorption. Potassium: which helps with the plants strength and root systems. Historically speaking, fertilizers have made large strides but can still be problematic if they aren’t absorbed by plants and instead enter water systems. Algae blooms are one example of when excess phosphorus makes its way into water systems. Many farmers are taking to winter crop coverage over the years, non harvested crops that get tilled and help add nutrients into the ground. This coverage helps to keep soil intact, preventing air driven migration of fertilizers into water systems.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on June 18, 2020.

Fertilizer ingredients typically have the big 3 - Nitrogen: the top nutrient plants absorb and ensures health. Phosphorus: which helps plants to store energy and helps with photosynthesis absorption. Potassium: which helps with the plants strength and root systems. Historically speaking, fertilizers have made large strides but can still be problematic if they aren’t absorbed by plants and instead enter water systems. Algae blooms are one example of when excess phosphorus makes its way into water systems. Many farmers are taking to winter crop coverage over the years, non harvested crops that get tilled and help add nutrients into the ground. This coverage helps to keep soil intact, preventing air driven migration of fertilizers into water systems.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on June 18, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @nicholesobecki | Families wait for a food distribution supported by a group of Kenyans living in Ireland, who launched a fundraiser to support those evicted from their homes in Nairobi’s Kariobangi settlement. Kenyan authorities forcibly evicted more than 7,000 people from land in an area known as Sewage this past April, defying a court order and leaving many stranded and homeless in the midst of the pandemic. Compounding these challenges, the country has also faced a devastating desert locust invasion and excessive rainfall, creating a perfect storm for food security this year. Follow me on @nicholesobecki for more coverage of the Covid-19 crisis in Kenya.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Nairobi, Kenya.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @lynseyaddario | COVID-19 Patient, Foysal Ahmad, 51, speaks with his wife, Nipa Begum, from the Intensive Care unit of the Royal Papworth Hospital in Cambridge, England, June 15, 2020. Foysal was among some of the most severe COVID-19 patients in the country, though after 55 days in the ICU, is making great strides with his recovery. Ahmed is on an ECMO machine, Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation , which essentially does the job of the lungs externally in order to give the body a chance to rest and recover. The Royal Papworth is one of only five centers in England to provide ECMO machines for respiratory failure. Even though the UK's death rate is falling, doctors continue to treat patients for COVID-19 across the country with many fearing a 'second wave' as lockdown rules continue to relax. The official government death toll of COVID-19 in the United Kingdom is one of the highest in the world, with over 41,000 deaths. Featured work shot on assignment for @natgeo. To see more of my work follow @lynseyaddario.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on June 17, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @lynseyaddario | Sean Kill, the foreman at Stoneman Funeral Service makes the final preparations on a coffin of a victim of COVID-19 in the garage where the funeral home had roughly 35 other coffins filled with victims of the Novel Coronavirus, in Surrey, south of London, England, May 21, 2020.  For more than 8 weeks, Stoneman Funeral services and its employees handled almost double the amount of funerals than average;  the funeral home had come close to running out of coffins, and has had to do makeshift storage methods to accommodate the deceased, including clearing out two garages normally used for hearses to accommodate those who passed away with COVID-19 and suspected COVID-19.  Many funeral directors and employees at funeral homes across England have expressed frustration with care homes, hospitals, and mortuaries, which don't always divulge whether a person has passed away with COVID-19 because they are legally not obliged to do so, even though this may put those who work with the deceased at increased risk of exposure. As a result, many funeral directors have been treating every death as if it were COVID+, and don the appropriate PPE while preparing the dead for burial. The United Kingdom was one of the last countries in Europe to decide on a nation-wide lockdown, and it now is suffering one of the worst death rates in the world, with the official government toll at over 41,000 deaths. Featured work created with the National Geographic Society COVID-19 Emergency Fund. To see more of my work, follow @lynseyaddario. @insidenatgeo
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on June 13, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @nicholesobecki | Lydia Akoth and her best friend Valentine Ayuma practice ballet through an online class on the sofa of Lydia’s home in Kibera, the largest of more than 100 informal settlements in Nairobi. The coronavirus pandemic is forcing children around the world to stay home and learn remotely, but Lydia and Valentine face huge obstacles to this: no computer, limited access to the internet, and little space to practice once their studio at Project Elimu closed its doors. “It’s scary right now in Kibera,” Valentine told me. “It’s crowded, and we’re worried about how fast the virus could spread. But practicing makes me forget everything. I feel like I’m flying.” Follow me on @nicholesobecki for more coverage of the Covid-19 crisis in Kenya.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Nairobi, Kenya.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @chiaragoia | In mid-April, I visited a few undertaking businesses in the worst affected provinces of Lombardy, the epicenter of COVID-19 in Italy. I never had the chance to extensively speak with people working in this field before and I found it valuable to do so during such a hard time. I wanted to hear their opinion, perspectives, and first-hand accounts. Many of their stories touched me; some of them were as clear as photos; others were quite disturbing. Here are some of the portraits, along with excerpts of interviews about their experience during COVID-19.
Michele Scaccabarozzi works at Giardino Degli Angeli, a funeral home near Milan. "I have the feeling that this is not over yet, although the number of deaths that we handle seems to have gone back to normal, for now.”
Cristiano Zanchi has worked in this business since 1992, he is now a staff manager. "One day, we had to organize 60 funerals, which was very tough as we usually do five or six per day."
Guido Monticelli has been working as an undertaker since 1980. "What impressed me the most was to see bodies of people who got literally consumed by the disease."
Fabio Brignoli works in the undertaking business for 10 years. "It's a stupid thing, it will pass soon, I thought. But at work, we started to see too many deaths, and [...] I started to understand what we were going through. It wasn't just an illness anymore; it transformed into a silent war."
Roberta Caprini comes from a family of undertakers “The thought that would save me every day was always to try to make a special gesture for the families of the deceased people."
Roberta Magoni works at Centro Funerario Bergamasco "Thank God my parents died two years ago, so I was able to tend to them, [...]. I wouldn't have been able to do it if they'd got ill during this time [of COVID-19]."
Enea Rota has worked as an undertaker for almost ten years. "I don't think I have fully metabolized what has happened in the past month and a half with this virus.”
To read more about this experience, a full article is now online. To see more of my work, visit @chiaragoia #covid19 #italy
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on June 10, 2020.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @matjaztancic | Cao Junjie, 30 years old, is a Chinese industrial designer and an innovator. His younger son Cao Shangfei, 4 months old, was born in midst of the pandemic in China and that urged Cao to come up with a solution. It didn't take long for him to adapt a backpack intended to carry a pet cat or puppy to a fully functional baby pod. The baby pod was fitted with an air purifying system and a device monitoring the air flow and air quality in the pod. After the baby outgrew the baby pod he designed the second edition that is completely 3D printed and features the same air purifying system (pictured here). The inspiration for the first baby pod came from the PlayStation game, Death Stranding. It took him 2 weeks and 6000 yuan ($840usd) to build it. The current 3D printed model took 4 weeks to complete with the same production cost.

Now that the pandemic is under the control in China, Cao is building a device that would help firefighters get in their gear faster and, well, also help him get dressed faster in the mornings. I have their family home in Langxia Town near Ningbo in Zhejiang province about 180 kilometers from Shanghai. In the photo you can see also his wife Kuang Lulu, 25 years old.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on June 10, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photos by Keith Ladzinski @ladzinski | Sunset over the U.S.S. Edson and a flooded parking lot at the Naval museum in Bay City, Michigan. Water levels are substantially high in the Great Lakes region once again this season, creating heavy damage and erosion throughout costal regions. The flooding has caused a delayed opening here at the museum, and an additional dock to be built to access the ship. While visiting the area I met a local volunteer named Bruce (swipe to see photo) a Vietnam era vet that was a fire control gunner on this very ship, a destroyer which is now a retired piece of history that can be toured and viewed by the public.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @ruddyroye | Lan (back left) and her friends wait for marchers to convene in New York’s Washington Square Park during protests following the May 25 death of George Floyd. When asked about her hopes for the outcome, Lan responded: “What I hope to see is a world where our kids, grandkids, and descendants grow up looking at the history books about racism and see it as completely unfathomable. The same way we look at our books and think slavery is unfathomable. The same way we can’t even imagine still living in a world like that. I want them to think of our time now ... just like that.”

ph_descripcion: Photo by @ruddyroye | Julius, a resident of Fort Greene, in Brooklyn, watches the protests linked to the May 25 death of George Floyd. Julius, who hails from Attapulgus, Georgia, said he was tired of having to go through this moment again. “They are killing us—they have always been killing us. What they are doing is like pushing us back into slavery. I remember when they choked that big guy [Eric Garner], I knew him. What’s wrong with these cops? They are trying to break our spirit, like Roots.”

As a mother, I was in pain when I heard George Floyd cry for his momma. I thought about my son immediately, and I knew I had to come out here in these streets. ph_descripcion: Photo by David Guttenfelder @dguttenfelder | Datelle Straub, Avery Lewis, and Titan Harness-Reed arrive at the Minneapolis protest wearing their 2020 graduation caps and gowns from Patrick Henry High School. They had a virtual ceremony due to COVID-19. “Because of COVID we couldn’t walk the stage, so we decided to put our robes on to show that there is black excellence in our community. And we walked the streets as our stage and protested,” Straub said. When he saw police approaching, he lifted his diploma. “As we were walking, cops jumped out of a van and aimed their guns at me and my friends. And put a red dot on our chests. It’s just frustrating that they are OK with killing the future.”

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @dannywilcoxfrazier | While in Detroit, I photographed Dr. Marjan Moghaddam as she checked Marcus Robinson's lungs at the Eastern Market. Robinson was suffering from a cough for several days, a typical symptom of COVID-19. Moghaddam recently returned to work at Henry Ford Hospital after testing positive for COVID-19 on March 29. Moghaddam works with medical students for Detroit Street Care and Street Medicine Detroit.
Moghaddam's family fled religious persecution in Iran and eventually emigrated to Canada in 1984. She has devoted her medical practice to underserved communities, including rural southern Georgia, before returning to Michigan where she teaches at Michigan State University’s medical school and works at Henry Ford Hospital Walk-In Clinics and Urgent Care Centers. "I went into medicine to save everybody, not just one person," Moghaddam said about her work with vulnerable and uninsured populations. "Because I see people at walk-in clinics my exposure was there." Many frontline health workers such as Moghaddam have contracted COVID-19.
Out in digital form, the essay and story, Detroit’s winning spirit helps it fight back against COVID-19, documents the disproportionate impact COVID-19 has had on poor residents in Detroit, especially the staggering statistic that African Americans make up 77% of COVID deaths in the city. Michigan Governor Gretchen Whitmer has taken action to study the disparities and impact coronavirus has had on African Americans. "This virus is holding up a mirror to our society, and reminding us of the deep inequities in our country, from basic lack of access to care, to access to transportation, to access to labor protections in the workplace," Governor Whitmer said.
While in Detroit, I was inspired by the strength and compassion I witnessed in the face of this crisis. There is not another city in the United States that has endured so much injustice, but still carries a powerful sense of pride and community. Please read Cassandra Spratling's personal account of COVID's impact on her family and community, her loved ones not escaping the impact of coronavirus. #onassignment #natgeo
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Detroit, Michigan.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @gena.g.steffens | Josef Villareal is 26, born and raised in Bogotá, Colombia. He’s gentle and soft-spoken, with an air of humble confidence about him. We talked for a long while, about many things, including the story of his life. Unlike most people, he doesn’t shy away from a single detail, not even the darkest chapters. He owns them, as we all should. Today, he’s just a normal dad trying to make sure his kids have enough to eat during the pandemic. He said a lot of things that I’ll never forget. One of them: “If I can be a warrior in the streets, in the gangs, I can be a warrior for my family.” Here he is outside his home in Altos de Cazucá. Follow me @gena.g.steffens for more. #colombia #barrio #womenphotograph
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on May 28, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photos by @xyzacruzbacani | In the first image, a temporary hand washing stations sits in the middle of the wet market in Bambang, a small town in Nueva Vizcaya, Philippines. After losing income for two months when President Duterte ordered a Luzon-wide enhanced community quarantine, store tenants are moving to a new space after the local government pushes through with the renovation. In the second image, residents of Bambang must follow a schedule and use a quarantine pass issued by the local government unit before they can enter the market. In the final image, Meliton, a market worker, checks the temperature of a resident before they can enter the wet market. With a population of 56,000, Bambang has no positive cases yet. I’m following this developing story for @natgeo . #philippines #asia #covid19
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on May 25, 2020.

After losing income for two months when President Duterte ordered a Luzon-wide enhanced community quarantine, store tenants are moving to a new space after the local government pushes through with the renovation. In the second image, residents of Bambang must follow a schedule and use a quarantine pass issued by the local government unit before they can enter the market. In the final image, Meliton, a market worker, checks the temperature of a resident before they can enter the wet market. With a population of 56,000, Bambang has no positive cases yet. I’m following this developing story for @natgeo . #philippines #asia #covid19
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on May 25, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @lynseyaddario | A coffin containing the body of a 56-year-old man is led down the aisle by two pall bearers, followed by undertaker Sarah Wallace, during his funeral at the Sedgemoor Crematorium in Somerset, England, on April 23. The deceased's father and son were the only mourners in attendance, as many loved ones fear attending funerals during the COVID-19 pandemic and comply with social distancing. The United Kingdom was one of the last in Europe to call for a nationwide lockdown to prevent large-scale deaths and illness from the coronavirus, and their current death toll is now the second highest in the world behind the United States, with over 35,000 deaths. To see more of my work follow @lynseyaddario.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @gena.g.steffens | Originally from the state of Carabobo, in Venezuela, Jolver Jurado had been working as a carpenter in Bogotá when the pandemic hit. He lost his job and, unable to pay his rent, started the journey back to his own country on foot several days ago. He estimates it will take him 20 days to get to the border. “It’s sad. I’m going back there defeated.” Follow me @gena.g.steffens for more. #colombia #insidenatgeo #womenphotograph #venezolanos
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on May 20, 2020.

Photo by Dhruv Malhotra @dmjaipur | Scientist Miss Neha Sharma and Lab technician Miss Maya, load tubes that contain dead virus RNA extracted from samples mixed with an accelerant for amplification into the realtime PCR machine in the Amplification room at the ADRL SMS Medical College, Jaipur, India. The real-time PCR machine will take 46 - 94 such samples and test them over a two hour period giving results at the end of the automatic process.

#covid19 #RT-PCR #testing #Jaipur #India

ph_descripcion:
Photo by Dhruv Malhotra @dmjaipur | Afternoon shift team inside the high security BSL 3 lab for testing COVID-19 samples at the ADRL SMS Medical College, Jaipur India. Nasal or throat swab samples arrive suspended in viral transport medium in sealed tubes, packed in sample transport boxes stored with cool packs. They are opened after exterior sanitization only in the BSL 3 lab. First, the sample is verified and numbered, then it is opened in the bio safety cabinet and a part is transferred to a tube containing Lysis buffer to kiil the virus and prepare for the next step – RNA extraction at a BSL2 lab.
In the third image, technicians work within the bio safety cabinet inside the BSL 3 lab, transferring viral samples from collection tubes to Eppendorf tubes, then discarding the excess sample from the pipette. The sample collection tube is sealed and kept, the ones that are confirmed positive are frozen and stored for future research. The loaded Eppendorf tubes are decontaminated from the outside and taken to another lab for RNA extraction of the virus either via automatic machines or using manual methods.

#covid19 #bsl3 #virology #Jaipur #India
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on May 19, 2020.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by Dhruv Malhorta @dmjaipur | Medical workers collect samples via throat swabs at a tent camp in Shivnagar II, Murlipura Extension, Jaipur India. Widespread on-location sample collection is being conducted as there have been several positive cases in the area and for effective community tracking they are trying to test as many people as possible. The patient first provides details to the pair of doctors who are sat together under the tent and then proceeds to have a sample collected via throat swab, the swab stick is suspended in viral transport medium in a sealable tube that is numbered, put into a zip lock, sanitized, and put into the chilled sample transport boxes that lie on the table.
#covid19 #samplecollection #medicalworkers #india
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on May 19, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @gena.g.steffens | As for many who live alone—myself included—Pedro Pablo Vega Reyes has struggled to keep his emotional health afloat during endless weeks of social isolation. Loneliness, or the lack of meaningful contact with other humans, is known to cause changes in the brain. For many, it can have serious consequences for mental health. I asked him what he tells himself each day when he wakes up in the morning. “This is about emotional survival,” he says. “So, I just tell myself, I’m going to try to remain calm regardless of whether it’s a good day or a bad day. I’m going to remain calm and wait for tomorrow to come.” Follow me @gena.g.steffens for more. #colombia #mentalhealth #loneliness #insidenatgeo
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on May 18, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photos by David Chancellor @chancellordavid | A bull elephant pulls itself clear of its muddy grave to gasp another breath of air in the Nanapa Conservancy, northern Kenya. The elephant is caught in sinking mud at the edge of a dam. A herder found it and immediately went to find a community ranger. The ranger notified his control room. Rangers are mobilized with support from the Loisaba conservancy (@loisaba_conservancy) and the Northern Rangelands Trust (@nrt_kenya) including @kieran.avery whose work I’ve been documenting this past week. He’s the one seen here digging it out. The elephant, now exhausted and severely dehydrated, is part dug, part dragged out of the mud that would surely have been his grave. Having been washed down it got up, gave itself a good shake and wandered off for a spot of browsing. The point here for me is not only that the elephant is now alive and well, but also more importantly, that all these organizations, although operating in extraordinarily remote parts of Kenya, are able to communicate, plan, support, and action the rescue and continued long life of this incredible creature. This has been a Herculean task to get to this point. The point, my point, is that it takes money to do this, and to maintain the infrastructure to support it. Without income from tourism in this part of the world this is going to get increasingly difficult to replicate. We all bang on about what will happen if tourism doesn’t return. However, if COVID-19 rips the soul out of this part of the planet it will not only be those who consume wildlife products that will be threatened by its icy talons, but also those magnificent creatures which these products are derived from: the wildlife itself. It’s vital we keep supporting those who support them on our behalf. To see more follow me @chancellordavid @natgeo @natgeointhefield #covid_19 #stopwildlifetrade #elephant 🖤
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on May 17, 2020.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by Muhammad Fadli @mfimages | Up to 20 million people usually travel within Indonesia for Eid al-Fitr, the holiday that concludes the holy month of Ramadan. This time, due to the economic impact of COVID-19 outbreak, many people have started their journey much earlier, even before Ramadan began. Pictured here are passengers on an intercity bus from Jakarta to Padang, a city on the west coast of Sumatra. The journey will take at least 40 hours, and due to high demand the bus company largely ignored the government’s rule to leave half the vehicle empty.

Follow me @mfimages for more coverage of COVID-19 outbreak in Indonesia and to see my other works.

#covid19 #coronavirus #mudik #indonesia
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on May 16, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @lynseyaddario | Garry Cooper, 68, works on a coffin at Turner Manufacturing, where the employees are working six to seven days a week to deliver coffins around southwest England during the COVID-19 pandemic. Colin Turner, 58, said, “This is the busiest we have been in 20 years; every one of our customers are all busy, and the southwest isn’t big on the COVID scale.” Turner now has a four-week waiting time for coffins, and is making 150 a week—the maximum they are capable of making—as opposed to their normal 100 a week. The United Kingdom was one of the last in Europe to call for a nationwide lockdown to prevent large-scale deaths and illness from the coronavirus, and its current death toll is now on track to be one of the highest in Europe, with over 30,000 recorded deaths. To see more of my work, follow @lynseyaddario.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on May 15, 2020.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @ruddyroye | One last touch and a flood of tears as Mike raised his eyes to the ceiling to wail, as Andrew Cleckley, the funeral home director began lowering the lid to the casket.
Annie Lewis, his mother, was 74-years-old when she passed in a nursing home in New York. The mother of four children and six grandchildren was warmly celebrated at a small ceremony made up of mostly close family members at the funeral home. Like so many New Yorkers, Ms. Lewis died without the company of her loved ones. “She had so much love for her children and family. She gave us so much love in her laughter, her concerns, her jokes , and especially the food she cooked for us. She lived in New York for 50 years, she lived her family,” daughter Alicia told me.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Brooklyn, New York.

ph_descripcion: Photos + video by @gena.g.steffens | Across the spectrum of wealth in Bogotá, Colombia, the crisis of COVID-19 looks and feels very different. Angie Patrícia Giraldo Duarte and her daughter, Karen, live in Unir II. Procuring food has become increasingly difficult, but what worries Angie most is her daughter’s schooling. Teachers have sent assignments to be completed online, but they don’t own a computer. “We’re falling behind,” Angie says. In the leafy sector of Virrey, there is less tension in the air. “For people who have the opportunity to be with their family, stay indoors, Rappis that bring everything to your doorstep, this is an ideal situation,” says María Angela. “But obviously, we realize this isn’t the reality for most countries, or even for most of our city.” Scroll for videos from the two very different neighborhoods where these pictures took place. Follow @gena.g.steffens for more. #covid19 #colombia #inequality
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on May 14, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photos by @gena.g.steffens | In one of the most affluent districts of Bogotá, Colombia, the streets are largely silent. A Louis Vuitton store is boarded up with a sign that reads, "The trip has stopped momentarily, eventually it will continue. Louis Vuitton wishes you and your loved ones health and security.” Meanwhile, in the same city, weeks of quarantine have unleashed a wave of distress in places like Altos de Cazucá. Many families are going hungry, and others, unable to pay their rent, are getting evicted from their homes. Residents here openly defy orders to stay indoors, risking their health and that of others to bring food home to their families. Follow me @gena.g.steffens for more. #covid19 #colombia #everydaylatinamerica
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on May 14, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Mark Thiessen @thiessenphoto | Recently Dr. Fauci came to the National Geographic photo studio so I could take his portrait to run along side an exclusive interview. Today he testified in front of the US Senate via video conference on the complex topic of opening up the US. He is in a modified quarantine because he came in contact with someone in the White House that tested positive for COVID-19. Fauci, the director of the U.S. National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, has become the scientific face of America’s COVID-19 response, and he said in our exclusive interview the best evidence shows the virus behind the pandemic was not made in a lab in China. He shot down the discussion that has been raging among politicians and pundits, calling it “a circular argument” in a conversation. In his almost 40 years as director of NIAID where he has tackled dozens of outbreaks, including HIV/AIDS, Fauci says the coronavirus is "extraordinary." Thanks to @beckythale for her assistance. Follow me on @thiessenphoto for more of my photography.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on May 12, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @lynseyaddario | Henry Robbins sprays a finish onto a coffin at Turner Manufacturing, where he and his colleagues are working 6-7 days per week to deliver coffins around South West England during the COVID-19 pandemic in Yeovil, England, April 30, 2020. The owner, Colin Turner, 58, said “this is the busiest we have been in 20 years; every one of our customers are all busy, and the South West isn’t big on the COVID scale.“ Turner has a four week waiting time now for coffins, and is making 150 per week—the maximum they are capable of making—as opposed to their normal 100 per week. The United Kingdom was one of the last in Europe to call for a nationwide lockdown to prevent large-scale deaths and illness from the Coronavirus, and their current death toll is now on track to be one of the highest in Europe, with over 30,000 deaths. To see more of my work, follow @lynseyaddario.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on May 12, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by David Chancellor @chancellordavid | Occasionally, just occasionally, you meet someone who makes you reconsider life and all that it entails. This last week, I spent time in Biliqo Bulesa Community Conservancy documenting some of the work and projects of the Northern Rangelands Trust @nrt_kenya. This is part of a larger story looking at how the downturn in tourism due to #covid19 will affect communities across northern Kenya. As a community led organization, they are seeing the impact of the pandemic across 42,000 sq kilometers of indigenous lands. I spent time with nursing officer Madina Kalo, who is employed by the Kenya government, seen here with Ramadan, who she delivered safely into the hands of his mother Hadija Galma. Madina is the lifeline that the entire population here rely upon; she is supported by volunteer community health officers who are currently employed informing the population about how to avoid COVID-19. However, life goes on here and during the time I spent with her, working from a tiny surgery room, attached to an even smaller delivery room, she dealt with malaria, fever (non-COVID related) coughs, colds, severed fingers, pregnancies, family planning, prenatal, and post-natal issues. She will shortly move into a slightly larger clinic, built by @nrt_kenya; it’s not grand, and definitely not well equipped but I’m certain she’ll fill it with the love and human spirit that has already burst the walls on the existing one. Difficult times ahead for all of us, but please do consider these communities who rely on the support of others, whether through tourism, or funding, both of which are becoming increasingly difficult to find. To see more follow me @chancellordavid @natgeo @natgeointhefield #northernkenya #kenya 🖤 #happymothersday 🇰🇪
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on May 10, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @lynseyaddario | Christine Baker, 72, and her husband, Peter Baker, 76, wave goodbye to her brother, Eric Hallett, 76, as his coffin is passes by on the street of Crewkerne, in southwest England, on May 4. He passed away in a nursing home. Because of the COVID-19 pandemic, Christine and her sisters were unable to attend his funeral in the crematorium, due to a social distancing limit on the number of mourners who can fit inside the hall, so family members lined the streets as his coffin made the journey from the funeral home to the crematorium. The United Kingdom was one of the last in Europe to call for a nationwide lockdown to prevent large-scale deaths and illness from the virus, and its current death toll is now on track to be one of the highest in Europe, with over 30,000 deaths. To see more of my work, follow @lynseyaddario.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on May 09, 2020.

Photo by Saumya Khandelwal @khandelwal_saumya | When the train arrived at the railway station, I felt like I was witnessing a dystopian world. The fear of the unexpected was in the eyes of people staring back at us, as we waited for the only train to arrive at the station that day. Migrants stranded all over India for over a month amidst the lockdown could finally move toward their homes in an organized manner when special trains were arranged by the government.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by Jackie Molloy @jackiemolloy13 | Al Bonsignore records a video of his wife, Kim, midwife Cara Muhlhahn, and doula Angelique Clarke (not pictured), while his daughter, Sativa, plays in the water with her toys. Instead of having her baby in the hospital as planned, the Bonsignores decided to have their second child at home due to the coronavirus pandemic.
In the second image, midwife Cara Muhlhahn hands newborn Suzette to her parents, Kim and Al Bonsignore, minutes after her birth. “That cry, that big cry, it was the most beautiful sound after all that,” Muhlhahn says.

In the final image, newborn Suzette Bonsignore looks up at her father, Al. “It’s daddy,” he told her. “You’re so perfect, baby.”
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on May 08, 2020.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @noralorek | Many bars and restaurants are still open in Sweden, but business has dropped sharply. Some owners say they wish the government would issue a strict lockdown so they could be eligible for federal assistance. The government started a ban on gatherings of more than 50 people. That rule however does not apply to bars and restaurants which would still be crowded with fewer people. Their restriction is to make sure groups of patrons stay an arms length apart, but people can still gather together around one table.

As of May 8, 3175 people in Sweden have died from COVID-19, a majority of the victims senior citizens. Gothenburg—a city of more than half a million people on Sweden’s west coast—has reported 3254 cases and 292 deaths. The capital of Stockholm has many more cases.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on May 08, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @lynseyaddario | 94 graves have been prepared at the Taunton Deane Crematorium, located in the Somerset in the South West of England, in the case the projected numbers of Covid-19-related deaths, due to peak at the end of June/ early July 2020, actually materializes, April 27, 2020. At present, none of the prepared, single graves have been utilized; the graves will be backfilled if they are not used. The United Kingdom now has the second highest number of Covid-19 deaths in the world, behind only the United States. The UK was one of the last in Europe to call for a nationwide lockdown to prevent large-scale deaths and illness from the Coronavirus. To see more of my work, follow @lynseyaddario.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @lynseyaddario | Engraved name plates of the deceased are laid out before being affixed to coffins in Taunton, Somerset, England, April 18. Traditional family-run funeral homes are going to great lengths during the coronavirus pandemic to ensure each death is treated with respect and dignity. While the United Kingdom hit the grim milestone of 20,000 COVID-19-related deaths recorded in hospitals, the number of those who have passed away in nursing homes and in their own homes is not included in government figures—the number of untallied deaths is presumed to be in the thousands. The United Kingdom was one of the last in Europe to call for a nationwide lockdown to prevent large-scale deaths and illness from the virus. To see more of my work, follow @lynseyaddario.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on May 05, 2020.

Photo by @ruddyroye | As governors and state officials face intense pressure to reopen, New Yorkers seem to be split on which side of the aisle to stand; to stay home or not to stay home; to wear a mask or not.
This weekend, New York’s weather peaked to a sun-filled 73 degrees and people were out in droves, in the streets and at the parks.
While some spaces have started to slacken their policies, some businesses continue to uphold a mask-only entry law. Meanwhile, most people seem to be wearing their masks when traveling on public transportation.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Da Bronx Ny.

ph_descripcion: Photo by David Chancellor @chancellordavid | This is Mary with Long’uro which means ‘cut’. He’s roughly 1.5 months old and a very new member of the nursery herd at Reteti @r.e.s.c.u.e where all are under 6 months old. The Reteti Elephant Sanctuary is situated on Namunyak Community Conservancy @nrt_kenya in the remote Mathews Range, among Kenya’s second largest elephant population. Orphan elephants arrive here for a multitude of different reasons; for example, simply losing their family as the herd moves off, or in this case, falling into a well whilst drinking and being unable to escape the hyenas which discovered him later that night and attacked him, resulting in the loss of his trunk. It is estimated that between five and ten elephant calves are rescued in northern Kenya each year, from a population of roughly 8700. Those received by the sanctuary are cared for by community members such as the amazing Mary, then returned to the wild. I’ll be following the story of Long’uro over the next weeks as I work with the community here who hope not to have to experience COVID-19. This little guy will have his own battles to fight. He’s strong and in the very capable hands of Dr. Stephen Chege so despite his loss, the prognosis is good. More tomorrow on how the surgery went to tidy up the torn trunk. To see more follow me @chancellordavid @natgeo @natgeointhefield #retetielephantsanctuary #elephant @sararacamp @nrt_kenya #covid_19
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on May 02, 2020.
