natgeoexpeditions, natgeoyourshot, natgeoadventure y 9 más siguen esta cuenta
ph_descripcion: Photos by David Chancellor @chancellordavid | As the world continues to deal with the rapid spread of COVID-19, northern Kenya braces itself for challenging times to come. Currently I’m working in a landscape that’s thankfully ahead of the curve of COVID-19. However, tourism here contributes to over 90% of all income within the community-conservation sector, with the funding going toward wildlife protection, scholarships & bursaries, healthcare, and wider employment. The hospitality sector has overnight ground to an abrupt halt. Without this critical economic driver, the consequences for the safety of wildlife and the social health of northern Kenya’s communities may far exceed the damage done by the virus itself if it does reach this extraordinary corner of the planet. Dorcas Lemargeroi, is the Sarara Foundation’s Director of Nomadic Healthcare. She is working tirelessly to mitigate this unprecedented threat and educate the remote communities here on how to prevent any potential spread of COVID-19. Dorcas and her team will monitor the situation here carefully over the next few weeks by engaging with the community to provide care and support, and at the same time, is supplying healthcare to the women and children of this region. Now more than ever we have to do what we can to assist these indigenous communities that call the last remaining wilderness areas left on Earth their home. For @natgeo to see more from this region follow me @chancellordavid @natgeointhefield #kenya #samburu #africa #covid19 #sararafoundation @sararacamp 🖤
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on May 01, 2020.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @noralorek | Doctors Rasmus and Sigrid take a break in the sun between their shifts in which their patients are treated for COVID-19 at the Eastern Hospital in Gothenburg, Sweden. “It’s strange to work in these times since we’re all new to this. Usually the elder doctors are always the experts, now we all have to adjust and learn more about the virus every day,” Rasmus said.
They care for the COVID-19 patients in the last 7-10 days before the patients are released to go home. ”We make sure they can breathe normally, eat by themselves, and show no signs of confusion,” Sigrid said. Follow me @noralorek for more on how Sweden is adapting to COVID-19.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on May 01, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @lynseyaddario | Judith Sinnott throws dirt into her aunt Joan Fudge's grave during her funeral at the Church of St. Bartholomew, in Bathealton, south west England, on April 15, 2020. Fudge passed away in a nursing home in Taunton with pneumonia, but was never tested for COVID-19. While many districts across the United Kingdom are limiting the number of people permitted to pay respects to a deceased on account of the COVID-19 pandemic, there are some areas that still permit mourners so long as social distancing is maintained. The United Kingdom was one of the last in Europe to call for a nationwide lockdown to prevent large-scale deaths and illness from the Coronavirus, and their current death toll of those who have passed away in hospitals, alone, has reached 20,000. The government has not included nursing homes into the total number of deaths due to COVID-19, and in fact, many of those who have died until recently in nursing homes and in their respective homes were not tested. To see more of my work, follow @lynseyaddario.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on May 01, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @junmichaelpark | A medical worker disinfects a booth after use at a "walk-thru" COVID-19 clinic in Seoul, South Korea, on April 23, 2020. The site is set up like phone booths in order to prevent contact between patients and medical workers. Aggressive testing, contact tracing, and isolating have been a key to South Korea's success against the coronavirus. This particular testing site has tested 2700 individuals and identified 4 confirmed cases, as of April 22. To see more stories from South Korea and beyond, follow me at @junmichaelpark.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 30, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @noralorek | After the livestreamed Easter Sunday service held at the Gothenburg Cathedral in Sweden, visitors were allowed to enter the cathedral for prayers. This was the first woman I saw in my city wearing a face mask. By April 30 I’ve only seen 45 people wearing masks in public. A big majority of those who can have been working from home since early March but on sunny days many have a hard time seeing social distancing as a solution. Follow me @noralorek for more on how Sweden is adapting to COVID-19.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 30, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photos by Aaron Huey @argonautphoto | I am making photographs for @NatGeo through FaceTime, of people around the world with extraordinary virus stories. Using a cell phone and my computer I can interview and photograph inside homes that I cannot travel to. The first set of stories were all mothers (and their new babies!) who gave birth with, or surrounded by, COVID-19. Next, I am looking for additional stories from every continent that are not about childbirth, but about other life circumstances and challenges people who have the virus are experiencing. Do you have COVID-19 and an extraordinary story that you would be willing to share with me for this project? Please DM me at @argonautphoto and Ill tell you more about how it works!
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 30, 2020.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @noralorek | Anesthetic nurses Emma Salmén and Anna Bertsson are pulling off the tape they use to avoid wounds from their face masks. They just performed a tracheotomy to an ICU patient who had been on a ventilator for several weeks. Many from their department were moved to the ICU and infection wards when the Eastern Hospital in Gothenburg, Sweden was declared the epidemic hospital in late March.
By April 30, 209 COVID-19 related deaths had been reported in the area of Gothenburg and surrounding cities.
Follow me @noralorek for more on how Sweden is adapting to COVID-19.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 30, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photos by David Chancellor @chancellordavid | These are photos of collaring bull elephants for research in the time of COVID-19 in Laikipia, Kenya. The International conservation charity @spaceforgiants has collared 50 elephants in its 15-year history. Many, like these, were made in partnership with @kenyawildlifeservice. Collaring elephants allows scientists to track elephant movements. That informs research into elephants’ behavior as they adapt to increasingly human landscapes. It also allows action to be taken if elephants regularly stray close to farmland. Elephants breaking into fields to feast on crops prompts retaliation from farmers, which can leave both people and elephants seriously injured or worse. This human-elephant conflict is the leading cause of elephant deaths in this part of Kenya, a trend growing across the African elephant range. Now the onset of COVID-19 will make matters worse. Tourism has collapsed here. As a result people have lost income and therefore the ability to support their families; the economy is crashing. Imagine now if their sole harvest for the year is destroyed by an elephant? With the data gleaned from these collared elephants, @spaceforgiants will be able to see how and where crop raiding elephants gain access to farmland, and by modifying fencing and replacing broken fencing they’ll be able to protect both human and elephant populations, keeping elephants safe from people by keeping people safe from elephants. For more follow me @chancellordavid @natgeo @natgeointhefield #kenya #elephant #thereisstillspace #ahealthyearth #africa #covid #covi̇d19 🖤
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 30, 2020.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @stephenwilkes I This is the fifth image in a series for @natgeo documenting New York City from above during this difficult moment in our history. This is Bryant Park, Sixth Ave, on April 6th at 1:00pm.
The parks within NYC have always been a beautiful refuge for all New Yorkers to escape the relentless energy of the street and hustle bustle of the city.

During this pandemic, streets and avenues are virtually empty. From a high altitude, even the parks seem empty as well. NYC from above is like looking down through a canopy of trees.
You have to really look, to see the hidden stories and people that are within the image.
Swipe to the right to see a detail of this image of Bryant park, there’s actually a man bent over working inside the center of the fountain.

It’s a level of detail that’s barely visible to the human eye, only in New York. To see more of my travels near and far follow me @stephenwilkes. #bryantpark #nyc #weareone #natgeo
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 29, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @lynseyaddario | Employee of Taunton Funeral Services, Tim Leach, places an identification tag on a man who just passed away with COVID-19 in a nursing home in Taunton, Somerset, England, on April 18, 2020. Traditional, family-run funeral homes like TFS have gone to great lengths during the Coronavirus pandemic too ensure each death is treated with respect and dignity. The United Kingdom was one of the last in Europe to call for a nationwide lockdown to prevent large-scale deaths and illness from the Coronavirus. COVID-19 hospital deaths in the United Kingdom rose past 20,000, becoming the fifth country to mark this grim milestone. To see more of my work, follow @lynseyaddario.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 29, 2020.

pg_descripcion:

natgeo.com/inthefield
natgeoexpeditions, natgeoyourshot, natgeoadventure y 9 más siguen esta cuenta
ph_descripcion: Photo of @lynseyaddario | I decided to wear a full-face respirator while photographing an undertaker and his assistant dressing an elderly man who passed away from COVID-19 three days prior. There is a danger of air escaping from the mouth as the body is moved and maneuvered while being dressed and groomed for viewing and burial, so I dressed for a high-risk shoot. I sometimes find it easier to work with this, rather than a mask and goggles, as I don't have to worry about my goggles fogging, or any air entering through a mask which may not be perfectly fitted. In the United Kingdom, the rules as to whether loved ones can view someone who has passed away with COVID-19 are not specified, and most undertakers have to decide for themselves in parts of south west England whether they feel comfortable dressing and preparing someone with COVID-19 for burial. To see more of my work, follow @lynseyaddario.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 29, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @junmichaelpark | At the peak of South Korea's COVID-19 outbreak, the government advised against all religious gatherings. In order to follow social distancing rules, a mega church in southern Seoul decided to rent a parking lot and hold "drive-in" services on Easter Sunday. As the country's daily number of new infections stays below a dozen, such restrictions have been gradually reduced. View more stories from South Korea and beyond at @junmichaelpark.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by Muhammad Fadli @mfimages | Old friends, Riki (left) and Revina ride on a ferry crossing from Java to Sumatra, Indonesia. Last year, after finishing school, they moved from their hometown in West Sumatra to realize their dream working in Jakarta. But the worsening COVID-19 outbreak has forced them to go back since their places of work have closed and high cost of living became unbearable. They were able to secure two tickets and traveled on an intercity bus just two days before the Indonesian government put a strict measure in order to prevent people moving out of Jakarta. Their journey home would take at least 40 hours.

Follow me @mfimages for more coverage of COVID-19 outbreak in Indonesia and to see my other works.

#covid19 #coronavirus #mudik #indonesia
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 28, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @junmichaelpark | A teacher conducts an online class with students at a private school in Seoul, Thursday, 23 Apr 2020. Normally the school year in South Korea starts in March, but it was postponed multiple times due to the Covid-19 outbreak. Wary of a potential surge in infections, South Korean authorities decided to experiment with online teaching, keeping schools and classrooms empty. Given that the situation has stabilized, the government hopes to open schools at the beginning of May. View more stories from South Korea and beyond at @junmichaelpark.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @sebastianhidalgo_photo | “You can’t say Larry without saying Marshall. It’s one word because we were partners most of our lives,” said Pastor Hatch, of New Mount Missionary Pilgrim Baptist Church in Chicago, Illinois as he mourns the passing of his best friend, Larry Harris on April 16, 2020. Harris died on April 1 from “natural causes” but had a history of heart attacks and COVID-like symptoms. His family couldn’t see him to maintain social distancing. Over 773 people have lost their lives in the first two months due to the coronavirus in the city. More than half of whom are black Chicagoans. Latinx are also disproportionately impacted by the virus, but numbers are complicated and often mislabeled as ‘white’ in neighborhoods with a large Latinx population. The staggering death rates within black and Latinx communities are largely due to deep-rooted disparities that have historically plagued neighborhoods of color.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 26, 2020.

Photo by @noralorek | Isabelle and Gunilla, like many of the visitors, are watching their first drive-in movie ever in Gothenburg, Sweden. They came to support the movie theater that had to adapt since Sweden enacted a ban on gatherings with more than 50 people. Only 24 cars are now in an area usually filled with up to 18,000 people enjoying festivals at the pier.
COVID-19 and new governmental restrictions forced theaters to close and their staff to come up with new ways of bringing culture and movies to the people in Gothenburg. Without more governmental support, many cultural institutions could soon be facing bankruptcy. Follow me @noralorek for more on how Sweden is adapting to COVID-19.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 25, 2020.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @stephenwilkes | This is the 4th in a series for @natgeo documenting New York City from above during this difficult moment in our history.
When I was 19 years old and working as an assistant for my mentor, the photographer Jay Maisel, I used to commute every morning from Long Island, New York, always traveling across the Kosciuszko Bridge. I cherished the moment of crossing this bridge, seeing the epic view of the Calvary Cemetery below with the New York skyline glowing in the distance.
In documenting the effects of this pandemic from above NYC, I decided this was an area I wanted to revisit at sunrise during this moment in time. As we flew across the BQE and I circled above the cemetery waiting for the light to break through some clouds, I noticed a red billboard in the distance just beginning to get early morning light. I realized that it had the word COURAGE spelled in block letters.

Courage perfectly describes all of the front-line and essential workers, who commute along this roadway into NYC everyday, saving lives, and keeping us safe. To see more from my travels near and far follow me @stephenwilkes. #iloveny #weareone #courage #natgeo
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 24, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @sebastianhidalgo_photo | An employee at La Fruteria––a grocery market on the Southside of Chicago––serves a family as they wait to purchase food. La Fruteria clientele are primarily African and Caribbean families but they also serve a variety of communities throughout Chicago. These times are different. As the store adjusts to the COVID-19 pandemic, only a handful of people, including family members, are allowed into the store. Employees are required to wear masks and gloves while serving customers and are protected by a glass divider.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 24, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @sebastianhidalgo_photo | At New Mount Pilgrim Missionary Baptist Church in the West Garfield Park neighborhood in Chicago, Easter services were held to an empty hall. The service was instead streamed LIVE on Facebook where over 4,900 worshippers attended virtually. Jennifer Hatch, Kenya Hatch, Rev. Marshall Hatch jr. (pictured here), and Pastor Hatch preached and sang the gospel while warning of political leaders that will take advantage of the most vulnerable amid the coronavirus pandemic. “We got to be careful,” preached Pastor Hatch in a live stream, “This is the atmosphere so-called strong leaders come into power because people will give up their liberties to feel more secure no matter how false that security really is.”
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 24, 2020.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @ruddyroye | New York hospitals and medical centers have been reporting that their ICUs are running at capacity. It has also been reported that patient beds line the hallways of the emergency department. I also witnessed a grave overcrowding of Morgues all over the Brooklyn area.
As a result, it is customary to see individuals who seem to fall outside the fray of society’s care strolling around the entrances to hospitals, as one resident said, “in case I need some help quickly. Look, all the stores and restaurants are closed. I don’t know how to protect myself. I don’t know where to get a mask, a pair of gloves, or even water to wash my hands. So I am sitting right here with the pigeons.”
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in New York, New York.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Saumya Khandelwal @khandelwal_saumya | After a nation-wide lockdown was announced to control the spread of COVID-19, migrant workers set on a journey to their homes, many walking for hundreds of miles with meager resources. Under the scorching sun, they walked and cycled relentlessly for days. After two days of continuous movement, a group of migrants took some rest under the trees by the highway. We decided to take a lunch break by the highway when I came across them, fast asleep under the trees. When I asked an onlooker, he said, “they have been asleep since morning, they haven’t moved an inch.” Follow me on @khandelwal_saumya for more from South Asia. #covid19 #coronavirus #lockdown #india
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 24, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @junmichaelpark | On Wednesday, April 15th, South Korea went to the polls while the rest of the world is battling the COVID-19 crisis. Voters exercised social distancing while waiting to enter polling stations. Upon entering, their body temperatures were measured, and they were required to sanitize their hands and wear disposable gloves. Including early voting on the previous weekend, almost 30 million Koreans cast their ballot, a 66.2 percent turnout. The country showed that democratic values and civil rights can be upheld even during a pandemic. Follow me @junmichaelpark to see my stories from South Korea and beyond.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 24, 2020.

Photo by @noralorek | Four COVID-19 patients are treated in this room at the ICU of the Eastern Hospital in Gothenburg, Sweden. Nurses and doctors are usually working in the infected rooms for up to three hours before taking a break, but the heat and no chance of drinking water makes them feel like it’s been a complete shift.
Several wards have their own COVID-19 response plans and quarantine wards but only one has safe gates and more open spaces in the hallway to remove protective clothing.
By April 22, 134 COVID-19 related deaths had been reported in the area of Gothenburg and surrounding cities. Follow me @noralorek for more on how Sweden is adapting to COVID-19.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 24, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @stephenwilkes | This is the third image in a series for @natgeo documenting New York City from above during this difficult moment in our history. Photographing NYC at night from above has always been a magical experience for me, but during this pandemic seeing the city at night was surreal. As we turned toward uptown from lower Manhattan I saw Park Avenue leading my eyes to an illuminated Grand Central Terminal, a glow in white light. The classic buildings along Park Avenue creating a tunnel from darkness to the light. To hear more about my travels near and far, follow me @stephenwilkes. #iloveny #parkavenue #grandcentralstation #nyc #natgeo

Photo by @noralorek | Universeum, a public science center in Gothenburg, Sweden is trying to keep their doors open despite the governmental restrictions of a maximum of 50 people gathering at a time.
Normally the aquarium hall is filled with people resting from the heat of the gigantic rainforest cube but today nobody is watching Terese diving to feed the cod.
Terese Swartz, a marine biologist and commercial diver, has been working here for 13 years but has never seen the place this empty. ”The worst is that nobody knows how long we will have to continue like this, we depend on visitors,” she said.
The science center is now hoping to receive governmental support to ensure that their animal care stays fully operational. Follow me @noralorek for more on how Sweden is adapting to COVID-19.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 23, 2020.

Photo by @williamodaniels I At the funeral for an elderly, in the village of Vieux Thann, near Mulhouse. Although she hadn’t been tested for the virus, she was buried like a victim. Neither her friends nor family attended the funeral for a variety of reasons, including the countrywide lockdown. As a priest and four undertakers laid her to rest in a sealed coffin, the undertakers adopted an unusual role: They prayed over her coffin. It was as though they were her family.
Follow me @williamodaniels for more coverage in France.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @junmichaelpark | Yesterday South Korea reported only 8 new cases of Covid-19. In the capital city of Seoul, with a population of 10 million, the number was zero. Gyeongbokgung Palace, usually bustling with international tourists, was almost empty, but life is getting back to normal. Performers reenacting royal guards from the Joseon dynasty were wearing masks embroidered with a pattern of a Dokkaebi, a mythical creature from Korean folklore. Though often mischievous, Dokkaebi are also believed to protect against plagues. Follow me at @junmichaelpark to see my photos from South Korea and beyond.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @sebastianhidalgo_photo | Julio Belazquez has resorted to making masks as a form of income amid the coronavirus pandemic in Chicago. Business is slow, he says as he makes hundreds more in the back room of a gift shop. “The whole world is dealing with this right now, but there is also a mental sickness we need to deal with.” Belazquez said in Spanish, “But my main concern is putting food on the table.” Over 513,000 people have filed for unemployment in just the few weeks of April in the state of Illinois. Since the shelter-in-place order was issued in March, the essential workforce––laboriously made up of people-of-color, according to the US census––are challenged to maneuver a new world.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 21, 2020.

Photo by @stephenwilkes | This is the second image in a series for @natgeo documenting NYC from above during this difficult moment in our history. I wanted to to capture The Empire State Building as it paid tribute to all the efforts by healthcare workers and first responders on the frontline of the coronavirus pandemic.

As we circled around the building, I saw 5th ave virtually empty of traffic below. As we hovered above this epic view, it was so emotional watching this iconic landmark begin to glow red and white, and pulse, “the heart beat of America.” I have lived in NYC with my family for many years. I am a New Yorker and my thoughts and prayers are with all New Yorkers and everyone throughout the world. We will get through this, we are all in this together. To see more from my travels near and far follow me @stephenwilkes#weareone #NYC #iloveny #empirestatebuilding #natgeo

Photos by @natandvir | The ancient Holy Fire Ceremony is one of the most important events in the Christian calendar. After a lot of effort, we managed to secure exclusive access to photograph the ceremony this year under the tight attendance restrictions enforced by the Israeli authorities due to the coronavirus pandemic. With great honor comes great responsibility. I am grateful to @natgeo for publishing this story and sharing these moments with its global audience. Here are a few more outtakes that I hope you will enjoy.
Thank you everybody for following this story. I’m @natandvir in case you’d like to see more of my work from New York and Israel.
Natan Dvir signing off. I have been Nat Geo-baptized by (holy) fire!

#holyfire #churchoftheholysepulchre #jerusalem #coronavirus #covid19

With great honor comes great responsibility. I am grateful to @natgeo for publishing this story and sharing these moments with its global audience. Here are a few more outtakes that I hope you will enjoy.
Thank you everybody for following this story. I’m @natandvir in case you’d like to see more of my work from New York and Israel.
Natan Dvir signing off. I have been Nat Geo-baptized by (holy) fire!

#holyfire #churchoftheholysepulchre #jerusalem #coronavirus #covid19

ph_descripcion: Photo by @pinaphoto | Livia Tatsuki and her partner Pablo Resende hit pans to protest against Brazilian president Jair Bolsonaro. Every night residents of the Copan and other people around Brazil have been hitting pans to protest against the denial to acknowledge the risks of Covid-19. I am covering daily life under quarantine in the Copan Building, the largest residential building in Brazil and Latin America with 1160 apartments and more than 5000 residents. The Copan was designed by the famous Brazilian architect Oscar Niemeyer in the 1950's, as a mirror of Brazilian society. This is my last post on this story in @natgeointhefield thank you everyone for looking at it. Follow me on @pinaphoto for more coverage of the COVID-19 crisis in Brazil.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in São Paulo, Brazil.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by Saumya Khandelwal @khandelwal_saumya | After a country-wide lockdown was announced in India to avoid the spread of Covid19, migrant workers set off on a journey back home, seeking the security of food. City life is expensive and in the absence of work they would not be able to sustain. Thus started a journey, in some cases, a thousand kilometers long. In the absence of trains, people started to walk, bicycle, or hitch hike carrying only the essentials to get to their villages. Here, people wait on a highway looking for their next mode of transportation.
Follow me for more from South Asia.
#coivid19 #india
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 20, 2020.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @stephenwilkes | New York City has become the epicenter for the Coronavirus. As someone who has spent decades photographing the city I love so deeply, I recognized that this moment in New York City will become an important part of our collective history.

With the generous support of @natgeo, I embarked on an assignment to document New York City from above in this moment in time. I wanted to capture the city skyline aglow in sunset light. Because of this pandemic, the city was on fire. The city’s newest additions to the skyline a glow in hot light, looking like a thermometer with an extreme fever.
This is the first image from a series that I’ll be sharing from this project. It’s one of my favorites, because it was in my mind’s eye, before I ever saw it. The lonely cloud over the city was something that I never could have imagined, and it is a poignant reminder of the painful cloud that currently looms over New York. #ILOVENY #NYC #WEAREONE
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 20, 2020.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @ruddyroye | Barry YG Wilson described himself as a caretaker/helper for the past 3 years at the Andrew T. Cleckley Funeral Home in Brooklyn. When I saw him he was just finishing a day shift that started very early in the morning. He was sitting outside the funeral home with a face that seemed like it had been drained of all its life. “I pick up the bodies and I drop them off. I [also] help with the cleaning and maintenance of the funeral home.
But I have not been able to do much of that because of all the bodies that have been coming in-it’s more than a horror show-this is the horror show. This is the first time I have ever seen something like this,” he said.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in New York, New York.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Muhammed Muheisen @mmuheisen | I’m glad to have been able to document part of this important story from Greece, which was published yesterday by @natgeo on how a sacred flame spreads across the world despite the pandemic. In this image, taken at Athens International Airport, Archimandrite Damianos holds a lantern bearing the Holy Fire brought from Jerusalem to Greece just hours earlier on Holy Saturday. For more photos and videos from different parts of the world, follow me @mmuheisen and @mmuheisenpublic. #muhammedmuheisen #Easter #GreekOrthodox #Greece #covid19

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @natandvir | The pinnacle of the ancient Holy Fire Ceremony is the moment the Greek Patriarch Theophilos III emerges from the Edicule with the Holy Fire, believed to miraculously materialize in the tomb of Jesus. This powerful moment has been for decades the starting point of the Holy Fire’s journey to millions of orthodox believers around the world. The importance of the Holy Fire and what it represents, much like the Olympic Fire, was clear to the Israeli authorities. The Israeli police and foreign ministry collaborated in a complicated operation allowing the fire to travel from Jerusalem to 10 countries by plane and to Egypt, Jordan, and the Palestinian Authority by land, all while keeping everybody involved as safe and healthy as possible. Much like the Olympic Fire once again, the Holy Fire travels by air to other countries in specialized containers designed to transport open flame in pressurized cabins.
Huge thank you to my photo editor, Mallory Benedict for having the vision to follow the journey of the Holy Fire all the way from the Edicule in Jerusalem to Metohi Panagiou Tafou church in Athens, where the arrival of the Holy Fire is usually celebrated by large crowds of the faithful. I was honored to be able to photograph the fire until it left Israel. Please check out the full story on @natgeo website to see the beautiful pictures of @mmuheisen who documented the second part of the journey in Greece.

Follow me @natandvir for more imagery from this story and other projects in New York and Israel.

#holyfire #churchoftheholysepulchre #jerusalem ##greekorthodox #covid19
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 20, 2020.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by Saumya Khandelwal @khandelwal_saumya | A sample collection team deployed by the government traveled to Sadar bazaar in Lucknow, India-an area thats has been sealed off for being a hotbed of Covid19-positive cases. The team travels to multiple locations in a day conducting tests for free. The job involves high risk and thus the PPE suits are necessary, but the high temperatures in northern India make it difficult for the lab technicians to stay in these suits for long.
Follow me for more from South Asia. #covid #india
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 20, 2020.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @natandvir | The Greek Patriarch Theophilos III leaves the Church of the Holy Sepulchre holding a long candle lit by the Holy Fire. The flame that is believed to miraculously materialize in the tomb of Jesus appears each year on Holy Saturday and symbolizes the resurrection of Christ. I installed 4 stand-alone cameras around the church, including one right next to the exit looking to capture the Greek Archbishop leaving the church with the Holy Fire toward Jaffa Gate. The camera that was running on an intervalometer continued photographing a while longer and captured this unique view of His Beatitude. Serendipity really is one of the photographer’s best friends.
Follow me at @natandvir for more imagery from this story and other projects in New York and Israel.

#holyfire #churchoftheholysepulchre #jerusalem #greekorthodox #covid19
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 20, 2020.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @ruddyroye | Laying hands on residents of Brooklyn is Elder Vayden Pinnock of
Outreach Church of Jesus, Brooklyn’s Chapter, on the corner of Utica and Church Ave. “In this time, social distancing will not save you, masks will not save you, gloves will not save you, only the blood of Jesus can.”
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in New York, New York.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @natandvir | In normal times, more than 10,000 pilgrims pack the Church of the Holy Sepulchre to receive the Holy Fire. Due to social distancing during the coronavirus quarantine, this year’s ceremony was closed to the public and restricted to about a dozen clerics from several of the Christian denominations that make up the Holy Sepulchre community. The church closed for the first time since 1349 and was opened only for this event. It was a surreal feeling to attend this historic ceremony that was very familiar and in the same time very different than all the ceremonies I photographed during the first years of my photographic career. These pictures were photographed this year, in 2008, and 2005. Follow me at @natandvir for more imagery from this story and other projects in New York and Israel.

#holyfire #churchoftheholysepulchre #edicule #jerusalem #greekorthodox
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 19, 2020.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @natandvir | In normal times, more than 10,000 pilgrims pack the Church of the Holy Sepulchre to receive the Holy Fire. Due to social distancing during the coronavirus quarantine, this year’s ceremony was closed to the public and restricted to about a dozen clerics from several of the Christian denominations that make up the Holy Sepulchre community. The church closed for the first time since 1349 and was opened only for this event. It was a surreal feeling to attend this historic ceremony that was very familiar and in the same time very different than all the ceremonies I photographed during the first years of my photographic career. These pictures were photographed this year, in 2008, and 2005. Follow me at @natandvir for more imagery from this story and other projects in New York and Israel.

#holyfire #churchoftheholysepulchre #edicule #jerusalem #greekorthodox

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @natandvir | Father Vasilios of the Greek Orthodox Church lights lamps inside the Edicule on Friday, one day before the Holy Fire Ceremony. Father Vasilios approached me and my assistant as we were wrapping up after a long day of installing and testing 4 stand-alone cameras in the Holy Sepulchre Church in Jerusalem and mentioned he is in charge of lighting all
the lamps on and inside the Edicule every day. As tired as we were, I spent another half hour enchanted by his meditative and meticulous personal daily ceremony. Yesterday he lit the lamps with the Holy Fire, said to materialize above the tomb of Jesus. Check out our story about the ancient Holy Fire Ceremony taking place in Jerusalem despite the coronavirus pandemic.
Follow me at @natandvir for more imagery from this story and other projects in New York and Israel.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @nicholesobecki | A street hawker hopes to find buyers for a pair of love birds in the vibrant, informal Kenyan marketplace, which in Kiswahili is called jua kali (“fierce sun”). Eight out of ten citizens depend on the marketplace for food, medicine, housing, and schooling. Jua kali is all hustle—high-speed, small-scale, day-to-day transactions between people. This way of life offers no social safety net, no systematic protection against a disaster such as a novel coronavirus. Follow me on @nicholesobecki for more coverage of the Covid-19 crisis in Kenya.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Nairobi.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @nicholesobecki | Nairobi paramedic Carol Wanjohi waits to transport a hotel guest who had tested positive for COVID-19 to an isolation ward at Kenyatta University Teaching, Referral & Research Hospital. The ambulance company, Emergency Plus Medical Services, has designated 10 ambulances specifically for transporting infected patients in Nairobi and 20 more across Kenya. Emergency health workers like Carol have the dangerous task of transporting confirmed COVID-19 patients from quarantine to hospitals and isolation facilities. Follow me on @nicholesobecki for more coverage of the Covid-19 crisis in Kenya.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Nairobi.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @rubensalgadoescudero | I came upon this group playing in a fountain a few days ago, actually the day before they completely closed this park. Young people around the world have struggled to empathize and conform to the new set of rules we’re all living under, and in Mexico City it’s no different. Everywhere I go I see teenagers and young adults out enjoying their new ‘free time’. I think I may have acted the same at that age…and wonder how to make them understand they are not invulnerable to this disease? That even if they are asymptomatic they may be putting others at risk. It’s a question we should all be asking ourselves, our siblings and our children. Follow me on @rubensalgadoescudero to see more of Mexico City through my lens.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 14, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @rubensalgadoescudero | Payasos (clowns) in Mexico are ubiquitous and represent thousands of full-time jobs. In the midst of an international crisis these performers still show up. Bringing joy to a nervous population, reminding them of the simple things that bring laughter, creating a moment that people forget about their daily struggles… but also the new ‘rules’ on social distancing. Follow me on @rubensalgadoescudero to see more of Mexico City through my lens.

Photos by @noralorek | Due to the ban on gatherings with more than 50 people, only 24 cars are standing on an area usually filled with up to 18,000 people enjoying festivals at the pier. Lisa and Kristoffer are like many of the visitors watching their first drive-in movie ever.
COVID-19 and new governmental restrictions forced movie theaters to close and their staff to come up with new ways of bringing culture and movies to the people in Gothenburg, Sweden. But without more governmental support, many cultural institutions could soon be facing bankruptcy. Follow @noralorek for more on how Sweden is adapting to COVID-19.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 13, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @rubensalgadoescudero | Madero Avenue is a pedestrian street in Mexico City's downtown historic center. On a normal evening this time of year it would be a sea of people. Just a few days ago this is what I saw- some families and couples walking, but mostly performers hoping to earn a small wage and vendors selling street food. ph_descripcion: Photo by @rubensalgadoescudero | I've been following the situation in Mexico closely over the past weeks. Case numbers are very slowly rising and the government has issued an official shelter in place order. This image was shot overlooking Mexico City's historic center a few days ago. It's far emptier than normal but there's still a lot of activity. This is partly due to economic necessity of people who work informally, and partly because of a disbelief in the severity of Covid-19. Photo by @noralorek | This year the Gothenburg Cathedral near my home chose to not invite their members but live-stream their Easter Sunday service. Sweden has minimal restrictions so far and is relying on the citizens to control the virus through social distancing. On sunny days you can still see hundreds of people sitting in restaurants and on foggy days like today the streets are empty. At the end of the Easter week the number of COVID-19 deaths in Sweden’s population of ten million was 899.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @williamodaniels | The funeral of Simone Piquemal at the Mulhouse cemetery in eastern France. Simone died from COVID-19. Although she has 34 descendants, only 5 members of her family were allowed to attend the funeral and they all kept social distance during the ceremony. This region is considered the country's epicenter of the epidemic, with nearly a third of COVID-19-linked deaths occurring here. Photo by @williamodaniels | Undertakers collect the body of an elderly person whose death was caused by COVID-19 at a nursing home in Bantzaheim, near Mulhouse, in eastern France. French authorities started to count deaths in nursing homes only on April 3, and by April 6 there was already 900 deaths registered in nursing homes. This region is the French epicenter of the epidemic, with nearly a third of the country's COVID-19 fatalities. Follow me on @williamodaniels for more coverage in France.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @williamodaniels | Undertakers collect the body of an elderly person whose death was caused by COVID-19 at a nursing home in Bantzaheim, near Mulhouse, in eastern France. French authorities started to count deaths in nursing homes only on April 3, and there were already 900 deaths registered in nursing homes. This region is the French epicenter of the epidemic, with nearly a third of the country's COVID-19 fatalities. It appeared to originate with a five-day meeting at one of the biggest evangelical churches in France, called the Christian Open Door, in mid-February. At that time, large gathering were still allowed and about 2,000 people gathered for song, prayer, and talks. According to the French government, this event was a key driver in the spread of the virus in France. Follow me on @williamodaniels for more coverage in France.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 08, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @nicholesobecki | E-Plus ambulance technician Levy Onguso took this image of me while I was embedded with their team here in Nairobi. Emergency health workers have the dangerous task of transporting confirmed COVID-19 patients from quarantine to hospitals and isolation facilities. Levy told me about his young daughter, and how much his wife worried about him. I felt how hot and uncomfortable these suits are, and the strange mix of urgent action and tedium that make up the days of these ambulance teams. It was humbling, and I’m so grateful for people like Levy, and all the health care workers risking their lives to care for others here in Kenya and around the world. Follow me on @nicholesobecki for more coverage of the Covid-19 crisis in Kenya.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @nicholesobecki | I made this portrait of Zedekia Agure and his children just behind the small stand he and his wife run, selling sweets, used clothing and soaps, in the Kibera informal settlement in Nairobi. He reminded me that there’s no one-size-fits-all solution to the coronavirus pandemic. The advice being given for Paris and New York may be the same as here, but the context is not. This family of seven share a one-room home, making any attempt at self quarantining very difficult, and potentially dangerous. “How will we earn our daily bread?” he asked me. “What happens if one of us falls sick?” Though coronavirus hit other parts of the world first, cases across the African continent are rising quickly — and questions like Zedekia’s are only becoming more urgent. Follow me on @nicholesobecki for more coverage of the Covid-19 crisis in Kenya.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Nairobi.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @nicholesobecki | Passengers board a vibrantly decorated local minibus — known as a matatu — in a busy station beside Gikomba Market in Nairobi. Matatus are the most common form of public transport in Kenya, with tens of thousands operating in the capital alone. As the numbers of coronavirus cases here rise, Kenyan authorities have directed all matatus to provide hand sanitizer and reduce occupancy to 60% of their capacity. Safaricom, the largest telecommunications provider in Kenya, is also working to facilitate cashless payment of fare through popular mobile money system M-PESA in the ongoing battle to combat the spread of the coronavirus. Follow me on @nicholesobecki for more coverage of the Covid-19 crisis in Kenya.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @williamodaniels | This is the entrance of the new emergency center in Mulhouse, eastern France, built in a few days by the French military on the parking lot of the city hospital to help support it. This region is the French epicenter of the epidemic, with nearly a third of the country's COVID-19 fatalities. It appeared to originate with a five-day meeting at one of the biggest evangelical churches in France, called the Christian Open Door, in mid-February. About 2,000 people gathered for song, prayer, and talks. According to the French government, this event was a key driver in the spread of the virus in France. Follow me on @williamodaniels for more coverage.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 07, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @pinaphoto | Me getting a flu shot this morning in the Copan building in São Paulo. The public health system came to Copan to give flu shots to the elderly and other people at risk. Since I have been photographing the residents under quarantine, I decided to take the shot too to stay safe. I am covering daily life under quarantine in the Copan Building, the largest residential building in Brazil and Latin America with 1160 apartments and more than 5000 residents. The Copan was designed by the famous Brazilian architect Oscar Niemeyer in the 1950, in the modernist way to become a mirror of Brazilian society. Follow me on @pinaphoto for more coverage of the Corona-19 crisis in Brazil.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in São Paulo, Brazil.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @nicholesobecki | “People need to laugh, especially now,” comedian Daniel Otieno, who goes by the name Pro Fate, told me. For the past few weeks he’s been producing short skits about the challenges of quarantine in Kenya, where eight out of ten people are employed in the informal economy. The skit he’s reviewing here parodies a thief who is in quarantine but, to keep working, steals from himself. He calls his work “com-education,” and hopes that humor will keep people’s attention, encourage safe practices, and maybe bring a smile or two. Follow me on @nicholesobecki for more coverage of the Covid-19 crisis in Kenya.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on April 03, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @pinaphoto | A self-portrait with Edyr Sabino and his daughter Helena and son Daniel, in what is said to be the largest apartment in the Copan Building at around 450 square meters. Mr. Sabino who is 63 and part of the risk group to COVID-19 has been self-isolating at home with his sons for the last two weeks. I have been documenting the life of the residents of the Copan building under quarantine in São Paulo. Since I was in Europe in February, prior to starting to photograph in the Copan, I spent 20 days in self-isolation to be as sure as possible I wasn't a threat to anyone. Edyr Sabino was very kind to accepted me into their apartment to photograph him and his family, but I had to be wearing all the safety protocols and social distance. Follow me on @pinaphoto for more coverage of the Corona-19 crisis in Brazil.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on March 30, 2020.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @gabrielegalimbertiphoto | Until two days ago, Gea and I worked together every day to tell the story of this coronavirus crisis. Gea is one of my dearest friends and a great journalist with whom I have worked for years. As journalists, we think it’s important to try to document what is becoming one of the hardest moments for our country and probably the world in our lifetimes. We take calculated risks to bring these stories to you, but people have to be informed about what is happening. People need to know what to do and how to act properly in this emergency. This is why journalists need to continue reporting these stories.
During these past few weeks we have been careful to take every precaution. We used the mask, kept safe distances and washed our hands as often as possible. For the last 48 hours she’s had a bit of a fever and cough. As of now she does not feel sick, but as a precaution we decided to separate and she is staying at home to monitor her condition. Yesterday we saw each other like this on her doorstep. I brought her groceries and she showed me the thermometer showing her temperature: 37.3 C (99.14 F). It’s hopefully nothing to worry about, but right now the precautions taken are never too many. Hold on Gea!
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on March 20, 2020.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @gabrielegalimbertiphoto | Milan, lockdown day 9.
The mass confinement imposed by the need to prevent coronavirus from spreading has helped new forms of sociality to rise.
Every night, at 6 pm, people reach for their windows and start playing an instrument or music on a loudspeaker, loud enough for everybody on the street to hear. In a few days, it has become a regular appointment, engaging people of all ages and kinds.
In this picture, Via Vigevano neighborhood, in the heart of Milan, a district well known for its “movida”, during a 6 pm party.
As for March 16, the epidemic of Covid-19 has caused 2,158 deaths in Italy, with over 28,000 infected. #corinavirus #covid19 #milano #italy #epidemic
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Milan, Italy.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @newshatavakolian | My father died of a heart attack exactly a year ago at 64 years old. We had planned a big commemoration ceremony for the anniversary of his death. We invited guests, and ordered food, but then had to cancel everything. It was very sad but what else could we do. We decided to go to Tehran's Behest-e Zahra cemetery. It's massive and usually very crowded. Iranians love to visit their loved ones and especially do so in the weeks leading up to the new year. But when we went it was empty. There was no one there, it was like a scary movie almost. This virus also creates a lot of stress. My sister went out to buy flowers for my father’s grave and we yelled at her because she wasn't wearing any gloves. Corona is so contagious that you have to be careful and worried all the time. I tried to think of my father, but there were so many distractions.
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on March 15, 2020.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @gabrielegalimbertiphoto I As Italy reaches its sixth day of complete lockdown, with new measures announced on March 11th to halt every movement and unessential economic activities, providing the correct news about the epidemic, the contagion and the hospitals’ situation is increasingly critical. Eleonora Rizzardini, 26, is the communication manager of the Sacco Hospital in Milan, specialized in infectious diseases and currently at the frontline of the emergency. She has been doing this job for just over a year, she is alone in the office, and this is her first job:l. She never thought she could find herself in such a position. At least 100 journalists call her every day. One of her main activities is trying to dismantle the abundance of fake news circulating these days on social networks: “I am obsessed with it, I check Facebook and WhatsApp groups all the time. This is one of the first health emergencies we face on social media, and it can be very scary. False information can be dangerous for people’s lives”. #covid19 #coronavirus #milano #hospital #italy
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Milan, Italy.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @gabrielegalimbertiphoto I Italy lockdown, Day 6. In the mortuary of one of the biggest cemeteries in Milan, a woman looks at a coffin sent here from one of the city hospitals. It contains the body of a foreign citizen and must be sent back to the country of origin. The cause of death is unknown, but could be the result of COVID-19. As of March 13, there have been 890 victims of COVID-19 in Lombardy, Italy, which account for about two-thirds of the victims in the country. In Bergamo, a city 60 kilometers (about 35 miles) from Milan, authorities were forced to store coffins in churches after the hospitals and morgues ran out of space. The untold fear is that cemeteries could fill up as well. #coronavirus #milano #italy #virus #covid19
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on March 14, 2020.
